fields.headline: Taken in on trust
fields.trailText: I don't want to come over all X-Files, but I sometimes think that when I'm writing about personal finance there are two worlds out there - worlds which run in parallel but never meet and never admit each other's existence.
fields.body:
I don't want to come over all X-Files, but I sometimes think that when I'm writing about personal finance there are two worlds out there - worlds which run in parallel but never meet and never admit each other's existence.

And the evidence for this theory comes from you - well perhaps not you personally, but from the readers of this column who send in emails about their experiences of buying financial products.

Because your emails are reminders of the everyday problems people experience with financial institutions, the inefficiencies, bad deals, breakdowns in communications. In this world, phones don't get answered, people get upset and we get disillusioned that the bank isn't really our best buddy but just another business trying to get as much as possible for as little as possible.

But then I find myself reading adverts and press releases about the joys of banking and how hard everyone is working for the customer, and I enter another world where everything smells of freshly printed brochures and banks are there because they want to help us and insurers are there because they really care. It's an enticing world, full of sincerity and we're-there-when-you-need-us slogans and before I can stop myself I'm writing articles about confident consumers getting great deals from great banks.

The gap between the two worlds is a kind of Grand Canyon of personal finance, with two worlds in denial of each other. As an illustration of this gulf, here's an example of a problem faced by a reader, a problem so ordinary that no one would really expect it to be reported. But it's what happens to real-life customers and in some micro-form shows the distance between the airbrushed version of financial services and what really happens.

Laurence Alster, from Hampshire, had a buildings and contents insurance policy for his three-bed detached house with HSBC. As it needed to be renewed, he decided to check if there were any better offers available, and found to his great annoyance that the £820 he had been paying was more than four times higher than prices available for similar cover elsewhere.

If he hadn't checked, HSBC would have taken the £820 and that would have been the end of it. And when he asked HSBC why he was paying four times more than the other quotes he'd received he didn't get a proper explanation, but at a stroke was offered the same cover for £520.

Disregarding the fact that this was still well above what was being offered elsewhere, it meant that with one phone call Mr Alster was able to take £300 off his annual insurance premium. If he hadn't complained, he would have been charged at the higher rate, even though the same cover was available from the same company for a third less.

And to make matters worse, a few days later he got a letter from HSBC offering to renew the insurance policy at a price even higher than the first offer.

Is this the rough and tumble of business or taking advantage of a trusting public? It certainly isn't looking out for the interests of the customer, who found out by accident that he could be paying less. This kind of "flexible" charging structure is something that you'd usually associate with a backstreet garage rather than a major high street bank.

HSBC, admitting that Mr Alster's complaint doesn't exactly put it in a good light, says that a home insurance package with a cheaper rate was introduced at the beginning of the year and still had to filter down to all their customers, including Mr Alster. The bank now promises that renewal notices will inform all their customers that there could be cheaper alternatives to their present home insurance policies.

This might at least mean that some good will come out of it, but it still leaves Mr Alster with some bruised feelings about his relationship with his bank.

"I wonder now how long I've been paying well over the odds for my insurance because I trusted HSBC to deal with my finances and to protect my interests. It seems to me that banks and similar financial institutions project images of affability and integrity that often don't match their policies. I've had a bank account with HSBC for more than 20 years now, but I'm thinking of changing that."

Apart from demonstrating the need to shop around, this case is a reminder that most consumers don't sit at home scanning league tables of loan rates and insurance premiums. Rather, they assume that they're paying more or less the going rate. And it's back to that word that underpins the banking system: trust.

fields.headline: Falstaff without fat
fields.standfirst:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/Brabbins
****
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
fields.trailText:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/Brabbins
****
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
fields.body:
Martyn Brabbins is such a superb interpreter of contemporary music - adept at untangling the densest, most refractory scores - that his qualities as a conductor of the standard orchestral repertory are often overlooked. Though there was an important new work in the programme - the first performance of James Dillon's Violin Concerto - Brabbins' prom on Thursday with the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra offered a chance to hear him conduct Elgar (the symphonic study Falstaff) and Brahms (the Second Symphony).

Both were lithe performances, without an ounce of expressive fat. The picturesque episodes of Falstaff were brought to vivid life, with ripely characterised solos from the principals, and the lingering coda was purposeful, never tearfully nostalgic. This was Elgar viewed from a European perspective rather than as part of an English pastoral tradition. It was fascinating to see how the work could be related to the Straussian symphonic poem - picturesque certainly, but also convincingly integrated and given a panoramic sweep that was maintained from first bar to last.

There was the same sense of purpose about the Second Symphony - no dallying, everything directed towards the release of tension in the dancing celebration of the finale; and there was a lightness of touch about the textures that perfectly suited this work - the least anxious and most outward-going of the Brahms canon.

Dillon's concerto, a Proms commission, is a multi-faceted single-movement work of about 25 minutes; it is dedicated to the memory of William Glock, former controller of Radio 3, who died recently, and who did more than anyone to establish the shape of the Proms as we know them today, in which new music rubs shoulders with the standard repertory. The Glasgow-born Dillon is 50 this year, and in mid-life his music seems to be clarifying; the immense complexity of his earlier works is giving way to music that has more air around it, though the physical energy and presence of his writing are as powerful as ever.

The Violin Concerto sets some ferocious technical challenges. The soloist (the superb Thomas Zehetmair) has to negotiate tumultuous glissandi and high-speed volleys of double and triple stopping, as well as lines that have an extreme high-pressure expressiveness to them. The violin part is sometimes swamped in orchestral figuration that can be suffocating, but there are passages in which it is set in relief against the thinnest of accompaniments. The relationship between the violin and orchestra is constantly being reassessed; the stamped-out rhythmic figure with which the concerto opens shows that Dillon these days is not afraid of making thematic statements, and there are numerous moments when the music relaxes into lyricism, and the violin is allowed to sing.

fields.headline: Conjurer's secret
fields.standfirst:
Leon Redbone
Edinburgh Jazz and Blues Festival
****
fields.trailText:
Leon Redbone
Edinburgh Jazz and Blues Festival
****
fields.body:
Relax, imagine sinking into a sofa made of marshmallow after a foot-slogging day, and you're getting close to the laconic spell cast by American singer-guitarist Leon Redbone. Near the end of a hectic week of Edinburgh Jazz Festival concerts, and ahead of the approaching frenzy of the Fringe juggernaut, this set was a pause for breath.

Redbone is out of time and out of place, strolling on stage to the Third Man theme music like Groucho Marx's chilled-out brother. With his white hat, waistcoat and cane, he cuts a dapper, old-fashioned figure, and the thick moustache and dark glasses enhance the Marx resemblance.

Redbone emerged in America in the early 70s, but is best-known in this country for the soft-shoe strum of the Kick Off Your Shoes song for the British Rail ad campaign. He sings this number with a voice like soft gravel - the easy delivery disguising the complexity of his exceptional ragtime picking on a battered acoustic guitar. Then he leans into the microphone: "I hear the company went out of business after that."

His bone-dry humour and ironic asides reveal a sharp, vaudevillian timing. He hasn't released an album since 1994 and picks most of his material from pre-war American songs - mainly blues but also long-forgotten tangos. Yet he packed the Queen's Hall with an audience that was instantly enveloped in his banter and tunes that were previously confined to dusty 78s and minstrel-show sheet music. All the while he produces curiosities from his jacket pockets, like a conjurer: a camera to take pictures of the audience, sheets of music that are carefully unfolded then discarded, and a bell-horn reminiscent of - this time - Harpo. Then he plays a ringing, hard-picking Robert Johnson blues that I doubt will be equalled in its intensity and sensitivity at any point of this festival. And that is his secret: beneath all the melancholic irony and deadpan banter is a masterly command of ragtime and swing and a genuine love of the American songs of the Depression era - all delivered in a unique, slurred, strangulated voice.

It's no surprise that Gary Larson made him a feature of the Far Side cartoons. To keep an audience enraptured by blowing bubbles to the zither version of A Night in Vienna (he's obviously got a thing about the Third Man) before sliding into a fabulous tempo-shifting version of Travellin' Man is some kind of multifunctional performance art in itself. To be honest, who needs the Fringe when Redbone's around?

fields.headline: Brown targets banks' £5bn rip-off
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government championed the cause of the consumer yesterday with a series of proposals aimed at preventing high street banks from ripping off their customers to the tune of £5bn a year.
fields.body:
The government championed the cause of the consumer yesterday with a series of proposals aimed at preventing high street banks from ripping off their customers to the tune of £5bn a year.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown - who approved the measures before leaving for his holidays - has set new standards for credit cards, required the publication of league tables of all financial products and sparked a surprise review of the voluntary banking code to which the banks and other financial firms comply.

But he took a more conciliatory tone than the banks had first feared, by promising to consult with them before creating a new regulatory body - to be known as Paycom - which will oversee the way payments between banks take place behind the scenes.

The banks had felt more vulnerable after the latest six-monthly reports to shareholders revealed, in many cases, record profits. The "big four" alone - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest (now owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland) and HSBC - at which the report is primarily aimed, made £8bn in profit between them.

In yesterday's announcement the government also repeated its determination to set up a universal bank in post offices to provide services to the "financially excluded" and help generate business for the ailing post office network. The banks, however, are refusing to back the scheme.

The series of measures follows the controversial investigation into competition in the financial services industry conducted by Don Cruickshank, who concluded that banks were overcharging customers by up to £5bn a year.

In 1998, Mr Cruickshank - who is now the chairman of the London stock exchange - embarked on the year-long investigation, which often met resistance from some of the major banks, at the behest of Mr Brown.

Earlier this year, he made 55 recommendations to the chancellor designed to loosen the strangle hold of the big four clearing banks on the provision of current accounts and small business banking. Yesterday, the chancellor backed the majority of those proposals.

"Too often banks and other financial services providers have been slow to give consumers the information they need to make informed choices and make the most of developing competitions, new technologies and new products," Mr Brown said.

Yesterday's long-awaited measures received an enthusiastic response from the Consumers' Association, along with a call for prompt action.

Mick McAteer, a senior policy officer at the association, said: "This is certainly a step in the right direction and a good result for the consumer association's long battle for a fairer banking system - as long as Gordon Brown's plans really do break up the banks' stranglehold over the banking system."

The chancellor also announced a review of the services to small business, in addition to a separate investigation into the issue by the competition commission.

The financial services authority, the regulator which will be responsible for introducing many of the proposals, said it was happy with the government's response to the Cruickshank review.

"Too often banks and other financial services providers have been slow to give consumers the information they need to make informed choices and make the most of developing competitions, new technologies and new products," Mr Brown added.

Tim Sweeney, the director general of the British Bankers Association, admitted he was "mildly disappointed" about the review to the banking code but said it contained little that was unexpected.

fields.headline: Take more care of yourself
fields.trailText: Individuals are abandoning private medical insurance amid spiralling premiums in favour of cheaper health cash plans, according to new figures from analysts Laing & Buisson. But people should make sure they fully understand the difference before switching, say health insurance advisers.
fields.body:
Individuals are abandoning private medical insurance amid spiralling premiums in favour of cheaper health cash plans, according to new figures from analysts Laing & Buisson. But people should make sure they fully understand the difference before switching, say health insurance advisers.

The number of people with private medical insurance (PMI) cover in the UK fell by 4.5% last year to 6,366,000 at December 31 1999, with the fall in demand concentrated solely in individual paid business, say Laing & Buisson. Company-paid subscribers grew by 1.2% while individual subscribers were down by 5%.

"High individual price increases and the absence of tax concessions have dampened individual demand for PMI in the last three years," says economist Philip Blackburn, author of the report. Individual PMI premium increases have typically been in excess of 10% - around four times inflation.

At the same time, the number of people covered by health cash plans (HCP) by the end of 1999 was estimated at 7,400,000, up 2.5% on the previous year.

PMI and HCP offer very different benefits and cover and suit very different needs, says specialist independent financial adviser Penny O'Nions.

Standard PMI policies are designed to pay for out-patient and in-patient private medical treatment and diagnositic procedures. "A PMI policy will get you a private bed regardless of cost and get you in and out of hospital quickly," she says. "They are ideally suited to the self-employed and anyone with a reason to get back to work quickly."

Health cash plans are a very different animal, designed to pay the subscriber tax-free cash benefits towards a wide range of health care treatment including a stay in hospital, optical and dental care, and certain "alternative" medical treatments such as homeopathy and acupuncture. Payments cover a fixed percentage of your costs up to a certain amount per year and you can use the money as you wish.

The advantage HCPs have over PMI policies is that they pay out whether you use the NHS or opt for private treatment and cover types of health care not usually covered by PMI.

"Cash plans suit the very young who can't afford high PMI premiums and people such as the elderly who are likely to make use of the additional benefits such as contributions towards hearing aids and glasses. But subscribers should be aware of their limitations," Ms O'Nions says. "They are not intended to provide private medical cover. People should understand that, if you elect to take 100% of your diagnostics and treatment on a private basis, the cash benefit levels are unlikely to cover the full cost."

The Hospital Saving Association (HSA), a non-profit making charitable trust, is the market leader in the HCP field with nearly three million people under cover and is the benchmark against which the proliferation of newer providers compete.

Under HSA's SuperPlan, a single weekly contribution entitles each member of the family - the subscriber, their partner and all children under 18 - to 21 health care benefits. Membership is open to most people under the age of 70, providing they are in good health at the time of joining, with no medical examination required.

Unlike many competitors, the HSA does not increase contributions as members get older. The qualifying period after taking out cover and claiming is six months (10 months for maternity) though there is immediate cover for accident casualty admission.

The choice of six weekly cover levels varies from £1.60 to £12.80 and you can change your subscription level at any time, though the normal six-month qualifying period will apply if you increase your option. As examples, at the lowest and highest levels of cover, every year each family member can claim up to £33 (£264) each towards dental care, £31 (£248) optical, £104 (£832) physiotherapy, osteopathy, chiropractic, acupuncture and homeopathy, £32 (£256) chiropody and £68 (£544) towards medical consultations.

Hospital benefits include weekly benefits of £70 (£560) as a hospital in patient for the member and their partner and £17.50 (£140) for each child, and the same weekly cash sums are paid for accident casualty admissions and worldwide emergency cover. Extra benefits include payments towards mental health/psychiatric treatment, time spent in a convalescent home or recuperating at home, a home help and care for the elderly.

Ms O'Nions says she is seeing a huge rise in the number of clients who are stopping their PMI premiums, preferring to self-insure by saving up towards paying for their own beds in private hospitals should they need treatment. Many are then taking out HCPs as a fallback. And, given the waiting time for some initial consultations on the NHS, "A lot of people see cash plans as a help towards getting initial diagnosis on a private basis," she says.

HCPs are generally much cheaper than PMI policies, bearing in mind they have no age-related or regional premium differences and one premium can cover a whole family.

Ms O'Nions compares the £6.93 monthly premium for HSA's lowest cash benefits and £55.46 for its highest benefits with a monthly premium of £32.83 for the cheapest full PMI policy covering both inpatient and outpatient private care (but no optical and other alternative care) for an 18-29-year-old.

Nearly all PMI providers now also offer HCPs, and new cash plans are rapidly coming on stream. The latest, Essentials Cash from Legal & General, offers three levels of cover with monthly premiums starting at £11.50 for a single person and £22 for a family.

Given the complexity of the healthcare insurance market and the wide variety of both PMI and HCP products available, it's probably worth consulting a specialist adviser when making a choice. A growing number of specialist healthcare intemediaries work on a commission-paid basis or will give fee-based advice with commission rebates.

For the name and address of a specialist near you, contact the Association of Medical Insurance Intemediaries (AMII) on freephone 0800-421216.

Under HSA's SuperPlan, a single weekly contribution entitles each member of the family - the subscriber, their partner and all children under 18 - to 21 health care benefits. Membership is open to most people under the age of 70, providing they are in good health at the time of joining, with no medical examination required. Unlike many competitors, the HSA does not increase contributions as members get older. The qualifying period after taking out cover and claiming is six months (10 months for maternity) though there is immediate cover for accident casualty admission. The choice of six weekly cover levels varies from £1.60 to £12.80 and you can change your subscription level at any time, though the normal six-month qualifying period will apply if you increase your option. As examples, at the lowest and highest levels of cover, every year each family member can claim up to £33 (£264) each towards dental care, £31 (£248) optical, £104 (£832) physiotherapy, osteopathy, chiropractic, acupuncture and homeopathy, £32 (£256) chiropody and £68 (£544) towards medical consultations. Hospital benefits include weekly benefits of £70 (£560) as a hospital in patient for the member and their partner and £17.50 (£140) for each child, and the same weekly cash sums are paid for accident casualty admissions and worldwide emergency cover. Extra benefits include payments towards mental health/psychiatric treatment, time spent in a convalescent home or recuperating at home, a home help and care for the elderly. Ms O'Nions says she is seeing a huge rise in the number of clients who are stopping their PMI premiums, preferring to self-insure by saving up towards paying for their own beds in private hospitals should they need treatment. Many are then taking out HCPs as a fallback. And, given the waiting time for some initial consultations on the NHS, "A lot of people see cash plans as a help towards getting initial diagnosis on a private basis," she says. HCPs are generally much cheaper than PMI policies, bearing in mind they have no age-related or regional premium differences and one premium can cover a whole family. Ms O'Nions compares the £6.93 monthly premium for HSA's lowest cash benefits and £55.46 for its highest benefits with a monthly premium of £32.83 for the cheapest full PMI policy covering both inpatient and outpatient private care (but no optical and other alternative care) for an 18-29-year-old. Nearly all PMI providers now also offer HCPs, and new cash plans are rapidly coming on stream. The latest, Essentials Cash from Legal & General, offers three levels of cover with monthly premiums starting at £11.50 for a single person and £22 for a family. Given the complexity of the healthcare insurance market and the wide variety of both PMI and HCP products available, it's probably worth consulting a specialist adviser when making a choice. A growing number of specialist healthcare intemediaries work on a commission-paid basis or will give fee-based advice with commission rebates. For the name and address of a specialist near you, contact the Association of Medical Insurance Intemediaries (AMII) on freephone 0800-421216.

webTitle: Winners and losers of merger proposal

fields.headline: Winners and losers of merger proposal
fields.standfirst: Robin Stoddart looks at which funds may flourish if the plans for the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Borse go ahead
fields.trailText: Robin Stoddart looks at which funds may flourish if the plans for the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Borse go ahead.
fields.body:
Now that the London Stock Exchange itself has shares that can be traded, albeit outside the market, investors need more than ever to keep an eye on the cost of dealing.

In the weeks ahead of the vote on LSE's merger with Germany's Deutsche Borse, investors may also ponder on how much of their funds they want to hold in top international companies and whether the risks around many smaller issues are too much to bear.

Under the merger proposals for iX-international exchanges, the German stock exchange partner, based in Frankfurt, will be responsible for trading in the shares of the smaller and faster-growing companies. London hopes to retain a large share of the business in the blue-chip equities that its much higher volume entitled it to before electronic systems and alternative dealing methods became a threat.

Besides the smaller and less transparent markets of Italy and Spain, each with world-class and rapidly growing industrial enterprises, other European countries are expected to join the new share dealing union.

France and Switzerland will wait to see how the wind blows from a position of considerable strength. The object of the exercise, at least for the founders, is efficient and cheap dealing for shareholders and ever more advanced and reliable methods of fund raising and commercial activity for businesses.

For smaller companies, particularly the mainly new ones listed on the Alternative Investment Market (Aim), which has grown intermittently but on the whole successfully since it was set up five years ago, the outlook is more uncertain. New issues and fund raising are running at high levels, averaging more than £100m a month of new money for investment this year. Income tax savings and capital gains tax concessions on new issues on Aim are attractive for investors, though they do not apply to property and holding companies.

Aim's big success has been in technology issues. There is little in the iX merger document to reassure market operators and institutional investment managers that the flow of funds into such companies will be maintained.

Frankfurt, through a planned link with Nasdaq, the world's second largest share market after the New York Stock Exchange and the outstandingly successful medium for promoting US technological development, will be the main centre for new issues. This might well lead to a full global exchange, with some threat to the UK tax benefits and dealings in purely local small companies.

The LSE has plenty of persuading to do ahead of the vote by members next month and directors of Aim companies will be seeking reassurance about the marketability of their shares before then.

Hundreds of investment funds seek to achieve growth on an international scale. Almost inevitably, the best took out stakes in US growth companies some years ago and the experience there of Fidelity, the largest privately owned investment management business, has paid off well. Fidelity International units have grown by 150% over five years.

Templeton, an offshore fund manager, has been among the best performers with its UK-based Alpha Beta funds just lately, but Quilter Global Growth is a consistent winner, with fourfold growth over 10 years. Perpetual was quite close behind, notably with its big Pep fund, but again there has been some slowdown over the last year. The same applies to CGU Morley, though over a longer period it is one of the better managers among the life assurance groups.

Old-established investment trust international generalists, like the giant Witan and smaller Law Debenture, have shown solid gains with threefold growth over 10 years, but with variations over the last year or so. The more specialist RIT Capital Partners, with fourfold growth over 10 years has been more consistent.

Over a shorter period, the purer technology specialists, led by Close Finsbury Worldwide Pharmaceutical shares have been clear winners. Henderson Technology stands out over three years, doubling and redoubling before the shakeout in the sector in the second quarter of this year. The old Henderson Electric & General has been a stout performer most years, but the early technology selections of the smaller Jupiter Primadona trust make it the clear long term winner before the last year or two with more than six-fold appreciation over 10 years.

It will be interesting to see whether the new Amerindo Internet Fund, which seeks out new American growth stocks, can flourish in these conditions. Then there are the mainly American hedge funds that seek to do equally well whether markets go up or down. They must benefit from an efficient new pan-European exchange with active derivatives trading to cover their bets.

webTitle: Want to get your own back? Set up a  web page - then name and shame

fields.headline: Want to get your own back? Set up a  web page - then name and shame
fields.trailText: First guerrilla gardeners reclaimed the streets: now vigilante consumers are taking direct action against companies they see as providing poor service.
fields.body:
First guerrilla gardeners reclaimed the streets: now vigilante consumers are taking direct action against companies they see as providing poor service.

A new breed of websites is naming and shaming companies which have failed their customers. One, www.badcustomerservice.co.uk was posted by David Butland, whose Daewoo caught fire. Another was set up by a man who had complained several times that his kitchen had been badly installed, but received no response.

Sheila McKechnie, managing director of the Consumers' Association, says she has been waiting for this kind of consumer power to erupt in the UK. "We first saw this in the States. A woman whose Ford had caught fire put a page on the internet signposted Flaming Ford. She was contacted by hundreds of other Ford customers who had had similar problems and the company had to pull the model.

"In the past the only option open to the dissatisfied customer, short of taking a case to court, was to go to their local paper. Now people can write about what happened to them on the internet, and can tell other people about it. And in the future, if enough people contact them, they could think about taking out class legal action, once new laws have come into force," she says.

The Office of Fair Trading earlier this year admitted that consumers are not fighting back. The number of complaints made to trading standards departments - currently running at around one million a year - is mere surface scratching. It estimates there are 85 million instances of customer dissatisfaction a year. Top of the list are food and drink, landline and mobile phone services, clothes, shoes and jewellery. Almost half are concerned with defective goods or substandard service.

Director general of Fair Trading John Bridgeman says: "This gives some indication of the huge problem which confronts consumer protection authorities like the OFT and trading standards. It also supports the current review of consumer protection laws to ensure people get a better deal."

Mr Butland took the step to act as his own personal ombudsman after his Daewoo caught fire just three weeks after he bought it. He was unhappy with the responses from the company (the UK customer relations manager did not reply and when a letter to the managing director did elicit a response, he was told it was for him to prove the cause of the fire) and wrote the site in a couple of hours.

A friend posted it on the net. The process cost him around £150, although people who already have their own site would pay nothing.

Both Mr Butland and the kitchen customer - who does not wish to be named - were asked by the company concerned not to post the site. "In the absence of conclusive technical evidence it may be unwise to publish anything on the internet," wrote Daewoo. The kitchen company offered £700 compensation to the customer - provided the site were taken down.

But there are legal implications in posting vigilante websites. The libel laws apply to the net as they do to all printed matter, so anyone who decides to take on Goliath must ensure the stones are slung accurately. The Consumers' Association says only a personal experience should be used. Emotive language and accusations which cannot be backed by fact should be avoided.

Companies will find this kind of direct action particularly wounding if they have no website of their own - www.badcustomerservice.co.uk has already received more than 20,000 hits. When a browser types the keyword into a search engine, the negative site will be brought up and some people may even initially mistake the vigilante sites for the official one.

"The company may well want to teach the person a lesson and there are plenty of instances of companies who know the law using it to frighten people," says Ms McKechnie. She adds that with old-style complaining, most people are chasing compensation and if this is received, the complaint generally goes no further. With vigilante consumerism, however, the damage may be done whether or not the individual is compensated.

David Butland says that posting the site has given him a sense of empowerment: "It's cheaper than lawyers and much more fun. I am not going to take this any further, but I very much enjoyed venting my frustration," he says. In the case of the kitchen customer, his reward was compensation, while before writing his page he had been ignored.

fields.headline: Barclays buy into Linq
fields.standfirst:
Brothers extend new technology interests
Special report: e-finance
Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Barclay brothers, owners of the Ritz Hotel and the Scotsman newspaper, have increased their exposure to new economy businesses by investing £10m in a Swedish wireless technology firm.
fields.body:
The Barclay brothers, owners of the Ritz Hotel and the Scotsman newspaper, have increased their exposure to new economy businesses by investing £10m in a Swedish wireless technology firm.

David and Frederick Barclay have bought an 11% stake in the Stockholm-based Linq, which is valued at €135m (£81m) and is planning a stock market flotation in the fourth quarter of this year. Linq develops, sells and implements corporate portals and employs 300 people in eight European countries.

The Barclays largely built their fortune through property and hotel investments but have recently taken more of an interest in new technology.

In January the publicity-shy, 65-year-old twins took a £3m stake in Jellyworks, the internet investment vehicle which has since been bought out by investment boutique Shore Capital.

In May they abandoned plans for an £80m flotation of Trigen Holdings, a biotech firm they own that specialises in researching cures for thrombosis.

The brothers base themselves either in a £60m castle on their own private island near Sark or in Monaco. Most of their assets are held through two Channel Island companies, October Corporation and Press Holdings.

Their highest profile assets are the Ritz and the Scotsman and Sunday Business newspapers. The latter include a pan-European business-to-business internet portal.

Last year the Barclays backed retail entrepreneur Philip Green's break-up of the Sears group. In 1997 they sold their Gotaas-Larsen shipping line for £465m, making a £100m profit.

Linq chief executive Michael Mandahl set up a London office in April. The company was founded in 1996 and has doubled both its turnover and the number of employees every year since then. Merrill Lynch forecasts that the worldwide corporate portal market will reach $15 billion by the year 2002.

fields.headline: Brown's customer charter
fields.standfirst: Chancellor makes it harder for banks to rip off customers
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown yesterday rejected Don Cruickshank's recommendation that all bank takeovers be referred to the competition commission and pledged to consult with banks before pressing ahead with the creation of a new regulator.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown yesterday rejected Don Cruickshank's recommendation that all bank takeovers be referred to the competition commission and pledged to consult with banks before pressing ahead with the creation of a new regulator.

In his long-awaited response to Mr Cruickshank's recommendations on boosting competition between the banks, Mr Brown announced measures designed to make it tougher for banks to rip off their personal and small business customers, however.

But he did not introduce compulsion on some of the proposals in the Cruickshank report, as had been feared by the industry, and neither did the chancellor introduce a windfall tax on their profits - just released and at record levels - which had unsettled share prices on Thursday.

In the more consumer-friendly measures, the chancellor announced plans for CAT (charges, access and terms) marked credit cards, similar to those in the mortgage and individual savings accounts market, as well as league tables for financial products.

Mr Brown endorsed most of the 55 recommendations made by Mr Cruickshank after a year-long review aimed at establishing why the "big four" - NatWest, HSBC, Barclays and Lloyds TSB - had such large shares of the current account and small business banking markets.

Yesterday, the biggest surprise for the industry was the decision to review their voluntary code of conduct towards consumers, which the British Bankers' Association admitted was "mildly disappointing".

A seven-member panel is to be set up to review the scope of the 10-year voluntary code which is in the process of being extended to small businesses. But the banks, fresh from their bumper crop of profits figures, were generally reassured that the government had decided not to act on the idea that any mergers between them should automatically be referred to the competition commission, which might have stifled any mergers between them.

They are already being subjected to a competition commission investigation into small business banking, due for publication in June.

There was also relief that the government would ask their views on a new regulator for the behind-the-scenes payments system, to be known as paycom. "We welcome the government's assessment that this is a complex matter and that it has committed to widespread consultation on the issue," Barclays said.

While there was speculation that Paycom was being dropped, the Treasury insisted it would go ahead. Yesterday's Treasury report said it was "attracted" to the idea of a new regime for the payments industry but recognised its complexity.

In what was regarded as a reprimand to the Association of Payment Services (Apacs) which controls the behind-the-scenes transfer of money around the system, the Treasury said it was "disappointed" that they had not embarked on a wider review of the membership criteria to join the systems which clear credit and debit payments.

The Treasury noted that other parts of the industry had already responded to the Cruickshank report. Banks, for example, are taking steps to make it easier for customers to move their accounts by automating the transfer of direct debit payments while charges for withdrawing money from cash machines will be dropped from next year.

Other parts of the industry had not responded, the Treasury said, adding that it had discussed potential measures which could be taken under existing legislation by the office of fair trading.

The Treasury and the financial services authority, the regulatory body which will need to produce many of the comparative tables about financial products, appeared to have reached agreement on most aspects of the Cruickshank report.

webTitle: Grounded by the fiasco in cyberspace

fields.headline: Grounded by the fiasco in cyberspace
fields.standfirst:
This week's high-profile glitch at Barclays is the latest in a series of incidents which will put many people off the whole idea of online services, but are the fears justified? Rupert Jones reports

Special report: e-finance
Barclays
fields.trailText: This week's high-profile glitch at Barclays is the latest in a series of incidents which will put many people off the whole idea of online services, but are the fears justified?
fields.body:
It's the ultimate nightmare scenario for many internet users - someone else being able to access your bank account details without your knowledge and then raiding your finances and embarking on a fraudulent spending spree.

The nightmare became a reality this week - at least the first part of it - when Barclays was forced to shut down its online banking service for several hours on Monday after customers were confronted with details of other people's accounts when they logged on.

Barclays, which claims to be the UK's largest online bank with 1.25m users, says only seven people were able to see other customers' details and insists it would not have been possible for them to actually carry out transactions on these accounts.

Barclays described the security flaw as "unacceptable". Ironically, the problems seem to have stemmed from an upgrade to its service carried out last weekend which included the introduction of a new layer of security, adding an extra stage to the log-in process. As a result of the problems Barclays ripped out the new software and reinstated the old system.

This week's incident is the latest in a series of internet security scares. Last month gas and electricity supplier PowerGen agreed to pay £50 compensation to up to 7,000 online customers after an error allowed their names, addresses and credit card details to be accessed by an unauthorised person.

And just a few months ago the Halifax was forced to temporarily close its online share-dealing service after a technical fault led to worries that some customers had been able to access other people's accounts. It also comes hard on the heels of technical problems that blighted the launch of two new online banks, Intelligent Finance (IF) and Cahoot.

Some internet experts say incidents like this could seriously hinder the growth of online banking and other net services. Unless these glitches are ironed out and security is tightened up, some of us will never have the confidence to explore the opportunities offered by online banks and retailers be cause we will be too worried about things going wrong.

The National Consumer Council, which has been campaigning for better internet security, says this week's events will have undoubtedly further dented consumer confidence. "Until providers such as Barclays address the problems of security, privacy and customer service, e-commerce will not take off," warns its director Anna Bradley.

Hammering home this message was a survey carried out this week by personal finance website Interactive Investor International, which found that 58% of internet users are not confident about the security of online banking services. One respondent said that he knows of one bank that allowed a friend to not only view another account-holder's details but also to transfer money out of it.

Another recent poll looking at the wider issue of online customer service, carried out for First Direct by the Future Foundation think-tank, makes for even bleaker reading. It asked people about their experiences of using online retailers, and found that almost six out of 10 web users claim to have suffered poor service, with gripes ranging from difficulty logging on to sites to email inquiries going unanswered.

One of the most disconcerting aspects of some of the recent episodes is that, rather than problems occurring in the transmission of data, it's the software that runs companies' "back office" systems that seems to be failing. The worry has to be that in the scramble to bring internet services to the market, companies may be cutting corners - not testing their software thoroughly and rushing new features in.

Alarm bells about internet banking security were sounded two months ago by Howard Davies, chairman of investor watchdog the Financial Services Authority. He said that while banks' outer defences tend to be pretty strong, it had found evidence of "poor internal security" at some banks - once you are inside, the barriers between different systems are not as robust as they should be.

This suggests they could be more vulnerable to attacks from within, such as from a disgruntled member of staff, than from a teenage hacker in his bedroom. However, it also indicates that if too much strain is put on these systems - for example, because a company has massively underestimated demand, as has happened with some of the net banks that have launched - security may be put at risk.

Banks and other online businesses would do well to heed the experiences of their counterparts in the US, which is some way further down the online cyberhighway than the UK. There, people are becoming increasingly intolerant of poor internet service - it is estimated that one-third of those who have opened an online bank account have closed it within months because of problems they have experienced.

It would be all too easy for the less technically minded among us to use incidents such as this week's fiasco as an excuse to turn our backs on internet banks and retailers on the grounds that we simply don't trust them. But that would be the wrong approach to take, says Ian Kirby at Arnold & Porter, a law firm that specialises in regulatory and IT issues.

"It would be a shame if something like this was to develop into such a situation that we all start behaving like Luddites. The internet is inevitably going to be one of the main mediums through which people do business in the future, and the things it can offer are extremely good - convenience and the ability to have much more control over your finances," he adds.

There are also the table-topping rates on offer to savers and credit card customers, in particular, who are willing to take the online plunge. Many of the very best savings rates are offered by internet banks or to the online customers of high street institutions.

In an attempt to improve the situation, the National Consumer Council is calling for a number of improvements including more secure payment systems which provide a decent safety net when problems occur; beefing up the existing protection for credit card transactions that go wrong; higher standards of customer service; and a government-backed publicity campaign to promote greater awareness of your rights and how to get redress.

The banks say it is important for people not to get the problems out of perspective. Barclays says that just seven out of 1.25m customers were affected by the glitch. And when it comes to credit card fraud, you're more likely to encounter problems with waiters or petrol station staff copying your card details and passing them on to counterfeiting gangs than you are with crooks using fraudulently obtained card details to make purchases over the net.

This currently accounts for just 2% of all UK card fraud losses, and is a crime that's about to be made a lot more difficult to commit. From October a new system will be in place allowing retailers to check the billing address of someone using a card to pay for goods online. Retailers will also start asking for the three extra digits that are printed on the signature areas of cards but which are not embossed on the front and don't appear on the magnetic stripe. This new system should help foil crooks who have stolen credit card slips, rather than the card itself, and who, in most cases, won't know the victim's address.

So what is the advice for online banking users concerned about the safety of their money and personal details?

The Consumers' Association recommends sticking with a UK-based bank which has signed up to the UK's banking code of practice and belongs to our banking ombudsman scheme. It also says that if you come across anything odd or suspicious, take a print-off of the screen so you've got some proof in case the bank denies there is a problem.

The CA advises people to check your bank's small print carefully to see what your liability is in the event of an unauthorised transaction being made on your account. Egg's rules state that until you inform them that something has gone wrong, you remain potentially liable for any transactions that occur. Other online banks take a less tough line, limiting your liability to £50 or nothing.

Industry body the British Bankers' Association adds the following tips:

 Keep your password confidential

 Make sure other people aren't able to observe your PC screen when you log on

 If you do your banking on a computer which is shared with other people, never store your password on its hard disk. Consider disabling your browser's ability to remember passwords and user names.

webTitle: Don't let the car stall your holiday

fields.headline: Don't let the car stall your holiday
fields.standfirst: Each year around 30,000 motorists are stranded abroad when their car goes wrong. Nick Pandya takes a look at the best deals for breakdown cover
fields.trailText: Each year around 30,000 motorists are stranded abroad when their car goes wrong. Nick Pandya takes a look at the best deals for breakdown cover.
fields.body:
Despite state-of-the-art engineering even Formula 1 cars can stall on the grid. So it's hardly surprising that one in 12 holidaymakers' cars breaks down before they reach the ferry port.

Each year the Automobile Association rescues around 30,000 motorists stranded abroad, with around 1,000 irreparable cars being being shipped back to the UK.

Anyone driving to the European sunspots this summer ought to give their car a full service before setting off. A car used mostly for town driving will suddenly be cruising at high speeds on open roads in high temperatures. Radiator hoses, electrical connections, brake pads and tyres are especially vulnerable.

The chance of even a minor mechanical hiccup while abroad is enough to make taking out a rescue package worthwhile. French garages charge at least £120 to tow away a car and, if you want to continue your journey, hiring one at short notice is expensive. Even more scary is the thought that, if repairs prove impossible, it may be cheaper to scrap the car and fly home rather than pay to ship it back.

But choosing your personal band of knights in overalls is not easy. The best-known, AA and RAC, appear expensive, but they do offer the widest array of extra-motoring services. They also say they are now getting the benefits of huge investment in new technology which can pinpoint a stranded driver in seconds. And by having their own fleet of patrolmen, who carry more spare parts in their vans, they claim to be able to serve the marooned motorist more quickly and better.

Other car rescue outfits, which use independent garages as their representatives, say that their standards of service are also high, as it is in their agents' best interests to get to members quickly. Most are paid for every call-out and if they are not up to scratch could lose the business.

If you are planning two or more trips abroad in any one year it is probably economical to take out yearly membership. As ever, it is important to read the small print. Although most breakdown services include repatriation of the car and up to four passengers as part of the deal, some companies may object to relaying everybody in your party.

The sort of cover typically provided by breakdown insurance includes: the cost of emergency roadside repairs, car hire if your vehicle takes some time to repair, the cost of getting spare parts to you (but not the cost of the parts themselves), provision of a chauffeur if the only driver is ill or injured, extra accommodation costs abroad and the cost of getting you and your car home.

There will usually be a limit on each bit of cover, say £1,000 for car hire, up to £40 per person per night for emergency accommodation, and an overall limit of £2,500 to £3,000 that may exclude the cost of transporting your car home, and legal expenses.

RAC's Individual Cover allows you to choose the level of cover that suits your needs. From £34 per year it provides roadside assistance, whether you are the driver or the passenger in any car, including a tow to a nearby garage. Add European Cover at £80 a year for stress-free trips across mainland Europe.

If your motor can't be repaired at the roadside within a reasonable time in the event of breakdown, accident or other motoring incident, it will arrange onward travel, additional accommodation or make other arrangements to get you home. You'll be compensated for the loss of your motor insurance no claims bonus and be provided with legal expenses and bail bond, if required, in the event of a motor-related accident.

For a broadly similar deal the AA charges £43 a year for basic cover plus £115 for making any number of European journeys during the year.

For motorists aged 55 and over, Age Concern Motor Breakdown Service (01883-834227) is priced at around £47 a year; an additional £17.56 will cover customers driving in Europe for up to 31 days in any one trip.

However, the AA/RAC grip on the breakdown market is now being seriously challenged by Direct Line, the Royal Bank of Scotland's direct insurance arm which controls Green Flag Breakdown Service. Direct Line is worth trying: it's promising to revolutionise the breakdown business by using risk-related methods to decide how much you should pay. So if you drive a reliable car and keep it properly serviced you'll pay less than someone who drives an older and poorly maintained motor.

Unlike both the AA and the RAC, Direct Line covers the car, not the driver. If you've picked the AA or the RAC, you'll then have to decide whether you want individual, joint or family membership - that can inflate the cost.

Direct Line claims that one advantage of its car-centred approach is that families with one car and several drivers would almost certainly be better off.

Another newcomer from the information highway making inroads on the hard shoulder is Autonational Rescue, which can be contacted by telephone or online, where it is offering website visitors 15 months' breakdown cover for the price of 12. Breakdown cover with Autonational Rescue starts at just £26 a year or for 15 months via its website.

 www.autonational.co.uk or call 0645-500999; AA: www.theaa.co.uk; RAC: www.rac.co.uk; Direct Line: www.directline.com or call 0845-246-8702.

fields.headline: Albert Hall Social Club
fields.standfirst:
Cuban Night
Royal Albert Hall
***
fields.trailText:
Cuban Night
Royal Albert Hall
***
fields.body:
World music seems to be on its way to achieving the status of classical music. First, Radio 3 sneaked it into its late-night shows; now, Cuban big-band music has made it on to the Proms programme. At the Albert Hall, roots enthusiasts mingled with classical concert-goers for the post-prom show billed as Cuban Night. The event was sold out, and the prom area was packed and ready to dance.

The audience may have been expecting the Buena Vista Social Club but instead they got two rather more current and contrasting representations of that country's music. Both were engaging and their enthusiasm was contagious.

Vocal Sampling, a six-strong a cappella group, reproduces vocally the instruments of Cuban music. They pinched their noses and sang into cupped hands to mimic trumpets, and imitated percussion by clicking their tongues into their microphones. They encouraged everyone to sing to their percussive backbeat as they launched into the classic Mi Guantanamera. Their theatrical act bordered on camp - complete with costume changes and swing-dance routines - and the promenaders laughed and danced along with them.

And then Los Van Van - dubbed the Rolling Stones of Cuba - invaded the stage. This 15-piece band has been together for more than 30 years and know how to work the crowd. Their high-energy set had a big, brassy, percussive sound, and was headed by three vocalists who seductively danced and shimmied across the stage, while the band leader - a bass-playing Leonard Cohen lookalike - controlled the tempo and direction. There was dancing in the aisles, and just for a short while, the Albert Hall was downtown Havana.

webTitle: Where you can store  the windfalls

fields.headline: Where you can store  the windfalls
fields.standfirst: Scottish Widows policyholders will have an average £6,000 payout this month. Some will spend, spend, spend - but for those looking to invest, Rupert Jones offers some options
fields.trailText: Scottish Widows policyholders will have an average £6,000 payout this month. Some will spend, spend, spend - but for those looking to invest, Rupert Jones offers some options
fields.body:
A summer spending spree is forecast for later this month fuelled by the billions of pounds of Scottish Widows windfall cash that will be dropping into the laps of 1.6m lucky policyholders.

In all, close to £6bn is being dished out by the insurer, with the windfalls varying in size dramatically - from £500 to £100,000-plus. The average handout will be just over £6,000.

A survey from CGU Insurance out this week predicted that the giant giveaway will help lift consumer spending this month to £49.4bn - a new high for this year. Home improvements, holidays and cars look set to top the shopping lists for those planning to spend, spend, spend, but many of those sharing in the bonanza will be keen to invest some or all of the cash, perhaps for a rainy day or to supplement their retirement income.

Some will have originally invested in a fairly low-risk Scottish Widows product such as a with-profits bond, and so will be keen to put their windfall cash into something similar. Others will view this as unexpected money and will be willing to take a bit of a gamble with it. Here we look at how you'll be getting your money and canvass the views of independent financial advisers as to possible investment options.

A total of £7.3bn is being awarded to policyholders, but £1.5bn of this will be paid out over time in the form of enhanced terminal bonuses to with-profits policyholders.

All of the 1.6m people will receive a fixed payout of £500. However, 900,000 of them are with-profits policyholders and will also receive a variable payment based on the type of policy, its size and how long it has been held for.

If you requested to receive your windfall in the form of a cheque, these are being mailed out from August 17 onwards. If you asked for it to be paid into a Scottish Widows Bank VIP Premier Account, it will be paid in at the same time. Assuming rates don't change between now and then, the account will pay interest of 6.25% though this includes a 0.5% interest bonus for the first six months.

If you requested your windfall in the form of loan notes (a sort of IOU), you'll receive a loan note certificate plus a letter highlighting the value of your windfall. Interest will be paid on the loan notes and the rate is likely to be around 5.9%.

So what are some of your investment options?

James Dalby, at Leeds-based IFA Bates Investment Services, says that for some policyholders, the handout will provide a much-needed boost to their flagging finances. "For them, it may be that the best course of action is to repay any small short-term debt."

At the other end of the spectrum, some people may be willing to plunge into somewhat riskier waters and might consider a technology fund "for a bit of excitement and long-term growth potential". One fund he particularly likes is Henderson Global Technology, which has notched up an impressive performance over the medium to long-term - it is the top fund in its sector over three and five years.

Mr Dalby also flags up Aberdeen Technology, which has been in the top quartile of funds in its sector for the past 10 years, and the Framlington NetNet Fund, which involves a slightly higher level of risk because it only invests in internet and internet-related companies.

Bates Investment Services has an A5 guide called Investing Your Windfall which is available free to Guardian readers - call 0800-0134-135.

Michael Aaron at the David Aaron Partnership, a Milton-Keynes-based IFA, says there will be a huge variation in the amounts people will receive. For those prepared to take a bit of risk, and who are prepared to commit their cash for the long term, he highlights some of the technology funds.

Many of these have fallen quite heavily from their highs earlier this year, and so there is some good value out there, he adds. Mr Aaron quite likes Aberdeen Technology, and also Aberdeen European Technology, which invests in Continental European technology-related companies.

Away from technology, he is a fan of ABN AMRO's UK Growth fund, which he says is "more aggressive than the typical UK growth fund" and has been a very strong performer - it is the number two fund in its sector out of well over 200 funds over both one and three years.

Others will take a more cautious approach and, for them, something like a with-profits bond may be well worth considering as these involve a lot less risk and volatility than many other share-based investments. "Companies we like include Prudential and Liverpool Victoria," says Mr Aaron.

Scottish Widows is keen to hang on to some of the cash it is paying out and will be offering people various reinvestment options, including the opportunity to put their money into its European Isa. This fund is aimed at those seeking capital growth through investment in Continental companies.

Chartwell Investment Management, a Bath-based IFA, says the Scottish Widows European Isa has "an excellent long-term track record" but points out that the fund manager largely responsible for this, Albert Morillo, left to join another company last year, taking two members of his team with him.

Jason Hollands, at Best Investment Brokers, says that as a result, people who put their money into the fund are backing "a fairly unknown quantity". Mr Morillo's replacement is Fiona Macrie, who was part of the European team but has not run a fund herself before. "I see no reason why you should want to go into that fund over other well-established, strong European funds run by companies such as Gartmore, Invesco and Threadneedle," he says.

Chartwell Investment Management has a Widows windfalls Q&A on its website: Chartwell-investment.co.uk

If you asked for it to be paid into a Scottish Widows Bank VIP Premier Account, it will be paid in at the same time. Assuming rates don't change between now and then, the account will pay interest of 6.25% though this includes a 0.5% interest bonus for the first six months. If you requested your windfall in the form of loan notes (a sort of IOU), you'll receive a loan note certificate plus a letter highlighting the value of your windfall. Interest will be paid on the loan notes and the rate is likely to be around 5.9%. So what are some of your investment options? James Dalby, at Leeds-based IFA Bates Investment Services, says that for some policyholders, the handout will provide a much-needed boost to their flagging finances. "For them, it may be that the best course of action is to repay any small short-term debt." At the other end of the spectrum, some people may be willing to plunge into somewhat riskier waters and might consider a technology fund "for a bit of excitement and long-term growth potential". One fund he particularly likes is Henderson Global Technology, which has notched up an impressive performance over the medium to long-term - it is the top fund in its sector over three and five years. Mr Dalby also flags up Aberdeen Technology, which has been in the top quartile of funds in its sector for the past 10 years, and the Framlington NetNet Fund, which involves a slightly higher level of risk because it only invests in internet and internet-related companies. Bates Investment Services has an A5 guide called Investing Your Windfall which is available free to Guardian readers - call 0800-0134-135. Michael Aaron at the David Aaron Partnership, a Milton-Keynes-based IFA, says there will be a huge variation in the amounts people will receive. For those prepared to take a bit of risk, and who are prepared to commit their cash for the long term, he highlights some of the technology funds. Many of these have fallen quite heavily from their highs earlier this year, and so there is some good value out there, he adds. Mr Aaron quite likes Aberdeen Technology, and also Aberdeen European Technology, which invests in Continental European technology-related companies. Away from technology, he is a fan of ABN AMRO's UK Growth fund, which he says is "more aggressive than the typical UK growth fund" and has been a very strong performer - it is the number two fund in its sector out of well over 200 funds over both one and three years. Others will take a more cautious approach and, for them, something like a with-profits bond may be well worth considering as these involve a lot less risk and volatility than many other share-based investments. "Companies we like include Prudential and Liverpool Victoria," says Mr Aaron. Scottish Widows is keen to hang on to some of the cash it is paying out and will be offering people various reinvestment options, including the opportunity to put their money into its European Isa. This fund is aimed at those seeking capital growth through investment in Continental companies. Chartwell Investment Management, a Bath-based IFA, says the Scottish Widows European Isa has "an excellent long-term track record" but points out that the fund manager largely responsible for this, Albert Morillo, left to join another company last year, taking two members of his team with him. Jason Hollands, at Best Investment Brokers, says that as a result, people who put their money into the fund are backing "a fairly unknown quantity". Mr Morillo's replacement is Fiona Macrie, who was part of the European team but has not run a fund herself before. "I see no reason why you should want to go into that fund over other well-established, strong European funds run by companies such as Gartmore, Invesco and Threadneedle," he says. Chartwell Investment Management has a Widows windfalls Q&A on its website: Chartwell-investment.co.uk

fields.headline: Yorkshire stumble on Rose's match
fields.standfirst: Somerset 359 Yorkshire 5-0
fields.trailText: Somerset 359 Yorkshire 5-0
fields.body:
The rain clouds lifted at lunch and the Quantocks, over which Coleridge and Wordsworth used to stroll in political and poetic contemplation, came into vision once more. That romantic landscape's emergence from the haze has often been a symbol of better times for Somerset.

Just as Jack White was reassured years ago when he could almost see his livestock again, Graham Rose was yesterday able to parade some uplifting batting that was pragmatic, good to watch and mostly untaxed.

Going in at No7, he strode to the wicket, looking as usual more like a west country farmer himself than the Londoner he really is. The shoulders are broad, the steps long and slightly lumbering. He could be on his way to the harvest field. Instead he was setting out on his 10th hundred, his third against Yorkshire, this journeyman allrounder who once went tantalisingly close to a place in a one-day international.

Rose is possessed of a gargantuan reach. He stretched a mile to stroke fours that most batsmen would let pass by. Here he was last out, caught at mid-off with a gesture that suggested Somerset were ready to fire an over or two at Yorkshire before the close.

There were 14 boundaries in his 124, an innings composed at a pastoral pace. On 29 he was nearly caught by David Byas, going wide at slip, but he was not often fallible and rarely in trouble. At the crease he stood characteristically tall and upright, the bat hanging just off the ground as if it were a trusted farmyard implement.

A win is overdue for Somerset, against whom the weather and Test calls have conspired. Now Somerset complexions seemed naturally rubicund again: first for Rose and then for Peter Trego.

The two were in an eighth-wicket stand of 161. Just back from his England Under-19 appearance, Trego responded to Rose's authority with a career-best 62. This is his first season of championship cricket and on yesterday's evidence there is much to come and acclaim, especially as he is seen essentially as a bowler. The 19-year-old spends his winters playing in goal for Western-super-Mare.

At times Yorkshire's attack looked painfully ordinary. There was some excuse, of course; they badly need Darren Gough and Craig White, who were at the Test, and the injured Ryan Sidebottom and Paul Hutchison. The fizz of the previous day had gone; the support bowlers offered minimum threat at times. There were also some short-pitched deliveries that bothered the home fans more than the batsmen and reflected Yorkshire's growing frustrations.

Peter Bowler, who had appeared technically superior to the other early Somerset batsmen, went to a leg-side catch. Keith Parsons, who strokes pretty off-drives taking him into the 20s and 30s, got no farther this time. Seemingly concerned by the drizzle, he swung his bat at Gavin Hamilton, lucky to miss. Next ball, still not attuned, he was leg-before.

But the middle order had all taken the score along modestly. Rob Turner, so far nothing like the controlled and consistent run-compiler of last summer, was out, caught by the promising debutant Simon Guy as he went to drive.

Ian Fisher quickly mopped up the Somerset tail with his three wickets. But it was a good day - and good recovery - for Rose and his promising pupil.

fields.headline: Tail-gunner Tudor is trigger happy
fields.standfirst: Surrey 310 v Lancashire
fields.trailText: Surrey 310 v Lancashire
fields.body:
Surrey have a tail as dangerous as a crocodile's and Lancashire felt the full swipe of it when there was finally some meaningful play here yesterday.

Lancashire's bowlers looked reasonably satisfied when Martin Bicknell was eighth out at 237. But Bicknell's resolute 28 was tame stuff compared with what followed.

Ian Salisbury and Alex Tudor, who each made 35, added 57 for the ninth wicket. Salisbury pulled Michael Smethurst for four and pulled and cut his fellow leg-spinner Chris Schofield for two more in one over in his 74-ball innings.

Tudor, who must be the best No10 in the land and seemed under the happy impression that he was Everton Weekes, was even more fluent. He faced only 54 deliveries and struck seven fours. He pulled Smethurst to midwicket for four to bring up the 50 partnership. Then he twinkled down the wicket to loft Joe Scuderi over mid-on and over the rope first bounce. Viv Richards would have been proud of that one.

Salisbury fell first, lbw to Smethurst. And Surrey were all out for 310 when Tudor was bowled by a pitched-up delivery from Andrew Flintoff.

This was more like Chelsea versus Manchester United than Surrey against Lancashire. Lancashire went 2-0 up, Surrey pulled level, Lancashire went ahead again and Surrey made it 3-3 in bonus points just before the final whistle. They replay today.

These are two of the three sides - with Yorkshire - with the best chance of winning the championship. And with the best part of a day lost to rain, and the chances of a positive result reduced, bonus points have become even more important to them.

Adam Hollioake, the Surrey captain, might have been tempted to declare at 250 for eight to deny Lancashire their final bowling point. His decision to bat on was vindicated.

Surrey resumed on 191 for six but only six overs were bowled before the players came off at 11.24. They resumed at 2.15 and bowled five overs before they disappeared again until 4.25, when they came back for a two-hour session. There was no time for Lancashire to bat at the end of the day.

The rain, which had washed out the final session on Wednesday, cost 59 overs yesterday and the umpires hardly deserved the slow handclap they received each time they plodded out, rather sheepishly, for yet another inspection.

Smethurst finished as Lancashire's best bowler, taking two more wickets to end up with figures of 29-12-63-6. It was his third five-wicket return this season, and his second in the championship.

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

250-299 (2);

300-349 (3);

350-399 (4);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*Note: in a draw where the scores finish level , the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: While several of its own (alleged) members are reluctant to credit the Fast Bowlers' Union with anything more than mythic status - Devon Malcolm, when facing Courtney Walsh, springs unerringly to mind - the notion of a Left Arm Union - quick to quickish only - sounds far more plausible.
fields.body:
While several of its own (alleged) members are reluctant to credit the Fast Bowlers' Union with anything more than mythic status - Devon Malcolm, when facing Courtney Walsh, springs unerringly to mind - the notion of a Left Arm Union - quick to quickish only - sounds far more plausible.

Bonded by adversity, a pair of card-carriers, Alan Mullally and Kevin Dean, tussled for supremacy at Derby yesterday. Laconic and genial, if a firm adherent to the minimalist school of post-match comment, Mullally's contribution to the Opinions section of the Cricketers' Who's Who extends to a positively verbose "good fun". Which presumably sums up the Hampshire southpaw's reaction to the pre-lunch exploits that saw him whip out the last four Derbyshire batsmen to finish with a lifetime-best nine for 93.

His national heir could well be Dean, who missed almost the whole of last summer but is far from alone among his breed when it comes to serious spinal ailments. Mark Ilott, Paul Hutchison, Jason Lewry and, this season, Matt Bulbeck have all been likewise afflicted, ditto New Zealand's Geoff Allott. Within the past decade, indeed, South Africa's Brett Schulz and Australia's Bruce Reid have been forced to retire. Hah, clever-clogs Latin scholars will titter, that'll teach 'em to be so sinister.

Dean, though, is making a spirited comeback. Fresh from a career-best eight for 52 against Kent, he took three of the first four wickets before Robin Smith's second 50 of the term helped the visitors close 169 behind. An impressive season's strike rate now stands at a victim every 37 balls.

At Edgbaston in June, Darren Bicknell and Guy Welton each ran up double-centuries while sharing a county all-wicket record stand of 406 for Nottinghamshire in a match that saw Warwickshire fail to muster a single wicket. Terra firma beckoned with inevitable alacrity when the return got under way 15 minutes late at Trent Bridge owing to damp patches on the square: Allan Donald ejected both openers inside 11 overs. Usman Afzaal passed 40 for the fifth innings running and remained unbowed on 58.

Ben Hutton - son of Richard, grandson of Sir Len - has been sullying the family name this season, cobbling together 47 in six championship knocks prior to Essex's trip to Lord's. Some of that lustre returned, however, a painstaking 55 off 167 balls enabling Middlesex to reach 287 before Phil Tufnell affirmed his penchant for controversy.

Having had a typically animated appeal for a bat-pad catch against Ian Flanagan rejected, Tufnell responded in decidedly atypical manner next ball when, as Flanagan trotted through for a single, he impeded his progress. For a chap whose passion for physical contact makes Gandhi seem positively Tysonesque, the perceived sense of injustice can only be boggled at. For a keener perspective, maybe he should join the Left Arm Union.
