fields.headline: Veterans need support - and quick
fields.standfirst: Creaking Ambrose bemoans lack of youthful understudies
fields.trailText: Davsid Hopps reports as creaking Curtly Ambrose bemoans a lack of youthful understudies.
fields.body:
There has been no more successful fast-bowling partnership in history than Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose and, after the footslogging involved in taking 861 Test wickets, they have no desire to see their legacy wasted.

With retirement looming, and a proud record against England to protect, they chose yesterday to press the next generation to start producing the goods.

As batsmen throughout the world can testify, it is advisable not to give Courtney and Curtly too much aggravation. Uncommonly, with the series in the balance, they have resorted to verbal bouncers, with the West Indies' back-up bowlers the chosen target.

"I have been saying for the last couple of years that it is time for the youngsters to come through and take over the mantle, but they are simply not ready yet," said Ambrose. "Myself and Courtney have to do all the work and I think that is a little unfair."

Ambrose has already announced his retirement at the end of the series; Walsh will confirm his decision at the end of the summer as he muses over whether the challenge of becoming the first fast bowler to take 500 Test wickets is worth the risk of an arduous five-Test tour to Australia, which has all the makings of one tour too far. Neither have ever lost a Test series against England.

"The youngsters should be the ones doing the bulk of the bowling, but this isn't happening," Ambrose complained, on behalf of a partnership with a combined age of 73. "I just hope that they come through quickly." One sensed that by "quickly" he meant sometime late this afternoon.

Walsh and Ambrose have so far bowled two-thirds of the overs this series, a state of affairs that with three Tests in rapid succession would put them under great strain if it was to continue.

They have also taken 24 of the 33 England wickets to fall and, if the majority have fallen to Walsh, Ambrose bowled brilliantly in defeat at Lord's without any luck.

While eulogies have sounded for Walsh and Ambrose all summer, the other support bowlers have fallen below their own modest standards.

Franklyn Rose and Reon King, who were both on duty here, have claimed their Test wickets at a comparable rate to England's finest, Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick, at about 28 runs each, but have so far have not suggested as much.

Walsh offered some encouragement. "As with Curtly, I was written off in my younger days," he said. "They said that I was too wiry and that I wouldn't make it, so it is satisfying to prove them wrong. I also remember before I left home being told that I shouldn't be in the squad, but being here and doing well gives you self-belief."

Duncan Fletcher, England's coach, was not crowing at a first-day close of 87 for four. He judged it "15 or 20 runs too much," citing the first rain break as particularly untimely. The most delicate situation had been addressed before play began: the omission of Graeme Hick, the ninth interruption to his Test career.

"It was very difficult, but we needed a left-hander in the middle order to break things up a bit," Fletcher said. "Graeme is still involved in the make-up of the team for the next Test. We might play seven batters at Headingley, but the pitch here was dry and the ground has a reputation for spin."

The England and Wales Cricket Board has resisted overtures from Bangladesh to provide the opposition for their inaugural Test this winter, even though they are engaged in convenient series in Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Fletcher seemed sympathetic to the players' marked reluctance to extend their winter commitments.

"To have played Bangladesh would have been an honour but these add-on tours have many difficulties," the coach said.

fields.headline: Under the red cloud
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel Stadiums can rise and fall, just like the teams that play in them and, almost without anyone noticing, Old Trafford has slid into international cricket's relegation zone.
fields.body:
The link between Manchester and rain in the popular imagination is an ancient one, predating cotton, football and gay nightclubs. It is, according to Mancunians, a myth - as potent but as bogus as the persistent folk belief in London fog.

They will produce rainfall figures to show that Manchester is about as dry as the Atacama Desert. No one ever believes them, which is one reason the Olympics are being held in Sydney, not here. This was probably lucky, otherwise the world might have got wet yesterday, not just cricket spectators.

The truth is that in Manchester it doesn't normally rain much; it just rains persistently, which is not the same thing. Traditionally, it pauses just long enough in the summer for a cricket match to be halted by the sun reflecting off greenhouse roofs (though somehow that experience has never been the same since Dickie Bird's retirement).

It is unusual for the skies to open and unleash a two-minute hailstorm that stops play for the next 3 hours. The occasion was marked by Dickie's emergence from the hospitality boxes to the middle for a social call, and perhaps some sage advice to his successors to avoid pressure for a premature resumption.

It was a nostalgic moment on a sad day for a grand old cricket ground. Stadiums can rise and fall, just like the teams that play in them and, almost without anyone noticing, Old Trafford has slid into international cricket's relegation zone.

Here we were, for the first day's Test cricket since that great Saturday at Lord's, and Old Trafford was not even half full. (There were, of course, about as many black faces as you get at the average Conservative Party conference, maybe fewer.) Today and tomorrow are both much better subscribed, and Lancashire are a little mystified why the Thursday should be so grim.

But things have reached a pretty pass. Next year Lancashire are being duly punished; Old Trafford will be the first of the six traditional venues to be denied an Ashes Test since 1975 - instead Manchester will be given a game against Pakistan in mid-May. Mid-May? That's really going to bring them off the footy terraces, that is. Why not say February and insult them properly?

Chester-le-Street is starting to challenge Manchester's position on the rota; Bristol, once as excited about cricket as, say, Marseille, may not be far behind. Hampshire have ambitions for their new stadium.

It seems to be nearly impossible to operate a successful sporting club in the giant shadow cast by the other Old Trafford. The Manchester Evening News last night had a 16-page supplement. Test Match special? Hardly. It was "Reds 2000".

Old Trafford Tests did quite well for a few years by winning a regular slot in July, far away from the football season. Now that the schedule appears to be drawn out of a hat, that has become impossible. Yet even so, yesterday - truncated and downbeat though it was - may still have provided the pivotal moment of the season.

In 1995 when West Indies last toured, it was at Old Trafford (in the fourth game of six) when Brian Lara slipped the bonds of an indifferent start and scored 87 and 145. England won that game but, for Lara, it was a platform. He followed up with 152 and 179, and killed England's hopes of winning the series stone dead.

Now here he was again five years on in another tight, low-scoring series: older, not necessarily wiser, certainly more traumatised. He was wearing shades under his helmet, but was sweatered against the weather. In so far as anyone can judge the expression of helmeted batsmen, he seemed unhappy. His first run was taken away from him by the fourth umpire, who concluded it should have been a leg-bye.

An edge here, a miscue there... he could have been out six times before he got to double figures. When that happens to a batsman of this calibre, you know for certain he is heading for a century.

Lara c Thorpe b Gough 13. Maybe that is the pivotal moment.

webTitle: Football League puts boot into Rothmans

fields.headline: Football League puts boot into Rothmans
fields.trailText: The game's bible, the Rothmans Football Yearbook, may never be the same again following a row between its publishers and the Football League over the kind of information that has made it compulsive reading for managers, players and fans.
fields.body:
The game's bible, the Rothmans Football Yearbook, may never be the same again following a row between its publishers and the Football League over the kind of information that has made it compulsive reading for managers, players and fans.

The 2000-2001 yearbook was launched last night but the Football League has said that its publishers will no longer be allowed to have personal statistics on players, such as their weight, height and background. It has also ruled that Rothmans should not be allowed to have information on clubs such as directors' names, ground information and lists of personnel. The Football League has recently signed a £65m internet deal with NTL that will contain websites for all its 72 clubs.

Since first being published 31 years ago Rothmans has been used by those within the game as the main reference book, particularly because of the personal information it contains on players. Fortunately for the publishers, they had managed to gather most of the information on players for this season's edition by the time the Football League intervened but there are fears that next year's book could be severely affected by the ban.

The book's editor Jack Rollin said last night: "There are going to be massive problems for next year. The only way we can get personal details of players is from the clubs themselves. I don't know how we are going to proceed but we are going to have to get around the problem. The tragedy is that people within the game rely on this book and the Footbal League is being very unfair."

A spokesman for the Football League said: "It's a real shame because the yearbook is the bible of the game. But we want to make sure that the information our clubs are providing is only used for the book and not sold to other internet sites. The publishers could not give us a guarantee that they will not sell information. We have an internet agreement with NTL that we have to honour."

The Professional Footballers' Association added to the proliferation of websites when, at Old Trafford yesterday, it launched its own site containing details of its members.

Givemefootball.com will be backed by the American media giant Sports Network and is promising to give the inside story on the game, including interviews with players and coverage of all the PFA's work. The Sports Network chief executive Mickey Charles said he is confident the new site will deliver results and information "quicker and better" than any of its rivals.

The Premier League is investigating a potential claim of up to £2.5m in wages by the injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi against Chelsea following the club's move to end his contract after receiving a £4m insurance payout. Chelsea have received the payout from their insurers after medical tests were carried out on the serious knee injury which the Italian suffered against West Ham in November 1998 and on which he has since had 10 operations.

The club, who have been paying Casiraghi his estimated £25,000-a-week wages since the injury, gave him six months' notice to end his contract which expires on August 17. From then on Casiraghi would no longer be a Chelsea player and therefore not entitled to receive any wages for the two years remaining on the deal he signed when he arrived from Lazio for £5.4m in 1998.

However, Casiraghi disputes the view of Chelsea and their insurers that his top-level career has come to an end. And his advisors have contacted London solicitors with a view to making an appeal to the Premier League or taking possible civil action in the courts.

The publishers could not give us a guarantee that they will not sell information. We have an internet agreement with NTL that we have to honour." The Professional Footballers' Association added to the proliferation of websites when, at Old Trafford yesterday, it launched its own site containing details of its members. Givemefootball.com will be backed by the American media giant Sports Network and is promising to give the inside story on the game, including interviews with players and coverage of all the PFA's work. The Sports Network chief executive Mickey Charles said he is confident the new site will deliver results and information "quicker and better" than any of its rivals. The Premier League is investigating a potential claim of up to £2.5m in wages by the injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi against Chelsea following the club's move to end his contract after receiving a £4m insurance payout. Chelsea have received the payout from their insurers after medical tests were carried out on the serious knee injury which the Italian suffered against West Ham in November 1998 and on which he has since had 10 operations. The club, who have been paying Casiraghi his estimated £25,000-a-week wages since the injury, gave him six months' notice to end his contract which expires on August 17. From then on Casiraghi would no longer be a Chelsea player and therefore not entitled to receive any wages for the two years remaining on the deal he signed when he arrived from Lazio for £5.4m in 1998. However, Casiraghi disputes the view of Chelsea and their insurers that his top-level career has come to an end. And his advisors have contacted London solicitors with a view to making an appeal to the Premier League or taking possible civil action in the courts.

webTitle: Cardiff City suspend their Panorama striker

fields.headline: Cardiff City suspend their Panorama striker
fields.trailText: The Cardiff City striker Dai Thomas has been suspended on full pay after video footage showed evidence of his involvement with English hooliganism at Euro 2000.
fields.body:
The Cardiff City striker Dai Thomas has been suspended on full pay after video footage showed evidence of his involvement with English hooliganism at Euro 2000.

Thomas, who was in Belgium as a supporter, was spotted in a BBC Panorama programme about football violence. He was then pursued by Belgian police to the infa mous Le Fiacre bar in Brussels before being arrested. Thomas, however, has denied being involved in any trouble.

The Belgian police have stated that the 25-year-old striker was taken to a regional detention centre before being deported, but Thomas claims that he was "caught up in a sweep" by the police.

"I did not believe that I was arrested at any time and I can confirm that I was not deported from Belgium but in fact made my own way home," he said.

"I have always been concerned to protect the good name of the club and, as I have said before, I will continue to cooperate fully with any investigation."

Cardiff City moved quickly to deal with the matter yesterday by announcing that Thomas will have to attend a formal hearing "to be con vened as soon as possible". The club's chief executive, David Temme, said the inquiry could involve the Welsh FA along with the Professional Footballers' Association.

Temme added: "These issues are being taken very seriously by Cardiff City but we must ensure that Dai Thomas has a full opportunity to respond to questions surrounding his visit to the European Championships. It would be wrong to pre-empt the findings of the hearing." Thomas cost Cardiff £100,000 when he arrived from Watford nearly two years ago after beginning his career with Swansea City.

The inquiry announcement coincided with a visit to Ninian Park by Cardiff City's prospective new owner Sam Hammam. He is expecting to buy an 82% stake in the club in a £3.1m deal within the next 10 days.

webTitle: Money-mad game cannot bank on fans' loyalty

fields.headline: Money-mad game cannot bank on fans' loyalty
fields.trailText: Is Steve Coppell's assertion that fans will never sway true? Loyalty is today bred on unrelenting success and has little to do with that all-consuming love for a local team.
fields.body:
Moments after vacating his job as manager of Crystal Palace for the fourth, and presumably, final time Steve Coppell was in reflective mood.

"There's no such thing as loyalty in football today," he said. "The only loyalty is between the supporter and his club. That will never die."

Coppell, the Scouser who played for Manchester United, has for some reason devoted the better part of the past 16 years to football in that suburban sprawl of south-east London.

One of the best wingers in an England shirt, Coppell has grown accustomed to "winging" it at Palace. He had to part company with 20 players in as many months while the club was in administration as a result of Mark Goldberg's spectacular financial failure.

Now a new superfan has bought the club and Coppell does not have the stomach for another rollercoaster ride. And who can blame him?

When one thinks of loyalty in football one thinks of players like Billy Bonds and David O'Leary and managers such as Dario Gradi, who has been at Crewe since leaving Palace 18 years ago, and Ron Greenwood. Coppell comes into that category, as someone who kept the faith rather than one eye on the next opportunity.

Loyalty to manager, coach, player and chief executive is rare enough, but is Coppell's assertion that fans will never sway true?

Alison Pilling of the Football Supporters' Association suggests that "the influence of television might mean it is less likely for youngsters to fall in love with their local club".

And what of the new profile of a football fan, the bloke who gets tickets from his banking colleague who happens to be on the board? He will be able to bore you rigid about the club's investment strategy but he will have no clue about the club's history pre-1992. This lot are floating fans who pay homage to the strength of the pound and the weakness of the euro rather than the strength of the defence and the weakness the centre-forward has for Scotch.

The growth in attendance figures for the Premiership is undeniably outstanding apart from the odd blip, including Aston Villa last season. But sponsors and advertisers acknowledge that they are slowly but surely gearing their campaigns more towards the over-30s. There are concerns that, because of escalating admission prices and the growth of season-ticket and corporate deals, the number of teenagers watching live football is in serious decline.

Every youngster now seems to have a silly haircut, a passion for Gail Porter and Radiohead and, more pertinently, supports Man United - not because their fathers did, not because they have even been to Old Trafford and not because of an appreciation of the club's history. No, they support them because all their mates do.

If, and it is a big if, United fall from grace at some stage, they will then attach themselves to the next footballing brand. This is not loyalty, merely an association with a concept that they see once a week on the telly. They are as close to United as they are to Carol Vorderman.

Last season United's home games attracted a cumulative attendance of 1.12m, an average of 58,017. In 1995 the average was 41,700. This is loyalty bred on unrelenting success. It has little to do with that all-consuming love for a local team, the team one supports automatically out of affliction and necessity.

A Chelsea fan of the early 1970s could relate to Bobby Tambling and Peter Osgood. They were probably not fit to lace the boots of Marcel Desailly and Gianfranco Zola but how can a teenager lucky enough to get a ticket for Stamford Bridge this season relate to Eidur Gudjohnsen and Carlo Cudicini?

And just when he has the hang of who is playing for his team, the early stages of player-fan bonding are wrecked when Carlos Kickaball pushes off to Italy. This is short-term loyalty, changeable as a chameleon.

Unlike one of Coppell's dashes down the line during his playing days, the fan of 2010 will run with the pack but have nothing at the end of it.

fields.headline: Red-hot Dutch
fields.standfirst: Three-breasted mutants. Villains getting their arms sliced off. Ultra-violent bug attacks. A head exploding on a windscreen. These are the 'blow-them-away' images director Paul Verhoeven loves to create.  An invisible breast-fondler is his latest - and Jesus could be next
fields.trailText: Three-breasted mutants. Villains getting their arms sliced off. Ultra-violent bug attacks. A head exploding on a windscreen. These are the 'blow-them-away' images director Paul Verhoeven loves to create. An invisible breast-fondler is his latest - and Jesus could be next
fields.body:
Paul Verhoeven once said that in every new movie he liked to give audiences at least one thing they'd never seen before, one image that would really "blow them away". If he had lacked this one urge, we might never have heard of the Dutch expatriate director of RoboCop, Basic Instinct and Showgirls.

Where to start with these images? With Peter Weller's arm being blown off by Kurtwood Smith in RoboCop? Or the moment when Smith himself, covered in toxic waste, is hit by a car and literally explodes, his head bursting on the windshield in a riot of scarlet brain tissue? Arnie using a corpse as a bullet-proof shield in Total Recall? Or Recall's villain, the redoubtable Michael Ironside, having both his arms severed by an out-of-control elevator? Or the ultraviolent bug attacks of Starship Troopers, to say nothing of pneumatic ingenue Denise Richards blowing chunks all over the camera?

And that's just the violence and the vomit. Sex has given Verhoeven a whole other theatre in his 30-years war with propriety. He gave us the most notorious non-porn beaver-shot in movie history in Basic Instinct, three-breasted mutants in Total Recall, and the ghastly spectacle of Showgirls - a movie quite capable of making heterosexual men never, ever want to see another naked female breast.

And that's just the American movies. Verhoeven's Dutch career in the 70s was another long catalogue of offences against public decency - at least in the eyes of the stolid burghers who ran the committee subsidising Dutch film production, who later, according to the director himself, ran Verhoeven right out of the country. There was the shadow of a gigantic erection (Rutger Hauer's) in his 1975 historical drama Cathy Tippel; Jeroen Krabbé being tortured by the Nazis, with a hosepipe pumping gallons of water up his arse, in the Dutch resistance thriller Soldier of Orange; a homosexual gang rape in the biker movie Spetters (one rapist spits on the victim's rectum for increased lubrication); and an onscreen castration (Krabbé again) in The Fourth Man.

Steven Spielberg admired Soldier of Orange and suggested to George Lucas that Verhoeven might make a good director for The Return of the Jedi. Then he saw Spetters. The idea was quickly dropped. "I suppose he was scared," laughs Verhoeven, "that the Jedi would immediately start fucking each other." And Basic Instinct's scriptwriter, Joe Eszterhas, claims the first time he met Verhoeven the director's first words were: "How can we get more tits and cunts into this movie?"

His first English-language project, Flesh + Blood, a medieval epic and possibly his most enjoyable movie, is so filled with rapes and beheadings that it pitched Verhoeven into the first of his many wars with the Motion Picture Association of America's ratings board. But with Hollow Man, his variation on the themes of HG Wells's The Invisible Man, Verhoeven again gives us things we've never seen before - a rat bloodily devoured by an invisible gorilla, an invisible dog killed by Kevin Bacon (we see a thermal image), and silliest of all, a woman's breasts being kneaded by invisible hands. But this time we're in R-rated territory - a "restricted" rating midway between a British "15" and "18".

"To my amazement," says Verhoeven, "when I cut the movie and gave it to the MPAA, they gave me an 'R'. This is the first time in the United States they didn't give me an 'X' - or an 'NC-17' as it's called now." Lest we forget, the NC-17 was created especially for Basic Instinct. Another first.

Unlike his movies, the 62-year-old Paul Verhoeven is not in the least bit vulgar, violent or stupid. In fact, he radiates intelligence as he talks rapidly in his near-perfect English. What makes him such a compelling speaker is that his articulacy and conversational brio come overlaid with a heavy Dutch accent that teems with pleasingly odd constructions ("more fastly"), quasi-Geordie vowel sounds, and profitably garbled meanings (actors "interfere" with each other, rather than "interact"). And oddly enough, given his most notorious and successful movie, the word he uses most often is "basically." As he talks about politics, the second world war, history and movies, it's clear that one is in the presence of someone who, in intellectual terms at least, could eat most of his fellow Hollywood directors for breakfast.

After all, he holds a PhD in mathematics and physics from the venerable and prestigious university of Leiden. At one point I can't resist addressing him as "Dr Verhoeven". What at first looks like a flicker of mild annoyance ripens finally into a broad grin and a self-deprecating chuckle. Does his proficiency come in useful with the effects boffins? I ask. "Oh yes, but it's hardly a necessity. And you rarely need mathematical formulae to achieve your goals as a director, which is just as well, because I've forgotten most of them."

Although Hollow Man deals with the nature of evil, and though Verhoeven is given to quoting Plato's Republic while discussing it, you can't fail to recognise it as the work of its author. Kevin Bacon plays the leader of a Pentagon-sponsored programme to develop invisibility for military applications. He and his team (Elizabeth Shue, Josh Brolin) have pioneered invisibility in laboratory rats and apes, but haven't yet restored any of them to full visibility. Bacon, an arrogant genius, decides that in order to preserve funding and maintain independence from the generals, he will use himself as the first human guinea pig. For the last two-thirds of the movie, we see him only when someone coats him with water, steam, paint, latex and, increasingly as the film continues, with other people's blood.

Apart from David McCallum in the 70s American TV series The Invisible Man, no one invisible has ever been an agent for order and goodness, and Bacon is no exception. "He's not a bad guy to start with," says Verhoeven. "We portrayed him in the early stages of the story with enough little nasty elements [he's a voyeur and doesn't much like his lab rats or staff] that you wouldn't be too amazed."

"Plato, when he discusses invisibility in The Republic, says that when a man becomes invisible, that he would start to behave in an evil way. He feels that the constraints of society make us behave in a decent way because we are afraid to get in jail or be punished in whatever way. But if we knew we would get away with everything, we would not behave so well, I think."

Does the same apply to Verhoeven? "Oh yes, but as far as I know, not to the degree of being criminal. At least I've never explored that or tried to explore it, although in my movies I do. I proposed once - it's not come to much yet - to do a movie about Adolf Hitler, which would clearly be about something that goes beyond evil. My interest in evil is self-evident, and as Alec Guinness once said, 'If you play Hitler' - as he once did - 'that doesn't make you evil yourself.' Everything we do about Hitler is a projection of our own vision on to him, but that doesn't make us into a person like Adolf Hitler. Artistry is different from real fact."

Hitler featured heavily in Verhoeven's childhood in the Hague, the administrative capital of Nazi-occupied Holland, site of the V1 launchpads and target of massive Allied bombing raids. "I cannot separate myself from what I saw during the second world war," he once said. He was two when the Wehrmacht swept into Holland in 1940, and his earliest memories included summary executions and the sight of his neighbours "picking up pieces of pilots".

But Verhoeven had another angle on the experience. "Living in an occupied country is something that's close to me," he says, and certainly the subject turns up again and again in his work, either in disguised form, with Starship Troopers, or directly, as in Soldier of Orange. "But I loved it," he recalls. "I thought war was great - bombing and planes and shooting and people being killed. Really wonderful. Being a child of the war, my tolerance for violence is higher than normal. Kids love violence. As an adult, you realise that violence is real. So my work is anchored in reality, it's hyper-realistic. Hence the need to show everything so explicitly: the fucking and the pricks and the shit and the drugs and the violence."

All of which earned him the opprobrium of the Dutch bourgeoisie, culminating in the bitter controversy over Spetters in 1980. "When I did Spetters, I got in big problems with Dutch society and they created this committee called the National Anti-Spetters Committee because they thought the movie was so disgusting that I should be banned from ever making any more movies. There's a lot of harsh things in Spetters, much harsher than in any American movie I've made. There was a lot of resistance. The reaction was even worse than the reactions I got here in the United States for Showgirls. One of the reasons I left the country was that the government subsidy board wasn't willing to give me any money because they thought that I was an indecent, perverted, decadent person. Which is probably true, but they shouldn't have held it against me."

Thirteen years after RoboCop, Verhoeven is no longer a Dutch emigre with a suspiciously arty-looking back catalogue. He is now a major American director, a figure of - but simultaneously not of - the Hollywood establishment, a maverick within the mainstream plotting a course of outrage and scandal into the new century. And if Hollow Man finds him in something of a creative holding-pattern that unites his two favourite genres - effects-based sci-fi and the suspense thriller - then we should remember that he has other interests, other kinds of movies he'd like to see made.

He has long wanted to make a movie about the Crusades, perhaps to make up for the budgetary restraints he chafed under on Flesh + Blood. His interest in a Hitler biopic may be purely theoretical ("I can't see anyone financing it in the US, and certainly not in Germany") but he has consulted biographer Ian Kershaw. "If you touch that subject," he says, "you're dead, basically."

"But," he says, touching on another biopic he's been researching, "the same thing applies to Jesus, strangely enough. If you touch Jesus, everybody gets upset."

Verhoeven, a lapsed Catholic, is a member of the Jesus Seminar, a group of mainly American academics who gather to discuss the historical Jesus. "What did he really do? What did he really say? I've studied it for nearly 15 years to help me conceive an outline that's nearly done now," he says. "I'm sure it will be controversial. I see the story more from a political point of view. For me it has a lot to do with Roman politics and how the high priests and the top aristocracy of Israel collaborated with the Romans. So you get the collaborating government in an occupied country where the people underneath are suppressed and try to find ways to deal with reality."

It's encouraging to see Verhoeven cast about for new and profitable subjects with which to offend large sections of the movie-going audience. First he did sex, then violence, then he came to America and did extreme violence, then even more explicit sex, all over again. Hollow Man offers cruelty to (digitally animated) animals, full-frontal male nudity and an invisible rapist. Politics is where he should head next. Think of the protests.

So is he mellowing? "Perhaps when you get older you want to be a little bit more... playful," he says. "For a long time, I had a completely cynical outlook on society. It's still there and it still runs in and out of the movies. But perhaps these days I'm a bit... I won't say wiser...just a bit more normal."

 Hollow Man will be screened at the Edinburgh Film Festival on August 25, preceded by a Reel Life discussion with Paul Verhoeven (tickets: 0131-623 8030).

"Living in an occupied country is something that's close to me," he says, and certainly the subject turns up again and again in his work, either in disguised form, with Starship Troopers, or directly, as in Soldier of Orange. "But I loved it," he recalls. "I thought war was great - bombing and planes and shooting and people being killed. Really wonderful. Being a child of the war, my tolerance for violence is higher than normal. Kids love violence. As an adult, you realise that violence is real. So my work is anchored in reality, it's hyper-realistic. Hence the need to show everything so explicitly: the fucking and the pricks and the shit and the drugs and the violence." All of which earned him the opprobrium of the Dutch bourgeoisie, culminating in the bitter controversy over Spetters in 1980. "When I did Spetters, I got in big problems with Dutch society and they created this committee called the National Anti-Spetters Committee because they thought the movie was so disgusting that I should be banned from ever making any more movies. There's a lot of harsh things in Spetters, much harsher than in any American movie I've made. There was a lot of resistance. The reaction was even worse than the reactions I got here in the United States for Showgirls. One of the reasons I left the country was that the government subsidy board wasn't willing to give me any money because they thought that I was an indecent, perverted, decadent person. Which is probably true, but they shouldn't have held it against me." Thirteen years after RoboCop, Verhoeven is no longer a Dutch emigre with a suspiciously arty-looking back catalogue. He is now a major American director, a figure of - but simultaneously not of - the Hollywood establishment, a maverick within the mainstream plotting a course of outrage and scandal into the new century. And if Hollow Man finds him in something of a creative holding-pattern that unites his two favourite genres - effects-based sci-fi and the suspense thriller - then we should remember that he has other interests, other kinds of movies he'd like to see made. He has long wanted to make a movie about the Crusades, perhaps to make up for the budgetary restraints he chafed under on Flesh + Blood. His interest in a Hitler biopic may be purely theoretical ("I can't see anyone financing it in the US, and certainly not in Germany") but he has consulted biographer Ian Kershaw. "If you touch that subject," he says, "you're dead, basically." "But," he says, touching on another biopic he's been researching, "the same thing applies to Jesus, strangely enough. If you touch Jesus, everybody gets upset." Verhoeven, a lapsed Catholic, is a member of the Jesus Seminar, a group of mainly American academics who gather to discuss the historical Jesus. "What did he really do? What did he really say? I've studied it for nearly 15 years to help me conceive an outline that's nearly done now," he says. "I'm sure it will be controversial. I see the story more from a political point of view. For me it has a lot to do with Roman politics and how the high priests and the top aristocracy of Israel collaborated with the Romans. So you get the collaborating government in an occupied country where the people underneath are suppressed and try to find ways to deal with reality." It's encouraging to see Verhoeven cast about for new and profitable subjects with which to offend large sections of the movie-going audience. First he did sex, then violence, then he came to America and did extreme violence, then even more explicit sex, all over again. Hollow Man offers cruelty to (digitally animated) animals, full-frontal male nudity and an invisible rapist. Politics is where he should head next. Think of the protests. So is he mellowing? "Perhaps when you get older you want to be a little bit more... playful," he says. "For a long time, I had a completely cynical outlook on society. It's still there and it still runs in and out of the movies. But perhaps these days I'm a bit... I won't say wiser...just a bit more normal."  Hollow Man will be screened at the Edinburgh Film Festival on August 25, preceded by a Reel Life discussion with Paul Verhoeven (tickets: 0131-623 8030).

webTitle: Such a perfect day for Stewart and England

fields.headline: Such a perfect day for Stewart and England
fields.trailText: Well as England bowled, Thursday at Old Trafford was dismal - wet, empty and anticlimactic. Today, unless you were a West Indies supporter, was a hundred times better. All together now: oh it's such a perfect day, and as Marcus Trescothick probably said to Alec Stewart in the dressing-room afterwards, I'm glad I spent it with you.
fields.body:
Well as England bowled, Thursday at Old Trafford was dismal - wet, empty and anticlimactic. Today, unless you were a West Indies supporter, was a hundred times better. All together now: oh it's such a perfect day, and as Marcus Trescothick probably said to Alec Stewart in the dressing-room afterwards, I'm glad I spent it with you.

Stewart could make runs in his sleep at the moment, whether or not he is in his pyjamas. His 50 was England's first of the Test series, but his fifth in succession in international cricket. He had some luck - notably when he played his favourite bad shot, the Harrow cut, within an inch of off stump - but he rode it brilliantly. It's as if he has looked at his fellow 37-year-old Courtney Walsh, bowling literally better than ever, and thought anything he can do, I can do almost as well.

But first the bowlers had to finish the job, and they did so superbly. Darren Gough deserved far more than his two wickets: in both forms of the game, he has been a level higher this summer than ever before, adding consistency and guile to his familiar hustle and bustle. His slower ball, now showing in Tests as well as one-day cricket, is so distinctive it ought to have a name of its own: the Gough-break, perhaps.

Andy Caddick bowled an impeccable line and overcame his distaste for first inningses. Cork was Cork. Craig White was suddenly hostile, a rich man's David Capel. And two of the catches, by Graham Thorpe yesterday morning and Nasser Hussain today, were world-class.

When England batted, it was not so much a game of two halves as two completely different games. Curtly and Courtney bowled their first 17 overs for 17 runs and three wickets (Walsh conceded more runs with one step, when he trod over the boundary rope after catching Hussain, than he did as a bowler in the first hour.) Franklyn and Reon bowled eight overs for 50.

Of course, Ambrose and Walsh are great bowlers, and Walsh has bowled better this summer than in any of his seven previous series against England. But England treated them with the most cringeing deference seen on Channel 4 since last night, when Lord Glenconner was fawning all over Princess Margaret. As Trecothick (forgivably) and Hussain (less so) prodded and poked, the collapse was waiting to happen.

When it came, it was partly thanks to a poor umpiring decision - Walsh's slower ball to Graham Thorpe may have been inspired, but as it didn't pitch, there is no way of telling whether it was turning. But 17 for 1 became 17 for 3, West Indies were right back in the game, and with only one senior batsman left, it was going to take something very special to turn things round.

The senior batsman supplied it, not just in his strokeplay but in his demeanour. Like the car in those billboards that are everywhere at the moment, he contains strong body language.

Trescothick gradually blossomed under the wing of the man he opened with in the one-dayers as they raced towards and past the 171 they put on against West Indies at Chester-le-Street three weeks ago. His technique did not entirely pass the examination from Professor Ambrose and Dr Walsh, but his temperament triumphantly did. He should last a little longer than the last novice to make 50 for England - Chris Schofield, who scored 57 against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge and hasn't been seen since.

Trescothick was very good, the bowlers were excellent, but Stewart surpassed them all. There's only one thing to say to the old sergeant-major: Gaffer, we salute you.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: Drink-drivers sent back to classroom
fields.standfirst: Home Office introduces compulsory lessons for problem drinkers as part of plan to tackle alcohol-related crime
fields.trailText: The 100,000 drink-drivers convicted every year face compulsory alcohol education and treatment courses under a shake-up of the motoring laws to be announced by ministers later this month.
fields.body:
The 100,000 drink-drivers convicted every year face compulsory alcohol education and treatment courses under a shake-up of the motoring laws to be announced by ministers later this month.

The Home Office unveiled its latest package of proposals to tackle alcohol-related crime yesterday, including the use of fixed penalty fines to deal with public drunkenness and disorder, giving the police the power to confiscate open bottles and cans from those drinking in the street, and new measures to encourage pub landlords to crack down on underage drinking.

Under the drink-driving proposals, convicted motorists would be expected to attend an hour and a half class each week for between six to eight weeks in a course which would be designed to get them to face up to their problem drinking and prevent them reoffending.

At present a small number of convicted drink-drivers pay to take such courses in return for a three-month deduction from their automatic 12-month driving ban.

Alcohol Concern said yesterday it had been pressing for such action for some time. "In the last three or four years the national strategy has concentrated on illicit drugs which have had most of the resources," its assistant director, Sue Boon, said.

"People are comfortable about seeing illegal drugs as the root of all evil; 90% of people use alcohol but are less comfortable about the fact that it causes even more problems. We want to see alcohol being given the same priority as the question of illicit drugs."

The Automobile Association gave a cautious welcome to the move, saying it had been shown that voluntary alcohol education classes worked.

However, a spokesman warned that if the classes were compulsory those attending might not have the same motivation. In the US some of the people sent for such reeducation simply turn up and spend the time playing cards.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said alcohol contributed to 40% of violent crime and 88% of criminal damage cases and the plan was part of a series of measures to reduce these statistics.

He confirmed that the government intends to push ahead with fixed penalty fines for cases of public drunkenness but indicated that this would cover seven or eight specific offences. Police officers would not collect money "on the spot" and those fined would have the right to appeal to a court. However, Mr Clarke said he did not envisage that drunks on the street would be breathalysed. Instead police officers would use their judgment in determining whether those stopped had had too much to drink.

The Conservative home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, was sceptical. "What sort of judgment will the officer be expected to make?" he said. "It is not like a speeding offence where you know from machinery that the car has been speeding... I want to know what evidence the police will need and what is the standard evidence that will be needed to prove the offence to a court."

Home office ministers hope the measures will help tackle violent undercurrents in Britain's urban nightlife.

"We think that establishing a culture in city centres around alcohol which is much tighter and more rigid, in partnership with clubs and pubs themselves and police, magistrates and local councils, will build an atmosphere where you violence takes place for less," Mr Clarke said.

The Home Office action plan also includes proposals to make the use of toughened drinking glasses, which lessen injuries from pub fights, a condition on issue of an alcohol licence.

The national expansion of "pubwatch" schemes, under which landlords share information about troublemakers, will also be given the go-ahead.

Mr Clarke was also keen to see further moves towards a voluntary identity card scheme for older teenagers so they could prove they were over 18. The government is considering placing a positive duty on landlords to establish the age of younger customers.

Pubs are also to be given stronger powers to exclude troublemakers and to refuse to sell alcohol to those who are already drunk.

fields.headline: 'Moderate' to lead Plaid Cymru
fields.trailText: August 4 2000: Plaid Cymru last night elected as its new leader Ieuan Wyn Jones, a moderate who says he is determined to take on Labour in the Welsh heartlands.
fields.body:
Plaid Cymru last night elected as its new leader Ieuan Wyn Jones, a moderate who says he is determined to take on Labour in the Welsh heartlands.

Mr Jones, MP for Ynys Mon since 1987, won 77% of the vote on a 60% turn out. He defeated two leftwing women and now faces a challenge to show he has the charisma to attract attention to his party.

Helen Jones, the straight-talking chairwoman of Plaid in the assembly, came second with 12.7% of the vote, and the Euro-MP Jill Evans, party chairwoman between 1994 and 1996, came third with 9.5%.

Mr Jones succeeds Dafydd Wigley as leader and becomes only the fourth leader of the party since the war. He won on the first ballot and the result reflects the continuing strength of Plaid in north Wales.

Plaid made spectacular breakthroughs in south Wales in the Euro and assembly elections, but appears to have slipped back since the election of Rhodri Morgan as leader of the Welsh Labour party.

In his manifesto, Mr Jones said he would like the party to adopt the phrase "full national status" to describe its aspiration for Wales. He added: "We need to be clear that Wales should aspire to whatever status gives us the greatest ability to control our destiny as a nation."

webTitle: News of the World suspends name-and-shame campaign

fields.headline: News of the World suspends name-and-shame campaign
fields.trailText: The News of the World has announced it will "suspend" its controversial name-and-shame campaign, and will instead continue to promote the implementation of new child protection legislation.
fields.body:
The News of the World has announced it will "suspend" its controversial name-and-shame campaign, and will instead continue to promote the implementation of new child protection legislation.

In a statement, the newspaper said it would continue its "For Sarah" campaign, named after murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne, by campaigning for a public register of sex offenders.

The newspaper's reversal comes after a string of vigilante attacks on men either named or mistakenly identified as those named by the campaign, and sustained criticism of the campaign by police and child protection groups.

A statement from Sarah's parents, Sara and Michael Payne, was read out at the News of the World press conference in London. The statement read: "We support the discontinuing of the News of the World campaign.

"Sarah's Law will give back power to parents to enable them to protect their children. This debate was long overdue and we look forward to hearing the Home Secretary's response to this decision."

The paper, which aimed to name 150 paedophiles, condemned vigilante action throughout the campaign. Its decision comes after a fifth man became the latest target of vigilante violence.

Surrey police said malicious letters were sent to a man with the same name as a convicted paedophile identified in the News of the World on July 30. Several neighbours living near Gerald Baker, 66, of Onslow Village, near Guildford, received the letter telling them he was the man identified by the paper.

The letter claimed to be from an organisation called Antimatter who said they provided "a service to the community by investigating and identifying anti-social behaviour", a Surrey police spokeswoman said.

On Wednesday, Michael Horgan, 55, became the innocent victim of the same group after it sent 500 similar letters to his neighbours.

Police had to provide both men with overnight protection as well as leafleting their neighbours to make it clear they were the victims of mistaken identity.

Last night, more than 150 people rioted outside the Portsmouth flat of convicted paedophile Victor Burnett, who was also named in the newspaper's campaign. During the three hours of violence which left a policeman in hospital, Mr Burnett's flat was stoned, a car outside was overturned and set on fire, and a brick was thrown into the face of a policeman.

The newspaper had claimed Burnett was not listed on the Sex Offenders Register because he offended before the law came into force, and was still a threat to children.

However, local police, who condemned the violence, stated they were fully aware of his activities and his whereabouts. Hampshire Police's deputy chief constable, Ian Readhead, said: "The vast majority of people on the streets of Paulsgrove last night were not concerned parents.

"They were people using the current debate over sex offenders as an excuse to carry out active disorder and violence."

During the three hours of violence which left a policeman in hospital, Mr Burnett's flat was stoned, a car outside was overturned and set on fire, and a brick was thrown into the face of a policeman. The newspaper had claimed Burnett was not listed on the Sex Offenders Register because he offended before the law came into force, and was still a threat to children. However, local police, who condemned the violence, stated they were fully aware of his activities and his whereabouts. Hampshire Police's deputy chief constable, Ian Readhead, said: "The vast majority of people on the streets of Paulsgrove last night were not concerned parents. "They were people using the current debate over sex offenders as an excuse to carry out active disorder and violence."

webTitle: The real shame is that police must protect paedophiles

fields.headline: The real shame is that police must protect paedophiles
fields.standfirst: The decision by the News of the World to expose child-sex offenders has put police in an impossible position, writes crime correspondent Nick Hopkins
fields.trailText: The decision by the News of the World to expose child-sex offenders has put police in an impossible position, writes crime correspondent Nick Hopkins
fields.body:
Obvious issues were raised by the News of the World's Name and Shame campaign to 'out' convicted paedophiles by printing their names and addresses on successive Sundays. The questions of advisability and morality have been tossed back and forth in the media over the past fortnight, to no great end.

The men were named, no doubt about that. They were shamed, too. But the News of the World, by accident or design, unleashed something far more furious and potent than ritual humiliation. Embarrassment of the offenders wasn't enough for some. Men, some of them entirely innocent, have been pursued and harassed.

When a 150-strong crowd descended on the home of a paedophile in Portsmouth last night, mob fever, whipped up by frustration and anger at the death of eight-year-old Sarah Payne, took over. Cars were burned, windows broken, a police officer was hurt. And the offender wasn't even at home. What would have happened if the rabble had got their hands on him? Police fear if the hysteria continues, one of these men will be lynched.

The News of the World has left forces across the UK to deal with the knotty practicalities of protecting those who have been convicted of heinous crimes from campaigners who are on the verge of committing them.

The association of chief police officers has been a leading voice in the criticism of the newspaper, correctly predicting that it would lead to vigilante-ism. As far as ACPO is concerned, there can be no leniency for the hordes who besiege and attack paedophiles.

The emergence of a group calling itself Antimatter, which claims to champion the rights of parents, will be treated in the same way as other groups the police regard as subversive, like Reclaim the Streets. If Antimatter won't work with the authorities, the police will try to infiltrate it. Files will be opened on leading members. Photographs of them will be taken and circulated to forces. The hunters will become the hunted.

In the meantime, the police will have to defend the paedophiles.

Every one of the men named by the newspaper will have been offered advice on safety. Most have been given fire blankets for their doors and windows, and some have had their homes fitted with emergency alarms.

For the men who are at most risk, safe-houses have been found; this is the sort of costly cover usually given to people on witness protection programmes before important trials. The irony has not been lost on officers.

Their fervent hope is that the News of the World will end its campaign, though a fudge of some kind, which saves the face of the new editor Rebekah Wade, is the most likely outcome. Until then, police thinking gets turned on its head; and they must continue to treat paedophiles as potential victims, and the gangs pursuing them as potential criminals.

fields.headline: Second victim of press hounding
fields.trailText: An RAC patrol driver has been given police protection after becoming the second man wrongly identified as a paedophile as a consequence of the News of the World's "name and shame" campaign.
fields.body:
An RAC patrol driver has been given police protection after becoming the second man wrongly identified as a paedophile as a consequence of the News of the World's "name and shame" campaign.

Five hundred houses close to the home of Michael Horgan, 55, in Lewisham, south-east London, received letters on Wednesday from an organisation calling itself Antimatter. It gave his name and address, and warned he was a twice convicted child molester.

An offender with the same surname and first name, living in south London, was identified on Sunday by the paper.

Mr Horgan has been given protection overnight and check-up calls every half-hour, and police are investigating the source of the letters. He said yesterday: "At first I thought it was a hoax, but my mother brought a letter in and she was in a state of shock."

In the letter Antimatter said it provided "a service to the community by investigating and identifying anti-social behaviour". A police spokesman said officers had leafleted the 500 addresses to point out the named resident was wrongly identified, and also said the real man was known to them and being monitored as a matter of routine.

Mr Horgan said there had been no incidents so far. Asked about the News of the World's campaign, he said: "They should take advice from the people that know what they are doing." In a statement, the paper said it had repeatedly stressed unlawful vigilante action was wholly unacceptable.

On July 23, the Sunday that the paper published its first list, a mob attacked the Manchester home of a man resembling one offender named.

Yesterday Cleveland police again criticised the paper for having put in jeopardy an undercover operation to arrest and extradite a sex offender.

Stephen Featherstone, 33, was arrested on an unnamed Spanish island, the police said, having quit his bar job on Monday on being named, with a photograph, by the paper on Sunday. In November he had jumped bail on conviction at Teesside crown court of indecent assaults on two girls under 16.

webTitle: Mob moves in on named 'abuser' injuring a policeman.

fields.headline: Mob moves in on named 'abuser'
fields.trailText: A policeman was injured last night after three men were targeted at their homes following the decision of the News of the World to name and shame convicted paedophiles.
fields.body:
A policeman was injured last night after three men were targeted at their homes following the decision of the News of the World to name and shame convicted paedophiles.

A police constable needed stitches after he was hit by a stone-throwing mob of up to 150 people who gathered outside the Portsmouth home of a man named in the newspaper.

Concern was also growing last night after a new organisation claiming to champion the rights of parents wrongly accused two men of being convicted paedophiles as a consequence of the campaign, Scotland Yard said last night.

The group, Antimatter, has leafleted hundreds of homes in south London incorrectly describing two men as sex offenders because they share names with two people identified in the paper last Sunday.

The victims have been given police protection. Police have conducted a leaflet campaign to persuade neighbours the men had been wrongly targeted.

In the latest incident last night, the mob smashed win dows of a council office and innocent home owners after it emerged the man they were targeting had moved out.

The attacks came after RAC patrol driver Michael Horgan, 55, of Lewisham, south east London, spoke out against the campaign when he was incorrectly identified as a paedophile. Antimatter sent leaflets to neighbours after a man with the same name was identified in the paper.

The leaflet said: "Thanks to the News of the World we can now target this man as a known paedophile."

Detective Inspector Steve Lamb of Lewisham CID said: "This malicious letter has caused Mr Horgan and his family considerable distress. It has taken up an enormous amount of police time ... at considerable expense to the taxpayer."

In the second case in two days, Victor Terry, 78, of Croydon, south London, received a copy of an Antimatter letter which incorrectly identified him as a convicted sex offender. Details of a man with the same name but nearly 30 years younger appeared in the paper last Sunday.

fields.headline: Sex offenders register
fields.standfirst: The release of photographs and details of the whereabouts of convicted child-sex offenders by a national newspaper has been condemned by police. Jeevan Vasagar and Julian Glover explain how the sex offenders register works
fields.trailText: The release of photographs and details of the whereabouts of convicted child-sex offenders by a national newspaper has been condemned by police. Jeevan Vasagar and Julian Glover explain how the sex offenders register works
fields.body:
Why is the sex offenders register in the news now?
Following the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne, which focused national attention on the threat to children posed by paedophiles, the News of the World dramatically upped the ante by publishing the names and photographs of 49 child-sex offenders. A week later it published a second set of pictures, and, the paper says, will continue to publish further pictures until it has outed everyone on the register. The paper called its campaign 'For Sarah' and claimed her murder proved police monitoring of paedophiles was not enough. Every parent had a right to know who the paedophiles were, it said.

What is the sex offenders register?
There are 12,000 people on the sex offenders register, which came into force in 1997; it includes all sexual crimes. Convicted sex offenders must register their names and addresses with the police, and inform them within 14 days if they move. Any offender failing to register can be jailed for up to six months and fined. The register is not retro-active and so does not include anyone convicted before 1997. In addition, police can apply for a community protection order, which lasts for a minimum of five years and can bar an individual from areas frequented by children.

So what do the police think of the News of the World's campaign?
They have condemned the paper's actions. Tony Butler, spokesman on sexual offenders for the association of chief police officers, said anonymity was an essential element of the register and the campaign would only endanger children's lives by driving the paedophiles underground. Police officers and representatives have met with the paper and Sarah Payne's parents in the hope of persuading it to call off the campaign. The police say all the publicity will drive offenders into hiding, perhaps making them more likely to re-offend.

Is there a precedent for the News of the World's actions?
Yes. In the outrage that accompanied the release of predatory paedophile Sidney Cooke, and before the introduction of the sex offenders register, the Sunday Express ran a similar campaign along the lines of: 'Could these evil men be living next door to you?'

What has been the result of the News of the World's actions?
Public fury has led to cases of 'lynch law' in which people suspected of being sex offenders have had their houses attacked by mobs. In south London, an organisation called Antimatter targeted Victor Terry, 78, an innocent man which it had confused with someone else of the same name. Another innocent man in Beswick, Manchester, was also besieged by vigilantes who mistook him for one of the paedophiles named in the News of the World. The paper says it has made it clear it does not want the public to resort to such actions.

Who gets told about the movements of sex offenders?
Head teachers, doctors, youth leaders, sports club managers and others, including landlords, are notified on a confidential basis of the existence of a local sex offender. But a system of general disclosure is unlikely to happen in Britain. In a recent legal ruling, it was declared that it was in society's interests for the offenders to be allowed to live normal, lawful lives.

What do other countries do?
In America, parents have access to pictures and details of all registered paedophiles. This right is known as 'Megan's Law' after seven-year-old Megan Kanka, who was found strangled near her New Jersey home six years ago. Her parents campaigned for the police to notify communities when paedophiles moved in.

What do Sarah Payne's parents think?
They have endorsed the News of the World's actions, and said that 'life should mean life' for sex offenders. The girl's mother, Sara, said: 'We think anyone who causes harm to a child in this way must be taken out of the community for life.'

fields.headline: Refund, Rejoice and Regret
fields.trailText: GIN SWIZZ
fields.body:
GIN SWIZZ

It is a well-known meteorological fact that if you put half-a-dozen Spurs fans together in a public place, their negative ions will increase the likelihood of rain by 50%. That's why so many keen gardeners live close to White Hart Lane. So it's not surprising to find that the world's most miserable supporters were at it again today, moaning about a "pathetic" offer by the club to refund season tickets for those mortally wounded at the sale of 33-year-old winger David Ginola.

The offer, announced this morning on the official Spurs website, will run until August 15. But it won't fool the Tottenham Action Group. "Clearly this publicity stunt has been orchestrated as an attempt to deflect criticism from the club following the sale of Ginola and the lack of a replacement," said Mark Jacob, spokesman for TAG (membership: 700). "Just when the mouth-watering prospect of Sergei Rebrov teaming up with Ginola had whetted our appetite for the forthcoming season, yet again the club have kicked loyal supporters in the teeth."

The swines. In fact, that £11m they spent on one of the best strikers in Europe over recent seasons was probably just to lull the fans into a false sense of happiness in the first place. And the decision to offer refunds on season tickets because a player had been sold only goes to show how rocky relations are between fans and club (in particular a certain Mr Sugar). It does not bode well for the new season, and neither does the situation look likely to change in the near future. Unless the board bows to fans' demands and re-signs Ginola, plays five up front, and resuscitates Danny Blanchflower, that is.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HAPPY SIGNING TO YOU

The Fiver today stumbled upon a scene of great celebration and merriment. Brightly-coloured flags and bunting lit up the streets. Bands played joyous odes. Thousands of well-wishers lined the streets, cheering, singing and waving. Had the Fiver taken a walk down the Mall to wish the Queen Mum a happy birthday? Sadly no - as the sniper's rifle we'd ordered hadn't turned up. In fact, the party we chanced upon was in Middlesbrough, and was being held to commemorate Bryan Robson finally landing a big-name player - well, these things only happen once in a hundred years.

Of course we're joking, because Robson has already bought Christian Karembeu and (ahem) Paul Okon. But there's no question that today's signing of Alen Boksic - who has finally agreed a £2.5m transfer from Lazio - is his most important of the summer. "I'm delighted Alen wants to join Middlesbrough," said Robson today, as he picked silly string out of his hair. "At his best, I rate him one of the best strikers in Europe." Boksic must wait on a work permit before the deal is rubber-stamped, but it would be a major shock if there are any problems - although the injury-prone striker hasn't played much international football of late, his reputation should see him through. What a lovely time everyone is having!

Unfortunately, things always seem to turn sour at parties the Fiver goes to. And sure enough, the atmosphere had an added twist of lime when rumours circulated that Christian Ziege will join Liverpool this weekend. And in a double whammy, lawyers have pored over the German's contract and found out that Middlesbrough will be forced to accept Gerard Houllier's £5.5m bid, well under their £8m valuation. Ah well, it's Robbo's party and he'll cry if he wants to.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Two seasons ago we finished seventh, last season it was fourth, so guess what our target is now!" - Gerard Houllier gives his best Rolf Harris impression ahead of the new season. Either that, or he's testing Steven Gerrard's arithmetic.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUACK QUACK

It's not often you see Arsene's Arsenal Wenger looking flustered. But today those famous facial lines seemed to grow into canyons, while his favourite suit appeared just that little bit more dishevelled. And the Fiver - finally taking the opportunity to use the Dr Hillary Jones' Doctor in the House CD-ROM we got for Christmas - was quick to diagnose the appearance of stress. Stress at seeing Overmars and Petit go to Barca. Stress at seeing David Seaman flapping away last night like a particularly happy seagull. And - most importantly of all - stress at the lack of cover for Thierry Henry.

It all made perfect sense. Particularly when Wenger started moaning about the lack of cover for Thierry Henry. "Of course we have Dennis Bergkamp and Kanu who are brilliant second strikers, but we still need more quality of the Thierry Henry type," the grim-faced manager admitted, as the Fiver debated whether to move to Harley Street and set up an expensive practice for sloaney types. "Ideally we must have a second guy who can take the same role as Thierry because we cannot expect him to play all the games next season." Pity you gave Davor Suker away for free then.

But it could just be that we've fallen victim to a classic Wenger mind game. Because, apparently, Arsenal have just made a £13m take-it-or-leave-it offer to Bordeaux for striker Sylvain Wiltord. And they've given the French club until Monday to respond or Wenger will "end his interest in the player indefinitely". (No we don't understand it either, but we're sure it's something very clever.) When Bordeaux coach Elie Baup was asked about Wiltord - who is refusing to train at the moment - he quipped: "Sylvain who? I don't have a player of that name in my squad!" He's joking, of course. And come Monday night Arsenal Wenger might be joining him in a stress-relieving smile too.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bradford are continuing their hunt for a striker. Middlesbrough's Brian Deane is believed to be in talks with the Bantams, and the Yorkshire club is also believed to be willing to match any offer from Manchester City for Paolo Wanchope.

Coventry may sign Norwegian striker Thorstein Helstad as replacement for £13m Robbie Keane. The Brann Bergen striker, is represented by notorious agent Rune Hauge, who said: "It's true that they are interested in Helstad, but we don't expect anything to happen in the near future."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wolves have signed Temuri Ketsbaia for £900,000. The Georgian international has put his name to a two-year contract at Molineux, subject to a medical and the granting of a work permit.

Geoffrey Richmond fears the name of Bradford City will not be big enough to attract West Ham striker Paulo Wanchope to Valley Parade. The Bantams have matched Manchester City's £4m bid for the 24-year-old and have also agreed personal terms with the Costa Rica international. But Richmond said: "My gut feeling is that our chances are something less than 50-50. The reason being that there is every possibility he will decide to join what is perceived to be a bigger club. We have been told he will make his mind up on Monday."

Marc Overmars signed for Barcelona three months ago, according to former Barcelona coach Louis van Gaal. "Overmars and Gerard are my signings," van Gaal told Sport newspaper. "As for Overmars, we had him tied up three months ago, and Gerard was on my high-priority list of targets."

Niall Quinn has signed a two-year extension to his current deal that will keep him at Sunderland until 2003.

Scotland U-21 international Scott Severin has agreed a new deal with Hearts which will keep him at Tynecastle until 2004.

Birmingham midfielder Martin Grainger has agreed a new six-year contract with the club.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm, 9pm SS3)

Big men toying with balls.

International Football (1.30am)

Learn to love Chris Waddle again with the official Fifa film of Italia 90.

British Eurosport: Women's Football - Live (5pm)

Bigots - don't bother.

Boksic must wait on a work permit before the deal is rubber-stamped, but it would be a major shock if there are any problems - although the injury-prone striker hasn't played much international football of late, his reputation should see him through. What a lovely time everyone is having! Unfortunately, things always seem to turn sour at parties the Fiver goes to. And sure enough, the atmosphere had an added twist of lime when rumours circulated that Christian Ziege will join Liverpool this weekend. And in a double whammy, lawyers have pored over the German's contract and found out that Middlesbrough will be forced to accept Gerard Houllier's £5.5m bid, well under their £8m valuation. Ah well, it's Robbo's party and he'll cry if he wants to. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "Two seasons ago we finished seventh, last season it was fourth, so guess what our target is now!" - Gerard Houllier gives his best Rolf Harris impression ahead of the new season. Either that, or he's testing Steven Gerrard's arithmetic. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUACK QUACK It's not often you see Arsene's Arsenal Wenger looking flustered. But today those famous facial lines seemed to grow into canyons, while his favourite suit appeared just that little bit more dishevelled. And the Fiver - finally taking the opportunity to use the Dr Hillary Jones' Doctor in the House CD-ROM we got for Christmas - was quick to diagnose the appearance of stress. Stress at seeing Overmars and Petit go to Barca. Stress at seeing David Seaman flapping away last night like a particularly happy seagull. And - most importantly of all - stress at the lack of cover for Thierry Henry. It all made perfect sense. Particularly when Wenger started moaning about the lack of cover for Thierry Henry. "Of course we have Dennis Bergkamp and Kanu who are brilliant second strikers, but we still need more quality of the Thierry Henry type," the grim-faced manager admitted, as the Fiver debated whether to move to Harley Street and set up an expensive practice for sloaney types. "Ideally we must have a second guy who can take the same role as Thierry because we cannot expect him to play all the games next season." Pity you gave Davor Suker away for free then. But it could just be that we've fallen victim to a classic Wenger mind game. Because, apparently, Arsenal have just made a £13m take-it-or-leave-it offer to Bordeaux for striker Sylvain Wiltord. And they've given the French club until Monday to respond or Wenger will "end his interest in the player indefinitely". (No we don't understand it either, but we're sure it's something very clever.) When Bordeaux coach Elie Baup was asked about Wiltord - who is refusing to train at the moment - he quipped: "Sylvain who? I don't have a player of that name in my squad!" He's joking, of course. And come Monday night Arsenal Wenger might be joining him in a stress-relieving smile too. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Bradford are continuing their hunt for a striker. Middlesbrough's Brian Deane is believed to be in talks with the Bantams, and the Yorkshire club is also believed to be willing to match any offer from Manchester City for Paolo Wanchope. Coventry may sign Norwegian striker Thorstein Helstad as replacement for £13m Robbie Keane. The Brann Bergen striker, is represented by notorious agent Rune Hauge, who said: "It's true that they are interested in Helstad, but we don't expect anything to happen in the near future." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Wolves have signed Temuri Ketsbaia for £900,000. The Georgian international has put his name to a two-year contract at Molineux, subject to a medical and the granting of a work permit. Geoffrey Richmond fears the name of Bradford City will not be big enough to attract West Ham striker Paulo Wanchope to Valley Parade. The Bantams have matched Manchester City's £4m bid for the 24-year-old and have also agreed personal terms with the Costa Rica international. But Richmond said: "My gut feeling is that our chances are something less than 50-50. The reason being that there is every possibility he will decide to join what is perceived to be a bigger club. We have been told he will make his mind up on Monday." Marc Overmars signed for Barcelona three months ago, according to former Barcelona coach Louis van Gaal. "Overmars and Gerard are my signings," van Gaal told Sport newspaper. "As for Overmars, we had him tied up three months ago, and Gerard was on my high-priority list of targets." Niall Quinn has signed a two-year extension to his current deal that will keep him at Sunderland until 2003. Scotland U-21 international Scott Severin has agreed a new deal with Hearts which will keep him at Tynecastle until 2004. Birmingham midfielder Martin Grainger has agreed a new six-year contract with the club. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm, 9pm SS3) Big men toying with balls. International Football (1.30am) Learn to love Chris Waddle again with the official Fifa film of Italia 90. British Eurosport: Women's Football - Live (5pm) Bigots - don't bother.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Brother embroiderer
fields.trailText: When will this embracing of all things embroidered end?
fields.body:
When will this embracing of all things embroidered end?

From Levi's denim with DIY patterns to the magnificent large-scale stitching on clothes by Kenzo, Lacroix and Givenchy, our crush on the crafts endures. The ambitious among you, then, may be delighted to learn of a machine that can stitch any designs you fancy on to just about anything you want. This magic machine is called the Brother PE 150 Design and costs around £500 (0161 931 2354). To quote the blurb, "you! (sic) supply the inspiration and PE Design creates a totally unique embroidery project at the touch of a button". A swirl of stitching here, a pretty pattern there and - hey presto - a reinvigorated wardrobe. You could even cover your clothes with Chanel's interlocking Cs or dinky little LVs. If you don't mind getting sued, that is.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  Smirnoff Ice
fields.trailText: Smirnoff Ice has achieved the seemingly impossible: made an alcopop socially acceptable for grown-ups. Cool places serve it. Cool people drink it. It's been held in manicured hands and rested on fashionably distressed bar tables all summer long.
fields.body:
Smirnoff Ice has achieved the seemingly impossible: made an alcopop socially acceptable for grown-ups. Cool places serve it. Cool people drink it. It's been held in manicured hands and rested on fashionably distressed bar tables all summer long.

Why? Well, the design helps, resembling a scaled-down vodka bottle, as does the fact that, unlike most alcopops, Ice is not syrupy-sweet or slyly marketed at the behind-the-bike-sheds gang. It is also a practically packaged night-out tipple for those whose "usual" is vodka-and-something. You can dance, jostle or, if you prefer, simply lurch drunkenly while clutching a bottle, without ice, lemon and straws flying everywhere.

The science bit? We're talking a blend of bitter lemon and Smirnoff Red vodka that tastes like vroomed-up lemonade - tricking you into forgetting it's 5.5% strength and your legs suddenly won't work properly. Imitations lurking in the pub fridge include Chekhov Ice but accept no substitute, no matter how brainy it sounds. It's got to be Ice, baby.
