webTitle: Find out who's wearing what where

fields.headline: All dressed up and somewhere to go
fields.standfirst: Does anyone bother to dress up these days? Of course they do! Join us at three of this summer's most fashionable parties to find out who's wearing what where
fields.trailText: Does anyone bother to dress up these days? Of course they do! Join us at three of this summer's most fashionable parties to find out who's wearing what where
fields.byline: Interviews: James Pretlove and Michael Oliveira-Salac
fields.body:
Party 1 Launch party for Tate: The Art magazine
Type Arty
Venue Silver Sturgeon on the Thames

ANOUSHKA AND PATRICIO GROSE FORRESTER

What are you? Patricio: "Embarrassed." Anoushka: "Placid."

What are you wearing? Patricio: "This is from my Overall Collection and is called Execution of Overall Embarrassment. I made it today and I'm wearing it to get seen." Anoushka: "My dress is from H&M, beads from The Bead Shop, tights from Deptford Market, shoes from a Notting Hill Housing Trust shop."

How much did it all cost? Patricio: "£39." Anoushka: "£60."

Funniest party outfit ever? Patricio: "What I'm wearing now." Anoushka: "A T-shirt with a hole over one gold-painted tit."

APRIL CRUTCHLEY

What are you? "A good size 14."

What are you wearing? "Turquoise suede mules and a Karen Millen turquoise cardie over a leopardprint dress, worn with a necklace of beads and feathers. I always overdress rather than underdress and I don't really pay any attention to what other people wear or think. This is probably the most expensive outfit I've ever bought."

How much did it all cost? "Just under £300."

Funniest party outfit ever? "For my 14th birthday, on a cruise down the Nile, I went dressed as a belly dancer."

Party 2 Birthday party for Superlovers streetwearlabel
Type Fashion
Venue Liverpool St's Great Eastern Hotel

MAMI JIN

What are you? "A mascot."

What are you wearing? "An 80s Thierry Mugler jumpsuit, a Martin Margiela T-shirt and Ray-Ban Aviators from the market."

How much did it all cost? "£120."

Funniest party outfit ever? "White panties with stockings, suspender belt and garter."

ANDY GILBERT

What are you? "Raw around the edges."

What are you wearing? "Secondhand top from Holloway Rd, Maharishi trousers, geography teacher shoes from Clarks."

How much did it all cost? "£185."

Funniest party outfit ever? "A tutu."

Party 3 Launch of Cerrutti Image Woman perfume
Type Smart
Venue Serpentine Gallery, Hyde Park

LORRAINE WILSON-MORRIS

What are you? "An achiever."

What are you wearing? "Grey trousers with a crocheted and beaded sarong (it's a shawl but I wear it around my waist), both from Oasis. A Next black chenille jumper and black shoes from Spain - the shoes there are so cheap. A silver bag by Calvin Klein, to match the trousers - I don't usually dress so that everything matches, but it all seemed to fall into place tonight."

How much did it all cost? "Approx £135."

Funniest party outfit ever? "I once went as a bunny girl with a fluffy white tail on a leotard. Another time I went as a nun, even though it wasn't actually a fancy dress party."

MARK "Surname unnecessary"

What are you? "Running on empty after a long week designing this event."

What are you wearing? "Burberry jacket from their seconds factory in Hackney; two T-shirts from I can't remember where; trousers, part of a vintage suit from Harvie & Hudson; matching (surprisingly) socks from Paul Smith; Nike trainers - and I've never really seen the point of underwear."

How much did it all cost? "£190ish."

Funniest party outfit ever? "Cable ties to keep my trousers up and pliers in my pocket so I could cut them to go to the loo."

webTitle: Style: The trainers of the future.

fields.headline: Sport couture
fields.standfirst: On your marks, get set, go ...  Albert Hill  runs down the trainers of the future
fields.trailText: On your marks, get set, go ... Albert Hill runs down the trainers of the future.
fields.body:
Only three years ago, the trainer was proclaimed to be on its last legs. A quiet retirement back to the tennis court seemed to be beckoning as Nike's profits slumped by half, Reebok's by 83%, and the buying public seemed more interested in the so-called "brown shoe", Birkenstocks et al.

Now it's a different story. The first £5,000 pair of trainers is rumoured just to have been sold (a pair of boxfresh Nike Air Jordan 1s, to a Japanese buyer), there is a major sports shoe exhibition, Design Afoot, starting tomorrow at the SanFrancisco Museum of Modern Art (due, according to the show's curator, to the "immense amount of creativity in the area"), Sky magazine is bringing out a bumper trainer supplement and the biggest trainer shop in the world, Footlocker, will open on London's Oxford Street next month.

The trainer industry's salvation came, ironically, from the fashion world that had ignored it for so long. DKNY's take on the trainer began to fly out of stores, Hermès' ludicrously priced trainer sold ludicrously well and Prada produced the ultimate minimal-chic sneaker. Pretty soon the sports companies began to realise it was a case of either acknowledging that nearly 90% of their trainers never even saw a track or field, or face the prospect of a sales drought. Unsurprisingly they took the former option, which takes us up to today.

Times are such that trainer shopping today rarely takes place in sports stores. It is increasingly likely to happen in more style-centred boutiques, department stores or in the new breed of trainer shops such as Offspring, Poste, Size? or Frontier that only have passing pretensions of being sports oriented. The new Puma Platinum "sports couture" range, for instance (which includes a Christy Turlington-designed yoga shoe that could well become the shoe of the summer), is currently available only in Harvey Nicks and Harrods, and the Adidas Micropacer, a reissue of a 1984 shoe, was only sold in very limited numbers (600 pairs per country) in very limited stores.

There is a Nike initiative under way, internally known as the Probe project, which will see small numbers of radically designed shoes leaked into select stores "when the wider market isn't quite ready", according to Offspring buyer Ghassan Hodieb, to "build up interest". "It's like the Nike Rift [a cloven, neoprene sandal, now worn by virtually every wannabe trendy the nation over]. That shoe was picked up by a few people years ago [pat yourself on the back if that was you] but now it's been adopted by the mainstream."

According to Hodeib, the Probe project trainers will look "like nothing you have ever seen before". Scheduled for imminent release, one is almost certain to be the Nike Ovidian, a shoe that is completely reversible. Another might (or might not) be the much muttered-about shoe designed by Nike in collaboration with Comme des Garçons' Junya Watanabe. Only sighted so far in Japan and on the web (www.mars.dti.ne.jp/~motonike/), it is as fashion-forward a statement as any major sports company has ever made.

Nike's head of design, Tinker Hatfield, says the future of Nike footwear is "smarter materials and more minimalist design. Somewhere shoes have gotten to the point where a lot of them are overdesigned." Hatfield is no doubt aware of the fashion crowd's recent predilection for the super-simple Adidas Stan Smith and Converse Jack Purcell. (And if it's Purcells you're after, try the new laceless jack slip-ons or chuck toggles.)

But technologies still play a major part in the cold war between sports shoe companies, especially with the Sydney Olympics almost upon us. Adidas have their Torsion technology, the Japanese company Asics uses a gel system, while Converse, in a rather crude case of oneupmanship with Nike, fill their shoes with "lighter than air" helium molecules. Meanwhile Reebok, after their gloriously gimmicky Pump innovation (the idea being you pump up the shoes), have turned to a system called DMX which incorporates pockets of moving air.

Nike still lead the pack when it comes to technology that captures the imagination. In 1987, they gave us the visible air window (wow, we went, we can walk on air) and now they give us the Shox system that will work on the same principle as asimple spring (wow, we cry, we can walk on springs). It's what Hatfield calls "romance in sports shoe design, theatricality _ the shoe as a caricature". You may have also heard of the Nike Presto shoe, a trainer that only comes in six sizes, ranging from XXS to XL, the idea being that the shoe adjusts to the size of your feet.

What we tend to be more interested in is whether our shoes will get the right heads turning. Nike, again, have got this stitched up with iD, a new ruse that's got the kids (that includes big kids) very excited. In this extremely clever ploy to make Nike not seem the gargantuan big brother company that it is, they offer "shoes designed by you" or, more specifically, one of four basic designs for which you can pick the predominant colourway but also have an eight-character word sewn around the heel (www.nike.com/).

Ask for the word fashion, though, and they will refuse. Although Hodieb at Offspring claims that many sports shoe companies "are led by us" (ie the fashionistas, not the athletes), they are not about to give their trainers kitten heels. Yet as Aaron Betsky, curator of the San Francisco exhibition, says: "The line between different sorts of shoes, where fashion and technology intersect, is beginning to blur." No doubt it will be us, then, who will be slack-jawed at what the next generation call trainers.

fields.headline: Shell dumps 120 service stations
fields.standfirst: Group says high petrol prices will not last
fields.trailText: Shell is to dispose of 10% of its British service stations in an attempt to boost global oil and gas earnings which are already running at £26m a day, the company said yesterday.
fields.body:
Shell is to dispose of 10% of its British service stations in an attempt to boost global oil and gas earnings which are already running at £26m a day, the company said yesterday.

The Anglo-Dutch group claimed it had made no profits from selling petrol in Britain for three years, contrary to the public view that oil majors are exploiting motorists.

Next month Shell will hand over 80 sites to Texaco and shut a further 60 but said it would cut petrol prices further if it needed to remain competitive with the supermarkets.

Mark Moody-Stuart, Shell's chairman, insisted peer pressure was only one of a number of factors that dictated the level of petrol prices, the main one being the cost of crude.

He admitted many customers were suffering from the high energy costs and promised longer term oil prices would fall. "Don't be blinded by this period of high oil prices, I cannot see it as sustainable," he said.

Garry Russell, who founded the Dump the Pump campaign aimed at boycotting stations one day a week to protest against petrol prices, said the latest Shell profits figures were "outrageous." He added: "It's hard to swallow claims they are not making millions out of motorists."

Shell's upstream and refining businesses has been cashing in on a second quarter crude price of $26.90 per barrel compared with $15.45 during the same period last year.

Shell increased net income to $6.5bn (£4.3nb) over the last half-year, a rise of more than 80% on last time.

The record result was boosted by a heavy cost-cutting programme which has sliced $3bn off overheads during the past two years. Shell has completed three-quarters of its target cuts within half the time and by the end of this year 18,000 jobs will have gone.

The company claims to have a return on capital employed of 16%, which would put it at the top of the oil league - on a par with ExxonMobil and above arch-rival BP.

While ExxonMobil and BP Amoco embarked on mergers as a way of countering a previous bout of low oil prices, Shell has concentrated on internal restructuring, and takeovers have been avoided. The shares ended the day up 7p at 555p.

Oil exploration and production company Lasmo also reported a huge jump in first half profits. Net profit before exceptional items was £126m, compared to £12m last time, on turnover of £500m.

Lasmo shares, which have outperformed the sector by nearly 8% since the start of the year, rose a further 3p to end the day at 129p.

He added: "It's hard to swallow claims they are not making millions out of motorists." Shell's upstream and refining businesses has been cashing in on a second quarter crude price of $26.90 per barrel compared with $15.45 during the same period last year. Shell increased net income to $6.5bn (£4.3nb) over the last half-year, a rise of more than 80% on last time. The record result was boosted by a heavy cost-cutting programme which has sliced $3bn off overheads during the past two years. Shell has completed three-quarters of its target cuts within half the time and by the end of this year 18,000 jobs will have gone. The company claims to have a return on capital employed of 16%, which would put it at the top of the oil league - on a par with ExxonMobil and above arch-rival BP. While ExxonMobil and BP Amoco embarked on mergers as a way of countering a previous bout of low oil prices, Shell has concentrated on internal restructuring, and takeovers have been avoided. The shares ended the day up 7p at 555p. Oil exploration and production company Lasmo also reported a huge jump in first half profits. Net profit before exceptional items was £126m, compared to £12m last time, on turnover of £500m. Lasmo shares, which have outperformed the sector by nearly 8% since the start of the year, rose a further 3p to end the day at 129p.

fields.headline: Supermarkets - do we need them?
fields.standfirst: Essential time-savers for a modern world or responsible for the destruction of urban and rural communities? William Moyes, Director general of The British Retail Consortium debates with campaigner Caroline Cranbrook. Have your say here.
fields.trailText: Essential time-savers for a modern world or responsible for the destruction of urban and rural communities? William Moyes, Director general of The British Retail Consortium debates with campaigner Caroline Cranbrook. Have your say here.
fields.body:
Dear Caroline,
Let's be honest, life without supermarkets would be hell. Thanks to their existence, what used to take all day now takes a couple of hours. Thirty years ago, by the time you had walked up and down the high street, visited a host of stores, queued at counters and checkouts and then trekked back home with as many bags as you could carry, the day was more or less over. And stores only opened nine to five. Now, responding to consumer demand, supermarkets operate extended opening hours and trade on Sundays. The number of lines stocked has also increased out of all recognition. Supermarkets now offer the choice of up to 40,000 lines - everything from economy to niche products at very competitive prices; they provide free car-parking and a number of other facilities such as financial services. They also sell a superb range of own labels, and offer home deliveries and internet shopping. Generally, none of us has to drive too far to get to the supermarket: we find them out-of-town or on the high street. A number of retailers are looking at even more convenient outlets in railway stations. Thirty years ago, customers would have given their right hand to shop in these sort of outlets, which we now take for granted. Yours sincerely,
William Moyes
Director general The British Retail Consortium

Dear William,

I agree. Most people who can, choose to shop in supermarkets for all the reasons you describe. Society now depends on them. They are here to stay. The global economy itself is vulnerable: to political instability, to unsustainable reliance on finite fossil fuels and to climate change produced by global warming.

But the argument has to move on. The country is saturated with superstores. Now is the time to count the cost of this convenience. The forces driving the supermarkets to ever-fiercer competition and increasing vertical concentration can also increase social deprivation and destroy the enabling structure of our local food economies which sustain our market towns and villages, the food producers who supply them and the people who depend on them.

Please remember that there are consumers who exist beyond the rosy glow of the supermarket - those who have no car, who are not on the internet, who live in a cash economy, whose shopping budgets are too small to qualify for home deliveries, who need their local shop for social contact and conversation. And don't forget the local food producers. Virtually all food production starts small-scale and depends on small retail outlets.

In east Suffolk, following the threat of a superstore, I surveyed 81 food shops and discovered they were sourcing food from 295 local producers. When superstores open, small shops close. Small shops, farms and food businesses are interdependent, providing employment and consumer choice. They are the basis of the rural economy. The way forward is to ensure we have the framework in place that enables the supermarkets to co-exist with the parallel integrated local economy, rather then compete with it until it is destroyed.

Yours sincerely,
(Lady) Caroline Cranbrook Campaigner

Dear Caroline,

The perception that suprmarkets operate out of "sheds" is not true. It is also worth emphasising that supermarkets have since 1996 been moving away from the larger format and are exploring a number of smaller, city-centre options.

I also disagree with you that competition is increasing social deprivation. The supermarkets are either testing or already running a number of initiatives to ensure that shoppers who live on estates can get to stores easily. There are bus schemes; a number of outlets offer taxi services; and some are investigating outlets on estates. But before stores can be sited on estates, crime needs to be addressed. It is also worth pointing out that supermarkets have been cutting prices for years. BRC's Shop Price Index, which is compiled independently, shows prices falling for the last 15 months in a row.

On suppliers, this week the industry has put together a code of practice to monitor the relationship between retailers and suppliers - a code welcomed by the NFU. All supermarkets, where they can, will use local suppliers. But it is paramount that these suppliers comply with appropriate legislation; that the quality of their products is first class and that production is adequate for the stores' needs.

Finally, I feel you forget a crucial ingredient: the consumer, who chooses where to shop. And if the supermarket is being chosen over and above the local shop, that is the nature of competition. It is important to remember that supermarkets are taking part in a number of initiatives to help local shops trade and in many instances survive. On job creation, here are the latest figures - the grocery sector employs 790,000 and has created 170,000 new jobs.

William Moyes

Dear William,

You have not addressed the fundamental problem I identified in my last letter: the need to ensure that the global economy of the supermarkets does not extinguish local food economies.

Size is fundamental to the whole problem. Supermarkets that are inappropriately large for their catchment area undoubtedly result in the closure of independent retailers. Thanks to government planning guidelines, few edge-of-town and out-of-town superstores are now being built. Government is now encouraging appropriately sized supermarkets in towns. But despite a number of small-scale initiatives, supermarkets have still not taken this policy on board.

The minister for local government has said that we are continuing to get "proposals for inappropriately sized supermarkets - even superstores - trying to piggy-back on designated local centres, or claiming to regenerate large out-of-centre sites". It is because of the growth of supermarkets that local shops have closed, leading to the creation of "food deserts". Solving the problem is certainly the responsibility of a number of stake-holders, including government and the police, not just the retailers. I hope you in turn will support the briefing paper published last week by The Centre for Food Policy. We need a multi-departmental strategy to solve the problem, and probably a Better Shops Task Force and Retailing Regulator as well.

Thirdly, there is local sourcing. Supermarkets have started identifying local products in their stores, which is good news. But these are usually from their mainline suppliers who happen to be local. I am concerned with providing a market for small producers. This summer, it was sad to see some of our local supermarkets stocking asparagus from abroad when British fields were filled with a much tastier home product.

Caroline Cranbrook

Dear Caroline,

Your approach to the issue of large v small is simplistic. And you fail to take into consideration the business case. But, I think it is important to point out at this stage that BRC represents the interest of the large, medium and small retailers and has a vested interest in seeing them all prosper and flourish. Diversity is a strength.

Supermarkets are not in the business of "extinguishing" smaller operators. It is a fact that many smaller operators fail because of a whole series of underlying costs and burdens which can impact on them more severely than on the large - such as upward only rent reviews; rates; the cost of crime and the burden of regulation, to name a few. Secondly, many smaller operators take the supermarkets head-on instead of seeking out innovative/niche ways of tackling the competition.

As to the criticism that supermarkets have still not taken on board the planning policies - that is rubbish! Supermarkets adhere rigidly to PPG 6 and 13 as interpreted through local development plans. The bottom line is that they are sticking to the guidance and local planning policies. We have the toughest planning regime in the European Union and it has been toughened twice since the introduction of PPG 6.

Equally untrue is the criticism that supermarkets have created food deserts. In most of these areas the problems of exclusion pre-date the growth in the expansion of supermarkets in the 80s and early 90s. Many estates were built without access to services into consideration, whether that be a doctor's surgery, dentist or retailer.

Retailers are not the cause of social exclusion, but can be part of the solution. Supermarkets do, where they can, work with small local suppliers. But these suppliers need to adhere to all legislation; the quality has to be first-class and production has to be adequate for the stores' needs. In many parts of the country, supermarkets provide shelf space for products supplied by regional food groups.

Finally, consumers can shop locally - but they also have the option of shopping by car, especially when doing the weekly shop. The growth of large supermarkets is not going unchecked. But the bottom line is: consumers are in control. They are demanding a wider range of products and services than ever before. If that is what they want that is what they will get!

William Moyes

Dear William,

I am not arguing that we should try to reverse the growth of supermarkets. Like many others I want to ensure that this continued growth is not to the irreversible detriment of the local community. Current retailing policy is driven largely by the multiples. We have no overall strategy for agriculture and retailing, though the two are interdependent.

Despite the abundance, choice and convenience of the supermarket, local food marketing is one of the fastest growing movements in retailing, as we see from the rapid expansion of farmers markets (0 to 250 in three years). Retailing in the 21st century must provide the consumer with the choice to shop outside the supermarket. The local food economy is sustainable, it reduces food miles, lessens car use and it underpins neighbourhood renewal in both urban and rural areas. We need to support local communities by ensuring the survival of local retailing but without depriving consumers of the benefits of out-of-town shopping.

It is not about one or the other but a third way, and we must address it together - government, consumers, producers and retailers, large and small.

Caroline Cranbrook

British Retail Consortium
Council for the protection of Rural England

fields.headline: Crowds celebrate Queen Mother's century
fields.standfirst:
Blair's birthday tribute to Queen Mother

What the world's papers said about the Queen Mother's 100th birthday
fields.trailText: Thousands of well-wishers cheered the Queen Mother today as she celebrated her 100th birthday today with other members of the royal family.
fields.body:
Thousands of well-wishers cheered the Queen Mother today as she celebrated her 100th birthday today with other members of the royal family.

With a wave and a familiar smile, the royal family's first centenarian took the nation's salute from the famous balcony of Buckingham Palace.

Earlier, she received a birthday card from her daughter the Queen, who signed the personal greeting "Lilibet" - her childhood name.

The Queen Mother asked her equerry, Irish Guards Captain William de Rouet, to open the envelope with his sword.

An estimated 40,000 well-wishers packed The Mall from Clarence House, the Queen Mother's London residence, to Buckingham Palace, to see the royal centenarian ride in an open carriage with her eldest grandson, the Prince of Wales.

She rode in an Ascot landau, decorated in her racing colours with garlands of gold and blue flowers, and pulled by four greys. A 41-gun royal salute was fired from nearby Green Park, earlier than expected, as the horse-drawn carriage entered the palace forecourt.

People sang Happy Birthday To You, cheered, and waved flags and banners as the Queen Mother stepped out on to the palace balcony.

The band of the Coldstream Guards played Happy Birthday To You and then one of the Queen Mother's favourite songs, Congratulations.

The Queen Mother moved her hands and arms to the rhythm of the music as the band struck up the 60s Cliff Richard hit.

She took the nation's salute - every wave met by a loud cheer - with her two daughters, the Queen and Princess Margaret, who were soon joined by the rest of the royal family.

Prince William, 18, and stood chatting to his father, the Prince of Wales, with his younger brother, Prince Harry, 15, nearby.

All senior royals celebrated with the Queen Mother at a private family lunch amid the splendour of the Bow Room at the palace.

Tonight, the Queen Mother was expected to go to the ballet with the Queen and Princess Margaret at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, central London.

Along the Mall there was a visible police presence after fears that renegade republican terrorists may disrupt the day, but most well-wishers were oblivious to the security arrangements as they strained for a glimpse of the royal carriage.

Among the crowd was Connie Missinger, a 47-year-old librarian from St Louis, Missouri. She said: "I came here especially for the birthday. I came here last year and had such a wonderful time that I thought I would love to come again. She is a very special person and has seen everything."

The carriage passed through the gates of Buckingham Palace to the strains of the national anthem. Many well-wishers who had been standing in The Mall began converging on the palace once the carriage had passed.

fields.standfirst:
Royal centenarian delights admiring crowds

Blair's birthday tribute to Queen Mother
fields.trailText: As the celebrations suggest, the "Queen Mum" is a revered figure for millions of Britons, particularly those old enough to remember the stalwart, stiff-upper-lip posture she and her husband, King George VI, demonstrated during the horrendous Nazi blitz of 1940 and 1941... Yet the reaction to this 100th birthday has been surprisingly mixed, with many taking the occasion to denounce the Queen Mother, her family and the whole concept of inherited monarchy She maintains a full time staff of 50 and regularly exceeds her million-dollar-a-year government allowance but manages to make people smile indulgently about it... In 100 years, she has never been known to wash a dish, make a bed or draw a curtain.
fields.body:
As the celebrations suggest, the "Queen Mum" is a revered figure for millions of Britons, particularly those old enough to remember the stalwart, stiff-upper-lip posture she and her husband, King George VI, demonstrated during the horrendous Nazi blitz of 1940 and 1941... Yet the reaction to this 100th birthday has been surprisingly mixed, with many taking the occasion to denounce the Queen Mother, her family and the whole concept of inherited monarchy She maintains a full time staff of 50 and regularly exceeds her million-dollar-a-year government allowance but manages to make people smile indulgently about it... In 100 years, she has never been known to wash a dish, make a bed or draw a curtain.

The Washington Post

She is Britain's hottest cover girl at the moment. It is virtually impossible to avoid the Queen Mother. She celebrates her 100th birthday today, but anybody would be forgiven for assuming her birthday passed a month ago, such as been the fervour surrounding the occasion... For years, the Queen Mum, as many affectionately call her, has been the only royal to avoid criticism. Partly due to age, no doubt. The author Alan Bennett once wrote that anyone who can still crack open an egg at the age of 80 is automatically sanctified. But now, some commentators are suggesting that she isn't quite the avuncular figure she appears.

The Irish Independent

What is the elixir which has given her such long life? She says: "If you ignore illnesses, they go away." Because she has never felt herself to be old, not even aged 97, when, visiting Cheltenham racecourse after an operation, she saw a group of pensioners and declared: "Let me say hello to those elderly people."

Corriere della Sera

One aspect of flirting with the Queen Mum is that one can share a joke with her about her longevity. Despite this, the memorial industry is running on full steam. Queen Mum figurines, china plates with her seal, special issue stamps, memorial coins, special editions of newspapers, new biographies. No royal event since the marriage of Charles and Di in 1981 has caused such a commercial whirlwind as this birthday.

Die Welt

Of the 602 mentions she has already received this week in the British press, next to none of the thousands of words were actually delivered by her. Even when London two weeks ago turned on an extraordinary pageant in her honour, the most revered member of the royal family spoke little... Despite the fact that she and her husband had essentially supported prime minister Neville Chamberlain's attempts to appease Hitler, her wartime resolve endeared her to millions. This, according to writer Anthony Holden, was why Britons chose to overlook her conspicuous human failings - her "stubbornly cruel treatment" of Edward VIII's lover, Wallis Simpson, whom she refused to receive even after Edward's death; "her wilful burial of her head in the sand during the domestic dramas of her own dysfunctional family; her key role in the casting of the Charles-Diana soap opera which brought the institution of monarchy to its knees".

The Melbourne Age

webTitle: Spurs offer refund to disgruntled fans

fields.headline: Spurs offer refund to disgruntled fans
fields.trailText: In an unprecedented move, Tottenham Hotspur have offered fans distressed at the sale of David Ginola to Aston Villa a full refund on their season tickets. The decision was announced this morning after a number of complaints posted by fans on the official Spurs website.
fields.body:
In an unprecedented move, Tottenham Hotspur have offered fans distressed at the sale of David Ginola to Aston Villa a full refund on their season tickets. The decision was announced this morning after a number of complaints posted by fans on the official Spurs website.

A club statement, posted on the site (www.spurs.co.uk) read: "Quotes from fans stating they would not have bought a season ticket if they knew David Ginola was going have highlighted to the board a genuine possibility that this scenario may exist.

"Any fan wishing to return their season ticket may do so by August 15, whereby a full refund will be given. The club would not like to feel that any of its fans have been misled."

Spurs' offer is believed to be the first of its kind in English football. Comings and goings are part and parcel of the modern game, but Ginola was so popular amongst White Hart Lane regulars, and relations between fans and chairman Alan Sugar so strained, that the situation appears to have required special treatment.

Today's developments come after club captain Sol Campbell told the club they must spend the money garnered by Ginola's sale on fresh talent. "We've sold a few players and we've got a bit more money now," Campbell said earlier. "So we'll see what we do with it.

"Tottenham are a massive club. A lot of people have got to start waking up and realising this club has so much history and the fans are so passionate. If everyone gets on the same wavelength, we can do something."

fields.headline: Little witches
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the pint-sized devils who want to be witches
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the pint-sized devils who want to be witches
fields.body:
1. The Pagan Federation has reported a surge of interest from youngsters keen to become witches.

2. Their interest, it seems, is being sparked by popular telly programmes like Buffy the Vampire Slayer and the lobotomised Sabrina the Teenage Witch.

3. Another inspiration is that young literary hound of hell Harry Potter, the adolescent wizard with the almost preternatural gift of making his author, JK Rowling, and her publisher, Bloomsbury Books, very very happy - and extremely rich.

4. Paganism, as explained by the federation, doesn't sound half as exciting as the would-be kiddiewitches probably think.

5. Its various branches, like Wicca, Druidry and Shamanism, have nothing to do with devil worship or evil spells.

6. But they do seem to spend a fair amount of time in pubs. And they dance a lot, especially in Abbots Bromley.

7. In spite of their herbivorous nature, the pagans do have a knack of getting up Christian noses. The federation's first youth officer, schoolteacher Ralph Morse, was suspended after he gave a couple of interviews. He was later reinstated.

8. The new surge of interest by children has disturbed John Buckridge, editor of the Christian monthly magazine Youthwork. He says that an interest in magic as harmless fun could lead to dangerous dabbling with the occult.

9. What he didn't add, is that it could make dangerous inroads on parental pockets, via the Sabrina, Buffy and Potter industries.

10. The new surge of inquiries by children won't do the federation much good. It doesn't accept under-18s. In fact, it doesn't seek converts. And you have to want, really really want to be a witch before you have any chance of being initiated.

webTitle: Blair's birthday tribute to Queen Mother

fields.headline: Blair's birthday tribute to Queen Mother
fields.standfirst: Queen Mother delights cheering crowds on 100th birthday
fields.trailText: The prime minister today joined in the tributes to the Queen Mother.
fields.body:
The prime minister today joined in the tributes to the Queen Mother.

In a taped broadcast, Tony Blair said: "The Queen Mother is, of course, enormously admired by everybody in Britain and right round the world. But I think what really marks her out is this extraordinary sense of duty, this sense of obligation to others which she has.

"When I went along a few days ago with the other political leaders to give our thanks on behalf of parliament, in her reply what came across was this immense understanding, not just of the country's history and traditions, but also this dedication and commitment and service to others.

"So we are not just honouring the birthday of a special person in terms of loyalty, we are also honouring somebody who has been a great example to us all of service.

"So a very, very happy birthday and very many happy returns."

fields.headline: Casting news
fields.trailText: Jeremy Irons joins forces with Forest Whitaker for terrorist attack thriller, Helen Hunt gets the Woody Allen treatment, Matthew McConaughey gets out of the water for Bill Paxton directorial debut, and Edward Norton reteams with the director who made him a star
fields.body:
 Jeremy Irons (pictured) and Forest Whitaker will co-star in The Fourth Angel, a British thriller that John Irvin is set to direct. Angel tells the story of a man (Irons) whose life is turned upside down when his wife and daughter are gunned down in a terrorist attack. As he seeks justice for his family, he comes into conflict with an FBI agent (Whitaker). Charlotte Rampling, Elizabeth McGovern and Jason Priestley are to lend support.

 Helen Hunt, who won an Oscar for As Good as it Gets, looks set to star with Woody Allen in his next project, which begins filming in New York this September for DreamWorks. Sources say Hunt and Allen are the central characters. The film is the first of a three-picture deal Allen recently made with DreamWorks, which will distribute domestically. Charlize Theron will have a minor role.

 Bill Paxton and Matthew McConaughey, who starred together in second world war drama U-571, could be reteaming for Paxton's directorial debut. McConaughey is in discussions to star in the psychological horror-thriller Frailty, described as Seven meets The Shining.

 Fight Club star Edward Norton will team up again with Gregory Hoblit, the director who first catapulted him to international fame. Norton won an Oscar nomination for his role in 1996's Primal Fear, and he has committed to work with Hoblit again in an adaptation of second world war novel Hart's War.

fields.headline: Ma'am before the storm
fields.standfirst: Royal special: a crazy collection, a quiet town crier, a clock fit for a king and  her Majesty's secret service
fields.trailText: Royal special: a crazy collection, a quiet town crier, a clock fit for a king and her Majesty's secret service
fields.body:
Will Ilkley bar more tat?

A life-size model of a Beefeater was expected to steal the show in a special Ilkley exhibition to commemorate the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.

Judith Watkinson was showing off part of her 4,000-strong collection of royal memorabilia at the Riverview nursing home, including replica crown jewels, tins, pictures - and a 20-year-old Christmas pudding from Sandringham.

Mrs Watkinson said: "I originally went into this shop to buy a coffee table. They didn't have it but there was this beautiful picture of the Queen and we bought that instead. That is what started it off.

"People say I am potty but I do not see why it is any different from collecting beer-mats."

Visitors were asked to make a donation to the Alzheimer's Society.
Wharfedale Observer

6 O'Clock, and all's not well
Swindon town crier Fred Ferris was forced to pull out of today's celebrations because he was losing his voice.

"You can't be a town crier with a croaky throat," he said. "It's fair to say I'm feeling a little bit becalmed because I'm missing it."

Mr Ferris started feeling under the weather on Wednesday and is now worried that the symptoms are similar to those he suffered when he had tonsillitis a number of years ago.
Swindon Evening Advertiser

Just in time
A Hinckley man has almost completed work on a royal clock he has been building for the past 18 years and which plays the national anthem.

Arthur Tomlin started his six-feet tall clock in the week that Prince William was born, intending to present it to the Prince and Princess of Wales. The clock face boasts a painting of Caernarfon Castle with Charles's coat of arms on one side and Diana's on the other.

Mr Tomlin earlier made wrought-iron gates to mark the Queen's silver jubilee in 1977.

"I knew nothing about clocks when I started - but I do now," he said. "It has been a lot of trial and a lot of error."

Mr Tomlin, 73, announced no plans for today's celebration.
Hinckley Times

The name's Liz - Queen Liz
Not only did the Queen Mother brave the Blitz in the second world war, but she may have been a teenage spycatcher in Felixstowe during the first one.

The East Anglian Daily press reports on a story that the young Elizabeth was hiding in bushes in a suburban garden eavesdropping on neighbours when she heard them talking about classified information. Alerting the authorities, the dentist next door was arrested for spying.

Unfortunately, "little more is known of the details of the story", the paper reports, and "the house's exact location is not known". Neither is the nationality of the dentist, though it is believed there was "a dentist with an Austrian-Germanic name in the town at the time".

Felixstowe historian and lecturer Doreen Rayner said: "A lot of things happened in war-time which went unrecorded."

"I wouldn't say that this incident didn't happen, but we just don't know the sources for it."
East Anglian Daily Times

Letter of the week
As a professional cat groomer, I feel the advice given by Hannah Sutcliffe in Pet Advice (Argus, July 29) is incorrect. An experienced groomer has no problem dealing with matted cats of any temperament without resorting to a life-threatening sedation or shaving.
J Bath, Hatherleigh Close, Bognor Regis
Worthing Evening Argus

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Snatch official website is launched, New York says no to David Lynch's art project, Kevin Smith gets the last word, and Whowantstobeamoviestar.com has the last laugh
fields.body:
 The official website for Guy Ritchie's Snatch has been launched. You can find it at www.snatch-themovie.com. The movie will be released on September 1.

 David Lynch's (pictured) entry for a public art show in New York has been sent back without going on display because it was deemed too gruesome for the public. The director created a sculpture for Cowparade NYC 2000, which features several hundred fibreglass cows decorated by artists and schoolchildren and displayed on sidewalks around the city. Lynch's bovine contribution was a headless cow with forks and knives stuck in its back. He also covered parts of the unfortunate animal with a reddish, blood-like substance. City Parks Commissioner Henry J Stern said: "I thought it was Charles Manson... David Lynch should stick to his day job, making movies." Lynch however admitted to disappointment on his piece's exclusion from the show. "Don't you think when people tell you you're allowed to do whatever you want as long as it's not sexually X-rated that they should stand behind their word and show your cow?" he said.

 Directors may dream of having the last word over their critics but few actually get to do so. Inside.com reports that director Kevin Smith, at a Comic-Con International panel discussion last weekend, was about to answer a question from FilmThreat critic Ron Wells, who'd been less than kind about Smith's Dogma. "Wait a minute, you're Ron Wells?" Smith asked of Wells, who was wearing a white tanktop and sported spiked blond hair. "Now I don't feel so fucking bad that you trashed my movie. As a matter of fact, now that I get an eyeful of you, I actually feel pretty fucking good that you didn't like it."

 Despite charges of illegality, and an investigation by the Californian Labor Commission (see our news story), the site that allows you to bid for movie roles Whowantstobeamoviestar.com is having the last laugh. With the auctions coming to a close this week (only the lead actor role remains to be bought), the site has already raised more than $200,000, and has had more than 1,500 bids. The film has yet to have a title, let alone a script.

fields.headline: The week on the net
fields.trailText: You're a sporting superstar who, despite being acquitted of murdering your ex-wife and her friend, still has the weight of public suspicion hanging over you. What do you do? Agree to partake in a question-and-answer session on the net that charges punters $9.95 a time to view your answers. That will win them over, surely? Of course, this is exactly what OJ Simpson did last Thursday on the AskOJ.com site. Entertainment Network, the company that set up the site, insists all the proceeds are going to charity. (Remember, Simpson owes $33.5m in damages following a separate civil case.) The company's eagerness to state its stance on the issue did not end there: the website includes a hefty footnote announcing its neutrality and the $100,000 reward it is offering for information leading to arrest of the murderer(s). The question session itself, however, hardly seemed worth the fee. During the questioning, Simpson "opened up", saying that he still misses his ex-wife Nicole, adding: "I get angry with the people she was hanging around with who contributed to this ... These were her party friends. So, yes, I do think partially her lifestyle contributed to it."

Agree to partake in a question-and-answer session on the net that charges punters $9.95 a time to view your answers. That will win them over, surely? Of course, this is exactly what OJ Simpson did last Thursday on the AskOJ.com site. Entertainment Network, the company that set up the site, insists all the proceeds are going to charity. (Remember, Simpson owes $33.5m in damages following a separate civil case.) The company's eagerness to state its stance on the issue did not end there: the website includes a hefty footnote announcing its neutrality and the $100,000 reward it is offering for information leading to arrest of the murderer(s). The question session itself, however, hardly seemed worth the fee. During the questioning, Simpson "opened up", saying that he still misses his ex-wife Nicole, adding: "I get angry with the people she was hanging around with who contributed to this ... These were her party friends. So, yes, I do think partially her lifestyle contributed to it."

Another celebrity keen to make his mark on the internet is Sting. Trouble is, someone else has already encamped themselves at sting.com - where they've been for the past eight years as it happens. Sting, as is customary with aggrieved pop stars, called in the lawyers. But in a rare victory for the seemingly little guy (see Napster's tussle with the music industry), arbitrators in the US ruled last week that Sting could not stop the domain name being used by someone else as Sting is not his real name, nor is it a trademark and it's a common word. There was much rejoicing at a forum especially set up at Sting.com following the ruling. "Who do these celebrities think they are that they should just get whatever they want just because they want it?" wrote "Rob14224".

And still they fall. Boo.com has already gone, ClickMango.com, the natural health e-tailer, announced this week that it is to close and news reached us, too, that Inspop.com, an insurance site, had probably wasted about £5m on advertising before its site was even ready for customers. Its Terminator spoof advertisement - "Renewal Day" - had been airing for two weeks on national TV but a technical fault, which meant the site could not talk to the insurance companies for whom it was selling, made the whole campaign look a bit useless. The company denied that a large chunk of its venture capital had gone up in smoke: "We've had an immense number of hits and we're developing name awareness." They have had an immense hit, all right.

webTitle: Income tax and capital gains tax

fields.headline: Income tax and capital gains tax
fields.trailText: Married couples may be able to juggle their finances if one of them falls into the higher tax-paying bracket or reaches the capital gains limit.
fields.body:
Married couples may be able to juggle their finances if one of them falls into the higher tax-paying bracket or reaches the capital gains limit.

This can be done by sharing bank accounts and putting assets into a partner's name.

But gay and lesbian couples do not have this opportunity as their union is not recognised in the eyes of the law.

They may be able to come to an agreement on how they can share assets, but should chat with a tax specialist or financial adviser for a structured plan.

The limit where the higher rate 40% kicks in is £35,115, taking the personal tax allowance of £4,615 into account.

Capital gains tax is payable after earnings of more than £7,900 in a single financial year.

fields.headline: Hollywood gets into Shaggs
fields.trailText: Hollywood is to remake the story of possibly the worst pop group ever. The three Wiggin sisters, who made up The Shaggs, released one critically panned album in 1970, and as quickly faded from public view
fields.body:
As we reported last week (see our feature), Hollywood is to remake the story of possibly the worst pop group ever. The three Wiggin sisters, who made up The Shaggs, released one critically panned album in 1970, and as quickly faded from public view.

Artisan Entertainment has acquired the band members' life rights as a basis for a feature film. Katherine Dieckmann will write and direct the curiously of-the-moment musical birth and fall of Dot, Betty and Helen Wiggin, who - bereft of ambition or talent - embarked on writing and performing songs one can only call cult.

Dieckmann, a former reporter who directed R.E.M.'s Stand video, just completed her first feature film, A Good Baby, starring Henry Thomas. The Shaggs is looking to shoot in early 2001. There is however no word yet on a Shaggs revival tour.

fields.headline: Boksic finally completes £2.5m Boro deal
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough have applied for a work permit for Croatian striker Alen Boksic after the player finally agreed a £2.5m transfer from Lazio.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough have applied for a work permit for Croatian striker Alen Boksic after the player finally agreed a £2.5m transfer from Lazio.

Boksic, 30, has passed a medical and agreed personal terms, and are now awaiting permission from the Department for Education and Employment to ply his trade in the Premiership.

Boro are hoping for a swift decision from the department, although the deal may be complicated by the striker's lack of international football in recent years because of injury.

However, manager Bryan Robson was delighted to have clinched his third signing in a week after spending £5m on Coventry's Noel Whelan and Lens striker Joseph-Desire Job.

"I'm delighted Alen wants to join Middlesbrough," he said. "At his best, I rate him one of the best strikers in Europe. However, we must now wait for a decision from the Department for Education and Employment. Given his considerable standing in world football, we're hopeful that we will be given the green light to bring him to Teesside."

Even if Boro's initial application were turned down on the grounds that Boksic does not meet the criteria of playing in a substantial proportion of Croatia's internationals in the last two years, they could appeal, arguing that his reputation leaves no doubt as to his quality as a player. The Teessiders were successful in a similar appeal last season when Juninho returned to the club on loan from Spanish side Atletico Madrid.

Boksic began his career at Hadjuk Split and had a spell in France with Cannes and Marseille, where he won a European Cup winners' medal, before heading for Italy.

He joined Lazio in November 1993, and apart from a season with Juventus in 1996-97, he has been there ever since.

However, injuries have interrupted his career and he started just 15 games last season, the last in April when he was replaced at half-time in a 2-0 away win at Piacenza.

The arrivals of big-money signings Hernan Crespo and Claudio Lopez over the summer further reduced his chances of regular starts.

webTitle: US acclaim for forgotten Brit flick

fields.headline: US acclaim for forgotten Brit flick
fields.trailText: The British film Croupier, which made no impact domestically, has been hailed as 'the sleeper hit of the summer' on its US release
fields.body:
On its UK release a year ago, the low-budget British film Croupier attracted satisfactory reviews, but made almost no impact at the domestic box office.

"It has style and atmosphere, but I longed for a leaner, tighter script," wrote The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw.

And the film was forgotten as quickly as it was taken out of cinemas. Until now that is. Get Carter director Mike Hodges's film played to the arthouse circuit in America briefly last year, and was subsequently released in a small number of cinemas.

USA Today newspaper has called Croupier "the sleeper hit of the summer", the Washington Post termed it "a lean, smart film that pokes at you with quintessentially English disdain and sarcasm". The movie has taken £2m to date in the US.

Furthermore its 35-year-old star Clive Owen, is being tipped as a hopeful for next year's Oscars. The Hollywood Reporter hailed his "intense and minimalist performance", and Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times compares his acting style to Sean Connery.

The film also features Alex Kingston (from ER) and Gina McKee in a story about a struggling writer (Owen) who works in a casino to come up with some inspiration.

webTitle: Fashion world set alight. Controversial collection inspired by burns care

fields.headline: Fashion world set alight. Controversial collection inspired by burns care
fields.trailText: An English designer has created yet another fashion sensation with garments intended to resemble the effects of burns on human skin.
fields.body:
An English designer has created yet another fashion sensation with garments intended to resemble the effects of burns on human skin.

Narrinder Sandhu, 36, conceived the idea after looking at slides of burns victims. Yesterday he denied courting controversy, "It is a celebration of how far technology and how far the medical profession have progressed," he claimed. "It's a very positive act, and I wanted to translate this into clothes."

Sandhu formerly designed for Jasper Conran, John Rocha and Betty Jackson. He described his flowing dresses, trousers, vests and shirts, singed and ripped to resemble burnt skin, as "very pretty and feminine".

The collection, his first, will be shown next month in Paris fashion week. It also has clothes inspired by the double helix of the DNA molecule, delicately embroidered with DNA-like patterns.

His next collection will refer to architecture and science. "Fashion tends to be reticent to look at areas which fashion people don't come across, such as the medical or science professions," he said. "It looks at past decades, the 1980s or 1940s, and so disappears up its backside. But look at the way people like Damien Hirst have pushed the borders of art."

Keith Judkins, director of burns care at Pinderfields hospital in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, disagreed with the term celebration.

"It sounds gruesome. It is exploiting someone's misfortune, and there is no celebration of technology in that." Needless to say, he thought recent patients might find the burns clothes "difficult to handle psychologically".

fields.headline: 1940s fashion
fields.trailText: The cinched-in waist, the angular protruding hips, the fitted, long skirt: when most of us think of fashion from the 1940s, it is this overly structured, almost parodic depiction of the female form that comes to mind. However, this silhouette did not make its appearance until the latter half of the decade, in 1947.
fields.body:
The cinched-in waist, the angular protruding hips, the fitted, long skirt: when most of us think of fashion from the 1940s, it is this overly structured, almost parodic depiction of the female form that comes to mind. However, this silhouette did not make its appearance until the latter half of the decade, in 1947.

At Christian Dior's first collection, the audience, clad in their austere, practical, postwar outfits, were confronted with these wholly original body-structuring outfits. After the dowdiness of 1930s clothes, necessitated by the financially crippling recent wars, such celebrations of femininity were both shocking and enthralling. Harper's Bazaar editor Carmel Snow dubbed the collection the New Look and Dior's fame was instantly established.

Another important player on the 40s fashion scene was Rene Gruau, whose illustrations of haute couture during this decade helped to shape the still-strong perception of the glamour of 40s fashion. Gruau, one of the last great fashion magazine illustrators before fashion photographers stepped in to dominate the field, used strong outlines to emphasise a woman's shape. The influence of Toulouse-Lautrec contributed a decidedly decadent feel to the posters - a welcome sight after the austerity of the past few decades.

So if the New Look was born of a desire for a return to femininity and luxury, it is not so surprising that designers today are harking back to that decade. We are at last fed up with that unisex look - all baggy combats and hooded tops - and delicate luxury (think Fendi and Prada) is again a desirable look.

At this year's autumn/winter 2000 collections, Michael Kors, Marc Jacobs, Galliano and Prada all paid their respects to the past with belted jackets, slim-fitting skirt suits, tweeds, tailored coats and fur collars, all accessorised with either ladylike hand-held structured bags, or demure peep-hole pumps. Kors even threw some fedora hats and large pearls into the mix, for heaven's sake!

Yes, the 40s are very much in fashion and, thanks to their emphasis on grown-up elegance, this is one trend that allows you to look both fashionable and stylish. And unlike the other current fashion favourite decade, the 80s, the 40s look can be done subtly - a clutchbag here, a curvy pump there, and you've got the look without looking too much of a blast from the past.

But it is, aptly, Dior's designer Galliano who most clearly utilises the lessons from the 40s. Unlike other designers, Galliano does not simply mimic the exact items of clothing from the past but rather expands on the experimentations of his predecessors. Besides their notoriously outré elements, Galliano's clothes for Dior employ deconstructed corsets and pleated trains, which both emphasise and distort the female figure, creating a modernised, exciting version of the New Look for a new generation.

fields.headline: Caine gets surprise package
fields.trailText: Developers in Newcastle are to send Michael Caine a lump of concrete from a Tyneside car-park, the 'Get Carter car park', which is to be demolished
fields.body:
Sir Michael Caine will soon receive a bizarre movie memento. A large package is being sent to the Oscar-winning actor - a lump of concrete from a Tyneside car-park where the actor had one of his early movie successes.

The package will come from developers who are planning to demolish a car park in Gateshead in the north of England. The town centre multi-storey car park was used in a key scene in Caine's cult gangster movie Get Carter (currently being remade with Sylvester Stallone) and is now known as Carter Car Park, but now local politicians plan to destroy the site as part of an extensive rebuilding program - despite protests from fans of the film.

A spokesman for Gateshead Town Centre Regeneration, Tony Danaher, said, "Get Carter was a great movie and there is a lot of affection for that car park. We know what a key movie that was for [Caine], so we're planning to send him a lump of the concrete. We're still looking at the possibility of inviting him along on the destruction day."

The spot has even become a tourist attraction - the Get Carter Appreciation Society meet there regularly, and it's featured in books on famous film locations. Despite fans' protests, the council is planning to continue with the car park's demolition.

fields.headline: Search Engine
fields.trailText: The banks may have retreated over cash machine charges but they are still well dug in when it comes to the millions of pounds gleaned from accidental overcharging of fees. Step forward, then, www.checkyourbank.com, a sort of "people power" page run by chartered accountants that (funnily enough) checks for signs of bank overcharging. All you have to do is gather your bank statements and paying-in books for the period concerned, work out the start and end date of the charging period, identify overdraft limits, interest rates used and any special tariffs agreed with your bank, register and punch in the details, and let these vigilante accountants work out the figures. The service is free until you need a detailed rundown of any overcharging with which to confront the banks. The cost? £12.50.

Clearly signposted in motorway blue, www.5minutesaway.com offers visitors 1,500 alternative stops (soon to rise to 4,000) - such as petrol stations, shops, restaurants, pubs and leisure services - that all lie within five minutes or three miles of major junctions. Just tap in the junction number and service you desire and, hey presto, the turn-off becomes a turn-on.

Continuing the spirit of choice and openness is www.opendiary.com ("the first interactive diary community on the internet"). If you want to find out what teenage American FrostyPolarBear did yesterday or why the Paranoid Android is dealing with the role of male cleaners in modern-day society, then this website is for you. To separate the wheat from the chat, tap into the Readers' Choice Top 50 for the best diaries. Samuel Pepys eat your heart out.

fields.headline: Stop 'name and shame' says minister
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: A Home Office minister has called on the News of the World to stop its naming and shaming campaign against paedophiles
fields.body:
A Home Office minister has called on the News of the World to stop its naming and shaming campaign against paedophiles

The call by minister Mike O'Brien came after a rampaging mob targeted a sex offender who was "named and shamed" as a paedophile by the campaign.

Police last night dispersed a mob of up to 200 people who went on the rampage outside the home of Victor Burnett, 53.

And today police are protecting an elderly man after he became the second innocent victim of a hate-mail campaign wrongly identifying someone as a paedophile who had been named in the News of the World.

Victor Terry, 78, was targeted by an organisation calling itself Antimatter, which had confused him with a paedophile of the same name. Letters giving his name and address and warning people with children to be on their guard were sent to about 300 households near his home in Croydon, south London.

"I think the paper needs to listen to the police, who are asking it not to continue," said Mr O'Brien.

Meanwhile, the newspaper condemned the mob, saying "unlawful vigilante action" was "wholly unacceptable", but added that it stood by its "clear objective" to protect children.

A spokesman for the Sunday newspaper said: "Throughout the 'For Sarah' campaign, the News of the World has repeatedly stressed that unlawful vigilante action is wholly unacceptable

"The clear objective of the News of the World's 'For Sarah' campaign, which is attracting massive public support, is to bring about the implementation of legislation for the protection of children."

The News of the World had named the former taxi driver and reported that he had abused more than 140 children. The incident last night left one police officer with a suspected broken nose and needing stitches after he was hit in the face by a rock thrown by one of the protesters in Paulsgrove, Portsmouth.

Rioters also hurled bricks and stones, smashed windows then overturned and torched a Lada car, thought to belong to Burnett's sister.

During the violent disturbance, local people carried enlarged versions of the picture of Burnett which appeared in the News of the World. Residents said organisers had co-ordinated 200 people with mobile phones and text messages, arranging to meet outside his house at 8pm. Windows were smashed at his flat, which is said to have been ransacked, and also at the Portsmouth City Council housing office across the road, in Allaway Avenue.

The council office was targeted because Burnett was allowed back to the flat, which is near a primary school, residents said.

It was said Burnett was moved out on Sunday but returned on Wednesday after the flat was fitted with a panic button and other security measures. But police confirmed he was again evacuated at 7pm yesterday before the violence started.

One woman, who asked not to be named, said: "He's been here for two years among children and we didn't know until the News of the World. "At first I supported the protest but it got too scary and involved too many people. It was out of control."

The area was peaceful again today, but police were maintaining a presence. But residents warned that other paedophiles in the area would be targeted and said organisers had threatened to return to burn down the housing office, which is surrounded by residential flats.

"We have seen innocent people being harassed," said Mr O'Brien. "I understand the concerns of other parents, but we need to manage the risk, and the police and the authorities are best to do that. "They have got to consider very carefully where they put ex-offenders," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"We have 110,000 ex-sex offenders on our streets today. "If we start identifying them it is quite likely some of them will go underground and it will be much more difficult to prevent their re-offending." However, Portsmouth North Labour MP Sydney Rapson said he could understand the rioters' motive. "We are living in a council estate and the housing authorities can bring these people to council housing and we have to put up with them," he told the same programme.

"They (paedophiles) certainly shouldn't be in areas where there is a large concentration of children." There was always a "potential danger" from paedophiles, whether or not they have served their time, and this was "a real problem", he said.

Hampshire Police spokesman Richard Horobin said no arrests were made following last night's disturbance and confirmed that Victor Burnett had left the area.

The demonstration appeared to have been prompted by the News of the World campaign, he said, adding that it was "very unhelpful". He said: "Innocent members of the public have been affected by this."

On Wednesday, Michael Horgan, 55, became the innocent victim of the Antimatter group after it sent 500 letters to his neighbours.

Police are leafleting neighbours to make it clear that both Mr Horgan and Mr Terry are the victims of mistaken identity. Detective Inspector Colin Bush of Croydon CID said: "The law of the land is that the police deal with these issues, not members of the public."
fields.bodyText: A Home Office minister has called on the News of the World to stop its naming and shaming campaign against paedophiles The call by minister Mike O'Brien came after a rampaging mob targeted a sex offender who was "named and shamed" as a paedophile by the campaign. Police last night dispersed a mob of up to 200 people who went on the rampage outside the home of Victor Burnett, 53. And today police are protecting an elderly man after he became the second innocent victim of a hate-mail campaign wrongly identifying someone as a paedophile who had been named in the News of the World. Victor Terry, 78, was targeted by an organisation calling itself Antimatter, which had confused him with a paedophile of the same name. Letters giving his name and address and warning people with children to be on their guard were sent to about 300 households near his home in Croydon, south London. "I think the paper needs to listen to the police, who are asking it not to continue," said Mr O'Brien. Meanwhile, the newspaper condemned the mob, saying "unlawful vigilante action" was "wholly unacceptable", but added that it stood by its "clear objective" to protect children. A spokesman for the Sunday newspaper said: "Throughout the 'For Sarah' campaign, the News of the World has repeatedly stressed that unlawful vigilante action is wholly unacceptable "The clear objective of the News of the World's 'For Sarah' campaign, which is attracting massive public support, is to bring about the implementation of legislation for the protection of children." The News of the World had named the former taxi driver and reported that he had abused more than 140 children. The incident last night left one police officer with a suspected broken nose and needing stitches after he was hit in the face by a rock thrown by one of the protesters in Paulsgrove, Portsmouth. Rioters also hurled bricks and stones, smashed windows then overturned and torched a Lada car, thought to belong to Burnett's sister. During the violent disturbance, local people carried enlarged versions of the picture of Burnett which appeared in the News of the World. Residents said organisers had co-ordinated 200 people with mobile phones and text messages, arranging to meet outside his house at 8pm. Windows were smashed at his flat, which is said to have been ransacked, and also at the Portsmouth City Council housing office across the road, in Allaway Avenue. The council office was targeted because Burnett was allowed back to the flat, which is near a primary school, residents said. It was said Burnett was moved out on Sunday but returned on Wednesday after the flat was fitted with a panic button and other security measures. But police confirmed he was again evacuated at 7pm yesterday before the violence started. One woman, who asked not to be named, said: "He's been here for two years among children and we didn't know until the News of the World. "At first I supported the protest but it got too scary and involved too many people. It was out of control." The area was peaceful again today, but police were maintaining a presence. But residents warned that other paedophiles in the area would be targeted and said organisers had threatened to return to burn down the housing office, which is surrounded by residential flats. "We have seen innocent people being harassed," said Mr O'Brien. "I understand the concerns of other parents, but we need to manage the risk, and the police and the authorities are best to do that. "They have got to consider very carefully where they put ex-offenders," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. "We have 110,000 ex-sex offenders on our streets today. "If we start identifying them it is quite likely some of them will go underground and it will be much more difficult to prevent their re-offending." However, Portsmouth North Labour MP Sydney Rapson said he could understand the rioters' motive. "We are living in a council estate and the housing authorities can bring these people to council housing and we have to put up with them," he told the same programme. "They (paedophiles) certainly shouldn't be in areas where there is a large concentration of children." There was always a "potential danger" from paedophiles, whether or not they have served their time, and this was "a real problem", he said. Hampshire Police spokesman Richard Horobin said no arrests were made following last night's disturbance and confirmed that Victor Burnett had left the area. The demonstration appeared to have been prompted by the News of the World campaign, he said, adding that it was "very unhelpful". He said: "Innocent members of the public have been affected by this." On Wednesday, Michael Horgan, 55, became the innocent victim of the Antimatter group after it sent 500 letters to his neighbours. Police are leafleting neighbours to make it clear that both Mr Horgan and Mr Terry are the victims of mistaken identity. Detective Inspector Colin Bush of Croydon CID said: "The law of the land is that the police deal with these issues, not members of the public."

webTitle: Concessions may be beginning of the end for Bush

fields.headline: Concessions may be beginning of the end for Bush
fields.standfirst: American presidential candidate George W Bush may have dug his own political grave by attempting to redefine the Republican party, writes Washington correspondent Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: American presidential candidate George W Bush may have dug his own political grave by attempting to redefine the Republican party, writes Washington correspondent Martin Kettle
fields.body:
The Republican national convention in Philadelphia embodied George W Bush's party strategy, and Bush's speech on the final night in turn embodied the convention.

The speech, like the convention, was a slick, impressive effort. But, like the convention, it tried to have it both ways. Another of the week's unacknowledged tributes to Bill Clinton, you might say.

Bush's speech made very bold claims indeed. His aim was nothing less than to "renew America's purpose", he said in his third sentence. It was "a time for new beginnings". The Democrats were "facing something new" - a Republican party which had redefined itself as the party of "ideas and innovation", "idealism and inclusion".

If all this sounded awfully like Bill Clinton, then that was because the speech, like the convention, was a straight lift from the Clinton playbook - but with one big exception.

In 1992 and more recently, Clinton took on his party. He challenged the Democrats to confront not just their run of defeats but the reasons why they had been defeated. He ran overtly as a different kind of Democrat, defying the party shibboleths on issues from trade to race, and forcing his party to choose between electoral failure and electoral success.

Like Clinton in 1992 and 1996, Bush offers American voters a new model of his own party, But whereas Clinton confronted the Democrats, Bush is trying to use finesse on the Republicans. He calls himself a compassionate conservative, and did so again last night, but his strategy is to be compassionate to people who value compassion and conservative to people whose priorities are conservative.

The Republican convention, which ended last night in Philadelphia, also had two very different faces. To television viewers who saw only what took place in the hall, it offered a radically new Republican face, multi-cultural, inclusive, caring and sharing. To lobbyists and corporations attending some of the nearly 500 networking and influence-peddling events that took place away from the convention centre, the convention offered an orgy of favours and special interests.

Given the extent of the political-commercial interface in evidence in Philadelphia, it would not be an exaggeration to describe the public convention as an organised lie.

That contrast was also manifest in the political messages of the convention, In the hall, all was warmth and tone. But the Republican party platform adopted at Philadelphia remains an overwhelmingly conservative document, far removed from the pragmatic and bipartisan tone of the week's speeches.

Bush's own speech could not resolve this dilemma. It contained powerful sections and potent themes, casting the Republican party as the party of all the people and Bush himself as a national conciliator. But it also contained trenchantly conservative pronouncements which no amount of spin-doctoring could disguise.

Yes, Bush offered a volley of Clintonian rhetoric about the nation being "daring and decent and ready for change". And yes, Bush's speech proclaimed the Republicans as the party of reform, not the party of repose. Yes, he also pronounced a plague on partisans of both parties, offering himself up as a man with "no stake in the bitter arguments of the last few years".

Moreover, as the speech ended and the first of 150,000 balloons began to descend to the convention floor from the rafters, Bush was joined on stage by a gallery of friends, relations and political colleagues. John McCain was there, along with Pennsylvania governor Tom Ridge and House speaker Dennis Hastert. But of Tom DeLay, Dick Armey, Dan Burton, Jesse Helms, Trent Lott and Henry Hyde there was nothing to be seen. If ever there was an opportunity to define the Republican Party afresh then here it was.

Yet the speech, like the convention itself, had two different faces. Alongside the warm words were harsh ones. Many of the biggest cheers of the evening came as Bush reiterated conservative positions which did nothing to challenge the party to change. No new gun laws. Lots of tax cuts. A commitment to sign a law banning so-called "partial birth" abortion. A fresh emphasis on religion. National missile defences whether they work or not. Not a word about big business, the international situation or the ultimate unmentionable of the week - impeachment.

Bush has skilfully put together a movement designed to place Bill Clinton firmly in his political grave. Many of his comments about Clinton were irresistibly to the point. The polls also show Bush may well win. But by offering so many concessions to the party rightwing, his speech may have contained the seeds not of Bush's victory, but of his defeat.

fields.headline: Overmars wrong-foots Arsenal
fields.trailText: The roof remained closed at the Amsterdam Arena last night where Arsenal were given the first chance to assess whether the ceiling has already fallen in on their Premiership and Champions League ambitions, writes Neil Martin .
fields.body:
The roof remained closed at the Amsterdam Arena last night where Arsenal were given the first chance to assess whether the ceiling has already fallen in on their Premiership and Champions League ambitions, writes Neil Martin .

Arsène Wenger's side had their first taste of life without Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit in the Amsterdam Tournament against, of all teams, Barcelona. The Londoners' 2-1 defeat merely reinforced that the loss of those two players to the Catalan club could be the difference between success and failure at Highbury this season.

To add to Arsenal's discomfort, Barcelona chose to play Overmars against his former employers. Petit was left on the bench rubbing shoulders with the likes of Rivaldo before replacing the Dutchman early in the second half to catcalls from the smattering of English fans.

Perhaps Arsenal were concentrating too much on giving Overmars an old-fashioned English welcome as Barcelona went ahead through Josep Guardiola's third-minute penalty before the Dutch winger had touched the ball. When he finally did, he teased Lee Dixon, above, before shooting at David Seaman.

The Gunners' Lithuanian triallist Tomas Danilevicius equalised but Philip Cocu, who has expressed an interest in playing for Arsenal, restored the lead before half-time.

Earlier the summer's biggest spenders Lazio, who bought around £71m worth of players in the close-season, left out their major new signings Hernan Crespo, who cost £36m from Parma, and Claudio Lopez, a £13m buy from Valencia.

But with a team including Dejan Stankovic, Pavel Nedved, Marcelo Salas, Sinisa Mihajlovic and Fabrizio Ravanelli, they drew 0-0 with Ajax in the opening game.
