fields.headline: Obituary: Abraham Pais
fields.standfirst: Brilliant theoretical physicist and writer who helped transform the direction of postwar research into the origins of the universe
fields.trailText: The physicist Abraham Pais, who has died aged 82, was one of a generation whose research transformed the face of science in the 1950s and 1960s, and provided a key to understanding the intimate structure of the universe. He then became an acclaimed historian and biographer.
fields.body:
The physicist Abraham Pais, who has died aged 82, was one of a generation whose research transformed the face of science in the 1950s and 1960s, and provided a key to understanding the intimate structure of the universe. He then became an acclaimed historian and biographer.

Pais probably received most plaudits for his study of the life and science of Albert Einstein, Subtle Is The Lord (1982), which remains a masterpiece among the portraits of the architect of relativity theory. He also penned the definitive biography of Niels Bohr, and subsequently turned his attention to 14 other illustrious scientists, who had appeared as the supporting cast to his previous books - men like Paul Dirac, Wolfgang Pauli, Mitchell Feigenbaum and John von Neumann.

Pais was one of the brilliant European physicists who went to the United States in the 1930s and 1940s and changed the course of American science. In his autobiography, A Tale Of Two Continents: A Physicist's Life In A Turbulent World (1997), he wrote: "People like me, who truly feel at home in several countries, are not strictly at home anywhere."

Born in Amsterdam, he was the son of Dutch Jewish schoolteachers. He later recalled a carefree childhood. At school, he was a smart, rather arrogant boy, always learning fast - especially arithmetic. He attended Amsterdam University, but showed little interest in physics until attracted by two lectures by the visiting Dutch-American physicist George Uhlenbeck, who had co-discovered spin, a crucial property of the electron.

Pais was hooked, and was able to pursue theoretical research on sub-atomic particles and fields. He obtained his PhD from the University of Utrecht on July 9 1941, just days before the Nazis banned the awarding of academic degrees to Jews. He took various teaching jobs, until forced into hiding in March 1943 after the Nazis began to deport Dutch Jews from Holland.

Helped by a non-Jewish friend, Tineke Buchter, he evaded capture until 1945, when he was arrested by the Gestapo. A close friend apprehended with him died at the hands of the Nazis, as did his sister Annie, though Pais and his parents survived.

After the war, he worked briefly with Niels Bohr at the Institute of Theoretical Physics in Copenhagen. Then, in 1946, he was recruited to the newly-created Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, by the American Nobel prizewinner Robert Oppenheimer, who had directed the Manhattan Project, which developed the first atomic bomb. In 1963, Pais moved to Rockefeller University, where he remained for the rest of his career.

In the spring of 1947, Pais was one of a group of hand-picked scientists invited to the keynote Shelter Island conference. This had been convened to examine the state of physics theory and decide on the direction of research that would restore morale and a sense of purpose to theoretical physics in the United States, which had slipped into the doldrums after the development of the atomic bomb.

The conference location was the Ram's Head Inn on Shelter Island, chosen as a relaxed country setting at a quiet spot near the Hamptons, on Long Island, thought suitable for an uninterrupted brainstorming session.

An illustrious guest list included existing, and future, Nobel prizewinners like Einstein, Hans Bethe, Enrico Fermi, Richard Feynman, Willis Lamb, Linus Pauling, Isidor Isaac Rabi, Julian Schwinger and JH Van Vleck. Other heavyweights in physics, including Oppenheimer, Edward Teller, the father of the H-bomb, Victor Weisskop and JA Wheeler, were also present.

Shelter Island was credited with providing the stimulus needed for the postwar advances in quantum field theory. It laid the foundation for the creation of Big Science, in which huge accelerators, or atom smashers, try to generate the fundamental particles that existed fleetingly at the time of the Big Bang origin of the universe.

Pais likened the state of particle physics at the time to "a symphony hall a while before the start of the concert". "On the podium," he said, "there are some, but not all, of the musicians. They are tuning up. Short brilliant passages are heard on some instruments; improvisations elsewhere; some wrong notes too. There is a sense of anticipation for the moment when the symphony starts."

The particular symphony that started with the tuning-up and improvisations in the spring of 1947 was to be called quantum electro-dynamics (QED). In 1952, Pais's own work proposed a concept called "associated production" to explain why certain particles lived for an unexpectedly long time before decaying. The particles, he suggested, were produced rapidly in pairs, but neither could decay quickly on its own. Experiments showed they existed, though for reasons that were not fully explained until later work by Murray Gell-Mann, the Nobel prizewinner who introduced the concept of a family of particles called quarks.

Pais collaborated with Gell-Mann in 1955 to suggest that what seemed to be a single particle could actually be a sort of superposition of two different particles, each with a different lifetime and decay mode. The prediction eventually led to an experiment by James Cronin and Val Fitch in 1964 that won them both a Nobel prize.

An early suggestion by Pais - that different elementary particles in nature might have an equivalent to the periodic table of chemical elements - is sometimes cited as one of the first insights of the direction that elementary particle research would take in the second half of the 20th century.

Pais is survived by his wife, his son, a stepson from a previous marriage, and a grandson.

Abraham Pais, theoretical physicist, born May 18 1918; died July 29 2000

webTitle: Fowler carried off with another leg injury

fields.headline: Fowler carried off with another leg injury
fields.trailText: There is no end to Robbie Fowler's injuries. The Liverpool captain, who underwent knee and ankle surgery last season, damaged his leg again in a game in Belfast last night when he collided with the Glentoran goalkeeper Alan Gough and was carried off after 32 minutes.
fields.body:
There is no end to Robbie Fowler's injuries. The Liverpool captain, who underwent knee and ankle surgery last season, damaged his leg again in a game in Belfast last night when he collided with the Glentoran goalkeeper Alan Gough and was carried off after 32 minutes.

Fowler started only eight games for Liverpool last season. He made it into England's Euro 2000 squad but was never called upon to play.

He opened Liverpool's scoring in the eighth minute at the Oval last night, controlling Bernard Diomède's cross, pulling away from a defender and drilling a shot into the bottom corner.

Patrik Berger, Vladimir Smicer and Danny Murphy scored Liverpool's other goals in a 4-0 win. Michael Owen hit the post after coming on as a substitute for Emile Heskey.

Owen looks like staying at Anfield despite interest from Real Madrid. The 20-year-old England striker has three years left on his contract and says that he would be "delighted to discuss" a new deal.

"I'm as happy as I've ever been at Liverpool," he said. "I'm proud to play for Liverpool and have no intention of leaving. The calibre of signings we have made is an indication of how far we are going."

Owen admitted to being flattered by the European champions' interest. "But I've never said I would want to leave, and I don't want to," he added.

Christian Ziege is due at Anfield today for a medical, it was reported last night.

Watford have completed the signing of the Tottenham midfielder Allan Nielsen for a club-record £2.25m and his Spurs team-mate, the goalkeeper Espen Baardsen, for £1.25m.

The out-of-contract Sheffield Wednesday midfielder Danny Sonner has joined Birmingham City. Wolves have taken Sami Al-Jaber on trial. The 27-year-old striker has scored 44 goals in 80 appearances for Saudi Arabia.

fields.headline: Inheritance tax
fields.trailText: Inheritance tax affects people with assets of more £234,000.
fields.body:
Inheritance tax affects people with assets of more £234,000.

For married couples, assets automatically go to the surviving partner, but gays and lesbians do not get the same treatment.

The best way to avoid inheritance tax is to give assets away. These gifts are called potentially exempt transfers because they escape inheritance tax if the person giving them away outlives the gift-giving by seven years.

Even if the person dies within seven years inheritance tax can still be avoided if insurance against their death is taken out and put in a trust.

A trust is a legally binding arrangement commonly used for cases when the ownership of assets is to be transferred. Gay men and lesbians may find trusts particularly useful as they distribute your estate in the way you want.

But because trusts are legal instruments, the wording has to be precise and you will probably need expert help from a financial adviser to sort one out. Trusts are easy to set up but difficult to undo.

webTitle: It's time we were in for a penny, in for a euro

fields.headline: It's time we were in for a penny, in for a euro
fields.standfirst: If Britain doesn't join the single currency soon, foreign investors may be inclined to take their business elsewhere, warns Mark Atkinson economics correspondent
fields.trailText: If Britain doesn't join the single currency soon, foreign investors may be inclined to take their business elsewhere, warns Mark Atkinson economics correspondent
fields.body:
Another day brings another warning about the dire consequences of Britain remaining outside the euro. Kunio Nakamura, president of Matsushita, the world's biggest consumer electronics company, yesterday joined the chorus of businessmen - mostly Japanese - holding a gun to Tony Blair's head. Unless he makes up his mind quickly about entering the eurozone, Britain faces an exodus of foreign investors, Mr Nakamura said.

It was the most apocalyptic warning to date about the dangers of Britain's stubborn, some say sentimental, attachment to the pound, whose strength is making it harder and harder for foreign and domestically-owned businesses to export from the UK to the rest of the EU.

Mr Nakamura's prediction of a widespread defection of inward investors should be treated with a pinch of salt. Loud complaints by Japanese manufacturers about the impact of the strong pound on their profit margins are well founded but they also reflect the difficulties of survival in a fiercely competitive global market for goods and the stress of doing business back at home, where the economy is still struggling to escape from a decade-long recession.

By contrast, profitable European and American service-based industries - banks, retailers etc - continue to pour billions of pounds in to Britain without complaint, recognising that there is more to a successful investment decision than sterling's value against the euro.

They are apparently prepared to overlook the downside of an overvalued currency and focus instead on the UK's otherwise attractive business environment, its flexible labour market and relatively light bureaucratic touch vis a vis continental Europe.

Nevertheless, it is an open question how long the Americans and other foreign investors will continue to favour Britain over the rest of the EU. While it's not always acknowledged by the Eurosceptic press, continental Europe is embracing economic reform with enthusiasm, deregulating its labour markets, cutting taxes and attempting to generate a more entrepreneurial business culture, thereby gradually eroding Britain's competitive advantage.

Once global investors wake up to the fact that this transformation is under way, they may begin to think twice about choosing Britain over France or Germany when it comes to launching a new business venture in the EU. After all, given similar business environments, where would you choose to locate your new factory/shop/office? The place where your profits could be wiped out virtually overnight by an unexpected swing on the foreign exchanges? Or the one where foreign exchange considerations are largely irrelevant because you are able to deal in a common currency?

fields.headline: New euro warning for Blair
fields.standfirst:
Resolve single currency issue or lose investors, says Matsushita president
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The prime minister was yesterday challenged by the head of the world's biggest consumer electronics company to resolve the uncertainty over Britain's entry to the euro or face an outflow of foreign investors.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
The prime minister was yesterday challenged by the head of the world's biggest consumer electronics company to resolve the uncertainty over Britain's entry to the euro or face an outflow of foreign investors.

In the strongest warning of the potentially damaging consequences of Britain remaining outside the single currency, Kunio Nakamura, president of Matsushita, said: "The immediate question is when the pound will be included in the euro. This issue is something Blair must solve."

Mr Nakamura, whose company's UK operations employ 4,900 people, added: "If Britain does nothing to solve the problem, foreign companies, regardless of whether they are Japanese, American or whatever nationality, may exit the country."

Mr Nakamura, who worked in Britain as president of Panasonic UK for 12 months in 1992, is the latest in a long line of foreign investors to warn of the dangers of prevarication. Earlier this week, Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of Nissan, met Mr Blair to request financial assistance - said to be as much as £50m - to offset the impact of the strong pound on company profits.

Toyota has indicated that it will seek equal treatment if this request is granted but Mr Nakamura said Matsushita would not petition the government for help.

"We would like to do as Nissan president Ghosn did and visit the country to complain that a strong pound is making it difficult for us to continue production in the country, but if every company did that there would be a huge fuss," he said in an interview with Reuters.

"We don't want to demand such subsidies and I don't think they'll work."

Mr Nakamura, who took over last month as head of Matsushita, has been frustrated by the performance of the company's European operations, which slipped into the red last year despite double-digit growth in sales.

A spokesman blamed the loss on the 10% appreciation of the pound against the euro over the past 18 months.

Matsushita, best known for the Panasonic and National brands, produces televisions, mobile phones, microwave ovens and computers at Cardiff, Thatcham and five other British factories. The gain in sterling against the euro has hammered the profit margin on exports of these products to the continent.

To offset the strength of sterling, Matsushita shifted production last month of 29-inch flat-screen television sets from Cardiff to the Czech Republic. The company is also importing more picture tubes and other components from Germany.

Although foreign manufacturers are nervous of being dragged into the domestic political debate on monetary union, the Japanese chamber of commerce has made it clear that it wants Britain to join as soon as possible.

In a leaked letter, British ambassador to Tokyo Stephen Gomersall warned that Britain's uncertain stance on the euro was unsettling Japanese investors.

In the past three months, Toyota, Nissan and Honda have reduced their dependence on British parts by more than 10%. Hitachi has stopped making personal computer monitors in Britain, Canon has cut 200 jobs in Scotland and Sumitomo Electric Wiring has announced the closure of its plant in the north-east. The withdrawal of Matsushita would be far more serious. Its four plants in south Wales employ more than 2,500 people as well as providing three or four times as many jobs for suppliers and transport companies. This has helped to revitalise one of Britain's employment black spots.

 The strong pound was blamed by Alstom Power for 400 job losses at its plant in Lincoln yesterday. The redundancies, almost 15% of the firm's workforce, follow a fall in orders and comes on top of 270 job losses last year.

fields.headline: Annuities
fields.trailText: A pension annuity is a regular income paid for the rest of your life in exchange for your pension pot on retirement.
fields.body:
A pension annuity is a regular income paid for the rest of your life in exchange for your pension pot on retirement.

Depending on your sex, whether you are a smoker, or even which part of the country you come from, a better annuity deal can be struck. Being a gay man or lesbian does not make a difference for a single person.

Only those who have full-blown Aids may be offered a better annuity - on the grounds that they will not live many years to reap the benefits of the pension built up over a working life. However, HIV positive pension holders will not be treated differently.

Gay and lesbian couples can also take out joint-life annuities, where they share the pension pot and when one partner dies the survivor continues to receive a smaller income.

But unlike married couples, one partner may have to prove financial dependence on the other. This can be done through jointly held bank accounts and mortgages.

For individual annuities, the money is likely to be left to your family rather than a partner unless you specifically request otherwise on a nomination form.

When you come to retire, the type of annuity you buy will affect your retirement income and whether your partner receives income should you die early.

fields.headline: Company pensions
fields.trailText: If a company pension is offered it is usually worth taking your boss up on the offer. This is because the firm will usually pay the admin costs and may top up your contribution - making it a better deal than most privately taken personal pensions.
fields.body:
If a company pension is offered it is usually worth taking your boss up on the offer. This is because the firm will usually pay the admin costs and may top up your contribution - making it a better deal than most privately taken personal pensions.

But death in service will see your pension pot go to your family rather than a partner unless you make special provision for the situation.

This is because unlike married couples, gay relationships are not legally recognised in Britain.

You will need to fill out an Expression of Wishes form to make certain that if you die before receiving your pension, the full amount you have accrued will be passed to your chosen beneficiary. So forget to fill out this form at the peril of your loved ones.

The type of pension you have, or the type of annuity you have bought, will affect whether your partner receives a pension income from your fund if you die. Check with your company for details.

fields.headline: Repayment mortgage
fields.trailText: This is now considered the simplest and probably the best value loan to take out, whether you are gay or straight.
fields.body:
This is now considered the simplest and probably the best value loan to take out, whether you are gay or straight.

The advantage for gay men is that it also avoids the pitfalls of paying extra for the insurance element of an endowment policy.

However, some lenders will still require you to insure the repayment of the loan. Avoid this problem by taking out a mortgage from a lender who does not require life insurance - these include Abbey National and Cheltenham & Gloucester.

If you don't have life insurance and you die, remember that your partner could be left with a mortgage debt they cannot cope with.

fields.headline: Personal pensions
fields.trailText: Personal pensions are worth considering if a company pension scheme is not offered or your lifestyle means you are unlikely to work for one company for more than a couple of years at a time.
fields.body:
Personal pensions are worth considering if a company pension scheme is not offered or your lifestyle means you are unlikely to work for one company for more than a couple of years at a time.

As a rule, don't bother going for any life insurance option with your pension if you are a gay man. The rates can be three times that for heterosexuals, you may be ripped-off.

Lesbians should not be affected.

Of course, this means it is necessary to take extra care that should something happen to you before retirement, your pension pot does not end up lining the wrong pockets.

Make sure you have selected a 'return-of-fund' option, which allows you to benefit from any growth the fund has seen if the contract is broken early.

This is standard for most modern policies, but private pensions taken out more than 10 years ago might be 'return-of-contribution' policies, where only the amount put in less charges is handed back.

In this case it may be worth switching your policy - but check to see if the life office will charge a penalty, in which case it may be cheaper to stay put.

Your pension pot may automatically go to relatives unless otherwise stated. Check the plan for a nomination form, where you can specify your chosen beneficiary.

Remember, you may want to change the nomination in the future - this should simply require the signing of a new form which can be dealt with via post.

If the pension plan does not have a nomination form you can always put down all the details in a will. See the section on wills for further details.

webTitle: Centenarians bask in Queen Mum's limelight

fields.headline: Centenarians bask in Queen Mum's limelight
fields.standfirst:
Others born on same day enjoy special celebrations
Special report: the Queen Mother at 100
fields.trailText: Others born on same day enjoy special celebrations.
fields.body:
Lives whose paths have never crossed before will briefly share celebrity today in their joint 100th birthday celebrations.

For the Queen Mother the day will bring a salute from the King's Troop Royal Horse Artillery, a march past by the band of the Irish Guards playing Happy Birthday, a trip down the Mall in an open-topped landau - weather permitting - and an appearance on the balcony at Buckingham Palace to wave to her well-wishers.

For Ambrosine Nielsen, born on the same day to an entirely different life, the celebrations have included a trip to the shops and an outing to her favourite bingo hall.

"She's a bit hard of hearing these days so she doesn't really speak over the phone, but otherwise she's very fit - probably fitter than the Queen Mum," said John McCourt, senior care officer at the residential home in Jarrow, Tyne and Wear, to which Mrs Nielsen moved last October. "At least she doesn't need two walking sticks. She still jogs everywhere."

Mrs Nielsen, who left school at 14 to work in a shop, puts her healthy constitution down to a daily glass of whisky and the regular application of Lloyd's Cream, an ointment for aches and pains.

Her daughter Astrid Maddison, 60, said that as well as her mother's hearing, "her memory is going a bit - she keeps telling you things over again. But otherwise her health is brilliant. We're going to have a big party at the weekend with all the relatives.

"She's very proud that she shares a birthday with the Queen Mother. She's a very loyal and staunch old royalist. It has helped shape her life that they were born on the same day. She's been looking forward to this since her 80th birthday." Mrs Nielsen is one of at least 11 in Britain who share their centenary birthdays with the Queen Mother - a tribute to improving health standards over the past 100 years.

They are only the ones whose relatives put their names forward to Buckingham Palace. Each will receive a greetings card from the Queen, though the one taken to her mother's home, Clarence House, in a special Post Office delivery will include a personal message.

Mrs Nielsen, born in South Shields, married Haakon, a Danish fisherman, after he passed through the port. They spent the second world war in Denmark under German occupation. They had four daughters, one now dead. Mr Nielsen died 30 years ago. There are 15 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Until two years ago Mrs Nielsen was still going to bingo, travelling across Newcastle by public transport twice a week.

Farther south, in Lockeridge, Wiltshire, Gladys Stickland today celebrates her 100th birthday with her family. She was married to a farm labourer and was a cleaner for many years.

Her son-in-law, Bryan Watts, said: "She is really looking forward to it. I think she feels a bit more special, because it is a day everyone knows about and she is sharing it with the Queen Mother. "We have arranged a big party in the village hall, and one nephew is even coming over from Australia." At Bingham, Nottinghamshire, Pris-cilla Croasdale is also 100 today. "I think of the national anthem as my tune," she said. "I think we are both doing very well for our age."

Asked whether she enjoyed having the same birthday as the Queen Mother, she replied: "She likes sharing her birthday with me too, you know."

webTitle: Bush vows to lead new US

fields.headline: Bush vows to lead new US
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush stepped out of the shadow of his famous father and staked his own claim to the White House last night, using his presidential nomination acceptance speech at the Republican party convention in Philadelphia to cast himself as America's national healer after the turbulent Clinton years.
fields.body:
George W Bush stepped out of the shadow of his famous father and staked his own claim to the White House last night, using his presidential nomination acceptance speech at the Republican party convention in Philadelphia to cast himself as America's national healer after the turbulent Clinton years.

Six years after the radical rightwing captured the US Congress and began setting new standards of political divisiveness, and less than two years after the party attempted to impeach Bill Clinton, Mr Bush painted the Republicans as a party of national reconciliation and renewal .

"We are now the party of ideas and innovation," Mr Bush told the 2,066 delegates and a television audience of millions. The Republicans were now "the party of idealism and inclusion, the party of a simple and powerful hope".

In a speech that relentlessly targeted the centrist swing voters who backed Mr Clinton in 1992 and 1996, Mr Bush told Americans that the past eight years had offered "so much promise, to no great purpose". Carefully adopting a more-in-sorrow-than-in-anger approach to Mr Clinton, who remains a demonic hate figure to Republican activists, Mr Bush simply said: "My fellow citizens, we can begin again."

The Texas governor also used his 45-minute speech to call on Republicans and Democrats to work together to rebuild the US's ailing pension scheme in time for the retirement bulge of the 2010s. "Now is the time for Republicans and Democrats to end the politics of fear and save social security, together," he said.

In an audacious passage - particularly coming from a man whose father served 12 years in the White House as president and vice-president - Mr Bush said that he lacked "the polish of Washington".

webTitle: Battle over GM sites hits Lincolnshire villages.

fields.headline: Battle over sites hits Lincolnshire villages
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: The Queen's Hall in Binbrook, Lincolnshire, is expecting a crowd next week, after news that a nearby hamlet has joined the litany of villages playing host to GM crop trials.
fields.body:
The Queen's Hall in Binbrook, Lincolnshire, is expecting a crowd next week, after news that a nearby hamlet has joined the litany of villages playing host to GM crop trials.

Boothby Graffoe, Chaddesley Corbett, Spital in the Street - and now Thorganby, where James Milligan-Manby and his brother, plus a neighbouring farm, will plant test acres of winter oilseed rape.

But on the streets of Binbrook, two miles down the river Bain from Thorganby, Kate O'Connell and her troops from the Gaia Trust have already been out with pamphlets about herbicides and the water table, after getting a leak on the decision that has given them a week's campaigning start.

"The water worries me more than the GM pollen issue," she said. "The problem at Thorganby is that they've got special permission to use glufosinate ammonium, which leaches into the soil. And that area uses aquifers for the water supply."

The claim, published in flyers for a meeting on the issue at the Queen's Hall, has jolted the largely cordial disagreements over GM in the West Lindsey district, where neighbours are keen not to fall out while vigorously arguing the toss.

Mr Milligan-Manby said: "They're saying this is a herbicide banned in winter, when the fact is that no one has previously wanted to use it at that time of the year. That's what is different about the trials."

Ms O'Connell emphasised that in England's largest agricultural county everyone wanted to understand the problems facing farmers. "They're having a desperate time," she said. "Most of them rent land at high prices and grow wheat or rape for prices which aren't so good. If they're being offered £10,000 for trials, as the farming press suggests, it's tempting. But when we've got 6,000 farmers in Lincolnshire and only a dozen or so are agreeing to do trials, you've got to ask yourself why."

Mr Milligan-Manby expects to go to the meeting and wants to talk things over with his brother before commenting in detail, but his basic attitude is that agriculture needs progress, and progress cannot happen without tests.

"I can see where Kate O'Connell's coming from but we live in the real world, with ghastly things like famine or Aids, and science has been our friend in improving things or preventing even worse things from happening. These are tests of products which have already jumped through lots of hoops for something like 10 years."

Matthew Bell, whose Lincolnshire Organic Producers Network has farmers on the Bain valley, said: "The speed of these trials is threatening Lincolnshire's other great prospect: serious interest in organics, at last, from the big growers."

webTitle: Governors resist plans for 'less serious' BBC1

fields.headline: Governors resist plans for 'less serious' BBC1
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: A battle is looming between BBC executives and the board of governors over controversial plans to drop serious programmes such as Panorama and Songs of Praise from BBC1.
fields.body:
A battle is looming between BBC executives and the board of governors over controversial plans to drop serious programmes such as Panorama and Songs of Praise from BBC1.

BBC managers are discussing a radical proposal from the director of television, Mark Thompson, to reorganise the corporation's channels along "genre" lines, with BBC1 focused more clearly on general entertainment.

But some governors are understood to have serious reservations about the plans, and at a meeting this week, they sent the proposals back to BBC managers for more work. Such has been the level of opposition that it is understood that a proposal to move Panorama to BBC2 will be abandoned.

Mr Thompson unveiled his vision at a speech in Canada this summer, which took many within the BBC by surprise. He outlined concerns about the changing habits of viewers with digital technology: research shows they are showing far less "channel loyalty". The corporation had to address the problem, he said, proposing that BBC channels should have a clearer identity.

In a key passage of the speech, he said BBC1 relied too much on factual programmes at the expense of big budget drama: "Documentaries are one of the glories of BBC production, but it is possible to have too much of a good thing."

The plan is to boost the entertainment output on BBC1, increase the amount of current affairs and serious programmes on BBC2, develop a new BBC3 youth and comedy channel out of the existing digital channel BBC Choice, and turn BBC Knowledge into BBC4, devoted to culture, philosophy and the arts. It is a long term vision, and would only be fully implemented after the analogue television signal were switched off and the whole country was watching TV on digital services, probably not before 2010.

According to the governors' summary of their meeting, they considered the plans in general, "but asked for more work on some aspects of the strategy, particularly in regard to news and factual programming". No decisions will be taken before September.

It is understood the governors are seeking assurances that factual programmes will remain a key part of BBC1's schedule. They also remain to be convinced that any plan to move the 9pm news to 10pm - which would not be implemented until ITV resolves its court battle with the independent television commission over the timing of its own news bulletins - would not result in a drop in ratings.

They are also keen to take a stand at a time when their future role is under review by the government.

The reorganisation of the BBC's television channels is likely to be the focus of Mr Dyke's speech at the Guardian international television festival in Edinburgh this month. There are signs that his vision will be less radical than the one outlined by Mr Thompson, who is seen as effectively his number two. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has expressed reservations about the idea - and he would have the final say over any radical changes to BBC services.

This week, the Commons culture, media and sport select committee warned the BBC that the licence fee could no longer be justified if the BBC were to abandon "mixed scheduling" - providing a broad range of programmes on one channel.

Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the governors, told the select committee last month that there are no plans to move Panorama, Question Time or Songs of Praise from BBC1 to BBC2.

webTitle: New tests introduced to catch drug-drivers

fields.headline: Four steps to keep drivers on their toes
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: If the next time you have the misfortune to be pulled over by the police they ask you to step from your car, stand on one leg, look skywards, close your eyes and touch the tip of your nose, don't panic; the officers are not on drugs, but they think you are.
fields.body:
If the next time you have the misfortune to be pulled over by the police they ask you to step from your car, stand on one leg, look skywards, close your eyes and touch the tip of your nose, don't panic; the officers are not on drugs, but they think you are.

New tests designed to catch out motorists who have been ingesting white lines rather than following them are to be introduced by police in response to a sixfold increase in drug-related road deaths in the past decade.

Drivers suspected of indulging in cocaine, cannabis, ecstasy or heroin will be asked to carry out a range of roadside callisthenics intended to indicate whether their performance at the wheel has been affected by illegal drugs.

As well as standing flamingo-like and touching the nose, drivers will be asked to walk in a straight line while counting their steps and to count off 30 seconds with their eyes closed without losing too much time. Finally pupil size will be compared with a card held next to a suspect's face with varying sizes of pupils imprinted on it. Small pupils indicate heroin use, large pupils are a sign of cocaine or ecstasy.

The tests will be employed in the absence of a reliable drugs "breathaliser". Anyone who fails one of the four tests, which can be repeated up to three times each, will be arrested and will have to provide a blood or urine sample for analysis.

Under a training scheme introduced by the Association of Chief Police Officers, officers will receive drug recognition training (DRT) to help them identify drug users, and instruction in field impairment testing (FIT) designed to catch out the unfit.

Tell-tale signs of drug use officers will be taught to look for include poor coordination or balance, slurred speech or drowsiness and facial itching.

Police expect to see a huge increase in the number of convictions for drug driving in the next 12 months and estimate they will take samples from 20,000 motorists in that time.

Richard Brunstrom, an ACPO spokesman and deputy chief constable of north Wales police, welcomed the measures. "We have not in the past had the specific techniques to deal with this problem but the measures we are now introducing for forces provide us with added means, by enabling us to apply the law more effectively and improve road safety," he said.

The roads minister, Lord Whitty, said: "The techniques being applied are simple and straightforward and can be applied anywhere to help enforce existing laws with greater rigour."

The tests

Test 1: Walk in a straight line while looking at your feet and counting off a pre-determined number of steps. If you lose count, stop, stumble or swerve off line you fail.

Test 2: Stand on one leg with your head tilted back. Shut your eyes, lift your other leg high into the air, then stretch out your arms and touch the tip of your nose with the index fingers of both hands. Lose your balance, miss your nose or open your eyes and you fail.

Test 3: Your pupils are compared with an indicator board held up to your face. Too big or too small and you fail.

Test 4: Stand with your eyes closed and count an estimated 30 seconds without speaking. Too quick or too slow and you fail.

fields.headline: Partisan feuds stall Treasury committee
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The chairman of the Commons Treasury select committee yesterday abandoned plans to produce any reports on contentious issues until after the general election, saying that cross-party feuding had made it impossible for MPs to reach a consensus.
fields.body:
The chairman of the Commons Treasury select committee yesterday abandoned plans to produce any reports on contentious issues until after the general election, saying that cross-party feuding had made it impossible for MPs to reach a consensus.

Giles Radice, the committee's Labour chairman, spoke of his disappointment after it was forced to issue a second report in six days that was divided along party lines.

While the majority of members agreed that the spending plans of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, did not threaten economic stability, two Conservatives, Michael Fallon and David Ruffley, released a minority report arguing that the increase in health and education budgets would force up interest rates.

They also argued that if the economy dipped Mr Brown would be forced to either slash spending or raise taxes.

Parliamentary select committees should leave party politics at the door. But with an election expected next spring, Mr Radice said the Tories on the Treasury committee did not want to sign any report that could be seen as supporting the government.

The committee will continue to monitor non-party political issues, such as the decisions of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, but Mr Radice said: "There's not much point continuing to produce two reports on highly contentious issues, like the budget. We may just have to hold hearings."

The Treasury committee is the only select committee to suffer such a collapse into partisanship. However, other committees have had to accept minority reports - most recently when Tories and Labour divided over the reform of parliament itself.

In the run-up to previous elections MPs have tended to don their political hats, and it takes skilful bipartisan chairmanship to secure a consensus.

At a press conference last week, divisions on the Treasury committee burst into the open as MPs traded insults after failing to issue a joint report on joining the euro.

The majority said Britain had fulfilled all the Maastricht criteria for joining, but the Conservative group would not agree.

"The consensus the public has come to expect from responsible select committees has broken down," Brian Sedgemore, a Labour member, said at the press conference, adding that Conservative members had told him that "between now and the next election 'it's war, and I can tell you that I won't be as well behaved in future'. It's a bad, bad, show."

The committee decided not to stage a formal press conference yesterday, although there was even disagreement over that, with Mr Ruffley and Mr Fallon both in favour of the report's public release.

Mr Ruffley is widely seen as one of best and toughest operators on the Tory backbenches. He was a special adviser to Kenneth Clarke when he was chancellor.

However, Labour itself divided internally over the euro report on some issues.

webTitle: MPs criticise controls on GM crop trials

fields.headline: MPs criticise controls on GM crop trials
fields.standfirst:
Select committee condemns government's 'damaging' delay in telling the public of accidental planting of contaminated seeds
Special report: GM debate
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday criticised the government's system for controlling GM organisms and said the accidental planting of crops contaminated by GM material this summer had serious repercussions for consumer confidence.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday criticised the government's system for controlling GM organisms and said the accidental planting of crops contaminated by GM material this summer had serious repercussions for consumer confidence.

They condemned delays in telling the public about the mistake involving seeds grown on the Canadian prairie and the confusion that existed between separate ministries before hundreds of farmers who had unwittingly planted the crops were advised to destroy them.

The Commons agriculture select committee's report on the embarrassing affair coincided with the publication of 25 new trial sites for winter-growing GM rape, although these will not be confirmed until later this month. The government has decided to press on with the planting before deciding next month whether to change existing buffer zones designed to protect the purity of crops from most cross-pollination.

The delay is partly because ministers are awaiting the results of a Canadian government investigation into the Advanta company's claims that its seeds were contaminated in 1998 over distances far greater than allowed for in Britain.

The government did not go public on the mistake until a month after Advanta informed the Ministry of Agriculture and the Department of the Environment. The select committee called for clearer procedures over handling such incidents, saying there was obvious confusion between the ministries.

"The lengthy internal debates on the incidents contrasts with the robust, rapid Swedish disclosure in like circumstances," the committee said.

It was essential farmers could plant conventional rape crops over the next few weeks with confidence. "That means this year's batch of seed must be tested and certified as free from GM content. For farmers near the field trials, it is also vital that they can be sure that their crops are protected as far as possible from inadvertent cross-pollination..."

That would require a rapid decision on buffer zones. The committee recognised that 100% purity was neither possible nor verifiable. But the Advanta affair had "highlighted a gap in the regulatory framework for the control of GM organisms which has serious consequences for segregation and consumer confidence".

The Ministry of Agriculture said the government had "learned some important lessons" from the episode. But Mohamed Al Fayed, owner of Harrods, said he was suing both the government and Advanta after 55 acres on his Balnagowan estate in the Highlands was unwittingly planted with contaminated rape seed. He accused the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, of showing "utter incompetence in failing to understand the gravity of the situation".

Many new trial sites are on or near 48 farms already involved in the three year programme. Crops on 10 existing sites have been damaged by anti-GM activists in recent weeks, and far more will be needed in 2001 and 2002 for the research, designed to measure whether there is any damage to wildlife and any genetic transfer between GM and non-GM crops.

No work has yet been done on measuring transfer outside the sites involved in the trials despite fears that this could happen over miles. The existing buffer zones between GM and non-GM crops are 50m for rape and maize for animal feed and 200m for sweetcorn, although distances of up to 600m are needed for some organic crops.

Ministers appear uncertain how much contamination should be tolerated, with Michael Meacher, environment minister, apparently thinking a level as low as 0.1%, the lowest measurable amount, might be needed for consumer confidence. A study for the government written by the national institute of agricultural botany, Cambridge, suggested that at those levels buffer zones would need to double for rape and sweetcorn. But distances could be reduced if a 1% contamination level was acceptable.

Crops on 10 existing sites have been damaged by anti-GM activists in recent weeks, and far more will be needed in 2001 and 2002 for the research, designed to measure whether there is any damage to wildlife and any genetic transfer between GM and non-GM crops. No work has yet been done on measuring transfer outside the sites involved in the trials despite fears that this could happen over miles. The existing buffer zones between GM and non-GM crops are 50m for rape and maize for animal feed and 200m for sweetcorn, although distances of up to 600m are needed for some organic crops. Ministers appear uncertain how much contamination should be tolerated, with Michael Meacher, environment minister, apparently thinking a level as low as 0.1%, the lowest measurable amount, might be needed for consumer confidence. A study for the government written by the national institute of agricultural botany, Cambridge, suggested that at those levels buffer zones would need to double for rape and sweetcorn. But distances could be reduced if a 1% contamination level was acceptable.

webTitle: Gunmen spring prisoners court in Slough

fields.headline: More New York than Slough as gunmen spring prisoners court
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Gunmen disguised as security guards burst into a crowded magistrates court in Berkshire yesterday, fired several shots into the ceiling, coshed a police officer, and then fled with two prisoners who had been brought up from the cells charged with burglary offences.
fields.body:
Gunmen disguised as security guards burst into a crowded magistrates court in Berkshire yesterday, fired several shots into the ceiling, coshed a police officer, and then fled with two prisoners who had been brought up from the cells charged with burglary offences.

The gang sprinted from Slough magistrates court to a getaway car which sped to the M4 motorway and headed for Windsor. As they drove away, shots were fired into the air.

Police launched a massive hunt shortly after the breakout at 12.40pm, using the Thames Valley force's helicopter to try to trace the car, thought to be a silver, four-wheel drive Subaru Impreza.

One witness, Majinda Singh, said the gunmen, who were wearing balaclavas, had fired four or five shots, sending court staff diving to the floor as screams rang out from the public gallery.

"Two guys came rushing into the court holding pump-action shotguns. It was absolute madness. It was like a scene from a film. I ducked for cover."

Another witness, Richard Wareham, said: "I heard the gun go off, there was shouting and then two prisoners ran out followed by the others. I saw them sprinting out of the courtroom. I really didn't want to look at them because they had guns and I didn't want to get involved.

"I was hiding in the corner. It was extremely frightening."

An accomplice of the gunmen is thought to have been in the court's waiting room and led the charge to the car.

The prisoners who escaped were Ricky Loveridge, 22, who was on remand at Bullingdon prison in Oxfordshire charged with conspiracy to burgle, and Richard Hurley, 19, who was on remand at Reading young offenders' institute charged with burglary. A third man who was with them in the dock, Terry Downs, lay on the floor and did not try to escape.

A plainclothes police officer who challenged the gang was hit over the head with the butt of a gun. He suffered cuts and shock.

An uncle of Loveridge, who would not give his name, said his nephew should give himself up. "I wish he would come back and get himself sorted out. He was probably pumped up from the situation. As a guess I would say he's been pulled along in the heat of the moment."

A police spokesman, Richard Goodfellow, said the gang of five were still on the loose last night. "It would appear a number of people entered a court and assisted the escape of two men who were appearing before the court," he said.

"During the incident a firearm was discharged several times inside the courtroom. A police officer was injured but it was not related to the discharging of the firearm in any way. We are currently searching Slough and the surrounding areas for all the people involved."

Superintendent Brian Langston described the raid as "shocking and disproportionate". He said it was the sort of incident that happened on the streets of New York, not provincial Slough.

It is understood both of the prisoners have connections with Gypsies and officers were last night targeting travellers' sites in the area.

The gunmen were wearing similar to those worn by traffic officers.

David Cook of Premier Prison Services, which is in charge of dock security at Slough magistrates, said it was "a terrible incident" and that an inquiry had started.

John Garnham, a JP in Berkshire, said magistrates courts were not protected properly.

"I am not surprised this has happened. The way courts are left open to this kind of attack is disgraceful."

webTitle: EC starts legal action against Microsoft

fields.headline: EC starts legal action against Microsoft
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the European Commission
Special report: the future of Microsoft
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The European commission opened legal proceedings against Microsoft yesterday amid allegations that the software group had abused its dominant position in the PC market by withholding important information.
fields.body:
The European commission opened legal proceedings against Microsoft yesterday amid allegations that the software group had abused its dominant position in the PC market by withholding important information.

Microsoft, already fighting a judicial ruling in the US that it should be broken up as well as legal action brought on behalf of thousands of Americans, was charged with abusing its monopoly in the market for servers in Europe.

Opening yesterday's action, Mario Monti, the EC competition commissioner, said: "We will not tolerate the extension of existing dominance into adjacent markets through the leveraging of market power by anti-competitive means."

The EC accused the company of providing on a partial or discriminatory basis information about how its operating system worked. This "friend-enemy" scheme was first raised in complaints made at the end of 1998 by Sun Microsystems.

Microsoft said it was confident of reaching a "positive resolution" to the case. A state ment insisted that it had made its APIs - machine code that allows developers to work on compatible software - "broadly available".

The company, which has two months to respond to the allegations, immediately accused Sun of using the courts for commercial reasons.

John Frank, the firm's Paris-based director of law, said: "Sun's complaint is based on their desire to gain access to our technical trade secrets...

"We are very disappointed by Sun Microsystems' continued effort to use government intervention to overcome the fact that Microsoft's products are outperforming theirs in the market place."

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates has also blamed his competitors for his legal woes this week.

In an interview with Red Herring magazine, he said Scott McNealy, the head of Sun, Larry Ellison, founder of Oracle, and Steve Case, chief executive of America Online, were "the primary billionaires I have seen behind this thing from the very beginning".

Mr Frank described yesterday's filing as "another step in a long legal process".

fields.headline: Exams regime 'harms pupils'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: State school pupils are being tested to destruction, according to a survey which found that the brightest youngsters face having to sit more than 75 external tests and exams during their time at school.
fields.body:
State school pupils are being tested to destruction, according to a survey which found that the brightest youngsters face having to sit more than 75 external tests and exams during their time at school.

It claims that most children suffer severe stress from the endless tests. Indeed, many endure stress-related illness, have difficulty sleeping and develop eating disorders such as bulimia and anorexia.

The problem is significantly worse at secondary schools where girls, who do better in exams than boys, suffer more stress than male classmates.

The survey, commissioned by the Professional Association of Teachers (PAT) and backed by the Secondary Heads Association and the Children's Society, is based on detailed responses from more than 8,000 secondary school pupils in England and Wales.

A full analysis will be published in the autumn, but initial findings published today reveal that stress is damaging teenagers' physical and emotional wellbeing.

Speaking at the PAT's annual conference in Cheltenham, its vice-chairwoman Geraldine Everett, a teacher at Leicester grammar school, said: "There is nothing wrong with a bit of stress in the run-up to exams but if there are undue amounts it affects performance. Some children can't even go into the examination rooms because of the levels of stress they are suffering."

The report, titled Tested To Destruction? A Survey of Examination Stress In Teenagers, reveals that by the time the average sixth former leaves school, he or she will have taken 75 or more external tests and exams (based on the number of individual papers within a subject). Those leaving at 16 will have taken more than 60.

The formal testing programme starts with "baseline assessment" for four- and five-year-olds within weeks of entering primary school, and ends with A-levels at the age of 17 and 18. In between, there are national curriculum tests at seven, nine, 11 and 14, followed by GCSEs. The figure of 75 would apply to a bright sixth former who had taken up to four A-levels.

But the survey warns that these figures are likely to rise with the imminent introduction of "world-class tests", for 12- and 13-year-olds and new modular AS levels. Schools also routinely organise mock examinations to monitor pupils' progress.

The report's author, Geoffrey Carver, PAT senior professional officer, said: "What a sad state of affairs... We subject our children to an examining regime that leaves many of them stressed, many of them demoralised. We spend enormous sums of money in the process. We have a system that measures only the easily measurable. And why? Because education is now an instrument of politics.

"Tests are becoming too dominant a feature of school life. They increasingly restrict teaching time."

In a separate move yesterday, a motion passed at the conference noted regret "that the introduction of testing for young people has replaced fun with stress in our schools".

Margaret Griffin, president of the Secondary Heads Association, called for the reintroduction of a larger element of coursework. "We have real concerns about the reliability of some of the tests," she added, revealing that she had sent back all 180 English papers taken by her school's 14-year-olds because of inadequate marking.

Headteachers intend to raise the survey's findings with ministers and government exam advisers at the qualifications and curriculum authority.

Labour insists that testing is a key part of its programme to raise standards.

fields.headline: The ambush of a quiet family wedding
fields.standfirst: The Browns: Chancellor meets convergence criteria
fields.trailText: It may have been his wedding day, but for once it was hard not to feel sorry for Britain's Iron Chancellor. Gordon Brown and his bride, Sarah Macaulay, had been within 18 hours of pulling off the private family occasion they had so carefully planned when they were hit by the matrimonial equivalent of a Budget leak.
fields.body:
It may have been his wedding day, but for once it was hard not to feel sorry for Britain's Iron Chancellor. Gordon Brown and his bride, Sarah Macaulay, had been within 18 hours of pulling off the private family occasion they had so carefully planned when they were hit by the matrimonial equivalent of a Budget leak.

And this was the result. Instead of 20 or so close family, friends and assorted children gathering for a quiet nuptial at Mr Brown's redbrick home, high above the Forth bridges in North Queensferry, there was a media scrum at the gate.

Their prey cornered, nearly 100 photographers and reporters waited for the nod from Inspector Benny Byers, then streamed up the gravel drive and walked all over the back lawn (as we'd promised not to) for the agreed photo-call.

Prompt at 11.30am, it became another Brown promise delivered, but it was proof that a man may have nerves of steel when macro-managing a £1 trillion economy and still be painfully shy about his private affairs. The chancellor's face looked happy but his hands were all awkwardness.

"A kiss, sir," cried the snappers after the newly weds came diffidently through the back door following the Church of Scotland service (no hymns, no vows of obedience). "Is this the happiest day of your life?" shouted the Sun, eager to strike up a conversation. No answer. You could have attacked the comprehensive spending review in detail yesterday and still not got a word out of him.

The new Mrs Brown, whose long term investment strategy has proved every bit as clever as her husband's, wore an elegant cream silk suit by Louise Kennedy, Mr Brown looked as neat as he is ever likely to in his usual dark blue suit and white shirt. He was wearing a pink I-bought-it-for-the-wedding tie, smart enough but knotted so that it hung halfway to his knees. It is something else for Mrs B to take in hand.

"Another kiss please," they cried after Gordon, 49, and Sarah, 36, had whispered briefly (an "informal bilateral" in Whitehall-speak) before engaging in a tentative peck. They tried three times without getting it quite right. A month on Cape Cod will do wonders.

Those of us who cover all the big social weddings remembered that, back in 1981, Prince Charles had responded more convincingly to the challenge - and look where that got everyone. So perhaps the Browns' reticence was a good omen.

Twenty-fours hours earlier nothing of this was supposed to be happening. As the Daily Record, the Mirror's Scottish sister paper, gleefully reported yesterday, "ill-informed speculation" in London had even suggested that the workaholic politician and the PR exec's six-year affair had broken up - like all the others.

Now we learned from Ian Austin, the chancellor's normally tight-lipped Brummie spokesman, that he had proposed in January. Hang on there. Surely the brooding Heathcliff of the Heather was busy in January? All his energy was focused on the Budget, the CSR, the Transport Plan and the NHS Plan. But no. He was also nursing a Romantic Plan. What a polymath!

It was the Record which was to blame for yesterday's bunfight in the back garden. Locals in the chancellor's Dunfermline East constituency, 13 miles north of Edinburgh, had spotted the banns notice for "James Gordon Brown" and "Sarah Jane Macaulay" a fortnight ago. Amazingly, only yesterday did someone tip off the Labour tabloid. No one was taking credit for handily diverting the press pack, first to St John's church in nearby Inverkeithing at first light, then to its neighbour, the more imposing St Peter's outside which the constabulary (this was deemed significant) had placed two traffic cones.

The media pack tramped between the two churches like City investors dashing between equities and gilts on Budget day before the penny dropped. Under Scottish law the Rev Sheila Munro did not have to use any of her three churches to do the deed. She could do it in a private home.

So that was why the bridesmaids and pages, the aged parents, the friends and Treasury aides had all turned up at the chancellor's famously minimalist home. The pack headed south and arrived in time to hear the wedding was over.

At last the day belonged to Sarah, not to Prudence, her rival for the chancellor's heart during many a Budget cycle. She had waited longer than the average spending minister for Mr Brown to decide to ditch Prudence in favour of commitment and investment for a purpose. The time was finally ripe. "A wonderful day," said the bride and groom, but only in a statement.

Apart from Ed Balls, the chancellor's righthand man, and his wife, Yvette Cooper, the junior health minister, no political heavyweights were invited. From London the Blairs sent congratulations. Even Michael Portillo, the chancellor's Tory shadow, refrained from calling it a "stealth" wedding.

Touring the television studios the chancellor's former spin doctor, Charlie Whelan, called it posthumous vindication of his own oft spun, much disbelieved claim that it had been love all along. New Labour had delivered 100% more Downing Street babies than the Tories, even allowing for inflation. Now Downing Street was delivering 100% more Treasury weddings than John Major had managed, real weddings, not ones promised for 2003-04 as long as the economy holds up.

As the media was treated to a glass of Sainsbury's champagne (at £11.99 it reflected Prudence's lingering influence), the chancellor's friends expressed quiet glee that he had finally taken the plunge. "About time too," they murmured.

webTitle: Serb army arrests Britons for terrorism

fields.headline: Serb army arrests Britons for terrorism
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office last night was urgently seeking information from the Yugoslav authorities over the arrest of two British police officers accused of being armed with military equipment to train pro-western forces in Montenegro.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and  Julian Borger in Philadelphia
fields.body:
The Foreign Office last night was urgently seeking information from the Yugoslav authorities over the arrest of two British police officers accused of being armed with military equipment to train pro-western forces in Montenegro.

Amid rising tension in the region before next month's federal elections, the Yugoslav army named the Britons as Adrian Prangnell, 41, a police detective sergeant based at Waterlooville in Hampshire, and John Yore, 31, a constable in the Cambridgeshire force.

They were arrested on Mount Cakor in Montenegro, near the Kosovo border, on Tuesday night along with two Canadians, Shaun Going and his nephew, Liam Hall, who are thought to have been working as contractors.

Serbian authorities have recently claimed that the SAS and special forces from other countries were training Montenegrin police in preparation for the republic's secession from Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav army said it had "enough material to prove the true intentions and aims of the arrested".

The allegations were dismissed as "absolutely absurd" by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) which said the two Britons had been seconded to a police training school in Pristina, Kosovo's provincial capital, to act as instructors.

A spokesman said they had been given "extended weekend leave" and it was not clear where they had gone.

The two Canadians are employees of Meridian Resources of Calgary, a contractor working in Kosovo. The company said they went missing after a brief holiday in Montenegro.

However, a Yugoslav army spokesman Colonel Slobodan Stojanovic, described the four men as "not tourists, but terrorists". He added: "Illegal material was found in their possession for which criminal charges are earmarked."

Yugoslavia, which is stepping up anti-western propaganda ahead of the September 24 federal elections, announced on Monday that four Dutchmen were arrested in July allegedly for plotting to kill or abduct the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, or the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and bring them to the UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

There are fears that Mr Milosevic might attempt to topple the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, while the US is engrossed in its presidential elections this autumn and reassert his control. There are already Serb garrisons in the autonomous republic.

According to western diplomats, the US and Britain are drawing up contingency plans to impose a "no-fly zone" over Montenegro if Slobodan Milosevic threatens to use force against the republic.

But a Yugoslav foreign ministry official said any such zone would be an unprecedented provocation.

Strobe Talbott, the US deputy secretary of state, and General Wesley Clark, the former Nato commander who led the campaign in Kosovo, are both convinced that the Serb leader will strike in the next few months.

General Clark, in particular, urged the White House and the Pentagon to begin making preparations: putting aircraft in place and securing the backing of as many Nato allies as possible.

Concern over an impending crisis is growing in Washington after Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of, state failed this week to convince Mr Djukanovic to participate in elections called by Mr Milosevic.

The Montenegrin government believes the elections will be rigged and that their significance is undermined by constitutional changes forced through by Serbia.

Foreign Office officials in London said yesterday that Nato governments wanted to "keep Milosevic guessing" over any action they may take over Montenegro.
fields.bodyText: The Foreign Office last night was urgently seeking information from the Yugoslav authorities over the arrest of two British police officers accused of being armed with military equipment to train pro-western forces in Montenegro. Amid rising tension in the region before next month's federal elections, the Yugoslav army named the Britons as Adrian Prangnell, 41, a police detective sergeant based at Waterlooville in Hampshire, and John Yore, 31, a constable in the Cambridgeshire force. They were arrested on Mount Cakor in Montenegro, near the Kosovo border, on Tuesday night along with two Canadians, Shaun Going and his nephew, Liam Hall, who are thought to have been working as contractors. Serbian authorities have recently claimed that the SAS and special forces from other countries were training Montenegrin police in preparation for the republic's secession from Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav army said it had "enough material to prove the true intentions and aims of the arrested". The allegations were dismissed as "absolutely absurd" by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) which said the two Britons had been seconded to a police training school in Pristina, Kosovo's provincial capital, to act as instructors. A spokesman said they had been given "extended weekend leave" and it was not clear where they had gone. The two Canadians are employees of Meridian Resources of Calgary, a contractor working in Kosovo. The company said they went missing after a brief holiday in Montenegro. However, a Yugoslav army spokesman Colonel Slobodan Stojanovic, described the four men as "not tourists, but terrorists". He added: "Illegal material was found in their possession for which criminal charges are earmarked." Yugoslavia, which is stepping up anti-western propaganda ahead of the September 24 federal elections, announced on Monday that four Dutchmen were arrested in July allegedly for plotting to kill or abduct the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, or the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and bring them to the UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague. There are fears that Mr Milosevic might attempt to topple the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, while the US is engrossed in its presidential elections this autumn and reassert his control. There are already Serb garrisons in the autonomous republic. According to western diplomats, the US and Britain are drawing up contingency plans to impose a "no-fly zone" over Montenegro if Slobodan Milosevic threatens to use force against the republic. But a Yugoslav foreign ministry official said any such zone would be an unprecedented provocation. Strobe Talbott, the US deputy secretary of state, and General Wesley Clark, the former Nato commander who led the campaign in Kosovo, are both convinced that the Serb leader will strike in the next few months. General Clark, in particular, urged the White House and the Pentagon to begin making preparations: putting aircraft in place and securing the backing of as many Nato allies as possible. Concern over an impending crisis is growing in Washington after Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of, state failed this week to convince Mr Djukanovic to participate in elections called by Mr Milosevic. The Montenegrin government believes the elections will be rigged and that their significance is undermined by constitutional changes forced through by Serbia. Foreign Office officials in London said yesterday that Nato governments wanted to "keep Milosevic guessing" over any action they may take over Montenegro.

fields.headline: Drink-drivers sent back to classroom
fields.standfirst:
Home Office introduces compulsory lessons for problem drinkers as part of plan to tackle alcohol-related crime
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The 100,000 drink-drivers convicted every year face compulsory alcohol education and treatment courses under a shake-up of the motoring laws to be announced by ministers later this month.
fields.body:
The 100,000 drink-drivers convicted every year face compulsory alcohol education and treatment courses under a shake-up of the motoring laws to be announced by ministers later this month.

The Home Office unveiled its latest package of proposals to tackle alcohol-related crime yesterday, including the use of fixed penalty fines to deal with public drunkenness and disorder, giving the police the power to confiscate open bottles and cans from those drinking in the street, and new measures to encourage pub landlords to crack down on underage drinking.

Under the drink-driving proposals, convicted motorists would be expected to attend an hour and a half class each week for between six to eight weeks in a course which would be designed to get them to face up to their problem drinking and prevent them reoffending.

At present a small number of convicted drink-drivers pay to take such courses in return for a three-month deduction from their automatic 12-month driving ban.

Alcohol Concern said yesterday it had been pressing for such action for some time. "In the last three or four years the national strategy has concentrated on illicit drugs which have had most of the resources," its assistant director, Sue Boon, said.

"People are comfortable about seeing illegal drugs as the root of all evil; 90% of people use alcohol but are less comfortable about the fact that it causes even more problems. We want to see alcohol being given the same priority as the question of illicit drugs."

The Automobile Association gave a cautious welcome to the move, saying it had been shown that voluntary alcohol education classes worked.

However, a spokesman warned that if the classes were compulsory those attending might not have the same motivation. In the US some of the people sent for such reeducation simply turn up and spend the time playing cards.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said alcohol contributed to 40% of violent crime and 88% of criminal damage cases and the plan was part of a series of measures to reduce these statistics.

He confirmed that the government intends to push ahead with fixed penalty fines for cases of public drunkenness but indicated that this would cover seven or eight specific offences. Police officers would not collect money "on the spot" and those fined would have the right to appeal to a court. However, Mr Clarke said he did not envisage that drunks on the street would be breathalysed. Instead police officers would use their judgment in determining whether those stopped had had too much to drink.

The Conservative home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, was sceptical. "What sort of judgment will the officer be expected to make?" he said. "It is not like a speeding offence where you know from machinery that the car has been speeding... I want to know what evidence the police will need and what is the standard evidence that will be needed to prove the offence to a court."

Home office ministers hope the measures will help tackle violent undercurrents in Britain's urban nightlife.

"We think that establishing a culture in city centres around alcohol which is much tighter and more rigid, in partnership with clubs and pubs themselves and police, magistrates and local councils, will build an atmosphere where you violence takes place for less," Mr Clarke said.

The Home Office action plan also includes proposals to make the use of toughened drinking glasses, which lessen injuries from pub fights, a condition on issue of an alcohol licence.

The national expansion of "pubwatch" schemes, under which landlords share information about troublemakers, will also be given the go-ahead.

Mr Clarke was also keen to see further moves towards a voluntary identity card scheme for older teenagers so they could prove they were over 18. The government is considering placing a positive duty on landlords to establish the age of younger customers.

Pubs are also to be given stronger powers to exclude troublemakers and to refuse to sell alcohol to those who are already drunk.

webTitle: Mugabe talks tough as war veterans expel farm family

fields.headline: Mugabe talks tough as war veterans expel farm family
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Just hours after they were driven weeping from their farm yesterday, the Parks family were trying to work out how it had gone so wrong so quickly. Were they victims of Robert Mugabe's threat to grab even more white-owned land? Or had they been set up by a former worker bitter at his dismissal?
fields.body:
Just hours after they were driven weeping from their farm yesterday, the Parks family were trying to work out how it had gone so wrong so quickly. Were they victims of Robert Mugabe's threat to grab even more white-owned land? Or had they been set up by a former worker bitter at his dismissal?

It hardly mattered to the "war veterans" who moved on to Mayfied Farm in Mazowe, less than an hour's drive from Harare, on Wednesday. Within a day they had forced the white owners off and claimed the land as their own. But Duncan Parks did not leave before he and 17 other white farmers who went to his family's aid had been held hostage and threatened with death.

The seizure of Mayfield Farm was the first such occupation since the government announced it would expropriate four times as much white land as originally planned, to give to poor blacks.

Even as the Parks quit their home, Mr Mugabe dispelled any doubts that he might have been persuaded by a visit from President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa or pressure from Zimbabwe's foreign donors that his economy is facing ruin if the government hands over most of the productive land to subsistence farmers.

He confirmed that the government plans to take 3,041 farms - about two-thirds of all white-owned land - and will expropriate more if it wants.

"The donors can stay with their money if their condition is that that money can only come if we give up the demand on land we are pursuing," he told a meeting of black farmers.

The road to Mayfield Farm was blocked by a felled tree. The veterans hung a sign at the gate: "Peter Hain, Robin Cook. Stop lying about Zimbabwe." In the yard lay thousands of corn cobs ready for packing, but no one was working.

The invasion was led by Chinotimba Brown, a member of the war veterans' national committee, who arrived in a Land Rover with government number plates.

"It's time for the colonialists to push out," he said. "The 804 [farms the government originally listed for expropriation] were not suitable and we are going to acquire more. If the 3,000 we are now taking are not sufficient we will go on acquiring more. All the farms can be acquired if necessary."

Mr Brown and the "war veterans" initially refused to allow Mr Parks to leave. Seventeen white neighbours turned up in the hope there might be safety in numbers. They too were taken hostage.

Several hours into the standoff, Mr Brown said all the farmers and the Parks family could leave on foot, without taking anything with them.

Duncan Parks did not want to abandon the house he has lived in all his life and the other farmers were not going to leave their vehicles.

"There was verbal abuse and death threats against all of us," Mr Parks said. But it was the beating of his workers that convinced the 55-year-old farmer to leave the land his family had owned since 1911.

Mr Brown denied workers were beaten or the farmers held and threatened.

Two hours after abandoning Mayfield Farm, Isla Parks sat between her husband and her son as the two men wept. "Be strong, be strong," she whispered.

Her son, Stewart, said: "I was trying to negotiate with them on why they were picking on us and what I had done wrong to them." He added that a former employee, dismissed for selling drugs, was at the gate as the family left.

"They said we were rough to our labour. We are not rough. When someone steals or sells drugs they have to be dealt with. I didn't turn him in to the police. I should have and I regret that," he said.

Shortly after Mr Parks and his family fled, the veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, arrived, cheered by the new tenants. "This is Zimbabwean land," Mr Hunzvi said. "We need land and it is going to be resettled. We will give land to the people."
