webTitle: 'Pubwatch' scheme a success in South Yorkshire

fields.headline: 'People won't stand for trouble at their local any more'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Bob Snashall sets out on an unusual pubcrawl this morning, delivering bulky agendas to all 22 pubs and clubs in the South Yorkshire former pit villages of Thorne and Moorends.
fields.body:
Bob Snashall sets out on an unusual pubcrawl this morning, delivering bulky agendas to all 22 pubs and clubs in the South Yorkshire former pit villages of Thorne and Moorends.

By the time he ticks off the Windmill and the Woodlands, just east of Doncaster, no landlord will have an excuse for missing a formidable tribunal on Monday, whose influence on violent drinkers now stretches as far as Lincoln and York.

Using quasi-legal documents, carefully checked with the clerk at Doncaster magistrates court, the Pubwatch committee administers bans on troublemakers, circulates photographs and holds appeals which, Mr Snashall says, have seen punters on their knees begging to be allowed back in.

"It finally gets home to them," he says, "when all their mates can get a drink as usual, but there isn't a pub or club for literally 20 miles which isn't going to show them the door."

Being "pubwatched" has entered the argot of the tight local communities, where the publicans' committee was set up 10 years ago to tackle alarming numbers of fights, drug-dealing and other aggressive crime related to drink.

"We knew why it was going off," says Bob, a former regular soldier who chairs Thorne and Moorends Pubwatch and sits on the committee of the main local licensed social club. "Every pit had closed and there was tap-all for people to do. But you couldn't let it happen and allow the villages to be taken apart."

The fightback came after a new community hall was burned down by vandals and the effect of drink and drugs - sometimes dealt in private backrooms of pubs - was too obvious to deny. Sixty-one local people were pubwatched in the first year, with bouncers and the police on hand to make sure the bans were effective.

It was tough. There were counter-attacks, smashed windows and Mr Snashall was jumped three times, unwisely, given his army background and three years laying gas pipelines across Siberia. The system has been forced to operate through a safe PO Box address, sending out bans and notices of the right to appeal through a local anti-drugs project.

But it is working. The pubwatched list, kept under the bar at all the licensed premises and exchanged with neighbouring pubwatches at Goole and more recently into North Yorkshire and Lincolnshire, is now down to 10. "Four of them are lifers," says Mr Snashall, "because their cases all involve drugs. But we review every ban every year."

The system also polices landlords and club staff, the latter sometimes including volunteers who handle large sums of money and take on serious legal responsibilities.

The group is conscious that it is dealing with individual rights. "We can only use photographs if someone's got form, and even then only staff are allowed to see them," says Mr Snashall. "But it's interesting how often other customers will slip up - say, if you've got new casual bar staff - and say: 'You know who that is, don't you? Look at your pubwatch.' People won't stand for trouble at their local any more."

The committee also detects a growing approval from local licensing magistrates, who cannot make Pubwatch membership a condition of granting a licence but are beginning to hint that it does not go unnoticed.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Ghostbusters/Mercury Rising/The Tom Green Show Cancer Special/The Funeral
fields.body:
Ghostbusters

(Ivan Reitman, 1984)

8pm, FilmFour

Hilarious supernatural comedy - with some eye-boggling special effects - that'll have you in ectoplasms of delight. Dan Aykroyd, Bill Murray (pictured) and Harold Ramis are ghostbusters suddenly inundated with work: the city's alive with spirits, and they're centred on Sigourney Weaver's apartment. It's a tough job, but someone has to go in there...

Mercury Rising

(Harold Becker, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

An autistic boy unwittingly cracks a top secret service code, causing cynical government man Alec Baldwin to call in the hitmen. So, as Ghostbusters would put it, who you gonna call? Bruce Willis. His FBI man is washed-up, over the hill and down the other side, but still able to turn the tables on those smart young heavies in a formulaic but efficient drama from the director of Sea Of Love.

The Tom Green Show Cancer Special

10.30pm, MTV

Testicular cancer: hardly standard MTV fare. But here it is, prime-time on a Friday night, and it's pretty interesting. Your capacity for "enjoying" it will depend on your opinion of Green's sub-South Park puerile humour, and your capacity to watch lymph node-removal surgery. But for once, there seems to be a point to his show (MTV's target audience falls within the parameters of men most likely to contract testicular cancer), and there's something about the sight of his sidekick playing with Green's cancerous ex-testicle post-surgery.

The Funeral

(Abel Ferrara, 1996)

3.55am, FilmFour

A pretty heavily macho 1930s gangster movie that sees Christopher Walken and Chris Penn playing brothers avenging the death of their commie kid brother Vincent Gallo. But you have to ask yourself, with brothers like those two, who in their right mind would hit him? It's a handsome and amusing evocation of a violent time, and the scorching performances - the film boasts Isabella Rossellini and Annabella Sciorra as well - just about keep the complex flashback-plotting on track.

webTitle: Afghan on hijack plane wins asylum

fields.headline: Afghan on hijack plane wins asylum
fields.standfirst:
Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: the Stansted hijack
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: A member of the group of Afghans who arrived in Britain in February on a hijacked plane yesterday won his asylum appeal against the home secretary's decision that he should not be given refugee status.
fields.body:
A member of the group of Afghans who arrived in Britain in February on a hijacked plane yesterday won his asylum appeal against the home secretary's decision that he should not be given refugee status.

The agricultural engineer, 35, who has not been named, told an immigration appeal panel that he was a leading member of an Afghan outlawed political party.

Judge Herbert Dunn allowed his appeal against Jack Straw's decision, after hearing he had been imprisoned for 40 days by the Taliban and beaten over the head with a brick.

The man said he had acted for the mujaheddin and feared he would be hanged if he were sent back to Kabul. Judge Dunn said he should be given asylum in Britain as was convinced that he faced "a well founded fear of persecution".

But his was the only case to succeed out of the 30 Afghans aboard the plane which landed at Stansted airport on February 7 whose appeals against refusal of asylum have been heard over the past week. One further case is to be heard on September 5.

Mr Straw told the Commons on February 10 that no one should believe that they would benefit from hijacking and said he wanted to see "removed from this country all those on the plane as soon as practicable".

But yesterday David Enright, a lawyer acting for some of the 31 people on the plane who have claimed asylum said he was "100% certain" they would ultimately all remain in Britain. "The appeals panel concluded that these people would be detained and investigated if they were returned to Afghanistan," said Mr Enright.

All those whose appeals have been rejected are expected to make a further application to the immigration appeals tribunal. The Home Office is also expected to appeal against yesterday's decision.

fields.headline: Crime time
fields.standfirst:
The analysis of crime figures at the postcode level is the way forward, according to Whitehall - it worked in New York, after all

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: When the Metropolitan police sent a delegation to New York city to see if there were any lessons they could learn from mayor Rudolf Giuliani's zero tolerance policy, they claimed to be unimpressed by the Americans' swamp tactics to tackle the symptoms of crime rather than its root causes. What they did admire, however, was the way crime figures in New York are broken down to precinct level, allowing police in a given neighbourhood to be made directly accountable. Precinct captains responsible for sending out beat patrols can see what impact they have on crime figures. And, perhaps more importantly, so can local residents.
fields.body:
When the Metropolitan police sent a delegation to New York city to see if there were any lessons they could learn from mayor Rudolf Giuliani's zero tolerance policy, they claimed to be unimpressed by the Americans' swamp tactics to tackle the symptoms of crime rather than its root causes. What they did admire, however, was the way crime figures in New York are broken down to precinct level, allowing police in a given neighbourhood to be made directly accountable. Precinct captains responsible for sending out beat patrols can see what impact they have on crime figures. And, perhaps more importantly, so can local residents.

British criminologists, especially those in the Home Office research, development and statistics directorate, were also impressed. This was one of the reasons ministers published a paper this week urging an overhaul of the way crime figures are collected and presented. Another reason is illustrated by the chart. The proportion of reported incidents that the system recognises as crime varies between different kinds of offence and overall is only about three quarters. The police - systems of reporting differ - apply their own tests to the public's allegations that something untoward has happened.

The key is local data. In the US, standard American crime figures are available county by county. In Philadelphia it is even possible for residents to find out what incidents have happened in selected crime categories on their block. Although some audit commission publications and websites, such as Upmystreet.com, imply that similar figures are available for each local authority or even postcode in England and Wales, that is still some years off.

The form in which statistics recording crime are published would be recognisable to a 19th-century civil servant. Traditionally, statistics have been broken down for each of the 43 police forces so that an incumbent home secretary has a good idea about what sort of job each chief constable is doing. But increasingly ministers see value in making much more local information available - both in terms of combating crime and reducing fear of crime.

For the first time, in January this year, annual crime figures were broken down to the level of the hundred or so "crime and disorder partnerships", which mostly follow local authority boundaries. Figures were even available for the more numerous basic command units - essentially each of the 300-odd police divisions in England and Wales.

This, however, is still a long way from the postcode definition of neighbourhood that accords with many people's idea of "the area in which I live". Only about 17 forces have logged crime data for their areas that are detailed enough to give a breakdown for postcodes. Such postcoded crime data usually only cover about 60% of addresses in any one patch. Some forces have started to collect crime data based on where specific offences were committed - the Home Office thinks it is still some years before this becomes common practice.

However, it now seems that there is the political will in Whitehall to give the whole process a push. It is not just crime figures that ministers are interested in making available at this very local level. The social exclusion unit in the Cabinet Office wants to see the office for national statistics taking on the task of making neighbourhood data available for a number of key social indicators. The idea is that local data would help explain crime patterns. Car crime might be correlated with such indicators as car ownership; burglary rates with types of residential property as well as unemployment and social deprivation.

"It is only with this level of detail that a local police force would be able to carry out a proper hot-spot analysis and identify trends and patterns that otherwise would be reliant on the instincts of long-serving officers, who with the best will in the world cannot absorb all of the information about crimes in their locality," says the paper on modernising crime statistics.

It is to be hoped that such computer-generated data would be in addition to, and not a replacement for, the judgment of the long-serving neighbourhood officer. But a serious effort is now being made by the government, Home Office and police to invest in the necessary computer software to take up the techniques that some American cities have for many years regarded as an important part of the fight against crime.

Perhaps this more numbers-based approach to tackling crime has something to do with the number of statisticians now to be found running the Home Office. The police minister, Charles Clarke, has a Cambridge degree in maths and economics; the home secretary, Jack Straw, is a fellow of the Royal Statistical Society; and Paul Wiles, the new head of research, is an enthusiastic number-cruncher.

Mr Clarke believes that such neighbourhood information can help reduce the fear of crime among even the most innumerate. He recently held a meeting in his Norfolk constituency called to discuss the rising crime problem. Local residents were fearful. But anxiety was assuaged when the police produced their breakdown for the patch. There had recently been only four crimes - and one of them involved the heinous offence of knocking over somebody's dustbin.

fields.headline: Judge stumps town's eleven
fields.trailText: When is a village not a village? When the name is Usk and the competition is the  Wadsworth 6X Village Cricket Championship, that's when.
fields.body:
It was just not cricket. That was the ruling at the high court in Bristol yesterday when the presiding judge upheld a decision to throw a south Wales team out of Britain's top village cricket competition - because it belonged to a town club.

Judge John Weeks QC agreed that the the club from Usk in Monmouthshire should not compete in the Wadsworth 6X Village Cricket Championship quarter-final this weekend, despite its one run victory over the Cornish club Werrington in the previous round. He said organisers were right to insist that, in cricketing terms, Usk was no longer a village.

After their narrow defeat, Werrington complained to competition organisers, the Cricketer magazine, that they thought Usk had the feel of a town. It had a town council, a mayor, a fire station, 14 pubs, and even a sign welcoming motorists to "the historic town of Usk".

But an Usk councillor, David Rennels, countered: "We were classed as a market town until 1975 when we lost our market and now we are just a village." It was also pointed out that Usk was a past winner of the best kept village competition.

The Cricketer sided with Werrington and Usk took the case to court to win back a chance to compete for a place in the final at Lord's.

The court hearing centred on rule four of the competition which states: "A village shall be deemed to be a rural community surrounded on all sides by open country and consisting of not more than 3,000 inhabitants."

David Hall, the club's lawyer, told the court that Usk had competed in the competition since 1993 and since its first year had been invited to join by the organisers without having to apply. "It is not disputed that Usk is a rural community surrounded on all sides by open country," he said.

But Judge Weeks said: "In my judgment the Cricketer is right to take into consideration other factors such as the existence of a town clerk, a mayor and the historic existence of a charter of the town in deciding eligibility."

He ordered the club to pay the Cricketer's costs, thought to be up to £10,000.

Outside the court, the Usk captain, Owen Watkins, took the loss gracefully. "We wish all the remaining teams the best of luck in the competition."

The Cricketer magazine owner, former Somerset captain Ben Brocklehurst, 78, who had been in court, said the decision was a victory for village cricket. "Once we heard that Usk was a town, we had to make the decision to ban them. For a town side to compete was against the whole ethos of the competition."

The rulebook was to be tightened up to avoid similar disputes between the 630 villages competing for the £1,000 first prize.

In the meantime Werrington face the Somerset village of Timsbury on Sunday.

webTitle: Anger as dome gets new £43m lifeline in 'loan'

fields.headline: Anger as dome gets new £43m lifeline in 'loan'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome was last night given another £43m loan to keep it afloat after further reports that it would be forced to close as early as October.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome was last night given another £43m loan to keep it afloat after further reports that it would be forced to close as early as October.

The new money - the third bail-out in four months - will come from the £53m the millennium commission received for its share of the sale of the dome to the Japanese bank Nomura last week. The Guardian then predicted the cash would go straight to the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, to keep it going until Nomura takes over at the end of December.

There were rumours last night that reports of the dome's early closure were leaked to force the commission's hand. The commission is believed to be keeping the final £10m in reserve in case of further crises.

The dome's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau - who has already squeezed an extra £89m of lottery money out of the commission - met commissioners yesterday to request more cash, days after he again insisted he would not ask them for extra grants.

But an NMEC spokesman last night said the new money was not a grant but a "cash advance, a loan in fact, which we had always budgeted for. That money was always going to be part of our business plan. PY [Gerbeau] has always been careful to deny he wanted any more grants rather than loans." He refused to say how long the dome would have survived without the money.

The dome stands little chance of being able to repay any money. Even with the 606,519 visitors in July - its best month so far - the dome is still short of the 20,600 visitors a day it needs to meet its revised target of 7m people. It was originally meant to attract 12m visitors before the break-even figure was dropped to 10m. To date, 3.7m have passed through the turnstiles.

The decision to bail the dome out yet again angered critics, who this week branded a highly critical Commons committee report on the attraction as too soft. Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, accused the government of "throwing more good money after bad".

Unions were given a "categoric guarantee" yesterday by the NMEC that the attraction will stay open for the rest of the year.

The GMB had demanded talks after the uncertainly over its future grew. A union spokesman said: "We have been assured that all jobs are safe. It appears the reports of the dome's demise have been somewhat exaggerated."

An NMEC spokesman said he knew of no immediate financial crisis, but added: "You don't have to be a genius to work out that we would need some of that money at some stage. We continue to plan for the dome to be open until the end of the year."

webTitle: Mystery illness linked to three more deaths of heroin addicts

fields.headline: Mystery illness linked to more deaths of heroin addicts
fields.trailText: The mystery illness which has killed more than 30 heroin users is being linked with three more deaths.
fields.body:
The mystery illness which has killed more than 30 heroin users is being linked with three more deaths.

After more than a month without further outbreaks of the deadly infection, the Greater Glasgow health board yesterday reported two more cases. One Glasgow woman died in hospital while another addict is in a stable condition.

And in Birmingham two men have died within 24 hours of each other after overdosing on what is believed to be an infected batch of heroin. An 18-year-old man was found dead at a flat in the city centre on Tuesday night. Another man, 39, who was found with him, is is critically ill in hospital. Another body of a man was found on Wednesday near a derelict building in the city centre.

The latest casualties bring the total number of cases in Scotland to 57, of which 22 victims have died, 18 of them in the greater Glasgow area.

There have also been recent deaths among addicts in Dublin, north-west England and Wolverhampton.

Greater Glasgow health board disclosed in June that the cause of the deaths was the bacteria Clostridium noyvi type A, which had contaminated the heroin.

Laurence Gruer, a consultant in public health medicine with Greater Glasgow health board, said: "In at least one case the heroin used had apparently been prepared at least six weeks ago. It is likely that virtually all of the contaminated heroin has now been used up."

The illness first emerged in Glasgow among heroin injectors in early May.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Murder police question mother

Detectives questioning a 34-year-old mother about the death of a new born baby said yesterday that they may investigate two other possible deaths.

The body of a baby, thought to be about three weeks old, was hidden in an outbuilding at a house in Rossington, near Doncaster. Police said the woman had been heavily pregnant as on two previous occasions "but with no new addition to the family".

£28,000 for Peter Rabbit

A privately printed first edition copy of Beatrix Potter's classic The Tale of Peter Rabbit, found in a box full of old books during a house clearance, fetched £28,750 at auction yesterday.

The book - one of 250 which Potter paid to have printed in December 1901 - was among the effects of a retired naval commander who died at his country home near Winchester.

Stolen mower man accused

A man has been charged with drink driving after he was stopped while driving a stolen sit-on lawn mower in Bristol. The unnamed 37-year-old has also been charged with damaging a police car and having no insurance.

10 held in arms base blockade

Ten anti-nuclear protesters were arrested yesterday after a blockade at an entrance to the Coulport armaments depot on Loch Long.

The protest was organ ised by the Trident Ploughshares group as part of two weeks of action against the Faslane submarine base on the Clyde.

Smoking 'hits fewer children'

The number of children exposed to passive smoking in England has halved in 10 years, due to fewer parents smoking and bans on smoking in public places, according to a report published today in the British Medical Journal.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund'found that children's exposure dramatically decreased between 1988 and 1998.
Keith Perry

Relaunch for ocean racer

Ocean yachtsman Pete Goss is to relaunch his £4m catamaran Team Phillips nearly five months after a 40ft section of her port bow snapped off during sea trials off the Isles of Scilly, it was announced yesterday.

webTitle: RAF to honour dead airmen, 60 years on

fields.headline: RAF to honour dead airmen, 60 years on
fields.standfirst: Wreck of world war two plane uncovered in Iceland
fields.trailText: For 60 years, the four RAF airmen were entombed 3,000ft up on a glacier in northern Iceland. Now their relatives are to see the four laid to rest with full military honours.
fields.body:
For 60 years, the four RAF airmen were entombed 3,000ft up on a glacier in northern Iceland. Now their relatives are to see the four laid to rest with full military honours.

Their plane, a Fairey Battle, crashed in 1941, and its wreck had lain buried under ice and snow until last year when the ice melted as a result of global warming. An RAF mountain rescue team is to fly out and recover the bodies for burial, with headstones given by the Commonwealth war graves commission, in a service at Reykjavik's military cemetery on August 27, 60 years to the day after the plane and its squadron arrived in Iceland during the second world war to provide anti-invasion cover.

The RAF has also traced the families of the four, and will fly them to the ceremony.

It will conclude a remarkable detective feat by Horour Geirsson, an Icelandic historian who rediscovered the wreckage last year.

The aircraft was one of 18 that arrived from France, following the Dunkirk evacuation, in August 1940. In May 1941 it was flown by Flying Officer Arthur Round, 26 and a New Zealander, accompanied by Flight Sergeant Reginald Hopkins, 21, to collect Pilot Officer Henry Talbot, 24, and Flight Sergeant Keith Garret, 22, who had been recuperating aboard a hospital ship moored at Akureyri in north Iceland following a road accident.

Shortly after taking off in heavy cloud on its return journey, the plane struck the glacier in the remote mountain region.

A week later British servicemen, accompanied by an Anglican and a Catholic priest, climbed to the crash site and found the bodies and wreckage. A short service was held and a wooden cross was erected, before the group were forced back by deteriorating weather.

Snow and ice soon covered the wreck and, after British forces had departed, its location became a mystery.

Mr Geirsson, who works at Akureyri museum and is a member of the Iceland Historical Aviation Society, became fascinated after hearing rumours in 1980. He made more than a dozen trips to the area, and, without realising it, walked over the wreckage on several occasions.

Finally, a friend researching at the Public Record Office in London came across a report by the search party, complete with map grid references. Then the warmest Icelandic summer for 30 years stripped away years of snow and ice.

"Last August we went up again, literally heading for a cross marked on a map," Mr Geirsson said yesterday. "We were shocked to find wreckage, small and large human remains, and personal possessions, all perfectly preserved. There were toothbrushes, a wallet with Icelandic money in it, and we could even read the name of a man written on the collar of an RAF shirt.

"Although I had been looking for it for so long, there was no feeling of gladness when we finally found the plane."

Some remains and small parts of the wreckage were removed by an Icelandic coastguard helicopter and the British embassy in Reykjavik was informed.

This month, the RAF decided to mount an expedition to recover more remains and to survey the site for a full excavation. Large parts of the plane, including the cockpit, are still under the ice, though Mr Geirson hopes eventually to salvage them.

Led by Squadron Leader Nick Barr, of RAF Kinloss in Morayshire, the team of six will fly to Iceland on August 18. Squadron Leader Barr said yesterday: "Whether people died today or 60 years ago, it is still our duty to try to bring them back to where they can be laid to rest."

His six man team would have an RAF Sea King helicopter to visit the crash site, though if the weather is bad they will have to go by foot and stay in tents for five days in temperatures of 10C below at night. "We will then take the remains down to Reykjavik for a memorial service with next of kin present on August 27, 60 years to the day when Fairey Battles first landed in Iceland."

The find has delighted surviving friends and relatives. Speaking from Palmerston North in New Zealand, Clive Round, nephew of Flying Officer Round, said yesterday that his uncle's parents, David and Mary, had mourned for the rest of their lives at not being able to bury their son.

"I am amazed they have found the remains of the four after all this time. I remember him going away on a boat, I must have been six or seven at the time. He played the piano accordion ... Now is the Hour."

Finally, a friend researching at the Public Record Office in London came across a report by the search party, complete with map grid references. Then the warmest Icelandic summer for 30 years stripped away years of snow and ice. "Last August we went up again, literally heading for a cross marked on a map," Mr Geirsson said yesterday. "We were shocked to find wreckage, small and large human remains, and personal possessions, all perfectly preserved. There were toothbrushes, a wallet with Icelandic money in it, and we could even read the name of a man written on the collar of an RAF shirt. "Although I had been looking for it for so long, there was no feeling of gladness when we finally found the plane." Some remains and small parts of the wreckage were removed by an Icelandic coastguard helicopter and the British embassy in Reykjavik was informed. This month, the RAF decided to mount an expedition to recover more remains and to survey the site for a full excavation. Large parts of the plane, including the cockpit, are still under the ice, though Mr Geirson hopes eventually to salvage them. Led by Squadron Leader Nick Barr, of RAF Kinloss in Morayshire, the team of six will fly to Iceland on August 18. Squadron Leader Barr said yesterday: "Whether people died today or 60 years ago, it is still our duty to try to bring them back to where they can be laid to rest." His six man team would have an RAF Sea King helicopter to visit the crash site, though if the weather is bad they will have to go by foot and stay in tents for five days in temperatures of 10C below at night. "We will then take the remains down to Reykjavik for a memorial service with next of kin present on August 27, 60 years to the day when Fairey Battles first landed in Iceland." The find has delighted surviving friends and relatives. Speaking from Palmerston North in New Zealand, Clive Round, nephew of Flying Officer Round, said yesterday that his uncle's parents, David and Mary, had mourned for the rest of their lives at not being able to bury their son. "I am amazed they have found the remains of the four after all this time. I remember him going away on a boat, I must have been six or seven at the time. He played the piano accordion ... Now is the Hour."

webTitle: Brewery 'leaned on Tory MP to stand down'

fields.headline: Brewery 'leaned on Tory MP to stand down'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Conservative party officials tried to broker a deal to persuade a disgraced MP to stand down at the 1997 general election under pressure from a former corporate donor, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Conservative party officials tried to broker a deal to persuade a disgraced MP to stand down at the 1997 general election under pressure from a former corporate donor, a court heard yesterday.

Rod Richards, who had been forced to quit as junior Welsh Office minister following allegations of an extra-marital affair which profoundly embarrassed John Major in 1996, was allegedly invited not to stand in his constituency in return for Whitbread writing off an £89,900 debt.

Mr Richards owed around £200,000 to Whitbread and other creditors including Barclays and Lloyds after he borrowed money to refurbish the Ynyscedwyn Arms pub, in Ystradgynlais, near Swansea Valley.

It would have been to the Tories' advantage, with Labour campaigning vigorously on sleaze, to have Mr Richards stand down in one of their safest Welsh seats, Clwyd North West.

The alleged deal was revealed in a witness statement from Sir Anthony Garrett, Tory campaigns manager in 1997, to a high court hearing yesterday where Mr Richards's main creditor, Whitbread, was seeking to have him declared bankrupt.

Mr Richards, who lost his Commons seat in the 1997 Tory wipeout but is now a Welsh assembly member, was fighting to save his political career as bankrupts cannot hold public office.

His counsel, Roxanne Ismail, told the court the suggestion that he stand down came from then party chairman Brian Mawhinney.

"There was a meeting in February 1997, Mr Richards was then an MP, to discuss the indebtedness of Mr Richards to Whitbread. The Conservative party was concerned about adverse publicity.

"Sir Anthony Garrett said that Brian Mawhinney said it had been indicated to him that Whitbread was prepared to write off the debt if Mr Richards agreed not to contest his seat at the next general election."

She added: "This suggests the biggest single creditor had another motive in pressing for bankruptcy."

The bankruptcy petition was brought after Mr Richards defaulted on a voluntary agreement to repay a percentage of his debts over five years.

He failed to make a £7,500 payment last December as he had to fund his defence against a charge of assaulting a young woman, Cassandra Melvin. Mr Richards, 53, was cleared of that charge in June.

The bankruptcy registrar William James yesterday dismissed the petition, saying Mr Richards, although late, had paid the overdue instalment. Making him bankrupt "will certainly destroy his political career and, more importantly, will seriously impair his ability to earn a living".

Mr Richards still faces a bill for half the costs of the hearing and has to pay the interest his creditors lost out on because of his late payment.

He said after the hearing: "The brewery boys have got a bloody nose. How refreshing - how Heineken." He added he had felt "numb and stunned" by the suggestion he stand down.

A Whitbread spokesman denied any approach had been made. "The suggestion that Whitbread would try to influence anyone whether or not to stand for public office is nonsense. Whitbread make no donations to political parties. That was true in 1997."

The company stopped donating to the Conservatives in 1994 in protest at an increase in alcohol duty.

Mr Richards, who resigned as Tory leader in the Welsh assembly to fight the assault charge, plans to resume his political career. But he may still be referred to the party's ethics committee, which has the power to expel him.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Tesco bolsters dominance

Tesco continues to consolidate its number one position in the £96bn grocery market, but its sales growth is slowing, according to two surveys.

Figures from the Institute of Grocery Distribution, based on food sales, showed Tesco increased its market share to a record 15.6% in the 12 months to December 1999, from 15.2% the previous year.

A study by market researcher Taylor Nelson Sofres based on a sample of shopping patterns showed Tesco's sales growth to be slowing.

Egg hatches 1,500 jobs

Internet bank Egg is to create 1,500 jobs by building a new call centre in Derby, the group said yesterday. Egg, which already has a call centre in Derby and another in Dudley near Birmingham, expects the new one to operating by April.

Amvescap upbeat

Amvescap, the fund management group once cited as a potential bidder for Perpetual, is seeking out expansionary opportunities in continental Europe.

Robert McCullough, chief financial officer, said that continental Europe was where the group, which yesterday reported a 75% rise in pre-tax profits to £255.6m, was expecting to see most scope for growth in the coming five years.

Pan-European Deutsche

Deutsche Bank, which failed to merge with German rival Dresdner Bank earlier this year, is to push out its Bank 24 retail operation across Europe.

It wants to use the Deutsche Bank 24 brand for retail and private banking in Italy, Spain, France, Portugal, Belgium and Poland, and to have 10.5m customers and workforce of 21,000. The bank announced yesterday it more than doubled its net income to €3.7bn (£2.2bn), the best first half results in its history.

Soros buys 600 buildings in UK

Billionaire financier George Soros yesterday became one of Britain's largest property owners with the successful acquisition of 600 government buildings by his Mapeley consortium. Inland Revenue announced yesterday it had awarded Mapeley the contract to own and manage the buildings, providing government departments housed in those buildings with serviced accommodation.

Wickes posts surge in profits

Wickes, the DIY retailer, yesterday reported a 26% increase in pre-tax profits which it said justified all claims it made during a successful defence against a £327m hostile bid from Focus-Do-It-All. Chief executive Bill Grimsey said further consolidation in the sector was inevitable.

fields.headline: Telewest misses target
fields.trailText: Cable television and telephony business Telewest yesterday conceded it would miss its targets for the roll-out of digital TV services by up to three months, prompting a further 11% fall in its shares.
fields.body:
Cable television and telephony business Telewest yesterday conceded it would miss its targets for the roll-out of digital TV services by up to three months, prompting a further 11% fall in its shares.

The company flagged its problems almost two weeks ago. At the time Telewest said it had suspended marketing of its digital service due to the shortage of a component in the set top boxes needed to unscramble the signal.

The shares, which fell 19p to 154.5p at the session close have now slumped 40% since the original announcement. Telewest chief executive Adam Singer said the company would be able to resume marketing the service across the country by the beginning of October.

"It's a delay, it's a pain, it's a bore but it's like a train which is 20 minutes late. It's late - it hasn't been cancelled," he said. "We have had the same problem as anyone using the same technology worldwide, including NTL and mobile phone operators."

The company had hoped to get 500,000 digital customers by year-end but has now put that target back to the first quarter of 2001. Telewest's problems have been thrown into sharp relief by a strong performance from BSkyB which recently announced that it had added 1m subscribers last year. Some 80% of BSkyB's 4.5m strong customer base is now receiving digital services.

Telewest currently has 223,000 digital customers in a total TV subscriber base of 1.1m which Mr Singer said put the company 18 months behind BSkyB.

Telewest reported a 35% increase in revenues to £514m for the six months to July.That figure was flattered by the merger with content provider Flextech. The underlying figure was 15% higher. Pre-tax losses were deepened slightly to £296m.

webTitle: Autonomy makes case for fast growth

fields.headline: Seize the day
fields.standfirst:
Autonomy makes case for fast growth
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy yesterday underlined its position as one of Britain's fastest growing technology companies by once again beating analyst growth forecasts.
fields.body:
Autonomy yesterday underlined its position as one of Britain's fastest growing technology companies by once again beating analyst growth forecasts. Revenues for the three months to June 30 jumped 51% compared with the previous quarter to $14.6m (£9.7m), while pre-tax profits soared from $440,000 to $5.1m. Margins slipped slightly from 93% to 90%. PepsiCo, Deutsche Bank and Compaq Computers were among new clients won during that period.

Chief executive Mike Lynch (pictured above) warned that Autonomy could not afford to slow. "This market is all about speed of opportunity, and the sort of technological transformation we are witnessing is only going to happen once."

The Nasdaq and Easdaq-listed firm produces software that automatically makes sense of unstructured data. It recently bought Cambridge-based voice recognition firm SoftSound. Analysts believe further acquisitions are likely after the appointment of Deutsche Bank financier Vatche Kalaidjian as new business development manager.

webTitle: Diversity will determine battle of the banks

fields.headline: Diversity will determine battle of the banks
fields.standfirst: Not everyone will be in the money
fields.trailText: At the end of the banks' half-yearly reporting season one thing is very clear: we are at that point in the cycle where profits are churned seemingly without trying and yet the chances to burn money needlessly have yet to show themselves. But before some lazy pundit calls for a raising of the "rip-off" placard, the detail of the numbers which have been rolling out over the past fortnight needs to be examined.
fields.body:
At the end of the banks' half-yearly reporting season one thing is very clear: we are at that point in the cycle where profits are churned seemingly without trying and yet the chances to burn money needlessly have yet to show themselves. But before some lazy pundit calls for a raising of the "rip-off" placard, the detail of the numbers which have been rolling out over the past fortnight needs to be examined.

It is not a pretty sight, particularly in the business of selling wannabe homeowners their loans. The competition is astonishingly fierce, which is why we have had veiled warnings from the likes of Abbey National and Halifax that net interest margins - the crucial gauge of profitability - are shrinking.

Not surprisingly, these mortgage banks are now threatening to lash out at the old big clearers. But their chances of success remain unclear. Halifax's main weapon to attack current accounts and the small business market - the Intelligent Finance telephone-cum-internet bank - has yet to start, while Abbey National's cyber-proposition, Cahoot, has only just been booted up.

The incumbents in these markets have the size and scale to fight back. And from here on out the betting is that those banks with the greatest diversity of business - the likes of Royal Bank now it owns NatWest and Barclays - are the ones that will be favoured by a cautious stock market.

Woolwich, Alliance & Leicester and their like will attract speculative money for as long as they remain independent. But in times of increasing competition the resilience that comes through the control of all sorts of niche business areas is what the wider investment community will be looking for. Diversity will also be attractive in a geographical sense - the sort of business run by HSBC, which is proving to be a veritable money making machine. Stand by for a sector shake-out this autumn.

Booth truth

If the camera never lies, it is probably as true that company accounts never quite tell the whole truth. So it has proved with Photo-Me International, the photo booth company which has been threatening to swamp the country's railway stations with internet-enabled e-booths.

A year ago it bought out a minority in terest in a Japanese associate, Nippon Auto-Photo, for £25m and declared that the transaction would "make a positive contribution to group earnings with immediate effect".

It certainly would, since Photo-Me was paying for the acquisition mainly in old photo booths and, as it now turns out, planned to book the difference between the asset value of the booths and the perceived value of the stake in Nippon Auto-Photo to its profits. Yesterday, the company's auditors blew the whistle on this dandy piece of accounting. Some £10.4m has been sliced out of the April 30 year-end figures, which were due to be published on Monday, and the £32m of profits the market was expecting will not now be met.

The company, which became an e-bubble favourite early this year, was screaming "technicality" yesterday, pointing out that its cash position is not affected by any of this. It has a great core business, it says, which it is developing for the digital age. If Nippon Auto-Photo had been quoted in Japan, the payment method and the booking of exceptional profits would not have been questioned by the auditors. But the market took a wholly non-technical view of the matter yesterday, marking the shares - which stood at the heady level of 436p seven months ago - 49p lower to 120p.

The reason for this is simple: over the past 12 months, Photo-Me's directors have sold literally tens of millions of pounds worth of stock. Chief executive Serge Crasnianski alone raised £28m of cash in January, ostensibly to pay for the cost of moving from France to Britain. Nobody cared too much when every new economy play on the London market was headed for the moon.

Now that that is no longer the case, more old-fashioned investment yardsticks are being used to assess companies. Fundamental things, like trust.

Small business

As the sharp and richly deserved sell-off in telecoms upstart Thus continued yesterday, it was perhaps inevitable that Energis, another "new telco" with rather broader vision, was caught up in the rush by investors to get out of the new economy.

So no one seemed to notice a tiny deal yesterday to set up a joint venture with a software firm called Graham Technology, with a view to offering digital TV services to business customers.

The idea seems sensible enough, helping firms of all shapes and sizes to get their e-commerce structures right, integrating sales and marketing online.

But the real eye-catching aspect of this venture, hatched in a sector where everyone is so used to multi-billion-pound deals, is the price tag: £3m.

webTitle: Added value in the dance capital

fields.headline: Added value in the dance capital
fields.standfirst:
In the mix
Island clubbers get the message
fields.trailText: Sun, sea and sex have made Ibiza one of the summer's most popular destinations but it is the cavernous nightclubs which have defined the island as the dance capital of Europe.
fields.body:
Sun, sea and sex have made Ibiza one of the summer's most popular destinations but it is the cavernous nightclubs which have defined the island as the dance capital of Europe.

Themed nights like Manumission at the hanger-size Privilege Club have come to epitomise Ibizan clubbing. Up to 8,000 people are attracted to sweltering evenings with top-earning DJs, a pool, fire eaters, a fake rainforest and, until recently, a live sex show.

If it is a Sunday, hardened clubbers head to Space , which opens at 8am and closes at six the following morning.

A night out is not cheap. Getting into the Ministry of Sound night at the Pacha costs £36; one spirit and mixer will set you back £8; a 250ml bottle of water costs £4. To sit down at a VIP table in a roped-off area overlooking the dance floor costs £500.

The club has a 4,000-person capacity but over the course of the evening 5,000 will come through the door. Around 75% will pay an entrance free; the rest will be VIPs or business associates. A unspecified chunk of the takings goes to a promoter such as Ministry.

But Ministry will make a small loss on its activities out in Ibiza this summer, according to the local club owners. The promoter declined to be interviewed but it is understood that the pay-off comes in future sales of Ministry-branded Ibiza compilation CDs.

It sells around 1m Ibiza albums a year, making around £5 a disc, so turning a 12-week stay in Ibiza into £5m in profit.

"Nightclubs are increasingly becoming living billboards for their brands," says Danny Whittel, operations manager for Pacha and a Falklands war veteran from Stoke-on-Trent. "We are looking to move into new business areas and have dozens of dot.coms and drinks brands asking to sponsor our events."

Pacha, like all the major club venues in Ibiza, is Spanish-owned. The group was established in Barcelona by the Urgell family and there are now 32 Pachas in the world, many franchised outlets.

Mr Whittel is trying to draw the venues closer together to increase their bargaining power with DJs by offering them block bookings at several events and to get the Pacha brand into new areas.

A record label, Pacha Recordings, was launched at the beginning of the summer and sold 30,000 CDs in three weeks. It has three merchandising shops in Ibiza and a beach bar. Worldpop , the cross-media company, is a corporate sponsor.

In October an 800-capacity Pacha club opens in the West End of London , and Mr Whittel plans a Pacha travel agency offering city breaks and entry to local clubs. Talks are under way with the cable television company Telewest about a weekly TV programme based on "clubbing lifestyle", and fashion designer Jean-Paul Gaultier has expressed interest in designing a range of Pacha-branded clothing.

Themed nights like Manumission at the hanger-size Privilege Club have come to epitomise Ibizan clubbing. Up to 8,000 people are attracted to sweltering evenings with top-earning DJs, a pool, fire eaters, a fake rainforest and, until recently, a live sex show. If it is a Sunday, hardened clubbers head to Space , which opens at 8am and closes at six the following morning. A night out is not cheap. Getting into the Ministry of Sound night at the Pacha costs £36; one spirit and mixer will set you back £8; a 250ml bottle of water costs £4. To sit down at a VIP table in a roped-off area overlooking the dance floor costs £500. The club has a 4,000-person capacity but over the course of the evening 5,000 will come through the door. Around 75% will pay an entrance free; the rest will be VIPs or business associates. A unspecified chunk of the takings goes to a promoter such as Ministry. But Ministry will make a small loss on its activities out in Ibiza this summer, according to the local club owners. The promoter declined to be interviewed but it is understood that the pay-off comes in future sales of Ministry-branded Ibiza compilation CDs. It sells around 1m Ibiza albums a year, making around £5 a disc, so turning a 12-week stay in Ibiza into £5m in profit. "Nightclubs are increasingly becoming living billboards for their brands," says Danny Whittel, operations manager for Pacha and a Falklands war veteran from Stoke-on-Trent. "We are looking to move into new business areas and have dozens of dot.coms and drinks brands asking to sponsor our events." Pacha, like all the major club venues in Ibiza, is Spanish-owned. The group was established in Barcelona by the Urgell family and there are now 32 Pachas in the world, many franchised outlets. Mr Whittel is trying to draw the venues closer together to increase their bargaining power with DJs by offering them block bookings at several events and to get the Pacha brand into new areas. A record label, Pacha Recordings, was launched at the beginning of the summer and sold 30,000 CDs in three weeks. It has three merchandising shops in Ibiza and a beach bar. Worldpop , the cross-media company, is a corporate sponsor. In October an 800-capacity Pacha club opens in the West End of London , and Mr Whittel plans a Pacha travel agency offering city breaks and entry to local clubs. Talks are under way with the cable television company Telewest about a weekly TV programme based on "clubbing lifestyle", and fashion designer Jean-Paul Gaultier has expressed interest in designing a range of Pacha-branded clothing.

webTitle: Utilities groups break new ground with exchange deal

fields.headline: Utilities groups break new ground with exchange deal
fields.trailText: United Utilities and TXU Europe, owners of Eastern Energy, yesterday signalled a radical shake-out of the British utilities market in a deal to exchange key parts of their electricity, gas and water businesses.
fields.body:
United Utilities and TXU Europe, owners of Eastern Energy, yesterday signalled a radical shake-out of the British utilities market in a deal to exchange key parts of their electricity, gas and water businesses.

Dallas-based TXU is paying £310m in cash for United's Norweb Energi electricity and gas supply business, taking on an extra 2.2m customers to become Britain's second-largest energy retailer. Centrica (British Gas) has 5.6m accounts.

But TXU also agreed to acquire Norweb's power purchase agreements - forward purchasing of energy at a fixed price. John Roberts, United's chief executive, said these were conservatively worth £176m, perhaps as much as £250m, and boosted the overall value of the deal to around £500m.

"This is more than just a sale," Mr Roberts said, outlining a seven-year deal worth £650m with TXU for United to manage its customer services operation, including billing, through its Vertex business - the first outsourcing deal of its kind in Britain.

Vertex, which is taking on Eastern's 1,250 customer services staff from September 1, will manage the accounts of its partner's 5.6m customers and a further 1.3m accounts if Western Power wins the bidding battle for Welsh multi-utility Hyder.

Mr Roberts said the two groups had created a marketing alliance between their respective energy and water businesses. Under the five-year exclusive arrangement United's North-west Water will be offered as part of a utility package to customers in Eastern's region while a similar package will be available in north-west England, including parts of the region served by Manweb. "This positions us very well for the opening up of competition in the water market," Mr Roberts said. United is one of several utilities considering splitting the assets of its water business from operational management but sees its future growth in running water operations in several regions. It plans to float its telecoms business next year.

The energy supply market is likely to be dominated by five or six groups providing electricity and gas for 4m-5m customers each. British Gas, Scottish Power, Innogy (National Power), PowerGen, France's EdF and now Eastern are competing for this market. "We can start to roll out our offer on a national basis," Eastern said.

TXU, which generates around 12% of Britain's electricity, expanded on to the continent by acquiring a multi-utility business in Kiel, Germany, with 1m customers, believes that future growth will come from offering innovative products, rather than just "bundling" services such as energy, telecoms and water.

Its Stay Warm service offers poorer homes guaranteed supplies at a fixed price regardless of consumption.

fields.headline: Island clubbers get the message
fields.standfirst:
British tourists enjoy cheap nights out with their mobile phones
Added value in the dance capital
In the mix
fields.trailText: It is 8pm on Saturday and the crowds of revellers are already out in force ready for an evening of fun in the West End of San Antonio, Ibiza's notorious party capital.
fields.body:
It is 8pm on Saturday and the crowds of revellers are already out in force ready for an evening of fun in the West End of San Antonio, Ibiza's notorious party capital.

A group of lads in football shirts and plastic fake breasts stumble down one of the side streets, cans of Tetley's in hand, searching for the nearest pub. Six teenage girls in tiny skirts and lots of make-up totter behind them giggling. On the beach a more mellow bunch has gathered in front of the Cafe del Mar to join in the nightly Ibizan ritual of watching the sun set.

The mood is relaxed, the music chilled, the people fashion conscious. As soon as the sun disappears the atmosphere of calm is punctured by a succession of electronic beeping tones. The sounds signal the arrival en masse of a series of text messages on mobile phones.

They might contain news of which DJs are playing where on the island, a message from an advertiser, like Durex, reminding revellers to take their condoms with them, an offer of cheap flights from budget airline Go or, most importantly, the chance to gain free entry to one of the island's superclubs.

This is marketing Ibiza 2000 style, aimed direct at the hundreds of thousands of British clubbers who visit the island each summer to "large it".

Up to a million British tourists will travel to the island (which has a permanent population of 80,000) this summer. It is the clubbers, typically aged 16-32 and with above average spending power, whose attention and money the clubs and consumer brands are out to capture.

Peter Powell, chairman of London-based Worldpop, the cross-media music company behind the text messaging, says: "Dance music is unquestionably the aspirational music genre for young people, and Ibiza is possibly the biggest dance music event in the world. Ibiza is not just a single weekend, it is a 12-week event, and millions of people migrate towards it. The young people who travel here are very valuable to advertisers, and text messaging is a very efficient way of targeting them."

British club operators such as Cream in Liverpool and London's Ministry of Sound take up "residence" in Ibiza each summer, running lavish club nights hosted by top DJs and attracting up to 10,000 revellers a time.

This weekend is Radio One's Ibiza 2000 weekend, when its DJs will broadcast live from the island. Chrysalis Group is spending £250,000 promoting its Galaxy Radio brand on the island. Rival dance radio station Kiss also has a presence, while media group Emap has set up its own radio station for the summer. Before Worldpop set up camp on the island this summer the phrase "e-commerce" was more usually associated with the island's burgeoning trade in the drug ecstasy.

The Ibiza Mobile Textmessaging Service is gathering pace as the Spanish authorities crack down on paper flyers traditionally used to advertise club nights. Residents are angry at the litter they cause.

Around 3,000 holidaymakers have signed up to the Mobile Ibiza service by registering at one of Worldpop's three internet cafes on the island. They receive two to four text messages a day, ostensibly from top DJ Pete Tong.

The most popular offers are free club entries. The entrance fee of £20-£40 prices the lager louts out of the market. But, by phoning a number at the bottom of the message, which costs around 25p per minute, the first few dozen clubbers to respond stand a good chance of getting in free that night.They only need to show the message to the club's doorman as proof. Around 50% of those who receive messages call the number, according to Simeon Berends, who creates the content for Worldpop and its technology partner, Mobile Channel Network.

"We were a little apprehensive when we first started the service because we weren't certain if it would catch on, but in the last few weeks it has gone ballistic," he said. "There are more than 3,000 clubbers on our database now, and the messages are much more effective than flyers. You choose to take messages. And if it saves you £35 getting into a club it's a service worth having."

Advertisers can send messages at three different stages: before the individual goes on holiday; while they are on the island; or when they return. The charge is between 20p and 30p per message per person. So, for around £650 plus VAT a company can put a message of up to 160 characters straight into the pockets of 2,500 people.

City institutions 3i, Amadeus Capital Partners and Chase Capital partners liked the Worldpop strategy - devised with Merrill Lynch and Spectrum Consulting - so they have become investors.

As the next generation of mobile phones is introduced and personalisation technology improves, Worldpop will be able to send better targeted messages, reflecting users' music tastes and their whereabouts on the island, according to Mr Berends. If one club is sold out and another half-empty, a message could offer half-price entry to anyone who turns up to the quieter club within the hour.

British software company Autonomy is even working on "dating technology", which will allow a user to programme his or her mobile phone with personal details (age, height, star sign, musical preferences) and their ideal partner. Autonomy software will send them a message, if someone matching that description is drinking elsewhere in the bar.

Worldpop's existing service, although a little rudimentary, is so popular that it will be used for the UK tours of pop band Steps and former Spice Girl Mel C this autumn.

Advertisers on the Mobile Ibiza service use electronic text messages with other more traditional marketing techniques. Condom brand Durex is capitalising on Ibiza's image as an island of sin, by having its "Freedom with Durex" blue double-decker bus driving around the island for three months. "We're encouraging people to look after themselves and their partner, and take home nothing more serious than great holiday memories," said Durex's John Flaherty. Kodak also has billboard presence on the island and in UK airports, while MTV recently put on an open-air concert for an estimated 10,000 people on the island.

Record store HMV and nightclub group Ministry of Sound both publish free weekly Ibiza magazines focused on the music, lifestyle and drug culture. HMV says it has around 30 different Ibiza 2000 compilation CDs on sale.

Consumer products group Unilever believes Ibiza is such an important bellwether of youth culture and emerging consumer trends that its "youth board" is being dispatched to the island in September on a fact-finding trip. The team, made up of 15 of the group's "coolest" rising stars in their late 20s and early 30s, are sent to immerse themselves in youth culture and discover the latest on "style leaders". They will report back to headquarters and ensure that the companies' brands are targeted accordingly.

Unilever executives say it is an important exercise. Patrick Cairns, brand director for Lynx deodorants, part of Unilever subsidiary Elida Fabergé, said: "It's absolutely vital and gives us a real competitive edge. Culturally it has done a lot for the company, giving it a slightly funkier edge than you might otherwise expect from a large company like Unilever."

The youth board's arrival in Ibiza coincides with Phoenix, a big Unilever funded outdoor festival to promote the new Lynx scent Phoenix. A multi-million pound pan-European promotion has been running for almost one year on the side of Lynx spray cans, and 2,500 competition winners from eight countries will be flown out to attend the event.

"It is a very powerful way of promoting the Lynx brand," Mr Cairns explained. "It shows we understand our customers, highlights the kudos of the brand and enables us to further our understanding of youth culture."

The influx of British business and revellers has not been without its problems. Locals complain about the noise and pollution. Drug use is widespread. Fights and stabbings are common in San Antonio, although tour companies say it is no different to any large British town on a weekend.

Two years ago, the British vice consul on the island quit in protest at the "degenerate" behaviour of British tourists. Ibiza is not the laid-back idyll that it was 13 years ago, when the first wide-eyed British DJs arrived on the island. The economy has enjoyed a boom, with low unemployment and high house prices, particularly for hilltop villas. The social price of economic growth has been significant, and is the subject of much local debate.

webTitle: TI strives to bridge value gap

fields.headline: TI strives to bridge value gap
fields.trailText: TI, the engineering group, is considering a range of options - including the radical one of going private - in order to correct the "mismatch" between its share price and its real value, Sir Christopher Lewinton, its chairman, confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
TI, the engineering group, is considering a range of options - including the radical one of going private - in order to correct the "mismatch" between its share price and its real value, Sir Christopher Lewinton, its chairman, confirmed yesterday.

Several British engineering companies, worried by their stock market ratings, are examining the private option and Sir Christopher, 68, is known to want to bequeath a healthier valuation when he quits the group, probably at the age of 70.

"The board remains concerned at the underlying mismatch between the perfor mance of the business and the share price and we are looking at how we can strategically address that problem," he said.

But he added: "We have the great luxury of having a strong business and are under no pressure to go for a quick fix... We do not want to act with unseemly haste."

TI shares, which hit a 12-month peak of 574p, rose 2p to close at 361p in a falling London market.

Some analysts rated the stock a strong buy, with UBS Warburg setting a target price of 550p, as TI posted pre-tax profits for the first half up 12% at £146.5m on sales 35% higher at £1.68bn. Analysts raised the full-year forecast closer to £290m.

Bill Laule, chief executive, said the group would continue to perform strongly, with double-digit growth in profits despite "a few wobbles" in the John Crane process and marine sealant business.

It was performing ahead of the cycle in the aerospace business. The automotive division, which provides fluid brake and power systems, had products on 87 of the top 100 platforms in the world and won $1bn in contracts in the first half.

TI has made £1.5bn of acquisitions in the past two years. Martin Angle, finance director, said growth would come from digesting these, and any further purchases would be relatively small.

webTitle: Brussels seeks car sales market reforms

fields.headline: Brussels seeks car sales market reforms
fields.trailText: The European car sales market is set for revolutionary change, according to a confidential report from the European Commission's competition authorities assailing manufacturers for their exclusive dealerships and paving the way for supermarkets to enter the market.
fields.body:
The European car sales market is set for revolutionary change, according to a confidential report from the European Commission's competition authorities assailing manufacturers for their exclusive dealerships and paving the way for supermarkets to enter the market.

The report, according to today's Economist, demolishes the case for the present "block exemption" from anti-monopoly investigation, drawing 36 conclusions from an evaluation of the current market that point to its abolition in 2002.

The findings of the Brussels competition directorate come after this week's order by the British government to impose a series of measures, including the granting of the same discounts previously only enjoyed by company and fleet buyers, to force down the average cost of a car to the consumer by £1,100.

Car companies, the Economist says, justify block exemption on the grounds that cars need a specialised after-sales service, but the commission's report says that equally specialised products such as computers, tractors and medical equipment are sold in a less restrictive fashion.

Brussels officials say the case for tying the sales of new cars and after-sales service "has lost its justification" since 1995, the last time the EU reviewed the issue, and dealers should be free either to sell or service new cars, whichever is the more profitable.

Condemning the inability of consumers to find cheaper spares because of manufacturers' desire to protect their margins, they conclude that the industry has prevented the creation of a genuine single market for cars in the EU. The Economist, pointing to recent fines against Volkswagen for making it hard for Germans to buy its cars in Italy, says similar penalties will be levied against Opel and Mercedes.

Brussels officials, it adds, hope that the internet will help break the stranglehold manufacturers retain on the market and that other newcomers will enter it if and when the block exemption is lifted.

fields.headline: I can't seem to find an honest man. Does such a thing still exist?
fields.standfirst: Next week: According to third parties, my former friends are "scared by and unable to deal with" my disability
fields.trailText: I am in my mid-40s and have recently started dating again after my divorce. So far I have been out with four men and have been surprised to discover that three of them were already in relationships. Each of these men slept with the woman in question and went out socially with them, but didn't consider them partners. Although I was unaware of the situation when they asked me out they did not conceal this information. In fact, one of them actually brought his friend on our date. When I expressed my surprise that he had a partner, he said that she was just a friend. To test this I kissed him passionately at the end of the date and gathered from his friend's reaction that she felt differently.
fields.body:
I am in my mid-40s and have recently started dating again after my divorce. So far I have been out with four men and have been surprised to discover that three of them were already in relationships. Each of these men slept with the woman in question and went out socially with them, but didn't consider them partners. Although I was unaware of the situation when they asked me out they did not conceal this information. In fact, one of them actually brought his friend on our date. When I expressed my surprise that he had a partner, he said that she was just a friend. To test this I kissed him passionately at the end of the date and gathered from his friend's reaction that she felt differently.

What I fail to understand is why women put up with this type of behaviour. Are they lonely? Are they just desperate? Or is this type of semi-commitment the only relationship men are prepared to offer nowadays? If this is all that is on offer, how does one react? I didn't meet any of these men through adverts or dating agencies.

Patience is the key

You fail to mention one rather pertinent fact - where you met these men. True, you do say that you did not meet them through adverts or dating agencies, but that leaves a lot of other possibilities. It makes a big difference where you meet people.

It's a reasonable bet that men in their 30s and older who frequent bars and nightclubs tend to be married types in search of excitement. If most of the men you are running into are dogs, then I would suggest you stop looking in kennels.

In my own office, the men can fairly be divided into the "puritans", who prefer to devote their time to one partner in the hopes of developing a full and satisfying relationship, and the "cavaliers", who have a, shall we say, more traditional view of relationships between men and women. The "cavaliers" take the view that once they have discharged their responsibilities to their partners, ie they have provided them with a home, children, money, etc, they are entitled to look for fun elsewhere. I have been on nights out where, amusingly, I was the only bloke not to have to take his wedding ring off and conceal it, mainly because I was the only single man in the party.

I'm not entirely sure where the myth developed that all women are victims and all men are bastards. It has been my experience that there is enough blame to be apportioned for us all to enjoy a slice of it. You should not be so hard on your own gender - being alone can be very hard and we are all guilty of occasional lapses of judgment. My advice would be to hang in there and keep looking. Four men isn't a lot. It really is a numbers game - the more men you date, the more likely you are to meet someone suitable. You should certainly lighten up a little.
N Cho, London

Stand up for yourself

As a twentysomething man, I am amazed at the low self-esteem that some older women have, and the cynicism of some older men. These women are made to feel lucky to have their (insecure) partner. This man is feeding his ego at the expense of others. You should not be "reacting", you should be actively deciding what you require. Set your own standards. Aim high for a man deserving of your attentions and don't sell yourself short.
Name and address witheld

A cautionary tale

In 1997, I began a relationship with a man I had known socially for four years, quite oblivious to his predilection for promiscuity. He subsequently called a halt to our brief relationship with an excuse about being hurt from previous entanglements, but resumed it five months later. He forced me to have unprotected sex with him after seven months together on the grounds that our relationship was sufficiently lengthy and dependable for such intimacy.

Four months later he stood me up on New Year's Eve and the following morning I found him in his house with another woman. She said she was just "having fun". He then confessed that not only had he had innumerable one-night stands throughout our relationship, he had also made an American woman pregnant. I later found out that this woman was HIV positive.

He said that she didn't care about him sleeping with other women "as long as she didn't know about it". He begged me to take him back with a sob story about how he had been abandoned at birth and adopted and how a former girlfriend had "trained" him in the ways of infidelity. At this time there was a strong possibility that I was pregnant by him so I reluctantly accepted him back, hoping that his promises of fidelity were true and that he would finally grow up. Some hope. When he later told me that he was sleeping around again I began to suffer panic attacks. My problem, he said, was that I had no empathy with other women; I was a nice person, well turned out, with far too many moral scruples and too intelligent; we had too much in common; I had too many interests. Some of his friends, he admitted with dis-belief, even thought I was beautiful.

I have been in a state of constant depression, not least because it has become clear to me that it is I who am a social pariah, not he. I have no idea why this is the case and I think you should be aware that by involving yourself with someone who has no concept of morality or scruples you are plunging yourself into a potentially ruinous abyss.

I truly had no idea that there were men or women who lived like this until my own life was destroyed by this man. You should consider yourself fortunate that the men you have encountered have been prepared to reveal as much about their conduct as they have. I have no expectation of ever meeting a remotely trust-worthy man. My ex-boyfriend is still sleeping with a number of women who are keen to keep his company in the hope that they might land a part in some TV show that he is involved in.

To say that the goalposts have shifted in male-female relations is an understatement. It is apparently much more acceptable these days to be promiscuous and selfish than to be a decent, moral, faithful, loving person. I do not profess to understand why.

You have been warned.
Name and address withheld

A few years ago, at the age of 43, I was diagnosed with a progressive neuro-muscular condition. This was a huge shock, and I have found it very painful to accept the new physical limitations of my life.

Unable to work full time in my previous occupation, I have recently started voluntary work, and hope that eventually I will find some new opportunities in life. My partner and family have given me loads of support, but several of my closest friends have withdrawn from my life. According to third parties, my former friends are "scared by and unable to deal with" disability. This is terribly hurtful to me as I supported them through traumas in their lives, and thought our friendship was unbreakable. My partner takes a more pragmatic approach, and says that, if they can't see that I'm still the same person, their friendship is worthless. I miss them terribly though, as I don't have other close female friends, and feel hurt by their rejection. Should I try to "educate" them about disability, or just try to move on?

fields.headline: In the mix
fields.standfirst:
DJs' brand extension
Added value in the dance capital
Island clubbers get the message
fields.trailText: DJs may only just be emerging from behind their decks to push for the sort of public profile usually associated with pop stars, but in earnings terms they are already catching up.
fields.body:
DJs may only just be emerging from behind their decks to push for the sort of public profile usually associated with pop stars, but in earnings terms they are already catching up.

Once merely players of the stars' records, they are fast becoming "brands" in their own right. Radio 1's Pete Tong , Dave Pearce and Judge Jules , along with freelance Paul Oakenfold , are among the highest earning and most powerful DJs. Mr Tong can charge an Ibizan nightclub up to £10,000 for a four-hour set. Clubbers will travel huge distances to hear him play, filling up venues and boosting bar takings.

Record labels view the DJs as a central part of their marketing strategy, and in an attempt to imitate "white label" releases from the US, they give the DJs new dance tracks up to three months before they are made widely available. By playing the "unknown" record they build up a demand among clubbers.

Last summer in Ibiza an unknown track titled Sing It Back, by Moloko , was given to a handful of DJs to play. It became a club anthem, a Tong favourite, and earlier this year demand from clubbers was such that it topped the singles chart in the UK.

DJs make their real killing when they sell their own compilation CDs. Mr Tong's Essential Collection series of compilation CDs has been selling hundreds of thousands of units a year at £15 each - and the Ibiza version is one of the most popular. A large chunk of each unit sale goes straight back to Mr Tong.

Muzik Magazine has estimated that he earns around £500,000 a year when his roles as a talent scout - he signed All Saints to London Records - A&R director and Friday night slot Radio 1 DJ are taken into consideration.

It is the last, part-time role that is the key to his power, and it has been the subject of some controversy. A national radio audience has given him a huge capacity to make or break a record: airplay on Mr Tong's show does not positively guarantee chart success but it certainly does help.

Last year the Conservative culture and media spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, alleged that Mr Tong was using his Radio 1 show to promote his own label. Mr Ainsworth claimed that Mr Tong played a single by Armand Van Helden , on the ffrr label, eight times; went on to sell 400,000 copies and reached number one in the charts. The BBC dismissed the claim, saying that Mr Tong was employed because of his influence on the club scene.
