fields.headline: No: 1692
fields.standfirst: Lord Glenconner
fields.trailText: Lord Glenconner
fields.body:
Age: 73.

Who is he? Formerly Colin Tennant, and probably the most eccentric member of the English aristocracy.

Background: The usual - Eton, Oxford, the Guards, the City. He then joined family firm C Tennant and Sons.

Sounds like a perfectly respectable, thoroughbred old chap if you ask me. Why do you say eccentric? In 1953 he spent a year in Trinidad on the family property. He then sold it and with the proceeds made a small investment of his own.

What was it? A flutter on the stock market? A new sports car? Actually, it was the island of Mustique.

Oh well. We all need to get away once in a while. You're almost certainly not invited. The isle is for A-list celebs only.

Such as? Mick Jagger and David Bowie both built homes there. And Princess Margaret also had a holiday house on the island.

Friends in high places, then? Oh yes. And compromising positions, too.

I don't quite follow. Neither did the princess. In last night's fly-on-the-wall television documentary about Lord Glenconner's colourful life, he was seen showing her his collection of explicit paintings from the Kama Sutra.

Be still my beating heart! That's what Madge would have said if she hadn't been so busy gawping at the naughty pics. "What are they doing?" she asked, innocently. "Well, they are carrying on," replied the Lord, "I think she will be impregnated, don't you?" he teased.

Is Her Royal Highness not familiar with the general order of hanky panky? On the contrary, the blushing princess caused a bit of a royal stink when, back in the 70s, she holidayed on Mustique with her young lover Roddy Llewellyn when still married to Lord Snowdon, so her naivety comes as something of a surprise.

Perhaps they spent the entire visit playing Monopoly. Perhaps.

Do say: Want to see my etchings?

Don't say: But what on earth are they doing?

webTitle: C&W boosts service to retailers with Reality link

fields.headline: C&W boosts service to retailers with Reality link
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless yesterday beefed up its services to online retailers in a plan to become one of Europe's biggest providers of data business services. It announced a joint venture with e-commerce group Reality, the logistics, e-commerce and customer management service business of Great Universal Stores.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless yesterday beefed up its services to online retailers in a plan to become one of Europe's biggest providers of data business services. It announced a joint venture with e-commerce group Reality, the logistics, e-commerce and customer management service business of Great Universal Stores.

Reality would bring to the agreement its distribution, customer management services and credit verification resources while C&W would provide web hosting and software support.

The market for services to online retailers is estimated to be worth $10bn within five years. Mike McTighe, C&W chief executive of global operations, said the venture was expected to be operating later this year. Netherlands-based e-tailer hot-orange.com is trialling the service.

Last month, C&W bought five internet-related businesses in Europe for $100m that will provide services including web hosting, design, network integration and e-commerce. The deal made C&W the third biggest internet services company on the continent.

C&W has splashed out more than £650m in almost two years to transform itself from a traditional telecoms operator deriving most of its revenue from voice traffic, into an organisation centred on data and internet protocol services.

The deal is also good news for GUS because the retailer's earnings have suffered in the competitive British market.

webTitle: TV guide: What the Airbus A3XX ad says about you.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Airbus A3XX ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Airbus A3XX ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: This extraordinary blockbuster opens on an ancient tiered building festooned with greenery. A breathy voice-over says: "They were the Seven Wonders of the World... and yet did the Hanging Gardens of Babylon have a cinema?" Cut to hundreds of Greek slaves passing buckets of water up a hill towards a temple. The voice-over continues: "Did the Temple of Artemis have showers?" It goes on in the same vein - did the Pyramids have bedrooms, the Colossus of Rhodes have a nursery? Finally we see an awestruck crowd walking towards a huge hangar in which there stands a massive aircraft, as the voice-over declares: "You'll find all these things on the Airbus A3XX. Where wonders never cease."

The jargon: This is the first ad for Airbus Industries' A3XX giant plane, which will carry 555 passengers, complete with cinemas, casinos, bedrooms and showers, and generally reinvent the way we fly in the 21st century. The ad is aimed at stimulating consumer interest in the aircraft as well as capturing the imagination of the aviation industry.

Personality: You're either an international businessperson who frequently flies around the globe or, more likely, one of those airline big cheeses who decides which craft to buy.

Financial status: Given that the A3XX is meant to be 20 per cent more efficient to run than existing long-haul aircraft, the theory is that the saving will be handed on to the consumer.

Telling lifestyle detail: After price, route and airline, the actual type of plane is apparently a key consideration among frequent fliers, so the chances are you're the aviation equivalent of a trainspotter.

Other relevant data: The A3XX will not, in fact, enter into service until 2005, so this is one of the first ever ads for a non-existent product. It's also the most expensive product ever advertised: each plane will cost $230m to build.

fields.headline: Stars in their eyes
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Lamarr's Attacks/Ferry Tales/Caught On Tape: Cheating Spouses
fields.body:
Faye Tozer wishes she could throw up out of taxi windows and get her tights ripped on a night out without a care in the world. She can't, because she's a member of cheesy/ saccharine pop combo Steps and, as such, has responsibilities. Her pre-pubescent fans would be horrified to learn of her vomit'n'lingerie shame so Faye's reverie must remain unfulfilled. She'll just have to settle for indulging in animal sacrifices privately with the rest of the band. It's far too easy to imagine them all standing round a marble altar in their long, red PVC coats and demon horns, dead goats and chickens strewn around, blood coagulating in pools as they whirl like dervishes and wail like banshees: "Better the devil you know. Better the devil you know ..." Or not.

Faye's revelation came during Lamarr's Attacks (BBC2), the subject of this week's assault being celebrity. Bemoaning his knowledge of banal celebrity titbits (Shane from Boyzone's fear of horses, Charlie Dimmock's mum's favourite drink), Mark Lamarr laid into the whole notion of celebrity and how once we had Jimi Hendrix and now we have Nicky Clarke. Do we, he cried, really need to know the colour of Gloria Hunniford's bathroom? (Well, no, we don't. But since we know that she recommends those adjustable beds and that her daughter drinks that funny milk, we may as well have a fully comprehensive picture of Hunniford's home life).

Lamarr, proving there is life after quiff and introducing some of his stand-up edge into the programme, rightly identified the most interesting questions about celebrity - why do we value fame, and why do we want to be famous? - but failed to follow through and provide adequate answers. As a comedy show (on the whole, a most amusing one) and not some epic documentary about society's spiral into a celebritocracy, all Lamarr could really do with his guests - Steps' Faye and Martin Kemp from EastEnders - was ask inane questions like "What's the most inane question you've been asked?"

So, in the end, what we got were merely more celebrity titbits - like Faye's vomit ambitions - and sentences that started with "To be honest_" which, as everyone who's ever been lied to knows, was Pinocchio's favourite line. And Lamarr slagging off fame and the rise of the micro-celebrity may strike some as biting the hand - and taking a large chunk out of the arm - that feeds you and, well, it was. But he did it with gusto. "What do we know about celebrity?" he asked at the end of the show. "Nothing." Which is a bit of a shame.

What we do know about fame is that it costs (and you start paying in sweat) and we only know that because Irene Cara told us in the eponymous Alan Parker film. Many a true word was said in legwarmers, as the band Payola discovered in Ferry Tales (BBC2). A run-of-the-mill, pile 'em high, sell 'em cheap documentary, it followed the rock band from Northern Ireland to their first gig in London. "I want to be in one of the most fabulously famous rock bands in the world," proclaimed lead singer Phil, forgetting the first rule of becoming famous: possessing an overwhelming desire to not want to be famous (well, so Faye and Martin said anyway).

Undaunted by this temptation of fate, Phil and the guys had their sleeveless T-shirts, black nail varnish and tight leather trousers packed and were destined for the Big Smoke. They had high hopes (after all, no one flung them overboard the ferry when they struck up an impromptu gig in the lounge area) and the "Man From EMI" was coming to see them. Judging by the size of the audience, he came alone and didn't much like what he heard. The boys went back to Ireland and their day jobs.

webTitle: Suharto is charged, but pins hopes on health let-out

fields.headline: Suharto is charged, but pins hopes on health let-out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian attorney general formally charged the former dictator General Suharto with corruption yesterday, arising from his 30 years in power.
fields.body:
The Indonesian attorney general formally charged the former dictator General Suharto with corruption yesterday, arising from his 30 years in power.

Officials said the trial should start later this month, but it is uncertain whether the ailing Gen Suharto, 79, will ever face the public humiliation of appearing in court.

His lawyers say their client, who suffered a stroke last year and has difficulty communicating, is not well enough to endure the rigours of a trial.

Government critics doubt the credibility of the whole process, suggesting that President Abdurrahman Wahid is acting hastily out of political motives before a key parliamentary session next week, rather than pursuing a thorough investigation.

Yushar Yahya, a spokesman for the attorney general, said that the status of the retired general, who ruled Indonesia with an iron fist for 32 years, until May 1998, had changed from suspect to defendant.

"The charges relate to unlawful acquisition of five trillion rupiah (£381m) by seven charitable foundations that Mr Suharto ran while in office," he said.

Mr Wahid has said publicly that he believes Mr Suharto stole about £30bn, but Mr Yahya said that such accusations were very difficult to prove. "We are proceeding with a case in which we have strong evidence and believe we can win," he said. "We will think about other issues later." The letters of indictment are expected to be formalised in the next few days.

Under Indonesian law a trial then has to begin within two weeks. Gen Suharto has been under house arrest since March, when he was declared a suspect. Mr Yahya said Gen Suharto signed a document yesterday indicating that he understood that he was now being charged with corruption.

Mr Suharto's lawyers continue to be indignant at their client's treatment, "What we are seeing is a gross abuse of human rights," one of them, Juan Felix Tampubolon, said. "This man is very sick, he has brain damage and cannot [understand] complex issues such as this. There is no way he should be put on trial."

One of Gen Suharto's team of personal physicians, Dr Hari Sabardi, warned against forcing the former leader into the courtroom, "We're not sure if he will be able to understand questions put to him and be able give the right answers," he said.

Not only did Gen Suharto suffer a stroke last year, he was also kept in hospital with internal organ problems. He says he can remember little about his time in power. Mr Tampubolon stressed that Gen Suharto was not trying to dodge the legal process. "Mr Suharto is ready to go to court because he has always obeyed the law," he said.

Mr Yahya insisted that there was no reason to halt the proceedings on health grounds. "At the end of last month Mr Suharto underwent a thorough medical examination by independent doctors and was declared fit enough to stand trial," he said. He declined to speculate on Gen Suharto's fate if convicted. Some officials have suggested that the man who once jailed hundreds of thousands of people without trial could face life imprisonment.

Mr Wahid has repeatedly said that he would pardon Mr Suharto if he returned the vast majority of his wealth. It is unclear if returning £381m would be sufficient to keep the former president out of jail.

Many people believe the whole process is just a political game being played by Mr Wahid, whose popularity has plummeted in recent weeks. He risks being impeached in a crucial session of the nation's supreme legislature, the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), next week when he will have to account for his first nine months in office.

"Gus Dur needs some successes desperately ahead of the MPR session to get his critics off his back," said Hendardi, a lawyer and government critic. "Many of us lawyers doubt the strength of the case against Suharto but the president needs to be seen to be acting against him."

A lawyer with the respected Indonesian Corruption Watch was equally dubious about the whole process. " In two or three months this case will be dismissed," he said. "This whole case against Suharto is all a big drama, a big show. This is Indonesia. The system is corrupt, anyone can be bought for the right price."

fields.headline: Standard's future is rosy
fields.trailText: Mauled in the wake of half-time figures on Wednesday, Standard Chartered shares - up 38p to £8.90 - clawed back some of the losses yesterday thanks to positive comments from broking powerhouse Deutsche Bank.
fields.body:
Mauled in the wake of half-time figures on Wednesday, Standard Chartered shares - up 38p to £8.90 - clawed back some of the losses yesterday thanks to positive comments from broking powerhouse Deutsche Bank.

Deutsche analyst Mark Eady reckons the fall - Standard shares tumbled 98p as investors took fright at a £480m restructuring plan included with the figures - has left the stock looking "attractively priced". It has been added to Deutsche's influential 20 stock European Focus List. Although Mr Eady has cut his profit forecast for the current year by 23%, he has increased his estimates for 2001 and 2002 by 1% and 5% respectively. Given Standard's growth prospects - revenues should recover in the second half of the year - the shares now appear to be in buying territory. Mr Eady has a "buy" rating and £10 target price on the stock, something investors might like to consider.

webTitle: Leader: John Prescott needs a big stick when railing at the railways.

fields.headline: Railing at the railways
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott needs a big stick

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: It is worth asking what the chairman of the public accounts committee, David Davies, was doing when the Tory government let the rail operating contracts he was so busy criticising yesterday. The answer is that he was giving it his ardent support. But let us celebrate a sinner's glimpse of the light.
fields.body:
It is worth asking what the chairman of the public accounts committee, David Davies, was doing when the Tory government let the rail operating contracts he was so busy criticising yesterday. The answer is that he was giving it his ardent support. But let us celebrate a sinner's glimpse of the light.

Privatisation as conducted by the Thatcher and Major governments was botched. For the sake of instant profits, the regulatory regime for rail was jerry-built. But John Prescott was also in parliament when British Rail was dismantled and by now has had long enough to think about a new structure. His stated priority is ensuring much-needed investment is made both by Railtrack and the train operators, but he has to insist public investment is not recycled through company balance sheets to bloat their bottom lines. Mr Prescott's enthusiasm for public-private partnership must not stop the state securing a fair return for taxpayers, possibly by means of an equity stake.

The national audit office critique of train operators rings bells down the line. With the exception of Midland Mainline and the Southend route, improvements are hard to find - what does the Sheffield line have that others lack? The government desperately needs a formula for improvement. The NAO displayed a certain innocence in failing to see how the train operators, approaching the endgame in the first franchise period, have the state over a barrel. They can threaten that unless their franchises are renewed they will offer only minimum service which on present evidence is a recipe for further, disastrous decline. The time has come at least to whisper the "n" word: nationalisation. The government has to be able to counter-threaten confiscation of assets that are being misused.

Mr Prescott's vaunted largesse in the summer spending round is going to take a long time to be realised in improved railway travel. Here and now he has two priorities. One is to stamp on any silly rivalry between the strategic rail authority and other rail regulators. The other is political. Franchise-holders for the most part are part of bigger corporate entities with public reputations to worry about, some of them dependent on government goodwill for the conduct of other parts of their business. It is not the prolixity of Mr Prescott's speech that will count in talking to them, nor his volume - what matters is whether he really does carry a big stick.

fields.headline: At this price? Thus
fields.trailText: The share market does not take kindly to shocks and Thus shares have paid the price this week for not keeping investors duly informed.
fields.body:
The share market does not take kindly to shocks and Thus shares have paid the price this week for not keeping investors duly informed.

Thus shares have fallen from 220p last Friday to yesterday's 124p. Shareholders reeled at the poor first-quarter results on Monday, which showed operating losses widening from £4.6m to £18m. Even more disconcerting was news that there would be a loss before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation. Most analysts are expecting Thus to report losses of between £5m-£10m for the full year.

Some are saying investors' confidence in Thus has been shaken and its shares are not likely to peak over £2 for possibly six months.

Thus's three main businesses are internet and interactive services, which account for more than half of its revenues, data and telecom services, and call centre services. Fierce rivalry in interactive services saw turnover drop sharply in the quarter. Revenues from Thus's highly successful Demon internet service provider were also battered by competition.

Thus lost a substantial number of its retail customers to BT and the current jitters about dot.com compa nies have only exacerbated investor concern.

Thus did report strong growth in its data and telecoms division for business customers in the quarter. Yet this division is a long-term growth story as Thus rolls out its national network that will offer customers services such as high speed internet access and video streaming.

But investors are impatient in waiting for growth and in improving its business market share Thus faces tough competition from the likes of Cable & Wireless and Energis.

Its 50.01% shareholder, Scottish Power, may give some investors comfort. But those who want more immediate growth would be better buying Energis and Cable & Wireless or otherwise hold on for a longer journey with Thus.

webTitle: Leader: Mugabe leads Zimbabwe towards ruin.

fields.headline: An African tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe leads Zimbabwe towards ruin

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Predictions that the damaging turmoil in Zimbabwe would subside in the wake of June's general election have proved to be optimistic. Although the ruling Zanu-PF party fought off the most concerted challenge to its rule since independence in 1980, the manner of its victory, relying heavily on intimidation and violence, underscored well-founded doubts about its ability to give the country the fresh start it so badly needs.
fields.body:
Predictions that the damaging turmoil in Zimbabwe would subside in the wake of June's general election have proved to be optimistic. Although the ruling Zanu-PF party fought off the most concerted challenge to its rule since independence in 1980, the manner of its victory, relying heavily on intimidation and violence, underscored well-founded doubts about its ability to give the country the fresh start it so badly needs.

A new cabinet was formed, but is sadly lacking in new policy ideas. This week's devaluation of the Zimbabwe dollar, for example, was a measure that the government stubbornly resisted until the crushing weight of Zimbabwe's problems finally gave it no choice. The devaluation will help exporters, but only if there is anything left to export. On present trends, this looks increasingly doubtful.

Zimbabwe's deepening economic crisis, the ruling party's inertia and the failure to take on board the electorate's clearly stated desire for change can be traced to a common cause: President Robert Mugabe. Africa's angry old man is, if anything, even angrier than he was before the polls delivered their stinging rebuke. He remains the repository of all real decision-making power, making a mockery of parliament, the courts and even his own ministers.

Reports that he might step down when his term ends in 2002, or even before, have been flatly denied and nobody in Zanu-PF appears strong or brave enough to beard him. Despite all this year's upheavals, including Wednesday's portentous general strike, Mr Mugabe, it seems, has not learned a thing nor shifted an inch.

Mr Mugabe's actions during the last few days amply illustrate his talent for intransigence and his gift for divisiveness. Responding to a strike by white farmers, he almost quadrupled, to more than 3,000, the number of farms he plans to seize without compensation. He reneged on a pledge to end land occupations by thuggish vigilantes and denounced all critics as "imperialists" and "racists".

With breathtaking irresponsibility, he told international aid donors that if they did not like it, they could "keep their money". And along the way, he managed to humiliate South African President Thabo Mbeki, who went to Harare this week to plead, on behalf of an investment-starved region already damaged by Mr Mugabe's antics, for a return to lawful, rational governance.

But there is little that is rational about Mr Mugabe's behaviour these days. Here is a man who for much of his career demonstrated enormous creative energy, a man whose brave, unifying vision for Zimbabwe advanced in the 1980s as education and health standards rose, ethnic and racial wounds appeared to heal, and an independent judiciary and press flourished. Now this same man, aged 76, turns destructive and vicious. Using force rather than persuasion, demonising opponents, fulminating against global economic realities that cannot be bucked, trying to ignore problems like the growing food, fuel and Aids emergencies, dabbling in the Congo war, and blaming Britain for his woes, he undoes all his own good work. For Mr Mugabe, the reclaiming of the land seems to have become the final, defining cause of a life-long liberation struggle.

This is about legacy now as much as justice; about a man whose time is running out, who desperately seeks vindication, who fears greatness deferred. Yet in his impatience and fury, in his bully-boy methods, he achieves only the devaluation of his leadership, the despoliation of his dreams. Sadly, Robert Mugabe's personal tragedy is one that all Zimbabweans must share.

webTitle: English cities 'the worst in the west'

fields.headline: English cities 'the worst in the west'
fields.standfirst: 'Visionary' architect who led government's urban task force accuses ministers and says comparisons with Europe leave him appalled
fields.trailText: Big English cities were yesterday labelled the worst in the western world by the architect who led a government task force which made a string of recommendations to improve depressed urban areas.
fields.body:
Big English cities were yesterday labelled the worst in the western world by the architect who led a government task force which made a string of recommendations to improve depressed urban areas.

Lord Rogers, once hailed as a visionary by Downing Street, criticised ministers for failing to recognise the rate of decline and not appreciating the importance of good design in the battle to pull neighbourhoods round.

Launching a bulky urban design guide, prepared by the government's regeneration agency, English partnerships, Lord Rogers listed a string of problems afflicting cities - widespread dereliction, boarded-up housing, litter-strewn streets and potholed roads.

"I do not think I have visited cities in Europe quite as bad," he told architects, planners and developers at the Tate Modern gallery in London.

Departing from a prepared text, he warned that it was pointless for the government to pour millions into improving schools, inner city hospitals and other services, without addressing good design in neighbourhoods.

"There is still a concept that if you get the social side right then you can deal later with the physical side," he said. "I cannot say too strongly how wrong this is."

He added: "Unfortunately, there are too many people who think architecture is an add-on, like adding lipstick to a gorilla, or bricks and mortar tied together with a pink ribbon."

Praising the design guide's strong criticism of countless British buildings, he hailed European cities - Barcelona (where he is an adviser to the mayor), the Hague, and Copenhagen as examples for England.

"For a rich nation, I am absolutely appalled by the state of [our] cities," he said. "When you look at the first 10 cities in Europe, I don't think any of them have quite as bad areas. I don't want to make it all sound bleak because we are beginning to look at the problem... but I don't understand why... the government does not recognise the scale of the problem.

"I still hear ministers saying 'look, it is going to take x years to get the education and the health service going, then we are going to look at the built environment' - and I gasp at that."

The design guide, meant to influence planners and architects and councils, does not pull any punches about the legacy of 1960s buildings blighting the urban landscape. "Almost everywhere looks like everywhere else." It accuses the big house builders of viewing houses simply as "products" rather than striving to create "places and communities".

The guide urges councils to create networks of streets, around once derelict areas -citing the example of The Calls area in Leeds - and calls for mixed neighbourhoods of rented and private housing to promote social diversity. It rails against "big box units", passing as department stores and dominating high streets.

Instead areas should incorporate a mix of uses. Belfast's Lagenside area is hailed as a model of regeneration. With English cities outside London towards the bottom of the European wealth league, Lord Rogers's main task force report last year called for a national crusade to improve the quality of urban life, create more jobs - inner city unemployment runs at twice the national average - and recycle an estimated 1.3m empty buildings such as houses, warehouses and factories.

Ministers were urged to provide a range of low tax incentives for developers. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, Lord Rogers's sponsoring minister, hopes that the Treasury might signal a range of incentives later this year.

Beauties... and a beast

Copenhagen

Hailed by Lord Rogers as an "immensely livable city" characterised by small squares with roads geared to walkers and cyclists. As a result car use has not risen over 20 years while cycling has increased dramatically.

The Hague

Lord Rogers's task force admired its bold civic architecture and mixed use housing which does not distinguish between social tenants and owner occupiers. It is also geared to professionals, rather than simply people on low incomes. Lord Rogers says it thus avoids the ghettos of rich and poor.

Barcelona

As well as being a world class city linked to the sea, its three miles of reclaimed waterfront is regarded as one of the best beaches in Europe. It has more than 100 newish civic squares. Neighbourhoods in the city are given a budget to improve their surroundings.

Manchester

Although the city centre has had a £500m makeover after the IRA bombing four years ago, the Arndale shopping centre - one of Britain's least loved buildings - is to undergo a £100m revamp. The city, like much of the north-west, is blighted with more derelict land than other parts of the country. Violent crime is also tarnishing the city's reputation.

fields.headline: A whole new ball game
fields.standfirst:
On defence, Europe needs to face up to the inevitable divorce from the US
Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: The House of Commons foreign affairs committee has, somewhat belatedly, focused on the uncomfortable implications for the UK and for Europe of the impending US decision to build a national missile defence (NMD) complex. Other governments and institutions on this side of the Atlantic have been expressing similar concerns for some time. The argument is an important one. But its greater significance is that the US is determined to pursue NMD regardless of the views of its allies (or recent test failures). NMD is one manifestation of the new, post-cold-war structure of security relationships. The issues at stake are as important for this country as those raised by the single European currency and closely related. It is time they were publicly acknowledged and debated.
fields.body:
The House of Commons foreign affairs committee has, somewhat belatedly, focused on the uncomfortable implications for the UK and for Europe of the impending US decision to build a national missile defence (NMD) complex. Other governments and institutions on this side of the Atlantic have been expressing similar concerns for some time. The argument is an important one. But its greater significance is that the US is determined to pursue NMD regardless of the views of its allies (or recent test failures). NMD is one manifestation of the new, post-cold-war structure of security relationships. The issues at stake are as important for this country as those raised by the single European currency and closely related. It is time they were publicly acknowledged and debated.

For 50 years, Nato has been at the heart of UK defence arrangements. Many hope that this can continue indefinitely, with periodic adjustments to take account of the European dimension. But the political, economic and technological facts argue otherwise.

The possibilities open to the US and to Europe in the field of security have always been different. For 40 years, the resulting contrasts in outlook were overridden by the shared perception of a single, immediate and existential threat. But the US today believes itself exposed to threats that, while no longer a danger to its existence, are global in origin. No European power is in this position. The US has the resources to act alone to assuage its anxieties and to protect its interests. No European power is in that position. Political dynamics guarantee that the US will seek to exploit its economic and technological potentialities to the full. Hence NMD.

This process has a momentum that will carry it forward independent of the wishes of the Washington establishment. It has little to do with diminishing US interest in Europe or in the special relationship. It has everything to do with a great and wealthy democracy developing its capabilities to look after itself in a multi-polar world.

If the European members of the alliance can together make an effort to qualify as a partner that must be heard, well and good. But if not, the US will increasingly make its own unfettered decisions. The rest of us will find ourselves applauding, cavilling or appealing from the sidelines.

Soon enough the next US president will be presenting the European members of the alliance with the old "burden-sharing" choice in a new and starker form. Will the Europeans be able to respond appropriately? The auguries are, at best, mixed. There was universal agreement after Kosovo that the Europeans must develop a more effective military capability, and that this probably meant spending more and certainly spending better. The UK government has given a strong lead, in its budgetary plans, its policy initiatives and its procurement decisions. But the reality is that, at present, virtually every other European government is proposing to spend less and that efforts to spend better remain unfulfilled. Institutional contortions unaccompanied by capability enhancements will infuriate the Americans and give us the worst of all worlds.

Later this autumn we should be able to judge better whether promises will lead to deeds. But today's soldiers agree that in a 10- to 15-year time frame no single European nation has a chance of maintaining a capability for sustained military activity beyond its borders that is balanced, credible and technologically compatible with that of the US.

The inefficiencies of trying to do so will become more absurd. A unit of defence expenditure already buys less in Europe than in the US. The absolute cost of maintaining viable armed forces will continue to soar. Electorates will become more reluctant to privilege apparently futile defence investment over more immediate domestic and civil international demands. A downward spiral will result. If European governments cannot manage a collective effort in the defence and security field, each of them will eventually find themselves facing an unpredictable international environment with inadequate military resources. Action, joint or otherwise, in such circumstances will seem pointless.

The prerequisite for the sort of European defence identity which might make possible publicly supported and cost-effective defence expenditure is the acceptance by the main European governments of a single, binding security and defence policy. Only such a policy would permit mutual commitment, a substantial measure of interstate role prioritisation and the maintenance of a credible European defence capability.

It may seem a fanciful idea today. Perhaps it will remain so. There is no law that compels governments and electorates to recognise where their best interests lie. Moreover a common policy, if agreed, would certainly not reflect purely British preoccupations. But if the attempt to create such an approach is not intensified, or if it fails, the inability of contemporary politicians to get ahead of their focus groups will be confirmed.

The main west European governments share vital international interests that will be pursued in common, starting soon, or not at all. The global village is emerging and it is enormously important for Europe that the village operates in accordance with values and rules acceptable to us as well as to the Americans. However the thought is gilded, this implies an enforcing capability, preferably one that takes some account of the UN dimension.

The only direct threat to the European homelands in the medium term is that from asymmetrical war, primarily the use of hi-tech devices or weapons of mass destruction against civilian populations by non-state groups or rogue states. Unless the main European players agree in advance as to how they will deal with such outrages together it is unlikely that the outrage itself will elicit a joint and forceful response.

Russia will lack for many years the economic potential to support a sustained military challenge to western Europe. But, although humiliated, it remains a great nation and a major nuclear power. It is critically important that Russia, which cannot avoid being an element in the transatlantic balance, is engaged in the development of Europe's response to the new global security environment. This too requires a common approach from western Europe.

Whatever the role of the European Union, Europe's leaders all know that the development of a single security and defence policy can only be built upon a consensus developed initially between France, Germany and the UK. It will be essential, of course, that the other European nations should be associated with such an effort in the right way and at the right time. The artificial distinction between collective defence and campaigns outside Nato countries will need to be reconsidered.

The maintenance of the closest possible transatlantic partnership must be a defining condition of any European defence identity. Nato should continue to provide the institutional framework for that partnership even if the alliance itself is progressively enlarged and transformed - as is inevitable. European defence cooperation will remain formally intergovernmental in character for a long time to come, not least because of the nuclear dimension. But in practice it would rapidly become unthinkable for the main European governments to move militarily without the others' active support.

No sudden crisis will result from the mere continuation of current policies. Present and planned weapons systems can run on, and run down, for a while yet. But unless these issues are resolved, Europe will be abandoning its security to fate. Having successfully surmounted the defence challenges of the last half-century, it would be a pity if Europe were to default on those of the next.

 Sir Michael Alexander was British ambassador to Nato and is now chairman of the Royal United Services Institute

webTitle: Cheney sinks his teeth into Democrats

fields.headline: Cheney sinks his teeth into Democrats
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: After a week on barely believable best behaviour at their national convention, the Republicans finally launched themselves into election combat mode yesterday, nominating George W Bush to lead them to the White House and end the Bill Clinton era.
fields.body:
After a week on barely believable best behaviour at their national convention, the Republicans finally launched themselves into election combat mode yesterday, nominating George W Bush to lead them to the White House and end the Bill Clinton era.

The Texas governor was due to accept the nomination in the most important speech of his political career last night, but already a new, more aggressive Republican tone had been set in the acceptance speech of his running-mate, Dick Cheney.

Mr Bush was expected to stick solidly to the dominant theme of the week, stressing in public his warm-hearted inclusivity. But for all the compassionate words and images inside the convention hall during the past four days, the fact remains that he will leave Philadelphia today committed to a policy agenda which contains few changes from the bedrock conservative policies on which Republicans have fought most recent elections.

Mr Cheney delivered the red meat speech that the 2,066 delegates had been denied all week, energising the faithful with a series of pointed attacks on Mr Clinton and the Democratic presidential challenger, Vice-President Al Gore.

"We are all a little weary of the Clinton-Gore routine. But the wheel has turned. And it is time, it is time for them to go," Mr Cheney told the convention, hijacking a line which Mr Gore had used against the Republican incumbents in 1992.

Twice more in his speech he returned to the "It's time for them to go" mantra, bringing the delegates to their feet in vintage displays of convention enthusiasm.

He lost no opportunity to link Mr Gore to Mr Clinton, underscoring the Republican high command's belief that "Clinton fatigue", allied to a generalised wish for a change at the top, represents Mr Bush's best chance of ousting the Democrats from the presidency on November 7.

"As the man from Hope goes home to New York, Mr Gore tries to separate himself from his leader's shadow," he said. "But somehow we will never see one without thinking of the other.

"They came in together. Now let us see them off together," he added, triggering one of several volleys of loud cheering.

When Mr Cheney was chosen as the running-mate last week, everything suggested that his principal role was to provide the conservative gravitas which the Republican ticket required to compensate for Mr Bush's largely unproven leadership claims. But his performance this week showed he also intends to play the "attack dog" role traditionally allocated to the number two man.

Mr Bush, meanwhile, promised an acceptance speech that "speaks from my heart".

"I'm going to lift the spirit of the country," he vowed. Aides said he would attack the Clinton record in a tone of regret rather than criticism.

Apart from the autumn election debates against Mr Gore, there was no more pivotal moment in Mr Bush's White House challenge than last night's address, the first time many Americans will have heard a sustained speech by a man who has been in public life for less than six years.

With the opinion polls showing him extending his lead over Mr Gore into double figures, the November election is increasingly the Republicans' to lose, a remarkable position considering America's economic prosperity and the fact that Mr Bush is what one commentator described as "the Republican party's blind date".

Partly because he is such an unknown quantity, Mr Bush's speech was expected to recapture some of the television audience that has voted the rest of the convention a big turn-off. Viewing ratings for the convention are down by 25% on 1996, a previous record low.

An evidently relieved Democratic leadership, which has been somewhat nonplussed by the successful soft focus of the convention, seized on Mr Cheney's speech to claim that "the mask is off at the masquerade ball".

"So much for the Republicans' positive campaign," said a Gore spokesman, Chris Lehane. "Tonight they're turning the clock back with a card-carrying conservative member of the Republican old guard. They're engaging in the only type of Republican politics they know: attack politics."

In a carefully timed leak, Mr Gore was said yesterday to have narrowed his choice of running-mate down to six: Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, Congressman Dick Gephardt of Missouri, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, and Governor Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire. He will announce his choice on Tuesday.

webTitle: Courts are crucial prize for the right

fields.headline: Courts are crucial prize for the right
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: To the American right, winning control of the courts is every bit as important as capturing the White House or Congress. And unlike their liberal opponents, rightwingers have prepared for what may be the most important battle for the country's heart and soul.
fields.body:
To the American right, winning control of the courts is every bit as important as capturing the White House or Congress. And unlike their liberal opponents, rightwingers have prepared for what may be the most important battle for the country's heart and soul.

Away from the bright lights of political conventioneering, conservatives have established an array of legal think-tanks centred on one institution: the Federalist Society.

Founded in 1982, the society has grown exponentially in recent years and now provides a career network for about 25,000 conservative lawyers and thousands of ambitious law students. According to a forthcoming report by a New York civil rights group, the Institute for Democracy Studies (IDS), the Federalist Society will act as a staffing agency for the federal courts and justice department in the event of an election victory by the Republicans under George W Bush "opening the way for a radical transformation of the American legal system".

The main issues in American society - abortion, guns, religion in schools, corporate accountability and the role of government - are increasingly being fought out in the courts.

The IDS says that leading figures in the Federalists have more radical ideas about reshaping the US than the moderate congressmen and administrators on display at the Republicans' Philadelphia convention.

Taking the original texts of the constitution as their guide, they would seek to roll back much of the state's involvement in daily life.

That would entail trying to overturn supreme court decisions guaranteeing abortion rights. It could also mean a judicial assault on much of the civil-rights legislation of the 1960s: the right argues that the state has no business trying to impose racial or gender equality through restrictive laws and social engineering.

The conservative wish-list includes stripping the government of many regulatory powers - emasculating or abolishing the environmental protection agency, for instance.

Some Federalist Society members are already well known. Before he became President Clinton's chief inquisitor in the impeachment saga, Kenneth Starr led the Federalist charge against the American Bar Association, the lawyers' professional body regarded by the right as a nest of liberals.

Several of the self-styled "elves" of the impeachment era were also Federalists.

These conservative lawyers helped to ensure that Linda Tripp's tapes of Monica Lewinsky talking about her affair with President Clinton came to the attention of the investigation team looking into the president's conduct.

The head of the Senate judiciary committee, Orrin Hatch, is also a Federalist. In 1987 he stripped the bar association of its role in vetting supreme court justices and federal judges, reducing its status to a simple legal interest group, on a level with the Federalists.

There are also a number of leading Federalists in the entourage of George W Bush, bent on winning the presidency for the Republicans. One of them, Boyden Gray, is a potential attorney general.

"These are the folks who are essentially waiting in the wings to take over as a new legal establishment," said Lee Cokorinos, research director at the IDS and co-author of its report, The Federalist Society and the Challenge to a Democratic Jurisprudence, due out next month.

The Federalists' executive director, Eugene Meyer, laughs off allegations that the society is the "vast rightwing conspiracy" Hillary Clinton alluded to at the height of impeachment.

"We don't lobby and we don't endorse candidates," he said.

"But of course a lot of people in the society are very involved in the public policy world, so a number of them will be active in government and in various institutions."

Mr Meyer pointed out that, unlike conspirators, the Federalists meet and discuss their views in the open.

According to a forthcoming report by a New York civil rights group, the Institute for Democracy Studies (IDS), the Federalist Society will act as a staffing agency for the federal courts and justice department in the event of an election victory by the Republicans under George W Bush "opening the way for a radical transformation of the American legal system". The main issues in American society - abortion, guns, religion in schools, corporate accountability and the role of government - are increasingly being fought out in the courts. The IDS says that leading figures in the Federalists have more radical ideas about reshaping the US than the moderate congressmen and administrators on display at the Republicans' Philadelphia convention. Taking the original texts of the constitution as their guide, they would seek to roll back much of the state's involvement in daily life. That would entail trying to overturn supreme court decisions guaranteeing abortion rights. It could also mean a judicial assault on much of the civil-rights legislation of the 1960s: the right argues that the state has no business trying to impose racial or gender equality through restrictive laws and social engineering. The conservative wish-list includes stripping the government of many regulatory powers - emasculating or abolishing the environmental protection agency, for instance. Some Federalist Society members are already well known. Before he became President Clinton's chief inquisitor in the impeachment saga, Kenneth Starr led the Federalist charge against the American Bar Association, the lawyers' professional body regarded by the right as a nest of liberals. Several of the self-styled "elves" of the impeachment era were also Federalists. These conservative lawyers helped to ensure that Linda Tripp's tapes of Monica Lewinsky talking about her affair with President Clinton came to the attention of the investigation team looking into the president's conduct. The head of the Senate judiciary committee, Orrin Hatch, is also a Federalist. In 1987 he stripped the bar association of its role in vetting supreme court justices and federal judges, reducing its status to a simple legal interest group, on a level with the Federalists. There are also a number of leading Federalists in the entourage of George W Bush, bent on winning the presidency for the Republicans. One of them, Boyden Gray, is a potential attorney general. "These are the folks who are essentially waiting in the wings to take over as a new legal establishment," said Lee Cokorinos, research director at the IDS and co-author of its report, The Federalist Society and the Challenge to a Democratic Jurisprudence, due out next month. The Federalists' executive director, Eugene Meyer, laughs off allegations that the society is the "vast rightwing conspiracy" Hillary Clinton alluded to at the height of impeachment. "We don't lobby and we don't endorse candidates," he said. "But of course a lot of people in the society are very involved in the public policy world, so a number of them will be active in government and in various institutions." Mr Meyer pointed out that, unlike conspirators, the Federalists meet and discuss their views in the open.

webTitle: Grants bring cheer to Bristol, gloom for Greenwich

fields.headline: Grants bring cheer to Bristol, gloom for Greenwich
fields.trailText: There was good and bad news yesterday for two of the world's most famous preserved ships: Isambard Kingdom Brunel's SS Great Britain has been approved for a heritage lottery grant; but the Cutty Sark, fastest and most beautiful of the tea clippers, has been turned down.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
There was good and bad news yesterday for two of the world's most famous preserved ships: Isambard Kingdom Brunel's SS Great Britain has been approved for a heritage lottery grant; but the Cutty Sark, fastest and most beautiful of the tea clippers, has been turned down.

Both ships have disastrous structural problems, the aftermath of inspired 19th century engineering innovation, due to corrosion of iron not designed to last 150 years.

The trustees of the SS Great Britain held a party on deck yesterday in Bristol, where the ship is in dry dock at the yard where it was launched in 1843, to celebrate approval in principle for the £7m grant toward a £10m scheme that should solve its problems for at least another couple of generations. In its day the transatlantic liner was the largest ship ever built of iron, and the first big ship to use a propellor.

The scheme will protect the hull under a glass "waterline", allowing visitors on the bottom of the dock to admire the enormous iron plates, laid like a clinker rowing boat. So severe is the corrosion needing treatment that the hull has dozens of rust holes stuffed with wire to stop pigeons flying in, and a report warned the entire ship could be lost in 25 years. It will be at least the fourth time the SS Great Britain has been rescued from disaster: she was wrecked on an Irish beach after her launch; and in 1970 she was towed back to Bristol from the Falkland Islands where she had been scuttled.

In Greenwich, where the Cutty Sark has been a London landmark since 1954, there was dismay at the news that their grant application has failed, although the heritage lottery fund has left the door open for further discussions.

Regarded as one of the most beautiful ships ever built, the clipper was launched in 1839 as the fastest in the world, racing back from China with the new tea crop. It too is threatened with structural failure without hugely expensive repairs. Though there was no official reaction from the trustees, they feared they had been hit by the "London factor", the perception that too many lottery grants have gone to the capital, including to the nearby National Maritime Museum and the old Royal Hospital.

webTitle: Dangerous bacteria mistakenly sent to shop

fields.headline: Dangerous bacteria mistakenly sent to shop
fields.trailText: A package containing a dangerous strain of tuberculosis bacteria, intended for the government's top security biochemical research base, was mistakenly delivered to a department store.
fields.body:
A package containing a dangerous strain of tuberculosis bacteria, intended for the government's top security biochemical research base, was mistakenly delivered to a department store.

Scientists at the centre for applied microbiology and research at Porton Down in Wiltshire were concerned when glass phials filled with the bacterial strain, did not arrive from a US laboratory. CAMR had been using the bacteria to develop a new vaccine against TB.

On January 7, Porton Down researchers received just the outer packaging and asked police to trace the parcel through a private courier company. But the inner container, marked only "bio-hazard", had already been delivered to the curtain department of Debenhams in Plymouth. After staff alerted the city council, the phials were collected from the store by a representative from CAMR within 24 hours.

CAMR and Devon and Cornwall police said there had been no risk to the public but Gary Streeter, Conservative MP for Devon South West, yesterday said the episode had been "a lucky escape" after details of the blunder emerged on Wednesday.

A spokesman for CAMR said: "All transport of biological material is controlled by strict international regulations and safety procedures."

However, a spokesman for the courier firm, Securicor Omega Express, said: "Such parcels are accepted into our system on the basis that they do not require special handling as defined by internationally recognised regulations."

webTitle: Cities angry over ITV's unauthorised Street plugs

fields.headline: Cities angry over ITV's unauthorised Street plugs
fields.trailText: ITV moved yesterday to quell a row over over fly posters promoting its top rated soap, Coronation Street.
fields.body:
ITV moved yesterday to quell a row over over fly posters promoting its top rated soap, Coronation Street.

Bills for the Weatherfield Gazette - the programme's fictitious local paper - have been appearing in London and Manchester, where the city council has threatened legal action.

The bills publicise the murder trial of one of the Street's characters, Jez Quigley, which is due to be screened next week. Three separate versions ask: "Will Steve Testify? Will Natalie get Justice? Will Jez Get Life?" They have appeared on roadside junction boxes, walls and other surfaces, instead of on authorised billboards.

A spokeswoman for Manchester city council said legal action was being considered as no permission had been granted for the posters. "All fly posting in the city is illegal. No consent has been granted for this material and we will be pursuing legal action where they are posting on the city council property," she said.

A spokeswoman for ITV, whose central marketing department is responsible for the campaign and not the maker of the programme, Granada, said the campaign was due to end shortly.

The posters in Manchester were being removed, and the London ones would come down soon. "Although we have not received any formal complaint about these particular posters they are being removed in order to avoid causing any inconvenience. We trust that this is the end of the matter."

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cafe Rogano, Glasgow
fields.body:
Cafe Rogano , 11 Exchange Place, Glasgow G1 3AN. Tel: 0141-248 4055

Rogano is to Glasgow what La Coupole is to Paris. This art deco restaurant was built in 1935. The cocktail bar and hyper-flattering lighting make it a place for louche lounging, even at lunchtime. Cheapskates head straight downstairs to the cheaper Cafe Rogano, where £10.95 buys a two-course (first and main) lunch or dinner. That's pretty damn good value and there's something for the most wide-ranging of palates as well as for vegetarians. Top-ranking items include starters of warm salad of duck livers and grilled goat's cheese with warm plums; among mains, seared tuna on spiced lentil salsa and seared chicken with squid ink pasta.

fields.headline: Just out: Kombucha
fields.body:
Form: Cloudy pink liquid with slight fizz. The blurb says it is a 2,000-year-old Korean health drink made from herbal tea and yeast, and aimed at cleansing and refeshing the body and soul. Madonna, Barbra Streisand and Meg Ryan swear by it, apparently. If that's a recommendation.

Flavour: A hint of strawberry, a whisper of apricot; lightly acidic aftertaste.

Verdict: Pleasant enough. Quite refreshing for the body. We'll reserve judgment on the soul.

Price: £1.55 per 250ml bottle; £3.25 per litre bottle at Selfridges.

fields.headline: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15
fields.standfirst: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.trailText: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Ichiban Noodle Cafe 50 Queen Street, Glasgow G1 3EN. Tel: 0141-204 4200

Noodles - cheap, cheerful, copious and child-friendly. Ichiban doles out oodles of noodles to a constant stream of eager eaters aged from six months to 66 years with ease and calm. It doesn't just do those huge steaming bowls of soba, ramen and udon noodles swimming in broth. If you're up for something a bit more recherché try the 11 variations on a sushi theme, from omelette to octopus or bento boxes of sushi, dumplings and tempura, and miso soup. Organic wine, Kirin and Asahi beers, and sencha tea for non-boozers. Lunch/dinner £5.50-£10.50 per head. Non-smoking and no booking but queues don't last long.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: With Great Pleasure/Happy Birthday Ma'am/Feedback
fields.body:
The loyal radio tributes for the Queen Mother's (pictured) 100th birthday start with a reading of the Poet Laureate's celebratory ode in With Great Pleasure (11.0am, Radio 4). Happy Birthday Ma'am (7.30pm, Radio 2) is a live show from the Royal College of Music, with Richard Baker introducing some of her favourite pieces. BBC Proms 2000 (7.30pm, Radio 3) features the National Youth Orchestra playing works with royal associations.

In Feedback (1.30pm, Radio 4), Roger Bolton puts another national institution through the wringer, and Helen Boaden, Radio 4's controller, is hung out to dry. There's the old gripe from correspondents about her failure to offer enough children's programming. The sprawling tedium of the extended You And Yours has drawn flak almost since it was introduced. Then there's the apparently terminal condition of Radio 4 comedy... The slavering malcontents among Boaden's nine million listeners have been anticipating this raw meat for months.

webTitle: Richard Norton-Taylor on the Human Rights Act

fields.headline: The fox in charge of the henhouse
fields.standfirst: The Human Rights Act is bringing to light contradictions in the home secretary's role
fields.trailText: It was a gift to those sections of the media eager to spread panic about the incorporation of the European Convention on Human Rights into English law.
fields.body:
It was a gift to those sections of the media eager to spread panic about the incorporation of the European Convention on Human Rights into English law.

After agreeing this week that two Sikh militants faced the risk of being tortured if they were deported to India, the special immigration appeals commission concluded their 49-page ruling with this observation: "We would add and emphasise this: law-abiding citizens of the United Kingdom might reasonably feel disquiet about a state of affairs which permits international terrorists proved to be a danger to the national security to remain here."

The commission members - Mr Justice Humphrey Potts, Judge William Dunn and Sir Michael Weston, a former ambassador to Kuwait - continued: "We can only say that this state of affairs follows upon article 3 of the European convention, the secretary of state's acceptance of that convention and its consequences, and the evidence we have heard in relation to the risks faced by the appellants in the event of their being returned to India."

As if to drive home their reluctance to set the Sikhs free, they added: "In future cases we would earnestly urge the secretary of state to consider whether the type of material he relied upon in these appeals is sufficient to do justice to the case."

The secretary of state to whom the commission referred is Jack Straw, the cabinet minister responsible for the Human Rights Act, which incorporates the convention and comes into force on October 2. He is also the minister responsible for protecting national security and countering terrorism. The two Sikhs, Mukhtiar Singh and Paramijt Singh, entered Britain hidden in a lorry. MI5 told the commission they had helped to arrange the supply of explosives from Pakistan to the Punjab.

Straw wanted them deported. The commission said the pair had a "well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of political opinion" and there were substantial grounds for believing they would face a "real risk of being subjected to torture" if they were sent back to India.

Article 3 of the European convention states: "No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment." By the way it couched its ruling, it was almost as if the commission blamed the European convention - and Straw - for forcing them to come to the conclusion they did. The Daily Mail certainly got the message. Under the front-page headline "Terrorists who can't be deported", it said: "Two Sikh terrorists must be allowed to stay in Britain despite the threat they pose to national security."

The next day, the London Evening Standard devoted two pages to "how Europe's human rights charter will affect British law". It cited the Sikh case, the end to the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces and how those accused of traffic offences will be able to withhold information by claiming the right against self-incrimination. In fact, these rights have been there ever since Britain ratified the European convention 50 years ago. But the Human Rights Act means that from October 2 people will be able to claim them here rather than having to go through the lengthy and expensive process of appealing to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg (which is nothing to do with the EU's court of justice, by the way).

This has not stopped judges appearing to be playing politics. Were the members of the special immigration appeals commission really suggesting that if it was not for the European convention, they would have sent the two Sikhs back to face torture? Why then point the finger at the convention and at Straw?

The appeal court last month turned the argument on its head when it suggested that rights guaranteed by the European convention are already enshrined in English law. Lord Justice Judge dismissed an attempt by state prosecutors to seize any emails or notes the Guardian and Observer may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler. "We surely appreciate," he said, "that the principles found in article 6 [of the European convention, covering the right against self-incrimination] and article 10 [the right to freedom of expression] are bred in the bone of the common law and indeed... the folk understanding of the community as a whole."

Straw has made it more difficult for himself by endorsing new, extraordinarily broad, definitions of Britain's "national security" and of "terrorism". After hearing evidence from Peter Wrench, a senior Home Office official, on another deportation case, the appeal court in May ruled that "the promotion of terrorism against any state is capable of being a threat to our own national security".

The new terrorism bill says that any act or threat of "serious violence" motivated by political, religious, or ideological reasons is an act of terrorism. Wrench admitted in the Sikh case that whether or not individuals should be prosecuted was a matter of "executive judgment", ie political. Should Straw - or any home secretary - be responsible for both the secret police and human rights?

fields.headline: On the menu: brawn
fields.standfirst: Food on the net
fields.trailText: Food on the net
fields.body:
It seems that some people think brawn is made from beef, perhaps due to its beefcake associations.

Never! So what is it made from?

Pork, pork and more pork, head and shoulder.

And then?

It's brined and boiled, then the meat is stripped off the bones, mixed with herbs and spices and the reduced cooking liquor, and allowed to set.

That's it?

That's it in south-west England. In the north-east they like to colour the meat a rather fetching orangey-red.

Why?

Don't ask me.

How can I find brawn?

Not nearly often enough.

www.chandosdeli.com

Online store cupboard of the Bristol food and wine merchant - and if this is just a selection of its range, one can only dream of what's to be found on the real shop shelves. Gourmet breads, olives etc, impeccably sourced, with drink to match.

Pros: A serious online venture, the site is updated weekly and features special offers such as the current bin end sale. The staff top 10 is a handy guide to selecting the best of the range, and you can email for further assistance.

Cons: Can be pricey; not the place for your weekly groceries.

Delivery: Within two working days if you order before 3pm.

Charges: £4.99; free for orders of more than £100.

fields.headline: Rights go by the board
fields.trailText: The Home Office inspectors' report indicates that thousands of DNA samples are being held illegally (Report, August 1). This confirms Liberty's fears that the police would not comply with the requirement in the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act to destroy entries on the DNA database when a suspect is found not guilty or the prosecution is discontinued
fields.body:
The Home Office inspectors' report indicates that thousands of DNA samples are being held illegally (Report, August 1). This confirms Liberty's fears that the police would not comply with the requirement in the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act to destroy entries on the DNA database when a suspect is found not guilty or the prosecution is discontinued. This means the the police are holding the DNA samples of innocent people.

The police must ensure these records are destroyed. If they don't, not only will they be failing to comply with the existing law, but they will also be in breach of article 8 (the right to privacy) of the European convention of human rights, which will be incorporated into British law on October 2. Liberty intends to mount a legal challenge to ensure that people's rights are not infringed in this way.

James Welch, Legal director, Liberty

One of the government's early commitments after winning power was to create a joint parliamentary select committee on human rights to give independent and authoritative advice to parliament on the compatibility of government measures with fundamental human rights.

The House of Lords has approved the terms of reference of the committee, and a senior legal adviser was appointed several months ago. But there has been a continuing failure by the government has to put the terms of reference to the Commons.

As a result, the select committee will not be in place on October 2, when the Human Rights Act is brought fully into force. The government will remain immune from its scrutiny while controversial measures are enacted.

Lord Lester

webTitle: Letters: Builders must abandon the Model T Ford approach

fields.headline: Builders must abandon the Model T Ford approach
fields.trailText: The debate about residential design on your pages over the past few days has been fascinating. I have spent five years on a planning committee and we've often had to give permission to poor-quality private housing developments.
fields.body:
The debate about residential design on your pages over the past few days has been fascinating. I have spent five years on a planning committee and we've often had to give permission to poor-quality private housing developments. Apart from the impossibly expensive flats that crowd Leeds waterfront, or some splendid eco-houses in Meanwood, I haven't seen one I'd buy for my family. I saw more good modern housebuilding in one week in the Dutch city of Delft than in 20 years in Britain.

The problem isn't with planners - I've seen them exhort, cajole, encourage and negotiate to try to achieve limited improvements to the wretched designs submitted by developers. As Riba president Marco Goldschmied points out (Letters, August 2), architects aren't the block either. Volume housebuilders rarely use them - and it shows. For people who want interesting, environmentally sustainable modern housing, the only options are finding an architect and builder, or self-build. As your correspondent Kay Stead eloquently pointed out, that's rarely practical. We're forced to compromise, either by buying the rubbish that the housebuilders choose to sell, or purchasing second-hand.

What is unreasonable about wanting the kind of energy efficiency taken for granted by the Dutch, the Swedes or the Germans? Is it unrealistic to demand that design reflects contours, prevailing wind, light and shade? Why do doors, windows and ceilings fail to take account of the fact that people are taller than they were in the 30s? Why can't we have homes whose design allows us to face the problems of ageing or disability with dignity and minimal disruption? Why must rewiring, replumbing or computer cabling inevitably involve ripping out plaster and the purgatory of redecoration? Why does the street layout of most modern estates put pedestrians last? Why does housebuilding require the use of huge volumes of sand, gravel and other non-renewable aggregates?

The volume housebuilders need to abandon their Model T Ford approach to design and production, and there needs to be an informed debate on the long-term implications of the jerry-building they currently perpetrate.

Cllr John Erskine, Leeds
John.Erskine@leeds.gov.uk

Marco Goldschmied's thinly veiled advert for the country to use more architects ignores the fact that architects have been part of the development industry for centuries. Whilst much of their work has succeeded, many of the appalling buildings from the 50s and 60s now being torn down, or which lie derelict, arise from architects' visions that they knew better than anyone else. And much of the "cultural Americana" he condemns is designed by his colleagues. The sniffy tone towards people "whose concerns are purely economic" (of course architects' fees are driven purely by altruism) is not helpful. We need constructive input into design issues, not more condescending lectures.

Dr Stuart Hill, Chief executive, House Builders Federation

fields.headline: Gordon's surprise
fields.trailText: The biggest surprise about Gordon Brown's wedding (Chancellor's wedding surprise, August 3) is that he managed to say "I do" - we all expected his reply to be "Only when the economic circumstances are right".
fields.body:
The biggest surprise about Gordon Brown's wedding (Chancellor's wedding surprise, August 3) is that he managed to say "I do" - we all expected his reply to be "Only when the economic circumstances are right".

Teresa Pearce, Erith, Kent

A Commons committee recommends that the minimum income guarantee should be raised to £90 (MPs support pension rises, August 3). A pensioner couple in my family has just been awarded 2p a week under the current MIG. Any suggestions as to how they might spend it?

Andrew Reece, London

John Humphrys is a voice of reason in a demented media world (Leader, August 3) . He is curmudgeonly only with purveyors of sophistry. More power to his elbow, I say.

Michael Fuller, Harpenden, Herts

Do Sandra and Hugh Wilmot (Letter, July 31) know that the ideal body weight related to height for an average male can be expressed as: W/H<+>2 = 22.5, where W = weight in kg and H = height in metres? Thus their son's data, height 1.8m and weight 80kg, work out at 80/3.24 = 24.7. So, unless he is very heavily built, he is 7kg (1st) overweight. The formula is unique to the metric system.

AK Mikkelsen, Welwyn Garden City, Herts

Re the scarcity of monkey puzzle trees (Letters August 2), one factor is the root system: the house opposite me was undermined by a fairly small one. Incidentally, Kew Gardens keeps a record of older trees and collects seed pods from them.

RK Williams, Redditch, Worcs

According to your reports, Hove has had no weather for several weeks. Is it no longer even dull there?

Tim Curran, Brighton

fields.headline: Gun culture
fields.trailText: Thank you for having the imagination to publish your article on the protest against the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, Tennessee (Street defence for Martin Luther King, July 15).
fields.body:
Thank you for having the imagination to publish your article on the protest against the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, Tennessee (Street defence for Martin Luther King, July 15). For more than 12 years, this permanent street protest has supported the aspirations of Dr King and encouraged people to boycott the museum.

The museum has a policy of using negativity and violence to educate children about civil rights. Work will soon begin on refurbishing the rooming house where James Earl Ray allegedly fired the fatal shot. The alleged murder weapon is an exhibit in the museum. As the US plummets further into the depths of gun culture, now is the time to heed Dr King's non-violence teachings.

There is a protest website (www.fulfillthedream.net) where more information is available on how the teachings of Dr King can be kept alive.

Jacqueline Smith, Memphis, Tennessee jsmith@fulfillthedream.net

fields.headline: Ethiopia's war is over
fields.trailText: Despite what Thomas Keneally writes (The Kosovo of Africa, July 29), the conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea is over. It was sparked by Eritrea's invasion of Badme and other Ethiopian territory in May 1998.
fields.body:
Despite what Thomas Keneally writes (The Kosovo of Africa, July 29), the conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea is over. It was sparked by Eritrea's invasion of Badme and other Ethiopian territory in May 1998. The Organisation of African Unity, the UN and every western country agree this was so. Mr Keneally has been duped with the "there are two Badmes" claim.

After two years of fruitless attempts to bring Eritrea to the peace table, Ethiopia took back its territory in May. There has been no international outcry because the international community is well aware that Ethiopia has simply taken back what was rightfully hers.

Ethiopia has no claim on the port of Assab or any Eritrean territory and its troops will withdraw from the buffer zone once UN peacekeepers arrive. As Mr Keneally admits, Eritrean refugees have been able to return to their homes and despite his claims, hundreds of thousands of Eritreans continue to live peaceably in Ethiopia.

Beyene Negewo, Ethiopian ambassador

After the Mengistu regime was overthrown in 1991, the new Ethiopian government reduced the army by 80%, abandoned conscription and cut defence spending to 2% of GDP. Ministers have lost their seats in elections and there is a critical private press. In Eritrea, the EPLF boosted defence spending to 38% of GDP. It has held no elections and tolerates not even the mildest criticism. From 1994 to 1998, it engaged in conflict with four neighbours - Sudan, Djibouti, Yemen and finally Ethiopia. At that time, its army was three times the size of Ethiopia's.

Tony Hickey, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia village.ethiopia@telecom.net.et
