fields.headline: Letters: Bruce Douglas-Mann
fields.trailText: Your obituary of Bruce Douglas-Mann (July 31) referred only briefly to his concern about housing and his work for Shelter.
fields.body:
Chris Holmes, director of Shelter, writes: Your obituary of Bruce Douglas-Mann (July 31) referred only briefly to his concern about housing and his work for Shelter.

I first met him in the mid-1960s, when he was the Labour spokesperson for housing on Kensington and Chelsea council. He was the first Labour councillor to align himself with the radical community activists who were working with local tenants to fight against evictions by rapacious property companies. He became one of the founder supporters of the Notting Hill Community Workshop.

At that time, North Kensington was notorious for the race riots of 1959 and the landlord activities of Rachman. The report of the Milner Holland inquiry into London's housing showed the acute concentration of multi-occupied, poor quality, but high-rent accommodation in the area - with the Golborne ward suffering from the highest levels of overcrowding in the whole country.

Bruce made a special priority of one particular injustice - the treatment of tenants of furnished accommodation. In 1965, the Labour government had restored security of tenure to tenants of private landlords, but only if the accommodation was unfurnished. In inner-city areas of housing shortage, landlords used this loophole to let poorly furnished rooms. Those most affected were recently arrived black families, especially from the West Indies. They were paying more money for poorer quality and less secure accommodation. It was a classic example of what is now known as "institutional racism" - and Bruce was one of the very few politicians to challenge it.

He took up this issue with relentless determination. One successful tactic - using his knowledge as a lawyer - was to challenge in the courts whether accommodation could be properly described as "furnished". This resulted in some spectacular victories for individual tenants.

More importantly for long-term solutions, especially after his election as MP for North Kensington in 1970, he played a key role in influencing Labour party policy to end the arbitrary distinction between the treatment of furnished and unfurnished tenants. As a member of the standing committee on the rent bill in the summer of 1974, he fought tenaciously, through late night sittings, to ensure that legislation became law before parliament was dissolved.

Those same qualities marked his membership of the Shelter board of trustees for 27 years, including serving as chair from 1987 to 1993. He was committed to all Shelter's work, including the practical services - helping people with all kinds of housing problems- but for him the most important role was changing housing policy to secure long-term solutions.

One special preoccupation was the reform of housing finance. He was deeply disappointed by Anthony Crosland's housing finance review in the mid-1970s. For more than 20 years, he argued passionately for changes to the public sector borrowing rules, which discriminate unfairly between investment by local authorities and private borrowers.

The common threads which ran through the successful practice of his law firm, political career and his voluntary work were his integrity, consistency of ideas and a quiet, but deeply held commitment to equality and justice.

John Grant writes: Bruce Douglas-Mann was one of life's awkward squad, which is perhaps why we maintained our friendship over many parliamentary years and beyond. As Edward Pearce's obituary made clear, Bruce was stubborn, but absolutely straight. He was indeed a hesitant speaker, but it was his determined adherence to principles that ensured that significant political progress was never really a runner for him.

This was never more clearly illustrated than when he crossed the floor from Labour to the SDP in 1982, some little while after my own defection. His insistence on fighting a bye-election in his Mitcham and Morden seat caused not just embarrasment but rage among the SDP leadership. It was an arguable decision, and it was made apparent to him that he could expect no help from the leadership if he pressed ahead.

Bruce lost not only his seat, but subsequently much of his appetite for politics, though he became a Liberal Democrat. He left his indelible mark in the bid to build a better society, especially so on the housing front and in his legal work on behalf of trade unionists in securing just rewards in industrial accident cases.

fields.headline: Pump up the jam charges
fields.trailText: The dump the pump protest cannot be dismissed as just a gripe by rural motorists in the Tory shires (Leader, August 2). The biggest boycott was in the north-east, where incomes are below the average, suggesting the campaign attracted the support of many kinds of people who need their cars, but are finding them increasingly unaffordable
fields.body:
The dump the pump protest cannot be dismissed as just a gripe by rural motorists in the Tory shires (Leader, August 2). The biggest boycott was in the north-east, where incomes are below the average, suggesting the campaign attracted the support of many kinds of people who need their cars, but are finding them increasingly unaffordable. Road users should indeed suffer the environmental and social costs which their motoring causes, but fuel duty increases are not the right solution.

Our research shows that the bulk of the social and environmental costs of road use occur in towns and at peak times. A car on a rural motorway imposes costs on others of only 0.8p per km. By contrast, the social cost of driving in a town centre at peak times is more than 50 times higher, at 43p per km. When we compared social costs against the amount motorists pay in fuel and vehicle taxes, we discovered that people in rural areas pay three times too much for the use they make of the roads. Yet urban drivers going to work or on the school run pay only one-seventh of the social costs.

People should pay directly for the roads they use. But fuel duty is a very unfair way of doing that. Tolls in town centres, coupled with big cuts in fuel and vehicle taxes, are the only way to improve the environment and to spread the costs of motoring more fairly.

Steve Bettison, Adam Smith Institute steve@adamsmith.org.uk

The true cost of petrol has to be measured in terms of environmental, as well as, financial impact. Transport is the third largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the UK: it is also the fastest growing source. By some forecasts, car traffic could treble over the next two decades, while van and lorry numbers could rise even more rapidly.

Cleaner, greener and more efficient transport systems provide the real solution to sustainable living. Directing petrol taxes back into improving transport options, just as tobacco tax revenues are now ploughed back into the health service, could provide a key mechanism for achieving mobility and access for the entire population - without it costing the earth.

Sir John Harman, Chairman, Environment Agency

John Prescott seems to have developed an unfortunate victim complex, centred for some odd reason on Friends of the Earth (Interview, August 1). We have spent the last few days defending high petrol taxes against Poujadist protesters. Despite Mr Prescott's claim that environment organisations have run away from this battle, we have in fact been far more active on the subject than any minister.

When Labour was elected, Mr Prescott said he would have failed if at the end of its first term there were not far fewer journeys by car. Now, he admits that there will be more. This failure is not entirely his fault: he has been obstructed time and again by Mr Blair and Mr Brown. We would like to work with him to increase the political clout of his department. Moaning at environment organisations will do no good at all.

Tony Juniper, Friends of the Earth

Of course, people on low incomes in rural areas suffer from high fuel prices: 75% of rural parishes have no daily bus service and those on low incomes are twice as likely to own a car in rural rather than metropolitan areas. Cars are an essential lifeline in the countryside. Cutting off the blood supply by increasing fuel costs will kill off the countryside.

Edmund King, Director, RAC Foundation

Our research shows that the bulk of the social and environmental costs of road use occur in towns and at peak times. A car on a rural motorway imposes costs on others of only 0.8p per km. webTitle: TV guide: What's happening in Big Brother.

fields.headline: The rat race
fields.standfirst: What's happening in Big Brother
fields.trailText: What's happening in Big Brother
fields.body:
Another week, another two house members are nominated for expulsion. As painful as it is to watch proposed expulsee Caroline struggle on, socially wounded, for another seven days, surely the public will vote against Andy tonight (even if he has staged a last minute popularity-ploy by openly snogging Melanie). It's the closest we can get to expressing our distaste for Nicholas, after all.

Meanwhile, as the household slumps a little deeper into its sinister self-generated culture, one thing has become clear. These people were brought together so we could spy on them fighting, sexual frisson-ing, building friendships and having breakdowns. You know - doing stuff. Yet all we're left with currently is one long-winded novice therapy session, in which the contestants pick at the scabs on their own particular, self-imposed brand of human condition. Their language ( When you do this, I feel blah) smacks of the kind of amateur psychology-speak of corporate team-empathy training courses.

Anna is thriving in the climate of shrink-speak. Despite being mildly disappointing on the proffering-of-unwanted-sexual-advances front - she's a lesbian ex-nun, for heaven's sake - we were led to believe we could expect that kind of thing. She is, perhaps, the only genuinely good listener in residence. However - regardless of Craig's fall from grace during Tuesday night's in-house voting - I'd still stake a lot on a man triumphing.

Perhaps Thomas who, though a touch surly, distinguishes himself by being quiet, soft-spoken and rather handsome. A default winner, maybe. And another thing: as the Nicholas farrago - ie the blanket non-recognition of a lying, scheming, poisonous element - steams on, I'm frankly surprised the whole nation hasn't dissolved into a heaving mass of paranoia. How do we know who to trust any more? Do all of us associate with a Nicholas? Would we ever find out if we did? These are frightening times.

fields.headline: Tokyo calling
fields.standfirst: For anyone who watches a lot of TV, Japanese culture is an open book - it's all crazy cartoons, Monkey and masochistic businessmen. Isn't it? Actually no, says  Mark Morris, as the BBC devotes a weekend to the subject
fields.trailText: For anyone who watches a lot of TV, Japanese culture is an open book - it's all crazy cartoons, Monkey and masochistic businessmen. Isn't it? Actually no, says Mark Morris, as the BBC devotes a weekend to the subject.
fields.body:
Flipping channels last week, I came across Tarrant on TV. Following the immutable law of British TV programmes about crazy foreigners, the first item was from Japan. Some skinny businessmen were competing in a bizarre and incomprehensible game show, which involved crashing through walls.

Ever since Clive James first chuckled patronisingly at clips of Endurance, we've accepted this as what Japanese pop culture is, along with Pokémon, Godzilla, karaoke, an obsession with schoolgirls and a loving adoration of bands that are washed up here. Instinctively, we know this to be true - in the same way as many Americans will tell you, brooking no denial, that One Man And His Dog is the most popular programme in Britain. You can shout at them till you're hoarse, but it won't change their minds.

Likewise, through no more adventurous tactics than watching a lot of telly, we know what goes on in Japan. That such clearly insane and pathologically dirty-minded people managed to build the world's second largest economy out of post-war ruins just becomes a bigger mystery.

So BBC Choice's Japan TV weekend seems to be shooting into an open goal: practically anything that deviates from this ingrained set of stereotypes will seem refreshing. Which makes it strange that with so much presumably unsaid, they start with Monkey. Popular in Japan? Yes, a long time ago. As relevant to contemporary Japan as On The Buses is to us? Likewise. Again.

As for Lum the Invader Girl, an old cartoon freshly dubbed into English, it isn't even clear whether this is some inept attempt to reheat the What's Up Tiger Lily? formula (a mere three-and-a-half decades on) or whether the weak, mildly dirty humour is translated directly from the Japanese. Either way, it's still not very funny.

Things get better with Music In Japan. Judged as a documentary, it's not great. But at least it takes apart the conventional wisdom, pointing out that far from being obsessed by ageing foreign rockers, the Japanese are unusually loyal to homegrown pop. Which they then profitably export to other parts of Asia: Japanese pop culture is dominant in countries such as Singapore, Thailand and South Korea. To the point where it raises bad memories. According to Dr Hugo Dobson of the University of Kent, who spent several years living in Tokyo, "Korea regarded this as cultural imperialism and only recently withdrew restrictions on the import of Japanese CDs."

But we are swiftly back on familiar ground with Sex In Japan, a programme which shows its hand from the start by starting in Tokyo's red light district. Much as if a fair representation of what goes on in Britain's bedrooms could be found in the least gentrified corners of Soho, Sex In Japan informs us that the Japanese don't connect sex and guilt, do like schoolgirls, consider porn photographer Araki to be a "genius" and are experts at bondage. "Actually, the high level of Japanese bondage is a fair comment," Dobson reveals. "Japanese bondage is streets ahead of its international competitors and can be quite impressive - if you are a boy scout."

But although there is undoubtedly much for the seeker of sexual oddity to find in Japan, it covers the banal truth. "Clearly, like anywhere else," Dobson says, "the majority of sex in Japan goes on between consenting adult couples in long-term relationships."

And there is nothing here that hasn't been covered thoroughly in the western media, with a thin veneer of cultural superiority coating the voyeurism. Yet there are genuine popular culture phenomena in Japan that we don't hear about, and not just J-pop stars. Ringu (The Ring) is the Japanese equivalent of Scream or The Blair Witch Project, a deeply disturbing horror movie about an urban legend that comes true. Massively popular in Japan - and in movie-loving Hong Kong - it has spawned three sequels in as many years, as well as a TV series.

Needless to say, it doesn't get a mention on Japan TV. Over here, it has been relegated to the arthouse ghetto of the ICA cinema (albeit with a general release later this month). Why? Because it doesn't fit our idea of what Japan is: you can't giggle at it, it's not a cartoon and it has nothing to do with miniaturised technology. Stock assumptions that the Japan TV season, looking for "the weirdest and the coolest", isn't inclined to challenge.

Mind you, just when you think you've purged your mind of a lifetime of smug Clive Jamesian sneering, it comes right back at you. The most respectable offering in the Japan TV season is Violent Cop, one of actor/ director Takeshi Kitano's best films. In the west, on the back of movies like Hana Bi, Takeshi is regarded as one of the great film-making talents of our time, a fixture at Cannes, Venice and Berlin. But back home, Hugo Dobson says "he's better known as that idiot hosting programmes where girls in bikinis compete to see who can sit in a bath of boiling water the longest".

Do you reckon Tarrant has a tape of that?

BBC Choice's Japan TV Weekend runs from 9pm-2am on Saturday and 9pm-2.20am on Sunday.

webTitle: Stella Duffy on the lack of sisterhood.

fields.headline: Why can't a woman be more like a man?
fields.standfirst: Stella Duffy on the lack of sisterhood
fields.trailText: Stella Duffy on the lack of sisterhood.
fields.body:
From Katie Roiphe using the ruse of "reporting others" to denigrate Hillary Clinton in Monday's G2 to the Big Brother girls playing each other off for the boys, women insist on making it easy for men. Men get the benefits from taking care of each other; we get left with the dregs.

Men promote other men - promote each other literally and promote each other's work. While women read both men and women, men generally read other men. Women read Nick Hornby, but how many men have read Helen Fielding? And few men slag off Hornby, while many women (yes, me too) have no qualms about denigrating the work of another woman. Why is it normal for comedy shows to have half a dozen men and one woman performer? Why is Smack the Pony promoted as a women's comedy show and The League of Gentlemen not called a men's comedy show?

Men look after men. Why don't women in power care for women? Could it be because in other women's failings we see our own and would rather ignore them? Most women have no problem disparaging men. The prevailing wisdom calls them feckless, childish, vain and useless at handling more than one task at a time. We love them for it, we smile condescendingly. But this is only the inverted "power" of the underdog - claiming we know better, letting him think he's in charge while we really run things. Wake up! He is still in charge. He runs every government in the world, he owns more than 80% of the planet's wealth and he decides what he does with it. It's not men's fault that they hold the sway of power; they were born that way. But if, after 40 years of second-wave feminism, we still want change, perhaps it's time we got on with making it happen.

We know it's hard to be a woman who stands out. And yet when we do accomplish those gains for ourselves, we often adopt the attitude: "If I did it, why can't she?" Until we learn that the only true power is in unity, we're doomed to smash against glass ceilings for ever.

It's easy to denigrate men. We're not them and, mostly, we're not much like them. But we are like other women. And most of us are aware that it's easier to be one or two women working with many men; easier to stand out as the only woman; easier not to have your weaknesses compared to another woman's. And I'm bored with it. Bored with women saying they don't like, don't trust each other. Men don't always feel the need to bond on every level before they consider themselves friends - where we require five drunken evenings, one snappy business lunch and three semi-pissed phone conversations, a round of golf seems to do it for them.

We complain that men don't like us but what about the possibility that we don't like ourselves? We'll forgive Bill his philandering, but not Hillary for putting up with it. We think it's fine for Tony to keep running the country, but wonder whether Cherie's right in going back to work so early. We forgive the sins of our fathers long before we forgive those of our mothers.

One of the problems is the requirement for the successful woman to become a star everywoman. When Alan Davies appears in a new sitcom he is judged as Alan Davies, not as a representative of all men, all comedy men, or even all comedy men with curly hair. When Rhona Cameron does the same, her work is judged as a woman, then as a lesbian, finally as a comedian. Clare Short is not a politician, she's a woman politician. Anita Roddick is expected to speak for all businesswomen. By requiring every woman to succeed on behalf of all women, we make that achievement impossible. Which of us can possibly please all of us?

Men help other men to success, probably without even noticing it. When a woman suggests another woman for work, isn't there always the worry that maybe she'll take the job from you? After all, The News Quiz and Have I Got News for You regularly have all-male panels; it's not a groundless fear to think that one woman touting another woman as clever and funny will do herself out of a job. Men seem to know that getting on well enough works. Why do we expect so much from ourselves and get so hurt when we don't get it?

How about using each other's good fortune as a guide, rather than a barb on which to snare ourselves? How about helping each other in the way men do - not because of the old school tie, rarely as part of a male global conspiracy, just because they can. And how about building on our strengths instead of ignoring them entirely - and then complaining when the boys do exactly the same?

Shane Watson is away.

fields.headline: Roberto Suárez
fields.standfirst: Notorious Bolivian drug baron and conduit for Oliver North's funds to the Nicaraguan contras
fields.trailText: However flattering it may be within criminal circles to be described as "the biggest drug dealer who ever lived", the handful of men who have claimed the title have invariably lived to regret it. Roberto Suárez, Bolivia's "cocaine king", lived longer than most, and has died aged 68, apparently of natural causes, with his family saying he had a heart attack. Not long ago, he told a television interviewer that going into the drugs business was, "the worst mistake I ever made".
fields.body:
However flattering it may be within criminal circles to be described as "the biggest drug dealer who ever lived", the handful of men who have claimed the title have invariably lived to regret it. Roberto Suárez, Bolivia's "cocaine king", lived longer than most, and has died aged 68, apparently of natural causes, with his family saying he had a heart attack. Not long ago, he told a television interviewer that going into the drugs business was, "the worst mistake I ever made".

A cattle rancher from Bolivia's "wild east" - the Beni region on the border with Brazil - Suárez moved into cocaine at roughly the same time as his more famous contemporaries in neighbouring Colombia. In the mid-1970s, the white powder was becoming the drug of choice for upwardly-mobile young professionals in the United States. With wholesale blackmarket prices in New York hovering around $60,000 a kilo, demand for the raw material - a paste made from the leaves of the coca bush - was rocketing.

But coca, a plant native to the lower slopes of the Andes mountains, grew poorly outside its original habitat in Peru and Bolivia. The Colombians, who had established themselves as the dominant force in the manufacture of the finished product, needed allies in the coca-growing regions if they were to keep their laboratories in business.

Enter Roberto Suárez. His genius was, first, to gather most of his country's producers of coca and cocaine into one organisation, which he called "the Corporation" and which one author described as the "General Motors of cocaine". It became a major supplier to the so-called Medellin cartel of Colombia.

Second, Suárez moved to ensure political protection for his enterprise amid the turbulent politics of what was then South America's most unstable nation. When one of the short-lived governments of the period, under Bolivia's first woman president, Lidia Gueiler, proved hostile to the drugs trade, her cousin, General Luis García Meza, who was also head of the army, began plotting a coup.

García Meza overthrew Gueiler's successor, Hernán Siles Zuazo, in July, 1980, three weeks after the latter's election to the presidency. His coup had been backed by Suárez's cocaine mafia, the military dictatorship of Argentina and the CIA. The world's first "narco-state" was born.

Michael Levine, the senior agent in the region for the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), had earlier penetrated the Suárez organisation and claimed he "was being offered thousands of kilos of cocaine a month". But the DEA, apparently under CIA pressure, had hampered Levine's operation, even to the extent of insisting that its computers held no information on Suárez. Eventually arrests were made, but the two key Corporation figures were subsequently released - at least one of them had close links to the CIA.

García Meza's government lasted little over a year, but Suárez continued to enjoy political protection. As his wealth grew, he even made an apparently serious offer to pay off the country's national debt in exchange for an amnesty. The offer was rejected.

Throughout the 1980s, Suárez enjoyed effective immunity. Strong evidence suggests that he also continued to deal with the American intelligence community. During the Iran-Contra affair, when Lt-Col Oliver North, of the US National Security Council, hit upon the idea of selling cocaine to raise funds for the anti-Sandinista "contra" rebels in Nicaragua, he used Suárez as a key supplier.

Eventually, however, the political protection wore thin. North's operation was exposed, peace broke out in Central America, and García Meza went on the run. Civilian democracy was becoming established in Bolivia - and Suárez was an embarassment.

In 1989, he was arrested at one of his northern Beni ranches - where police could have found him earlier had they wished - and put on trial for the production and trafficking of cocaine. Sentenced to 15 years in jail, he was released after serving less than half his sentence. With his assets seized, and cut off from his customary source of easy cash, Suárez was, once again, merely a cattle rancher.

According to his lawyer, he had 18 children from several different marriages. One of them, Roberto Suárez Levy, was killed in 1990 during a gun battle with police.

Roberto Suárez García, rancher and drug trafficker, born 1932; died July 20 2000

With wholesale blackmarket prices in New York hovering around $60,000 a kilo, demand for the raw material - a paste made from the leaves of the coca bush - was rocketing. But coca, a plant native to the lower slopes of the Andes mountains, grew poorly outside its original habitat in Peru and Bolivia. The Colombians, who had established themselves as the dominant force in the manufacture of the finished product, needed allies in the coca-growing regions if they were to keep their laboratories in business. Enter Roberto Suárez. His genius was, first, to gather most of his country's producers of coca and cocaine into one organisation, which he called "the Corporation" and which one author described as the "General Motors of cocaine". It became a major supplier to the so-called Medellin cartel of Colombia. Second, Suárez moved to ensure political protection for his enterprise amid the turbulent politics of what was then South America's most unstable nation. When one of the short-lived governments of the period, under Bolivia's first woman president, Lidia Gueiler, proved hostile to the drugs trade, her cousin, General Luis García Meza, who was also head of the army, began plotting a coup. García Meza overthrew Gueiler's successor, Hernán Siles Zuazo, in July, 1980, three weeks after the latter's election to the presidency. His coup had been backed by Suárez's cocaine mafia, the military dictatorship of Argentina and the CIA. The world's first "narco-state" was born. Michael Levine, the senior agent in the region for the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), had earlier penetrated the Suárez organisation and claimed he "was being offered thousands of kilos of cocaine a month". But the DEA, apparently under CIA pressure, had hampered Levine's operation, even to the extent of insisting that its computers held no information on Suárez. Eventually arrests were made, but the two key Corporation figures were subsequently released - at least one of them had close links to the CIA. García Meza's government lasted little over a year, but Suárez continued to enjoy political protection. As his wealth grew, he even made an apparently serious offer to pay off the country's national debt in exchange for an amnesty. The offer was rejected. Throughout the 1980s, Suárez enjoyed effective immunity. Strong evidence suggests that he also continued to deal with the American intelligence community. During the Iran-Contra affair, when Lt-Col Oliver North, of the US National Security Council, hit upon the idea of selling cocaine to raise funds for the anti-Sandinista "contra" rebels in Nicaragua, he used Suárez as a key supplier. Eventually, however, the political protection wore thin. North's operation was exposed, peace broke out in Central America, and García Meza went on the run. Civilian democracy was becoming established in Bolivia - and Suárez was an embarassment. In 1989, he was arrested at one of his northern Beni ranches - where police could have found him earlier had they wished - and put on trial for the production and trafficking of cocaine. Sentenced to 15 years in jail, he was released after serving less than half his sentence. With his assets seized, and cut off from his customary source of easy cash, Suárez was, once again, merely a cattle rancher. According to his lawyer, he had 18 children from several different marriages. One of them, Roberto Suárez Levy, was killed in 1990 during a gun battle with police. Roberto Suárez García, rancher and drug trafficker, born 1932; died July 20 2000

fields.headline: Sir Philip Jones
fields.standfirst: The man who reluctantly helped to get Concorde off the ground
fields.trailText: Sir Philip Jones, who has died aged 69, was the second of three senior civil servants responsible for handling the Anglo-French Concorde project from its inception to operational status. The archetypal Whitehall mandarin, with brilliant intellectual background and rigid integrity, he went on to major roles in the development of Britain's oil, gas and electricity supplies.
fields.body:
Sir Philip Jones, who has died aged 69, was the second of three senior civil servants responsible for handling the Anglo-French Concorde project from its inception to operational status. The archetypal Whitehall mandarin, with brilliant intellectual background and rigid integrity, he went on to major roles in the development of Britain's oil, gas and electricity supplies.

The son of a police chief inspector and a teacher, Jones was born in Kent, but the family moved to Wales while he was still a child, and he identified with Wales for the rest of his life. He attended Cowbridge grammar school and won an exhibition to Jesus College, Oxford, where he studied greats (ancient history and philosophy). After national service as a junior officer in the Royal Artillery from 1953-5, he became an assistant principal in the then Ministry of Supply.

Jones was soon deeply involved in the controversies over the proposed supersonic airliner - not yet named Concorde. By 1967, he was assistant secretary at the Ministry of Technology, under the first director-general of the project, Jim (later Sir James) Hamilton.

The top civil servants suddenly found they were deeply divided. Jones and Sir Ronald Melville, permanent secretary at the Ministry of Aviation, felt strongly that it was commercially unviable and should be cancelled. Hamilton, backed by Air Chief Marshal Sir Christopher Hartley, controller of aircraft, argued that it was a great project, which should go ahead. They took their problem to the then technology minister, Tony Benn. "What are you talking about?" he asked. "Of course, we are going ahead."

Despite his misgivings, Jones succeeded Hamilton as DG Concorde, and was admired by his colleagues for the way in which he put aside his personal feelings. He was much respected by his French counterparts during the years of nationalistic negotiations that followed, and was perhaps the last of his breed to use a pipe as a debating weapon - gaining time to reflect on the subtleties of French while filling and lighting it, and then aiming the stem across the table as he replied. It seems likely, however, that his lack of enthusiasm was reflected in the anti-supersonic coverage in most of the media during the 1970s.

Jones was probably relieved when Kenneth Binning, another fast-track mandarin, took over as DG Concorde, while he was transferred to the Department of Energy to handle oil and gas policy. Here, his negotiating abilities found a new outlet in handling the franchises for the North Sea oil leases. Insiders expected him to take over from Sir Donald Maitland as the department's permanent secretary, but the story goes that he fell out with the then Conservative chancellor, Nigel Lawson, and was given, in the words of a colleague, "the best consolation prize you can get", the chairmanship of the Electricity Council.

With the industry facing privatisation, Jones fought - and won - a grim battle with Lord Marshall of Goring, chairman of the Central Electricity Generating Board. Marshall wanted the CEGB to retain control of the national grid, while Jones wanted to introduce competition by handing over responsibility to the area electricity boards. Marshall's public campaign was defeated by Jones's more subtle negotiating skills in Whitehall.

When the Electricity Council was wound up in 1990, the former civil servant became chairman of Total Oil for eight years, where his Concorde experience helped to maintain good relations with the French holding company. He also became a member, and then chairman, of the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, the Welsh Office seeking his services in improving teaching and research standards in Welsh universities and colleges. Among his honours was the the Lion of Finland decoration, confered in 1997 by that country's president.

Sir Philip married Mary Phillips in 1955, and they had two sons. She died earlier this year.

Sir (Thomas) Philip Jones, civil servant and industrialist, born July 13 1931; died July 19 2000

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: Why Bush should not be elected

fields.headline: Clinton's foreign forays were dubious. Bush would be worse
fields.standfirst:
A Republican administration bodes ill for the rest of us
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A Republican administration bodes ill for the rest of us.
fields.body:
We began the last decade with a Bush in the White House, and we may continue in this one with another in the same place, a possibility that illustrates the sadly circular nature of recent history. Perhaps worse than that - for the older Bush, if a limited man of the upperclass right, did have a few virtues, while his son is a man of no apparent quality or achievements. Worse, too, in that what it seemed permissible to hope for under the father seems remote indeed should the son be elected.

The father at least spoke of a better ordered world, and some of his policies contributed toward it. The son, by contrast, speaks only of a dangerous planet against which America must be protected, whether by radars and missiles or by hard-faced trade negotiators.

Ten years ago it was reasonable to look forward to a degree of nuclear disarmament sufficient to keep proliferation in check, to a resolution of Middle Eastern conflicts, to progress in Africa, to democratic evolution in Russia and, more broadly, to a consensus among the better-off and more powerful states that would make all international problems easier to deal with than they had been.

No doubt these hopes underestimated the obdurate nature of these problems and no doubt, too, that the instruments of policy, whether the choice was aid, intervention, sanction or mediation, were overestimated. There is no question that the efforts that were made, by the United States under President Clinton and by other countries, were very flawed.

The collapse of the Camp David talks, on the one hand, and the inexorable rise of national missile defence, on the other, frame the grand failure of the last decade. If Saddam had been brought down and a democratic Iraq had emerged - not so much of a forlorn hope as the cynics say - the resulting momentum might have encompassed an early settlement between Israelis and Palestinians. If an early settlement had been achieved in any case, it might have led to changes that would have undermined Saddam.

Neither chain developed. In part it was bad luck, in part lack of determination, in part lack of balance. Who knows whether a United States that had been consistently more even-handed, and more sustained in its application to the problem, might not have been able to pull off Camp David, by inducing the Israelis to give more and the Palestinians to take less? If so, even at this late stage, a new regional chemistry might have begun to work.

Saddam's survival is not the only reason that the idea of invulnerability to missile attack again took root in American politics. But, together with North Korea's manoeuvres, it reinforced such tendencies. The connection between enemies who can't be bested and who may soon possess weapons of mass destruction, interventions that don't come off, mediations that fail and force-field fantasies at home is evident. It is not so much that missile defence will work, as that the entrenched American belief in the power of technology makes it potent politically, in a way it could never physically be as an actual system.

The Republicans contributed to the failures of the two Clinton administrations but they can hardly be blamed for them. What they can be blamed for is seizing on those failures, at home and abroad, and turning them into the foundations of their policies for the future. At home, Clinton failed to reverse the American trend toward greater inequality of income. As with social democrats in other countries, his emphasis on education and opportunity, and even on health, ended up benefiting the middle class more than the truly disadvantaged.

The Republicans would row back on what Clinton achieved. Sprinkling Latinos, blacks and single mothers around to dramatise a new rhetoric of inclusion does not alter the fact that the Republican emphasis on decentralising social policy puts power into the hands of local elites who, it has been persistently demonstrated, act largely in their own interests.

The Republican party would be the worst party, for instance, to deal with the triangular conflict between Latinos and African-Americans in the older urban centres, starved of income and industry, and the largely white and middle-class population of the suburbs and the new "edge cities". Not far from the convention centre where the Republicans are meeting, in the Puerto Rican areas of north Philadelphia, two thirds of the children are growing up in households earning less than $15,500 a year, according to figures in Mike Davis's illuminating new book about Latino politics.

Little has been heard about what the Republicans would do about that, even though protest marchers have tried to raise the issue. Because of the wall in their minds between the United States and the rest of the world, even the rest of America, Republicans would be equally ill-equipped to deal with the challenge of a future in which political choices in, for example, Mexico or Venezuela, will affect the mood and the demands of people of Latin American background in US cities. Foreign policy and domestic policy could be mingled in novel ways as such connections develop.

But it is in foreign policy that a second Bush era is most to be feared. A Republican administration would not regard Clinton's failures abroad as a reason to try again but, in general, as a reason not to try at all. There may be exceptions to this, especially in the Middle East, and allowance must be made for the steadying influence of power and state department expertise. But America under the Republicans would be much less ready to engage, to take risks and to make sacri fices than it has been under Clinton, and since it has been very imperfectly ready to do so under the Democrats, that is saying something. Those who now recount, some of them with misguided glee, the ways in which American and western policies have gone wrong - how sanctions have killed children or how military intervention has led to more ethnic cleansing or how UN supervised elections have been subverted - might soon pine for the days when American action in international emergencies was at least a possibility.

The Republicans may be shifting a little. But they still remain the major party most committed to low state spending, to limited social programmes, to strategies that lead to greater disparity in income and quality of life for Americans, and, abroad, to policies emphasising defence and protection over aid, cooperation and working through the United Nations. In both home and foreign policy the Republican style is the same - a camouflage of inclusionist rhetoric over the reality of vested interest. In America itself, the security of the advantaged classes over the security of the whole society, and, abroad, the security of one nation set far too high over the security of other nations. The Democrats are hardly free of such tendencies but a Republican administration might well entrench them. The awful festival of humbug just concluded in Philadelphia bodes ill for America and the world.

fields.headline: The marketing men
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Farming is at a low ebb. I know men and women struggling to make a living on land that has been farmed by their families for generations. Jimmy Bell's family has farmed at Wingates since the 16th century and he intends to ensure that his young son carries on. "But if things go on like this he won't be able to make a living," he told me. "We live in beautiful country, but you can't make a living out of a view." Jimmy is now selling his prime home-produced lambs direct from the farm to local customers at farmers' markets. He also sells to customers who come to the farm to buy. The Bell family has a Texel cross ewe flock which runs on 300 acres, with 100 hoggs following on. Jimmy has invested in a chill room to hold 40 lamb carcasses and has upgraded his premises to match all environmental health standards, as well as learning butchery skills himself.

Farming is at a low ebb. I know men and women struggling to make a living on land that has been farmed by their families for generations. Jimmy Bell's family has farmed at Wingates since the 16th century and he intends to ensure that his young son carries on. "But if things go on like this he won't be able to make a living," he told me. "We live in beautiful country, but you can't make a living out of a view." Jimmy is now selling his prime home-produced lambs direct from the farm to local customers at farmers' markets. He also sells to customers who come to the farm to buy. The Bell family has a Texel cross ewe flock which runs on 300 acres, with 100 hoggs following on. Jimmy has invested in a chill room to hold 40 lamb carcasses and has upgraded his premises to match all environmental health standards, as well as learning butchery skills himself.

Jimmy's wife is involved in the new enterprise. Lambs from Wingates have proved themselves among the best, with championships won at Acklington mart and at the Simonside country fair. "I believe that a farmer who produces for the top end of the market should be the one to reap the benefits," Jimmy says. "Not the supermarkets."

There is something reassuring about buying food from the person who has been responsible for it, from start to finish. Peasant markets have long been a fact of life in France, Italy and Spain, with no middlemen and few overheads. Apparently, it was the farmers around Bath who showed the initiative here and started the markets movement, which spread through the west and south of England and appeared in the north two years ago. Durham, one of the first in the region, now holds a weekly Saturday morning market. Hexham, Morpeth and Alnwick hold markets once a month and attract hundreds of regular customers.

Never mind the weather, many of the markets are held in the open air. "Well worth a visit," said one gentleman as he brandished a bunch of carrots. "We've bought real vegetables with dirt on!"

webTitle: Sick Kray moved to hospital for tests

fields.headline: Sick Kray moved to hospital for tests
fields.trailText: Reggie Kray, the London gangster jailed more than 30 years ago, was moved to hospital yesterday for tests amid fears that he has liver and kidney problems.
fields.body:
Reggie Kray, the London gangster jailed more than 30 years ago, was moved to hospital yesterday for tests amid fears that he has liver and kidney problems.

Kray, 66, an inmate at Wayland prison in Norfolk, was examined in the hospital wing last week. His condition was considered serious enough for a referral to Norfolk and Norwich hospital early yesterday.

A recent report claimed Kray had lost the will to live following the deaths of his twin, Ronnie, and elder brother, Charlie, and was being kept alive on liquid food and a powerful painkiller. Kray's wife, Roberta, dismissed the claims.

In a statement on the Krays' website last week, she wrote, "Due to ill health, Reg has been transferred for observation and further tests.". She added, "He is not in any danger."

Norfolk and Norwich hospital refused to say why Kray had been admitted.

fields.headline: Trade war warning for DTI
fields.trailText: Britain faces the prospect of continual trade wars, Scotland's breakaway from the union, and marginalised ministers unable to pull effective policy levers - unless the government is radically re-engineered, according to a Department of Trade and Industry report.
fields.body:
Britain faces the prospect of continual trade wars, Scotland's breakaway from the union, and marginalised ministers unable to pull effective policy levers - unless the government is radically re-engineered, according to a Department of Trade and Industry report.

The report, by a civil servant, comes as the DTI starts a rethink of its role. Stephen Byers, the secretary of state, has argued recently that globalisation is forcing his department to rethink how it can help to restructure the economy and make it more competitive.

Today he will say globalisation can succeed only if its benefits are spread throughout the UK.

"We cannot be satisfied if the average standard of living is rising as a result of a few people doing a lot better. The creation of a privileged winners' circle limited to certain people, geographical areas or sectors of the economy will hold back our whole economy."

He will cite new figures showing how gross domestic product in the north in the past 10 years has not risen in line with the south. He is likely to use the figures to ensure applications for northern projects are given priority.

The DTI report, Globalisation Trends and Issues for Government, prepared by the futures unit, set out three scenarios based on different government responses to the changing economic environment.

In one, Institutional Impotence, it warned that if Whitehall failed to change ministers could become in thrall to nationalists, protectionists and non-governmental organisations such as the environment group Greenpeace and the World Trade Organisation. The UK would become engaged in continual low intensity trade wars inside and outside Europe.

It adds: "Scotland is threatening to break away, seeing its future in the Nordic countries rather than the UK."

Any attempt by the DTI to halt globalisation by imposing tariffs to protect English jobs would fail.

In a second scenario, Markets Win, the author, Michael Wild, warned against cutting back too far on government regulation. If there were no mechanism other than the market to balance claims on society, the government would be forced into retreat, the civil service would become unable to attract the best and the brightest, and the DTI would be able to operate only at the margins and be "unable to pull policy levers effectively".

Globalisation might not lead naturally to a fair dispersal of wealth, the report said. "Recent experience shows increasing clustering, particularly for knowledge industries. This may lead to a core of prosperity and a periphery of relative poverty, with rising income inequality and consequent social and political implications."

NGOs such as Greenpeace could "turn issues such as care for the environment into global brands and exploit their emotive force worldwide, usually to exert pressure on governments and multilateral NGOs such as the World Trade Organisation. Government may not be in control here: NGOs can increasingly set the pace on such issues".

The best hope for the DTI was for forms of government to be radically re-engineered, perhaps around project teams staffed by skilled specialists and supported by a central knowledge base.
fields.bodyText: Britain faces the prospect of continual trade wars, Scotland's breakaway from the union, and marginalised ministers unable to pull effective policy levers - unless the government is radically re-engineered, according to a Department of Trade and Industry report. The report, by a civil servant, comes as the DTI starts a rethink of its role. Stephen Byers, the secretary of state, has argued recently that globalisation is forcing his department to rethink how it can help to restructure the economy and make it more competitive. Today he will say globalisation can succeed only if its benefits are spread throughout the UK. "We cannot be satisfied if the average standard of living is rising as a result of a few people doing a lot better. The creation of a privileged winners' circle limited to certain people, geographical areas or sectors of the economy will hold back our whole economy." He will cite new figures showing how gross domestic product in the north in the past 10 years has not risen in line with the south. He is likely to use the figures to ensure applications for northern projects are given priority. The DTI report, Globalisation Trends and Issues for Government, prepared by the futures unit, set out three scenarios based on different government responses to the changing economic environment. In one, Institutional Impotence, it warned that if Whitehall failed to change ministers could become in thrall to nationalists, protectionists and non-governmental organisations such as the environment group Greenpeace and the World Trade Organisation. The UK would become engaged in continual low intensity trade wars inside and outside Europe. It adds: "Scotland is threatening to break away, seeing its future in the Nordic countries rather than the UK." Any attempt by the DTI to halt globalisation by imposing tariffs to protect English jobs would fail. In a second scenario, Markets Win, the author, Michael Wild, warned against cutting back too far on government regulation. If there were no mechanism other than the market to balance claims on society, the government would be forced into retreat, the civil service would become unable to attract the best and the brightest, and the DTI would be able to operate only at the margins and be "unable to pull policy levers effectively". Globalisation might not lead naturally to a fair dispersal of wealth, the report said. "Recent experience shows increasing clustering, particularly for knowledge industries. fields.headline: Sri Lankan reforms 'will end bloodshed'
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, announced plans yesterday for a new constitution offering, she said,the best hope of ending the civil war which has claimed 60,000 lives in 17 years.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, announced plans yesterday for a new constitution offering, she said,the best hope of ending the civil war which has claimed 60,000 lives in 17 years.

"Today is... arguably one of the most important days in the history of this country," she told parliament.

Much of her speech was drowned by the noisy protests of the opposition United National party. Its leader, Ranil Wickremesinghe, walked out soon after she rose to speak, and many of his MPs tore up their order papers in protest. One even set fire to his.

The government hopes that the new constitution, which gives more autonomy to the provinces, may eventually persuade the Tamil Tiger rebels to abandon their fight for an independent homeland in the north and east. So far the Tigers have insisted that they want nothing less than outright independence.

"I believe that this package offers the best hope to enduring peace in our country and the best chance of saving ourselves from more calamity," the president said.

"The war in this country is one of the bloodiest in the world, and a small, poor country can no longer afford the cost in human or financial resources."

The UNP has accused her of rushing the reforms through parliament without consulting the Buddhist clergy sufficiently.

The reforms need a two-thirds majority in parliament followed by approval in a referendum, which will not be held before the general election expected around October.

webTitle: Lovers' loss - Designer chic replaces site of Doisneau's kiss

fields.headline: Lovers' loss - Designer chic replaces site of Doisneau's kiss
fields.trailText: In the background the town hall is still there, and the lamp-post. But the terrace on which Robert Doisneau took what is probably the best-known Paris photograph is no more. The Cafe de l'Hotel de Ville, scene of his celebrated Baiser, has closed and will reopen next month as an upmarket pastry shop and tea-room.
fields.body:
In the background the town hall is still there, and the lamp-post. But the terrace on which Robert Doisneau took what is probably the best-known Paris photograph is no more. The Cafe de l'Hotel de Ville, scene of his celebrated Baiser, has closed and will reopen next month as an upmarket pastry shop and tea-room.

"Part of Paris' soul is being torn out," said Christian Navet of the Paris cafe-owners' association. "First it was banks who bought up the best-placed sites, now it's designer clothes stores and chic eateries. When is someone going to realise that as well as the monuments, there's a living heritage here that needs defending?"

Doisneau shot Le Baiser de l'Hotel de Ville, the archetypal picture of Paris's most archetypal open-air activity, on the terrace of the cafe in 1950. Although he later admitted using professional models, his photograph of a young, tousle-haired man planting a kiss on the lips of a slender girl became a symbol of Paris romance, selling 250,000 copies a year in poster form.

The demise of the picture's location, in the 4th arrondissement, has dismayed conservationists and upset latter-day lovers who delighted in recreating the image.

"Of course it's a sad day," said Alexandre Gady of the regional heritage commission. "But I'm afraid there's little we can do - it's the freedom of commerce. Sometimes in cases like this we've been able to save the facade and the old sign. But unfortunately, this one was nothing special." The change marks another step in the gentrification of Paris, which has lost many landmarks to designer names.

The damage has been worst in once-bohemian St-Germain-des-Près, where such Left Bank notables as Charles Aznavour and Catherine Deneuve have founded pressure groups to try to halt further invasion.

"This neighbourhood has people to fight for it," said Anne Biraben, a member of one such group. "Sadly the 4th arrondissement, Le Baiser or not, hasn't."

webTitle: Unicef launches immunisation programme in Cambodia

fields.headline: A small jab from Unicef, a giant leap for Cambodia
fields.standfirst: Health has improved and for the first time in 30 years there is no rebellion. But modernisation has been a mixed blessing for Phnom Penh
fields.trailText: Health has improved and for the first time in 30 years there is no rebellion. But modernisation has been a mixed blessing for Phnom Penh
fields.body:
The factory girls from the Cambodian countryside line up for the needle, chivvied by Chinese supervisors. Half-crying and half-laughing, they are inoculated against tetanus by teams from Unicef, operating at speed. Two thousand workers, disposed of in an hour and a half, file back to the vast workshop to produce garments - "ladies bottoms" - for the US market.

The international division of labour represented by Taiwan's garment industry has reached Cambodia, the latest sign of change in a country hauling itself painfully out of the past. More than 100,000 young women migrants have flocked to the capital's northern suburbs. "They are very happy," a Chinese manager said. "They earn $40 [£27)] month, but some get $60 or more with overtime."

It is not quite so simple. Last month workers at some factories went on strike to raise the minimum wage and three were injured when security guards fired on them.

But Unicef and the ministry of health have seized the opportunity to launch the immunisation programme against tetanus, one of the biggest causes of neo-natal mortality.

"There is a problem with TBAs - traditional birth attendants", a Unicef spokesman explained. "They often use a sharpened length of bamboo or dirty scissors to cut the cord, then they put a nest of mud on top of the [stump]."

The women will return to the countryside to get married: if they complete the immunisation course, they and their babies will be protected for life.

"There has been tremendous progress in health," Unicef's project officer, Andrew Morris, said. "Of course there are problems: health salaries are too low and care is often poor quality. But the government has moved from plans to action, and malnutrition has already been reduced."

It reflects a more general shift to normality after the up heavals of 1997-98 - effectively a political coup by the prime minister, Hun Sen, and his People's party, with the reluctant assent of the main opposition party, the royalist Funcinpec, led by Prince King Sihanouk's son Norodom Ranariddh.

The still powerful remnants of the communist Khmer Rouge rebel movement have been "integrated" peacefully by Hun Sen. The national assembly will soon consider a plan for a genocide tribunal, on terms agreed with the UN, which could produce at least symbolic guilty verdicts against their surviving leaders.

"By whatever methods", said a western ambassador, "Hun Sen has established a government whose legitimacy no one now questions. And for the first time in 30 years there is no armed opposition."

The uncertain future of the ailing King Sihanouk, 77, who says he has reached "the setting of the sun", is taken calmly. There is speculation about which of several princes may succeed: it could be a convenient way for Hun Sen to remove Prince Ranariddh from the political scene.

All this means very little to millions for whom everyday life is a struggle to survive. A visit to the Kandal prison on the other side of Phnom Penh shows just how far the efforts of the government and international agencies have to go.

"The policy is to provide nurses for each prison," the governor, Muong Sam Arth, said. "But they don't come here, because they don't have medicine." If a prisoner is sick and has money, Mr Arth will buy medicine for him. "It's not convenient to send the prisoner to hospital," he said. "We have to provide guards and everything, even a bedpan."

His biggest headache at the moment is four-year-old Chin Pheu, whose mother, Sun Deur, is in jail for killing her niece in revenge when she found her husband making love to her sister. Now she is afraid that her son will be killed in turn if he returns home.

"This is not the place for a child," Mr Arth said. Mother and son share a cramped cell with nine other women in a compound of 250 inmates, the rest of them male. The cell has an open stone toilet and is bare except for a few sleeping mats. The women wash in a dirty trough outside when the men are locked up.

Khieu Chan Boramey, a slender 16-year-old from the countryside, also ended up in prison.

"My father married again," she said. "I loved my boyfriend and got pregnant, so I was sent to Phnom Penh to look for my aunt. I couldn't find her and had no money to pay the motorbike driver."

The driver tried to force her to work in a brothel: when she refused, he told her to steal some earrings from a little girl. She was jailed for six months. The three-month foetus aborted naturally in prison: "on the ground," she explained.

Mr Arth said that he would hand her to Licadho, an organisation which campaigns for prison reform. "Otherwise she will be in trouble. Some bad guys have already told me they want to 'adopt' her."

These sad tales illustrate deeper flaws in a society which has been brutalised since the Khmer Rouge era.

"People have become more violent and selfish since then," said Chanthol Oung, director of the Women's Crisis Centre. "Older people say that before the war they helped one another; now the value of the community is put last."

Cambodians suffer too from the usual ailments familiar in the developing world - over-population, unemployment and a chronic shortage of land.

A baby boom when family life resumed after the Khmer Rouge means that the 20-25 age group - those most likely to marry - will grow by 40% in the next five years. "There are those without land and those who will become without land," said Jacqueline Desbarats at the Cambodia Development Resource Institute. "Rice yields may be higher because of high yield grains, but the income gap is widening."

Unemployment is higher in town than in the country, and many seasonal migrants end up sleeping on the streets. Crime is rising, and with it an ugly trend of mob murders, often encouraged by the police.

Last week a suspected motorcycle thief was beaten and burned to death. His alleged accomplice was taken away by the police and then shot "while trying to escape".

"People are very proud of these killings," Eva Galabru of Licadho said. "When we investigate a case, they say, We've killed about 10 here; why are you excited about one?"

It is the expression at the grassroots of Cambodia's "culture of impunity", in which the high and powerful are believed to get away, sometimes literally, with murder.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
France keeps Concorde ban

Air France Concordes are to remain grounded until the questions about their safety have been fully answered, a senior French transport ministry official said yesterday.

Gilles Ricono said the investigation of last week's crash , which killed 113 people, was progressing well but experts had to decide what new safety measures were required before the ban would be lifted.

Pakistan seeks Kashmir inquiry

Pakistan called for an independent investigation into the latest bloodbath in the Indian-ruled part of the disputed Kashmir region.

The foreign minister, Abdul Sattar, said India should let international humanitarian organisations and foreign journalists discover who was responsible for the massacre of 90 people on Tuesday.

India blames Islamabad and pro-Pakistani militants for the killings.

South Africa acts on taxi feud

Heavily armed South African police sealed off the black township of Khayelitsha, outside Cape Town, yesterday in an attempt to end murderous attacks on commuter buses.

Seven people have died in the violence, which has been blamed on a four-month feud between taxi operators and a bus company over lucrative commuter routes.

Canadian navy to free tanks

Three Canadian warships off the coast of Newfoundland were preparing yesterday to board a ship which was refusing to land its cargo of Canadian army tanks and other equipment until it received payment.

The ship's US owners are in dispute with the Montreal company which chartered it to return £100m- worth of equipment from Kosovo.

Lanzarote, the final frontier...

Russian cosmonauts can look forward to sun, sand and sangria when they get back to Earth after a marathon mission in space.

A deal signed yesterday gives those returning from the Mir space station a three-week expenses-paid trip to the Canary Islands.

webTitle: Fragile signs of rebirth in Danube's tainted delta

fields.headline: Fragile signs of rebirth in Danube's tainted delta
fields.trailText: Red is the colour of destruction in the Danube delta: the rusty red of the bulldozers sent by the late Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, now being cut up in their hundreds for scrap; the reddish brown of the scrub growing on the land Ceausescu had drained for agriculture, the colour caused by the salinity which soon made it useless for farming.
fields.body:
Red is the colour of destruction in the Danube delta: the rusty red of the bulldozers sent by the late Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, now being cut up in their hundreds for scrap; the reddish brown of the scrub growing on the land Ceausescu had drained for agriculture, the colour caused by the salinity which soon made it useless for farming.

By the time Ceausescu and his wife Elena were shot in December 1989 only vast quantities of fertilisers could keep the crops coming.

Some drained areas - the reed islands of Babina and Cernovca in the north-west of the delta - never succeeded in pushing up a single plant of their designated product, rice.

"According to the ideology of those days," said Grigore Baboianu, director of the Danube delta biosphere reserve, "the delta in its natural state was a waste ground, prey to flooding and mosquitoes, just waiting for development."

A waste ground containing the largest area of compact reed beds in Europe, the environmentalists here say; the temporary or permanent home of more than 300 species of bird and 35 species of fish.

The reeds helped filter out the human and agricultural sewage of the eight - now 11 - countries upstream. Ceausescu decided to cut them down to make paper.

Travelling down a narrow channel overgrown with weeping willows, we came across hundreds of pelicans fishing with cormorants and herons. The pelicans' technique is to form a circle and beat with their wings and feet to frighten the small fish into the centre. Other birds arrive to share the feast.

In communist times, too, the pelican was a protected bird, but its food supply was ruined by the drainage schemes. Under Ceaucescu 80,000 hectares (200,000 acres) was drained, half for agriculture, half for fish-farming ponds.

Dykes were raised, big areas dredged, and electricity installed to run the pumps which filled the ponds in spring and emptied them in autumn. But fish production refused to prosper.

The biosphere reserve began breaking holes in the dykes three years ago. It says it has has already given 5,000 hectares back to the water. This summer, it plans to return another 6,000.

"We were astonished how quickly life reappeared," said Marian Tudor of the Danube Delta Institute, which is working with the biosphere reserve to restore the region.

"The explanation we reached was that the seeds lay dormant in the ground for more than a decade."

Babina island - a former drained area on the Romanian-Ukrainian border and now the pride of the restoration project - lies at heart of what Ceausescu planned as paddy fields.

The wind rustles gently in the reeds here. There are water lilies in the pools again and a snow of duck feathers at the water's edge.

But the restoration work is not without its problems, and its opponents. Fourteen thousand people live in the delta region. Work on the dictator's projects gave them a steady income in the 1980s, and there were basic industries like fishing.

But the projects are dead and the delta is fished out.

"My son is 14 now, soon he will finish school,"a fisherman said, resting his oars on his way to lay nets for the evening. "According to the law, I am not allowed to take him with me. But if I don't teach him to fish, he'll starve to death - there's no other work here."

The fisherman used to work in the shipyards of Sulina, the delta's main port.

Now the yards and canneries are closed and the last of Romania's motorised fishing fleet lies rotting in the harbour at Tulcea.

"The most important alternative to fishing is tourism," Grigore Baboianu said.

The fisherman shook his head and raised his huge, net-caloused hands. "What am I supposed to do with tourists?"

But in the Delta hotel in Tulcea, earnest groups of French and Austrian birdwatchers could be seen at breakfast.

But if I don't teach him to fish, he'll starve to death - there's no other work here." The fisherman used to work in the shipyards of Sulina, the delta's main port. Now the yards and canneries are closed and the last of Romania's motorised fishing fleet lies rotting in the harbour at Tulcea. "The most important alternative to fishing is tourism," Grigore Baboianu said. The fisherman shook his head and raised his huge, net-caloused hands. "What am I supposed to do with tourists?" But in the Delta hotel in Tulcea, earnest groups of French and Austrian birdwatchers could be seen at breakfast.

webTitle: Weekly guide to the US movie chart-toppers

fields.headline: Friends of the girth
fields.standfirst: Weekly guide to the US movie chart-toppers
fields.trailText: As I watched The Nutty Professor II: The Klumps today, it struck me that Los Angeles is an atypical American city in one very striking way. Seeing Eddie Murphy play six members of an extremely rotund family reminded me that there are relatively few fat people here.
fields.body:
As I watched The Nutty Professor II: The Klumps today, it struck me that Los Angeles is an atypical American city in one very striking way. Seeing Eddie Murphy play six members of an extremely rotund family reminded me that there are relatively few fat people here. I don't just mean amateurs with beer guts, baggy bums and boy-boobs, which can be shed with a little exercise and careful eating. I mean mightily, terrifyingly overweight: belt-refusing, elastic-waistband, zero-portion-control, entire-left-column-of-the-menu-for-breakfast, Mister Creosote fat.

Here in the City of Angels, where a fistful of amphetamines can technically count as a good square meal, we tend to venerate the suicidally superthin, the harrowingly anorexic, and a physical ideal so lean you can hold it up to the sun and see right through it. It's easy to explain. California's Riviera climate necessitates the shedding of clothes in high summer (you want proof? I'm typing this in my undies), and there can be no stronger disincentive to lardiness.

The youth-hungry studios, with their narrow, quasi-Aryan aesthetic of beauty, tend to up the pretty-to-ugly ratio by drawing in all the beautiful, bored people from the Great Plain and the Big Empty. Every vain little boy or girl intoning their intended stage-names into the bathroom mirror in South Bend, Indiana, every Wisconsin prom princess who couldn't get into college... they all end up here. Their omnipresence sometimes convinces you it's perfectly normal to have only 2% body-fat and an arse like a knot in a piece of string.

So thank you, Eddie Murphy, for reminding me that the rest of America refuses any and all such restraints in the presence of a heaving table of grub. At Disney World in Florida I once saw a man so surreally fat that he seemed to advance towards me in undulating waves of flesh. The entire turnstile had to be removed in order to admit him. I thought of the measuring poles by many rides that read "You must be at least this tall to ride this rollercoaster", and wondered if there was an equivalent "at least this thin" clause to cope with such gargantuan amusement-seekers. And changing planes in St Louis a few years ago, I found myself trapped on the walking conveyer-belt behind a midwestern business man so enormous that his thighs dragged against both side walls. I just gave up and sat on my suitcase.

Out there in real, hungry, high-protein America the people are gorging themselves, laying siege to the smorgasbord, pouring gallon-tubs of ice cream down their necks, and scarfing sacks of potato chips, buckets of popcorn, and two-litre bottles of Pepsi. And that's just between their five square meals a day.

Obesity figures are off the chart nationally, perhaps because America holds only 5% of the world's population, yet grazes a full quarter of the world's food supply. This is the land of the man-made fat Olestra, the first federally-sanctioned plastic food. It's the home of the junk-food plea bargain, pioneered by lawyers for the man who shot San Francisco politicians George Moscone and Harvey Milk in 1978. Dan White had, his attorneys contended, been insane at the time of the killings because of his addiction to Twinkie bars (principal ingredients: sugar, lard, little else). He served less than two years. And every week there's another tabloid story about a man so fat he's been marooned inside his double-width trailer since the Carter administration.

American regional cooking includes such ventricle-straining cuisines as meat-intensive Texas barbecue, the starch-based, fibre-lite, southern white working-class diet that did for Elvis (favourite snack: triple-layer fried peanut butter and banana sandwich), and its considerably tastier and spicier, albeit no less lard-centric black equivalent, soul food - greatly favoured by the Klumps - with its dependence on the cheapest cuts of meat, chit'lins, tripe, headcheese and so on.

All this leads to the notion that portly Americans are a persecuted minority ("It's a glandular problem!"), an extraordinary conceit, since their every whim is catered to and indulged, and anyway, they're the majority. I'd love to see a list of political demands. The right to a little respect, special turnstiles, wider people-movers, plus a chicken in every deep-fryer and unlimited salad bar privileges? All this in the face of the direst warnings, like the fact that America's best-loved fat men - John Belushi, Divine, John Candy, Chris Farley, and my favourite family-sized country singer, Jimmy Heap - all now reside in coffins the size of the box my tumble-drier came in.

The Klumps makes it easy to forget that Eddie Murphy is in fact a rather slender feller. His writers have fattened up the most popular element of the original, the fridge-worshipping family of corpulent Professor Sherman Klump. All are again played by Murphy in a bravura display of one-man ensemble acting.

The last Nutty Professor movie reminded us what Murphy is best at: character-based sketch comedy. He's an indifferent actor, yet he's always the most compelling presence in the frame, so what better solution than to turn him loose on a roomful of his own characters? The same principle applies to his wonderful animated ghetto comedy The PJs, in which he also plays half a dozen characters, from Thurgood Stubbs the janitor to Smokey the crack addict (Thurgood: "Who goes there?" Smokey: "Not me. Nuh-uh. I went 'hind the dumpster. Like a gen'leman.")

Nutty Professor II reprises the formula with likeable results, though it's more scatological than its predecessor (little wonder - American Pie's writers had a grubby hand in the screenplay). The MacGuffin this time is Sherman's new fountain of youth potion. It's coveted by his self-generated id-monster Buddy Love, who has rebuilt himself using canine DNA strands.

Libidinous and amoral, Buddy is easily distracted by cats, and lays down newspaper in public toilets. Again, the ensemble dinner-table scenes are technically mind-boggling, funny and often very tender. It's great to see Murphy making so much of the second act of his career.

Let's hope we never again have to suffer the dismal likes of The Distinguished Gentleman, Harlem Nights or Boomerang. Meanwhile, long may he bring on the belly laughs.
