fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: The Carriers are Waiting | The Bone Collector | Simpatico
fields.trailText: The Carriers are Waiting | The Bone Collector | Simpatico
fields.body:
The Carriers are Waiting
Retail (£15.99)
Artificial Eye
Cert 15
****

It's a black and white Belgian comedy with one of the year's least memorable titles. But don't let any of that put you off. The Carriers are Waiting is a droll one-off, thoroughly eccentric, wincingly funny and luminously photographed by Philippe Guilbert. Its central character is a local-paper photojournalist (Benot Poelevoorde), a raging-tempered autocrat who makes The Fast Show's Competitive Dad look like an enlightened parent.

We first meet the family at dinner where, after a brief attempt at long-distance pip-spitting, father decides that the way to crack a world record (and win a Lada) is the as-yet underappreciated art of door-opening, as performed by his son under the expert tuition of his coach - also Dad's only friend. (A hand coach is apparently essential for shaving seconds off your door-opening technique when you are aiming for 40,000 openings in 24 hours.)

Next door lives a mild-mannered man who lives for his champion pigeon, Napoléon, and is befriended by Poelevoorde's eight-year-old daughter (a performance of great natural charm by Morgane Simon). His son, meanwhile, works on a radio show in which he points out errors in films. That's the weird set-up which leads in all kinds of bizarre plot directions.

The comedy is absurdist, but this is never simple farce: director and co-writer Benot Mariage takes his characters seriously in all their bumbling imperfection and Poelevoorde makes a real person out of his explosively frustrated father helplessly destroying his family through his desperate attempts to improve their lot.

This is a film you can't imagine anyone ever pitching to studio execs: it seems to have got made because a group of people had the strength and determination to take some bizarre characters and even stranger ideas and put them on screen with loving care and no compromises. Look out for the ex-photographer - like his anti-hero Poelevoorde - and documentary-maker Mariage, whose feature debut this is.

The Bone Collector
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar
Cert 15
**

A would-be serial killer thriller with a mushy heart. Denzel Washington is the quadriplegic forensics expert who sifts data from his bed between seizures while Angelina Jolie is the young cop drafted in to do the rotten jobs ("Now I want you to saw off the corpse's hands") while in walkie-talkie contact.

The killings take place in familiar murk while the perp leaves obscure clues in grand movie tradition: it's Seven meets Rear Window. Philip Noyce's film is never big on believability and gets sillier exponentially up to its soap opera-style ending. Michael Rooker fans will note an all-too-brief appearance from an old hand at serial killer movies and the only other plus is the compulsively watchable Jolie.

Simpatico
Rental and DVD (£17.99)
Alliance Atlantis
Cert 15
***

Simpatico trails all the suggestions of a class act: derived from a Sam Shepard play and with a quintet of players you expect to rise to this sort of occasion (Jeff Bridges, Nick Nolte, Sharon Stone, Albert Finney and Catherine Keener). But its tale of regret, recrimination and redemption set in the horse-racing world is a bit too gloomy and overwrought to engage and its plot doesn't seem fully thought through.

It starts with a boozy, dishevelled Nolte (he hasn't looked this wrecked since Down and Out in Beverly Hills) calling the smoothly successful Bridges, who immediately races to see him. Is this blackmail or faithful old friendship?

There's a bit of both as our lead characters swap places and the film gradually uncovers the dirty deed of 20 years earlier which altered their destinies irrevocably - much of it through unconvincing flashbacks - in which Finney plays himself, but the other principals are portrayed by younger actors. The co-producer, adaptor and director is Brit Matthew Warchus, better known as a theatre director, proving they can't all be Sam Mendes. The DVD includes a short "featurette" with interviews.

webTitle: Hollywood gets the superhero recipe right

fields.headline: 'At last, earthlings, you have seen the light'
fields.standfirst: With X-Men smashing box office records and more comic book movies on the way,  why did it take Hollywood  so long to get the superhero recipe right?
fields.trailText: With X-Men smashing box office records and more comic book movies on the way, why did it take Hollywood so long to get the superhero recipe right?
fields.body:
Call it the geek effect if you will, but the huge opening weekend for the X-Men movie - $54.5m, the sixth highest in history - sent a collective sigh of relief around the swimming pools and lunch-spots of Hollywood last month.

Thankful for the box-office bonanza were not only the anxious executives - at 20th Century Fox - who had financed the movie to the tune of $75m, but every other green-eyed studio suit with a comic-book movie in development. Here was an intelligent, faithful comic-book movie that had not only made money but had appealed to both rabid fans of the source material and audiences who didn't know Wolverine from Wolverhampton. Suddenly the words "comic-book movie", a term hitherto guaranteed to strike dread into executives' heart, had a far happier, far more profitable connotation. No longer did it mean Batman & Robin, Spawn, Steel or The Phantom.

To most people, however, comics remain a largely misunderstood medium, perceived as childish entertainment and primarily read by an audience of spotty, unwashed, maladjusted, black-clad teenage boys. But look beyond the cliche - the garish covers and the Lycra-clad superheroes duking it out with aliens high above cityscapes - and you'll discover comics offer a world of richly imaginative material. Writers such as Alan Moore (Watchmen), Grant Morrison (JLA), Garth Ennis (Preacher) and Warren Ellis (Transmetropolitan) consistently produce work of impressive creativity, exploring the limits of the political, the social and the fantastical.

Yet for every Batman, Men In Black, The Mask, or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles there's a dozen Judge Dredds, Tank Girls or Viruses propping up video bargain bins the world over. In recent years, there have been a number of notable exceptions to the it's-a-comic-book-movie-so-it-must-suck rule - Blade and The Crow among them - but only a few have been truly great.

Most comic fans agree that Richard Donner's 1978 Superman, starring Christopher Reeve, is one of the best examples of the genre - though its flaws are apparent three decades later. "There are parts in it that are a little dated," admits X-Men director Bryan Singer, "'Can you read my mind?' The flying in the air. But there are parts like Superman and Lois Lane's first date on the roof of that building that are brilliant. The writing, the acting..."

So why have the movies tended to get so wrong so often since then? After all, what are comics but storyboards for a movie waiting to be directed? "The resemblance is simple," says Frank Miller, creator of the seminal graphic novel The Dark Knight Returns, who has recently adapted another of his works, Ronin, for Pi director Darren Aronofsky. "They both involve telling a story in pictures, but the differences are vast." Dave Gibbons, co-creator with Alan Moore of the ground-breaking series Watchmen agrees. "A comic script looks a bit like a film script and a comic book looks a bit like a storyboard, but there is no sound or movement in a comic book."

"Pouring a comic-book story into a movie mould can tend to cast a harsh light on inherently fantastic elements," muses Seven screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker, who recently wrote the script for The Silver Surfer as well as an early draft of the X-Men movie. "Without the flourish of the artwork, it's like telling the story of an opera, rather than singing it."

Often, it seems, there is no respect for the source material on which the movie is based. Part of the problem seems to lie in condensing what are often decades of plotlines and complex characters into a two-hour movie that tries to satisfy diehard fans as well as mainstream audiences.

When Joel Schumacher took over the reins of the Batman series from Tim Burton with Batman Forever he gave it a camp makeover that left fans of the Bat aghast and cinema audiences perplexed. Burton may not have been a big comic-book fan but he understood the motivation behind Batman and presented him as a lone vigilante in a brooding, menacing vision of Gotham City. Schumacher's flouncy take was almost a return to the pop art nonsense of the 60s Adam West TV show.

Ironically, it's on the small screen that comic-book characters have found greatest success in recent times. Two of the finest examples can be found nestling in kids' TV - Batman: The Animated series and its follow-up Batman Beyond (aka Batman of the Future). In fact, Bat aficionados assert the most faithful Bat movie is not Burton's but the animated movie Batman: Mask of the Phantasm, a spin-off from the TV series.

On the big screen, however, comic-book movies haven't come much better than The Matrix, which Spawn creator Todd McFarlane recently deemed "the perfect comic-book movie". This despite the fact that, like Buffy, it didn't actually come from one. The Matrix proved that a comic-book sensibility could work as a movie, if treated seriously. And that, one suspects, is the key.

"There's still this perception that comic books can't be taken too seriously," says Walker. "The resulting movie version is so often a bad, campy translation. I think we could get past that by starting to treat comic-book movies in the way that Marvel Comics were unabashedly perceived in the 60s - as pop mythology. That's how I think of The Silver Surfer - as psychedelic lore."

When The Usual Suspects director Bryan Singer was initially offered X-Men he hadn't even heard of the comic book and turned it down. His producing partner, Tom DeSanto, was an X-Men fan and persuaded him to re-evaluate the material - by likening two of the comic's main characters, Professor Xavier and Magneto (played in the film by Patrick Stewart and Sir Ian McKellen respectively) to Malcolm X and Martin Luther King. "Prejudice and discrimination is ever-interesting to me and has been the backbone of X-Men since its creation," Singer explains. He told his cast not to read the comics as reference and bristled when anyone called it "a comic-book movie".

He says: "This comic book was a science-fiction idea that happened to be done graphically. I will treat it seriously and with as much respect as I would treat any science-fiction movie, and I will treat its source material with the same respect."

Perhaps the biggest irony is that the comic-book industry itself has, over the last few years, been battling a serious decline in sales. In the late 80s, Miller's Dark Knight and Moore and Gibbons's Watchmen, together with Neil Gaiman's highly influential Sandman, led comics back into the mainstream with their adult sensibilities and character-driven tales. By the early 90s, there were comics selling by the millions.

But it was less a result of a boom in interest than greedy speculators buying up multiple copies of various issues and storing them away as investment opportunities which inflated the market unrealistically. While X-Men and The Uncanny X-Men remain the industry's biggest sellers, their monthly sales are in the low hundreds of thousands. In today's market, a comic selling 40,000 copies per monthly issue is deemed a successful title.

"We are in a deep hole of our own making and what needs to be done is far more drastic and expensive than any current publisher wants to do," insists Kurt Busiek, writer of several monthly comics including Marvel's Avengers. "We need to be reaching out to new readers. The answer has to be to get comics in a format, a package and at a price that will compete economically with something like Time magazine."

Grant Morrison agrees: "Comics have shrunk into comic shops which now look like porn shops and people are frightened to go in there. When Superman was selling between 4m and 6m a month, you could buy them anywhere, in any shop. One of the things they must do is get them back on the streets, back in the hands of children, out of the hands of weird 35-year-old men who collect them and sustain the industry."

Morrison for one remains optimistic. "I'd be proud to stand up and say this medium is as diverse as any other. It's just that comics have got so shy, so embarrassed about themselves they don't want to tell anybody. Comics have reached adolescence after being in childhood for so long, and they're stuck with their specs taped up with Elastoplast. What they have to do is get a girlfriend, get out and start being cool."

X-Men is released on August 19.

Zap! Biff! There's more to come...

There has never been a better time to be a comic character. Fox, with its eye on a franchise, has announced an X-Men sequel, set to open in summer 2002. A big-budget version of Marvel's Spiderman will hit screens late next year under the direction of Evil Dead auteur Sam Raimi after years of legal wrangles over who owned the movie rights.

Also on the horizon are adaptations of a host of Marvel favourites: among them, Daredevil, Fantastic Four, The Silver Surfer, The Hulk and Iron Man - the last is said to be of interest to Tom Cruise. Marvel, a company that four years ago was facing bankruptcy, has grasped the importance of film for its survival and has inked a deal with Artisan - the company that released The Blair Witch Project - to adapt another nine of its characters for the movies.

Warner Bros, meanwhile, has restoked its Superman project, Christina Ricci has been lined up to play an android assassin in Adrenalin, and Johnny Depp is currently in Prague shooting From Hell, a version of Alan Moore's Jack The Ripper epic, directed by the Hughes brothers.

Writers such as Alan Moore (Watchmen), Grant Morrison (JLA), Garth Ennis (Preacher) and Warren Ellis (Transmetropolitan) consistently produce work of impressive creativity, exploring the limits of the political, the social and the fantastical. Yet for every Batman, Men In Black, The Mask, or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles there's a dozen Judge Dredds, Tank Girls or Viruses propping up video bargain bins the world over. In recent years, there have been a number of notable exceptions to the it's-a-comic-book-movie-so-it-must-suck rule - Blade and The Crow among them - but only a few have been truly great. Most comic fans agree that Richard Donner's 1978 Superman, starring Christopher Reeve, is one of the best examples of the genre - though its flaws are apparent three decades later. "There are parts in it that are a little dated," admits X-Men director Bryan Singer, "'Can you read my mind?' The flying in the air. But there are parts like Superman and Lois Lane's first date on the roof of that building that are brilliant. The writing, the acting..." So why have the movies tended to get so wrong so often since then? After all, what are comics but storyboards for a movie waiting to be directed? "The resemblance is simple," says Frank Miller, creator of the seminal graphic novel The Dark Knight Returns, who has recently adapted another of his works, Ronin, for Pi director Darren Aronofsky. "They both involve telling a story in pictures, but the differences are vast." Dave Gibbons, co-creator with Alan Moore of the ground-breaking series Watchmen agrees. "A comic script looks a bit like a film script and a comic book looks a bit like a storyboard, but there is no sound or movement in a comic book." "Pouring a comic-book story into a movie mould can tend to cast a harsh light on inherently fantastic elements," muses Seven screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker, who recently wrote the script for The Silver Surfer as well as an early draft of the X-Men movie. "Without the flourish of the artwork, it's like telling the story of an opera, rather than singing it." Often, it seems, there is no respect for the source material on which the movie is based. Part of the problem seems to lie in condensing what are often decades of plotlines and complex characters into a two-hour movie that tries to satisfy diehard fans as well as mainstream audiences. When Joel Schumacher took over the reins of the Batman series from Tim Burton with Batman Forever he gave it a camp makeover that left fans of the Bat aghast and cinema audiences perplexed. Burton may not have been a big comic-book fan but he understood the motivation behind Batman and presented him as a lone vigilante in a brooding, menacing vision of Gotham City. Schumacher's flouncy take was almost a return to the pop art nonsense of the 60s Adam West TV show. Ironically, it's on the small screen that comic-book characters have found greatest success in recent times. Two of the finest examples can be found nestling in kids' TV - Batman: The Animated series and its follow-up Batman Beyond (aka Batman of the Future). In fact, Bat aficionados assert the most faithful Bat movie is not Burton's but the animated movie Batman: Mask of the Phantasm, a spin-off from the TV series. On the big screen, however, comic-book movies haven't come much better than The Matrix, which Spawn creator Todd McFarlane recently deemed "the perfect comic-book movie". This despite the fact that, like Buffy, it didn't actually come from one. The Matrix proved that a comic-book sensibility could work as a movie, if treated seriously. And that, one suspects, is the key. "There's still this perception that comic books can't be taken too seriously," says Walker. "The resulting movie version is so often a bad, campy translation. I think we could get past that by starting to treat comic-book movies in the way that Marvel Comics were unabashedly perceived in the 60s - as pop mythology. That's how I think of The Silver Surfer - as psychedelic lore." When The Usual Suspects director Bryan Singer was initially offered X-Men he hadn't even heard of the comic book and turned it down. His producing partner, Tom DeSanto, was an X-Men fan and persuaded him to re-evaluate the material - by likening two of the comic's main characters, Professor Xavier and Magneto (played in the film by Patrick Stewart and Sir Ian McKellen respectively) to Malcolm X and Martin Luther King. "Prejudice and discrimination is ever-interesting to me and has been the backbone of X-Men since its creation," Singer explains. He told his cast not to read the comics as reference and bristled when anyone called it "a comic-book movie". He says: "This comic book was a science-fiction idea that happened to be done graphically. I will treat it seriously and with as much respect as I would treat any science-fiction movie, and I will treat its source material with the same respect." Perhaps the biggest irony is that the comic-book industry itself has, over the last few years, been battling a serious decline in sales. In the late 80s, Miller's Dark Knight and Moore and Gibbons's Watchmen, together with Neil Gaiman's highly influential Sandman, led comics back into the mainstream with their adult sensibilities and character-driven tales. By the early 90s, there were comics selling by the millions. But it was less a result of a boom in interest than greedy speculators buying up multiple copies of various issues and storing them away as investment opportunities which inflated the market unrealistically. While X-Men and The Uncanny X-Men remain the industry's biggest sellers, their monthly sales are in the low hundreds of thousands. In today's market, a comic selling 40,000 copies per monthly issue is deemed a successful title. "We are in a deep hole of our own making and what needs to be done is far more drastic and expensive than any current publisher wants to do," insists Kurt Busiek, writer of several monthly comics including Marvel's Avengers. "We need to be reaching out to new readers. The answer has to be to get comics in a format, a package and at a price that will compete economically with something like Time magazine." Grant Morrison agrees: "Comics have shrunk into comic shops which now look like porn shops and people are frightened to go in there. When Superman was selling between 4m and 6m a month, you could buy them anywhere, in any shop. One of the things they must do is get them back on the streets, back in the hands of children, out of the hands of weird 35-year-old men who collect them and sustain the industry." Morrison for one remains optimistic. "I'd be proud to stand up and say this medium is as diverse as any other. It's just that comics have got so shy, so embarrassed about themselves they don't want to tell anybody. Comics have reached adolescence after being in childhood for so long, and they're stuck with their specs taped up with Elastoplast. What they have to do is get a girlfriend, get out and start being cool." X-Men is released on August 19. Zap! Biff! There's more to come... There has never been a better time to be a comic character. Fox, with its eye on a franchise, has announced an X-Men sequel, set to open in summer 2002. A big-budget version of Marvel's Spiderman will hit screens late next year under the direction of Evil Dead auteur Sam Raimi after years of legal wrangles over who owned the movie rights. Also on the horizon are adaptations of a host of Marvel favourites: among them, Daredevil, Fantastic Four, The Silver Surfer, The Hulk and Iron Man - the last is said to be of interest to Tom Cruise. Marvel, a company that four years ago was facing bankruptcy, has grasped the importance of film for its survival and has inked a deal with Artisan - the company that released The Blair Witch Project - to adapt another nine of its characters for the movies. Warner Bros, meanwhile, has restoked its Superman project, Christina Ricci has been lined up to play an android assassin in Adrenalin, and Johnny Depp is currently in Prague shooting From Hell, a version of Alan Moore's Jack The Ripper epic, directed by the Hughes brothers.

webTitle: Should George Lucas be feted with a retrospective?

fields.headline: The menace
fields.standfirst: A George Lucas retrospective? We shouldn't be celebrating this pernicious, infantile film-maker
fields.trailText: A George Lucas retrospective? We shouldn't be celebrating this pernicious, infantile film-maker
fields.body:
I believe George Lucas to be the devil. Or, at least, say, Stalin. Accumulating power and money like a despot, feigning a jejune passion for the junk he watched as a child, manufacturing movies that lock on our weakest instincts with the single-mindedness of a speared hammerhead's death grip, George Lucas is a bane on the culture, a marauding scourge, a million locusts chewing up what's left of our newest art form's withered integrity.

However much I'd like to, I cannot say that no one has had a more pernicious, infantilising influence on modern movies than Lucas - Steven Spielberg carries at least half of the devastation on his oblivious conscience, and together they represent the most powerful sensibility in the history of mass media, a mass media that is in their time (and to some extent due to their popularity) the most pervasive and powerful ever known to man. It's a sensibility, it should be said, that is defined by condescension and "emphasis". The numbers, as everyone knows, are humungous, and that's reason enough to sound the alarm and storm the gates.

Instead, Lucas is being feted with a retrospective at the Barbican. They're calling it "the first major tribute in Britain to the work of one of the central, pivotal figures in American motion picture history", and since those words are chosen carefully, they're not wrong, as long as you read "central, pivotal" in terms of Lucas's role in the new Hollywood's all-too-successful attempt to plagiarise, bastardise, digitise and deintellectualise itself into a shit-bellied coma. Certainly, he is the Pope-King of Hollywood in that sense. But a retrospective?

The manner by which civilised man congratulates the millionaire for his millions can sour the stomach, and it is Lucas's personally-owned empire that the curators must be worshipping: the full-on salute is honouring a man who has directed only four films in 30 years. Thus, the programme has been rounded out with films he produced (such as forgotten boondoggles Willow, Labyrinth, Tucker: The Man and His Dream and Radioland Murders), and, most appallingly, with Lucas's "influences".

It's difficult to imagine that any intelligent adult could look at Lucas's track record over the last quarter-century and suppose that he was influenced by anyone other than his accountant and marketing team. Saying that Lucas was marked by his viewing of Kurosawa's Seven Samurai (why not include the same director's The Hidden Fortress, from which Lucas lifted plot elements for Star Wars?) is a bit like saying Stephen King can't get Proust out of his system. As for High Noon, the most simplistic of American westerns, you can imagine how little Georgie Lucas sat in the matinee and realised he could turn this sober chestnut into a real smash - by having Gary Cooper chase the villains through dangerous canyons on hover-cycles, and by having Grace Kelly replaced with a Frank Oz-voiced puppet.

Lucas wasn't always the Antichrist; in fact, his first two films were rigorously naturalistic, inventive, deeply imagined and - my God - mature examples of the "American new wave", the throng of gritty, unsentimental Hollywood movies that emerged in the late 60s and continued until Lucas himself dropped the toxic bomb of Luke Skywalker on the scene in 1977.

Lucas was one of the young movement's key figures, taking over the fort straight out of film school alongside Coppola, Scorsese, Rafelson, Hellman, Bogdanovich, and co. THX 1138 (1971), expanded from his superb student short, is a despairing dystopian portrait of a loveless society controlled by technology, living underground and policed by machinery. Austere, full of ambiguity and so masterfully visualised that the white-on-white corridors, antechambers and techno-cluttered offices suggest a working future, not a conjectured fantasy, might be the best science-fiction film of its decade; it is, inarguably, the most tough-minded.

Lucas hit the jackpot with his second film, American Graffiti (1973), and as happens all so rarely, a marvellous film became beloved by audiences. Explodingly witty (where did Lucas's sense of humour go?), fondly realised and perfectly shot and performed, Graffiti immediately established the retro teen comedy as a bankable genre, and that genre's unattainably high bar. Exploring his personal memories about a car-crazy, rock'n'roll midwestern teenhood in the late 50s and early 60s, Lucas made a movie that just melts in your mouth - there's nothing forced or stupid or contrived about it. The characters have three full dimensions, their experiences are electrifyingly specific but blessed with a universal glow, and the free-flowing script keeps almost a dozen personas afloat without a moment of strain. Lucas made the movie feel as if it was something he was born to make, and for a few years he became one of America's promised sons.

Lucas may have started Star Wars with the same type of innocent ardour, but it didn't last long. It's even conceivable that Lucas started his saga as he said he did - as a homage to old Flash Gordon serials. What honour could be dealt to those odious antiques remains unknown; what Lucas did instead was re-engineer the fluff of sci-fi serials until it all resembled carnival rides (a metaphor still overused by action-film-loving critics - when's the last time anyone went on a rollercoaster?). Audiences began mistaking having their stomach flipped for a thrilled response to effective moviemaking, and down the slope we slid.

To argue against Lucas is to argue against the pre-adolescent logic, storytelling retardation, cardboard characters, video game graphics, whorish pandering and wholesale idea thefts of the Star Wars movies, and those arguments are easy to make if you are old enough to drink in public. But it's Lucas's (and Spielberg's) snake-oil-cheat ideas and relentless mechanical authority that should let the case for the prosecution rest: thanks to them, the very language of movies has been degraded into the cine-visual equivalent of grunts, hand gestures and cave paintings.

Now, and for the last 20 years, what makes Hollywood movies is a different box of tools than when Lucas was making THX and Graffiti and Spielberg was making Duel and The Sugarland Express. Today, it's the digital-effect gotcha, the preprogrammed jet-rocket ride, the come-hell-or-high-water "sense of wonder" (abetted by rays of blue light), the condensation of every scene into a two-minute sketch filled with meaningful looks and single-line declarations (people used to "talk" in movies), the eschewal of the convincing two-shot in favour of the manipulative close-up, the everything-in-the-foreground TV compositions, the stilted sitcom rhythms, the relentless dramatic crescendos fabricated solely from drill-sergeant-like soundtrack ba-booms and pointless Steadicam movements.

Forget the unpredictability, textured reality, visual complexity and organic narrative of Five Easy Pieces, Two-Lane Blacktop, Scarecrow, McCabe & Mrs Miller, Badlands, The Conversation, Dog Day Afternoon, Taxi Driver, Sorcerer, The Deer Hunter, et al.

In Lucas-dominated cinema, no dramatic scene is any more informative than the music cues that accompany it. Nothing makes its way into a film without serving an explicit and simplistic narrative purpose; texture and believability for their own sakes are forbidden. (Digital effects are indulged in, of course, subject to their own law of diminishing returns.) Every shot and cut is calibrated with cynical expertise to control the feelings of the spectator; movies have always trucked in blatant manipulation, but only today are we seeing this ambition realised so adroitly that the movies' emotional life, far from being genuine or resonant or fresh, has the merciless thrust of a sophisticated sales job.

Thanks to Lucas, Hollywood movies lie like rugs, and in doing so display abject scorn for filmgoers' ability to tell bullshit from truism, sales job from art. The sad fact is, often their scorn isn't misplaced, and audiences show little capacity or readiness to sift their cinematic encounters for cock-and-bull. The Phantom Menace, after all, is close to bringing in a billion bucks, and for some people, wealth is all the justification Lucas needs. But the money is his, not yours or mine; we're supposed to profit from the film as an experience. The last time anyone profited from Lucas's work besides himself, Nixon was president. "Central, vital"? Like a worm is central and vital to the inedibility of an apple.

 George Lucas: His Films and Inspirations is at the Barbican from August 5-27. The Art of Star Wars exhibition continues at the Barbican art gallery until September 3. Box-office: 020 7638 8891. Cinema hotline: 020 7638 8891

webTitle: Televangelist Tammy Faye Messner is being reborn as a gay icon

fields.headline: At 10 she found God. At 16 she found make-up. And the two have never left her
fields.standfirst: Televangelist Tammy Faye Messner danced, sang and made fudge for Jesus on US TV. And now the ex-wife of Jim Bakker is being reborn as a gay icon
fields.trailText: Televangelist Tammy Faye Messner danced, sang and made fudge for Jesus on US TV. And now the ex-wife of Jim Bakker is being reborn as a gay icon
fields.body:
Fate has not been kind to Tammy Faye Messner. In the 1980s, when she and Jim Bakker, her then husband, headed the Praise The Lord (PTL) television ministry, spreading the gospel to 13.5m homes and generating more than $120m annually, her spidery eyelashes and crocodile tears served as fodder for countless late-night television satires. She struggled with drug addiction, a workaholic husband and the strains of raising a family on camera. Even the cushy lifestyles of her dogs were criticised.

Then, in 1987, Jim Bakker publicly admitted using $265,000 of PTL money in an unsuccessful bid to buy the silence of Jessica Hahn, a church secretary who claimed he had sex with her in a Florida hotel room. A disgraced Bakker handed control of PTL over to the rival televangelist Jerry Falwell, who put the ministry into bankruptcy and smeared him as a homosexual. Tammy watched their media empire crumble. With her husband convicted of defrauding PTL supporters of $158m and sentenced to prison, she was reduced to selling off her television wardrobe to get by.

Her faith has been tested. Now, in the twilight of her celebrity, she is, bizarrely, being resurrected as a gay icon. "We've always been intrigued by her," said Randy Barbato who, with Fenton Bailey, has produced and directed The Eyes of Tammy Faye, a documentary about Christian broadcasting's former first lady: "Christianity and materialism, spirituality and fabulousness - somehow, she manages to wrap them up in one package. We all spend a lot of time feeling bad about ourselves, because sometimes we feel spiritual and sometimes we want to go shopping. Well, that's what she is, a fabulous mess."

Organised in tidy chapters, which are introduced by hand puppets, the film charts Tammy Faye LaValley's rise from humble origins as the eldest child in a devout family of eight living in International Falls, Minnesota. At 10, she found God, falling flat on her back in an Assemblies of God church and speaking in tongues; at 16, she discovered make-up. The two have never left her. In 1961, when she was 19, she wed Jim Bakker, a fellow student at North Central Bible College in Minneapolis. They were promptly expelled for marrying, but soon began touring the Bible Belt as itinerant preachers.

Televangelism was in its infancy in 1965, when they got their start at Pat Robertson's fledgling Christian Broadcasting Network, where they created a children's programme and founded The 700 Club, Christian television's first talk show. Seven years later, eased out by Robertson, they moved to California, where, with Jane and Paul Crouch, they founded the Trinity Broadcasting Network (now the biggest force in televangelism). But that partnership also foundered.

At last, in 1974, they started the PTL Network in an abandoned furniture store in Charlotte, North Carolina. Mixing glitzy entertainment with down-home family values, and preaching a "prosperity gospel" which put a divine seal of approval on both the growing affluence of American evangelicals and the showy lifestyles of their television ministers, PTL quickly mushroomed into a vast corporate enterprise. Heritage USA, the $200m Christian retreat that Jim Bakker built with PTL money, ranked with Disney World and Disneyland as one of the nation's most popular theme parks.

Tammy was co-host of The Jim and Tammy Show, but she also produced her own programmes, including the daily Tammy Faye's House Party, where she entertained guests, offered advice on homemaking and shopping, staged fashion shows, danced, sang and made fudge.

Rev Mel White, a gay Christian advocate who (before coming out) worked closely with many of the major televangelists, explains her appeal: "For the evangelical community, she was Dr Joyce Brothers, Martha Stewart and Carol Burnett, all rolled into one." But The Eyes of Tammy Faye also reveals a more radical Tammy, who hosted shows on controversial topics like penile implants, interviewed a gay minister with Aids in the earliest days of public debate about the illness, and reached out to drug addicts and others excluded by the broader evangelical community.

Rev White is convinced that, for PTL's largely rural, female and older audience, Tammy provided an image of empowerment. "Her fans were people who grew up in a very fundamentalist tradition," he said, "not being able to wear make-up, or dance, or go out in public. So here comes Tammy, with her dyed hair and make-up, her ebullient spirit and outspoken ways with both men and women. She talked about sex, and flirted with Jimmy. She took on the caricature of an obedient wife, and blasted it. You have never seen Pat Robertson's wife, or Jerry Falwell's wife. They stay at home, doing what those wives do."

Bailey and Barbato were introduced to Tammy's work by their friend and business associate RuPaul, the actor, performer and drag superstar, who narrates the documentary. The pair have lived and worked together since they met as students at New York University film school 17 years ago. Bailey is British and was educated at Oxford; Barbato is from New Jersey. "I bring the low culture," he says, "and Fenton brings the high." World of Wonder, their Los Angeles-based production company, has turned out documentaries on various subjects: male prostitutes in Los Angeles, the experience of a juror on the OJ Simpson trial, the off-screen life of Ellen DeGeneres. Currently, they're developing Party Monster, a documentary about Michael Alig (a former denizen of the downtown New York club scene, now serving time for manslaughter) into a feature with the producer Christine Vachon.

A combination of sincerity and irreverence has frequently led them to focus on figures reviled in mainstream culture: "A common thread in our work is our interest in people who have been marginalised, judged or excluded," Bailey says. "We live in celebritocracy. We need these larger-than-life media personalities, and yet it's as if we have a moral prejudice against those who live for the camera." Barbato agrees: "Somehow, having them as targets to judge makes us feel better about ourselves. In Tammy's case, after a certain point, everyone was invited to pick up a stone and throw it at her."

The Eyes of Tammy Faye is also a fable about the strange afterlife of television. In the early 1990s, after divorcing Bakker and marrying Roe Messner (the developer of Heritage USA, who was himself convicted of bankruptcy fraud in 1995), Tammy found herself shut out of Christian broadcasting. In 1996 she became a co-host of a talk show on the Fox Network with Jim Bullock, an openly gay actor. The show was short-lived, her secular media comeback is still awaited.

The Eyes of Tammy Faye opens with Tammy living in relative seclusion in the California desert, awaiting Roe Messner's return from prison - ministering to her Yorkshire terriers, writing poetry and playing the organ in her Palm Springs church. "You can't go forward looking into the rearview mirror of your life," she cautions. "We wanted Tammy to sing the Gloria Gaynor anthem, I Will Survive, over the credits," Bailey says. "But she wouldn't do it."

© 2000 The New York Times. The Eyes of Tammy Faye screens at the Edinburgh Film Festival (tickets: 0131-623 8030)

She struggled with drug addiction, a workaholic husband and the strains of raising a family on camera. Even the cushy lifestyles of her dogs were criticised. Then, in 1987, Jim Bakker publicly admitted using $265,000 of PTL money in an unsuccessful bid to buy the silence of Jessica Hahn, a church secretary who claimed he had sex with her in a Florida hotel room. A disgraced Bakker handed control of PTL over to the rival televangelist Jerry Falwell, who put the ministry into bankruptcy and smeared him as a homosexual. Tammy watched their media empire crumble. With her husband convicted of defrauding PTL supporters of $158m and sentenced to prison, she was reduced to selling off her television wardrobe to get by. Her faith has been tested. Now, in the twilight of her celebrity, she is, bizarrely, being resurrected as a gay icon. "We've always been intrigued by her," said Randy Barbato who, with Fenton Bailey, has produced and directed The Eyes of Tammy Faye, a documentary about Christian broadcasting's former first lady: "Christianity and materialism, spirituality and fabulousness - somehow, she manages to wrap them up in one package. We all spend a lot of time feeling bad about ourselves, because sometimes we feel spiritual and sometimes we want to go shopping. Well, that's what she is, a fabulous mess." Organised in tidy chapters, which are introduced by hand puppets, the film charts Tammy Faye LaValley's rise from humble origins as the eldest child in a devout family of eight living in International Falls, Minnesota. At 10, she found God, falling flat on her back in an Assemblies of God church and speaking in tongues; at 16, she discovered make-up. The two have never left her. In 1961, when she was 19, she wed Jim Bakker, a fellow student at North Central Bible College in Minneapolis. They were promptly expelled for marrying, but soon began touring the Bible Belt as itinerant preachers. Televangelism was in its infancy in 1965, when they got their start at Pat Robertson's fledgling Christian Broadcasting Network, where they created a children's programme and founded The 700 Club, Christian television's first talk show. Seven years later, eased out by Robertson, they moved to California, where, with Jane and Paul Crouch, they founded the Trinity Broadcasting Network (now the biggest force in televangelism). But that partnership also foundered. At last, in 1974, they started the PTL Network in an abandoned furniture store in Charlotte, North Carolina. Mixing glitzy entertainment with down-home family values, and preaching a "prosperity gospel" which put a divine seal of approval on both the growing affluence of American evangelicals and the showy lifestyles of their television ministers, PTL quickly mushroomed into a vast corporate enterprise. Heritage USA, the $200m Christian retreat that Jim Bakker built with PTL money, ranked with Disney World and Disneyland as one of the nation's most popular theme parks. Tammy was co-host of The Jim and Tammy Show, but she also produced her own programmes, including the daily Tammy Faye's House Party, where she entertained guests, offered advice on homemaking and shopping, staged fashion shows, danced, sang and made fudge. Rev Mel White, a gay Christian advocate who (before coming out) worked closely with many of the major televangelists, explains her appeal: "For the evangelical community, she was Dr Joyce Brothers, Martha Stewart and Carol Burnett, all rolled into one." But The Eyes of Tammy Faye also reveals a more radical Tammy, who hosted shows on controversial topics like penile implants, interviewed a gay minister with Aids in the earliest days of public debate about the illness, and reached out to drug addicts and others excluded by the broader evangelical community. Rev White is convinced that, for PTL's largely rural, female and older audience, Tammy provided an image of empowerment. "Her fans were people who grew up in a very fundamentalist tradition," he said, "not being able to wear make-up, or dance, or go out in public. So here comes Tammy, with her dyed hair and make-up, her ebullient spirit and outspoken ways with both men and women. She talked about sex, and flirted with Jimmy. She took on the caricature of an obedient wife, and blasted it. You have never seen Pat Robertson's wife, or Jerry Falwell's wife. They stay at home, doing what those wives do." Bailey and Barbato were introduced to Tammy's work by their friend and business associate RuPaul, the actor, performer and drag superstar, who narrates the documentary. The pair have lived and worked together since they met as students at New York University film school 17 years ago. Bailey is British and was educated at Oxford; Barbato is from New Jersey. "I bring the low culture," he says, "and Fenton brings the high." World of Wonder, their Los Angeles-based production company, has turned out documentaries on various subjects: male prostitutes in Los Angeles, the experience of a juror on the OJ Simpson trial, the off-screen life of Ellen DeGeneres. Currently, they're developing Party Monster, a documentary about Michael Alig (a former denizen of the downtown New York club scene, now serving time for manslaughter) into a feature with the producer Christine Vachon. A combination of sincerity and irreverence has frequently led them to focus on figures reviled in mainstream culture: "A common thread in our work is our interest in people who have been marginalised, judged or excluded," Bailey says. "We live in celebritocracy. We need these larger-than-life media personalities, and yet it's as if we have a moral prejudice against those who live for the camera." Barbato agrees: "Somehow, having them as targets to judge makes us feel better about ourselves. In Tammy's case, after a certain point, everyone was invited to pick up a stone and throw it at her." The Eyes of Tammy Faye is also a fable about the strange afterlife of television. In the early 1990s, after divorcing Bakker and marrying Roe Messner (the developer of Heritage USA, who was himself convicted of bankruptcy fraud in 1995), Tammy found herself shut out of Christian broadcasting. In 1996 she became a co-host of a talk show on the Fox Network with Jim Bullock, an openly gay actor. The show was short-lived, her secular media comeback is still awaited. The Eyes of Tammy Faye opens with Tammy living in relative seclusion in the California desert, awaiting Roe Messner's return from prison - ministering to her Yorkshire terriers, writing poetry and playing the organ in her Palm Springs church. "You can't go forward looking into the rearview mirror of your life," she cautions. "We wanted Tammy to sing the Gloria Gaynor anthem, I Will Survive, over the credits," Bailey says. "But she wouldn't do it." © 2000 The New York Times. The Eyes of Tammy Faye screens at the Edinburgh Film Festival (tickets: 0131-623 8030)

fields.headline: La Veuve de Saint-Pierre
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: [The film's] spare, taut narrative is enriched and enlivened by a simply magnificent performance from Binoche. She has never looked more luminous and her screen presence has never been more commanding
fields.body:
Patrice Leconte's rich film-making is already on view here with his The Girl on the Bridge. Now La Veuve de Saint-Pierre (The Widow of Saint-Pierre) amplifies our sense of his flair for classically simple storytelling, his skill with ideas, his bold visual sense of place and his happy ability to elicit visceral and well-realised performances from an accomplished cast.

This is a 19th-century tale of uxorious passion and provincial French history. Daniel Auteuil is the captain of a military garrison in Saint-Pierre, a desolate French island colony off the Canadian coast. Juliette Binoche is his wife: a beautiful and morally passionate woman with whom the captain is utterly bewitched. They become involved in a complex knot of civilian political tension when an itinerant labourer, Neel Auguste (Emir Kusturica, the Palme d'Or-winning director of Underground), kills someone in a brawl and is sentenced to death. But on the cusp of modernity, the French judiciary find they can do nothing until one of the new-style guillotines is imported and an official executioner appointed. And during the wait for these, Neel becomes a protege of the captain's wife and a well-loved local figure. In deference to his wife's interest, the captain effectively mobilises the army in Neel's defence.

There is something very French in the ideas deployed here: the way Leconte demonstrates the economies and technologies of the state, and the historical moments in which power relations are reformed and recombined. "When power feels threatened, it can be very ferocious," says one character, and when one hapless island immigrant is bullied and cajoled into being the guillotine's operator, he is given a choice: "From this moment you are the executioner - or the victim!"

This spare, taut narrative is enriched and enlivened by a simply magnificent performance from Binoche. She has never looked more luminous and her screen presence has never been more commanding: a seductive and redemptive intelligence. Her career is entering what can only be described as its golden age. Set alongside her performance in Michael Haneke's toughly intriguing Code Unknown (arriving here at the Edinburgh film festival later this summer), this is a chance to see one of the great screen actresses of our time at her peak. This is the power that Garbo and Monroe must have exerted in their prime; to be a witness to it is really thrilling.

fields.headline: Gone in 60 Seconds
fields.standfirst: Car chase capers have had their day and someone should put Vinnie's acting career out of its misery
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's all reasonably entertaining, but it is never clear whether we should buy [it] as a toughly modern, tech-aware action pic - or just another episode of The Dukes of Hazzard
fields.body:
Gone in 60 Seconds is a glitzy, ritzy reworking of a 1974 car-jack caper originally directed by HB Halicki, here starring the unerringly horse-faced Nicolas Cage opposite a slouching and sexy Angelina Jolie. This film, produced by action-meister Jerry Bruckheimer and directed by Dominic Sena, revs up the sex interest and pulls out the choke on the dewy-eyed family loyalty. But also, more startlingly, it has an unlikely cameo for our very own Vinnie Jones, who has been encouraged to believe that he has a future in the movie star business.

Frankly, it would be kindest to put Mr Jones out of his misery now. Like a tough but compassionate gamekeeper, someone has to grasp the wounded bird that is Vinnie' s film career and snap its neck cleanly. Unlike Arnold Schwarzenegger - with whom Vinnie has unblushingly compared himself - he has no feeling for comedy nor knack for dialogue. Tellingly, he is mute for the entire picture except for a well-rehearsed speech at the end. And in an American context, he doesn't even look that tough. Their tough guys are tougher than our tough guys. Vinnie is Joe Bugner in a world of Muhammad Alis.

This film attempts to bring the world of car-thievery and car-chasery into the 21st century, where cars are far slicker and more trouble-free than they were 30 years ago. It's a world of better suspension, hi-tech computer designs and automatic transmission systems; a world in which the duller, smaller, more bulbous and economic-to-run models from Europe and Japan have extensively invaded American streets.

The business of driving - and indeed stealing - such cars was an appreciably more romantic and artisanal business then, and so there is something almost subconsciously nostalgic about a film in which a group of loveable rogues led by Memphis Raines (Cage) have to steal 50 cars or his brother Kip (Giovanni Ribisi) gets whacked by a sinister limey villain played by Christopher Eccleston, whose utter loathsomeness is signalled to cinema audiences by having him snort at baseball, calling it "boring".

This is not just the burglar's art of busting into cars; it is all about having people on the inside, in automobile showrooms and export offices in Bonn and Tokyo. And this being the 21st century, it means the infiltration of computer systems. All thrillers must now have some nerd tapping away on his laptop, his occult expertise enforcing grudging or ungrudging respect from the rest of the cast - and this car-theft movie is no exception.

Nicolas Cage goes through the motions as the twoc-shock maestro who has retired from the game to run a sweetly sentimental kart-track for kids somewhere in the sticks. Ribisi is in full greasy-haired, gravelly-voiced mode as his tearaway kid-brother; he worships Cage, who has to revive his old trade in order to get him out of trouble. Disappointingly, though, there is not much for Angelina Jolie to say or do.

Now more than ever, the idea of two cars chasing and being chased through crowded city streets seems almost pastoral. Chase through the city streets? It is impossible to drive, law-abidingly, for more than two feet without facing gridlock and choking fumes in today's urban environment. So the romantically daring idea of roaring continuously around, swerving, accelerating, outwitting, and all without accidentally running anyone over, now looks even more implausible.

The chase sequences that Bruckheimer and Sena rustle up here are entertaining enough, but as with M:i-2, they are so flashy, and so dependent on head-spinning cutting, that we are left with no idea of what it might actually feel like to be in a car chase, and it deprives us of the sense of spatial awareness on which real tension depends. It does not have any of the raw bumps and jolts of Bullitt or The French Connection.

The PlayStation game Driver, which was derived from Walter Hill's The Driver, has the feeling of harsh and unyielding 70s car suspension cleverly designed into its software. But Bruckheimer's Gone in 60 Seconds pretty well does the exact opposite of this: it designs out the real effects of car-theft. As a ride, it is too super-smooth.

Also, Gone in 60 Seconds does not manage the roustabout comedy of Smokey and the Bandit. There is a scene in which Cage has to drive up a ramp at high speed and then float in slow-motion over the rest of some traffic. That is an effect familiar from dozens of similar films, but Sena has not amassed the dramatic tension to make it acceptable as a gasp-inducing stunt, nor has he invested sufficiently in the picture's comic status to make it a tongue-in-cheek flourish.

It's all reasonably entertaining, but it is never clear whether we should buy Gone in 60 Seconds as a toughly modern, tech-aware action pic - or just another episode of The Dukes of Hazzard.

webTitle: Historic triumph lights up the future for France

fields.headline: Historic triumph lights up the future for France
fields.trailText:
Tens of thousands of French supporters crowded the Place de la Concorde yesterday to cheer the
          winners of the European football championship, as politicians, the media and business started
          assessing the feel-good factor flowing from a unique achievement.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of French supporters crowded the Place de la Concorde yesterday to cheer the winners of the European football championship, as politicians, the media and business started assessing the feel-good factor flowing from a unique achievement.

To celebrate the first time the same national team have won the world and then the European cup , even the staid newspaper Le Monde splashed the story alongside an unprecedented colour photograph.

Headlines in national papers describing the players as "the kings of Europe" caught the mood of a country whose self-confidence has grown by leaps and bounds in its efforts to deal with social and economic shortfalls since the Socialist government was elected in 1997 - a year before the world cup.

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, whose political popularity stands at over 60% and who was in Rotterdam to congratulate the winners, seems the most likely leader to gain from national euphoria as France heads for local, parliamentary and presidential elections in the next 22 months.

He described the 2-1 victory over Italy as a timely omen for the start of the country's six-month EU presidency.

Having already taken credit for a 1m reduction in unemployment, to 9.8%, and a leap in economic growth, the leftwing government can also thank its footballers for putting a brake on racism.

The team, who include players of Algerian, West African, Caribbean and central European origins alongside Gallic French, were already treated as an international example of racial harmony in 1998 after defeating Brazil.

The sports minister, Marie-Georges Buffet, said yesterday that the multi-ethnic side proved that France had created a harmonious society "that could do great things together" - a claim that has been supported by the drop in support for the anti-immigration National Front party.

"The image of ethnic mixing is at the origin of a collective spirit that meets every test," the leftwing daily Liberation said in its leader. " France 's victory, its secret, is without doubt based on the winning combination of two styles - physical and technical."

The rightwing Figaro agreed, adding: "Zidane and his heroic teammates are more than just footballers. They represent a France which wins, a France which dreams."

The ethnic mixture was evident in the crowd of 400,000 which filled the Champs Elysees on Sunday night and the gathering outside the Crillon Hotel on the Place de la Concorde, where the players appeared on the balcony like royalty. The biggest cheer was reserved for Zidane, whose Algerian origins would have divided the country 10 years ago.

Although France shows every sign of an economic boom, the feel-good factor will have to be kept alight for nine months before the municipal elections test the real popularity of the government.

fields.headline: Down Under by Bill Bryson
fields.standfirst:
(Doubleday £16.99). Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Gee. Australia is a very, very big country and no one knows much about it. Especially Americans. Which makes it the ideal spot for another of my homey little travelogues...
fields.body:
Gee. Australia is a very, very big country and no one knows much about it. Especially Americans. Which makes it the ideal spot for another of my homey little travelogues.

So what else can I tell you by way of background? Well, it's very, very big, there are loads of deadly creepy crawlies (Yuck!!), it was colonised by convicts (imagine!!) and the present inhabitants can be fairly chippy. But let me say, right here, right now, that I love Australians.

So where shall I start my trip? A colour magazine is paying me to turn around a quick piece on the Sydney-to-Perth Express so that seems as good a place as any. The train stops at Broken Hill. Pause, while I read up the history books and repeat some amusing anecdotes. We go for a day's driving out in the bush and when I get back I look at the map and see we've hardly moved out of Broken Hill.

Gee, it's a big country. The next leg of the train ride goes smoothly. I go in the cab for a bit and then I slum it in third class for a couple of hours. Scar-ry. And this is Perth, but I can't stick around as I've got another job to do in the Middle East.

Hi. I'm back. But not for long as I've only got a month and I'm hoping to cover the whole of the south-east corner, so we'd better get going.

Hey, look, there's a pet food shop that sells porno out the back. That's really neat. And, wow, the cricket on the car radio really cracks me up. "I wonder if he'll chance an offside drop scone here or go for the quick legover." Crazy. Why can't all these guys play exactly the same games as the rest of us? Such as American football.

Here's Adelaide (pause for some historical anecdotes) and there's the fascinating museum. Unfortunately it's closed for the day and my schedule's too tight to hang on.

Oh, and that might have been Melbourne and, wow, I must be back in Sydney and I'm outta here.

Right, I'm back for a few days so we're going up north. Ah, it's the rainy season. I hadn't thought of that. So Cairns is as far as I get. Let's take the plane to Darwin (not very nice) and drive to Alice Springs.Now, I'll just nip to Ayers Rock for a couple of hours as I've forgotten to book a hotel, then it's over to Perth for a suntan and Bob's your uncle. My cheque's in the bank.

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested:

Big Bill goes walkabout and sees everything and nothing. A snake bite would have put everyone out of their misery.

webTitle: Sketch: Why the grey matter to Bush the younger

fields.headline: Why the grey matter to Bush the younger
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The funny thing, looking down from the gods of the convention balcony, is how old they all are. The party of the future - led by the president for the 21st century - is the party of arthritic knees, stomach acid and hernias. Tax breaks for toupees and face-lifts? That would have raised a cheer.
fields.body:
The funny thing, looking down from the gods of the convention balcony, is how old they all are. The party of the future - led by the president for the 21st century - is the party of arthritic knees, stomach acid and hernias. Tax breaks for toupees and face-lifts? That would have raised a cheer.

And the funnier thing, to a visitor from the allegedly old country, is how nobody seems to notice. George Junior, basking in the spotlight he loves, is older than Bill Clinton, who is departing after two full terms.What's most obvious about running mate Cheney? Not his Attila voting record or even his three heart attacks. It's that he can barely trot, let alone run.

Dick Cheney, dark-suited, dumpy and follicly challenged, looks a good decade beyond his certified 59. The past is always with him: the years in the White House backrooms with Ford, the congressional years, the years at the Pentagon. Those years lie heavy. They are, oddly, his ticket to ride.

"Eight years ago, when I completed my time as secretary of defence, I loaded a U-Haul truck and drove home to Wyoming," he declaimed on his big night. "I didn't plan on a return to public office. Lynne and I settled into a new private life. There was time for fishing and grandchildren..." Now who did you last see loading his domestic clobber into a hired van and heading into the distance? Got it. Ken Clarke, '97, pottering back to Nottinghamshire and his own white-haired wife. But Ken - around the same age as Dick, with added hair - is yesterday's man, consigned to oblivion by the teenage Turks of the succession.

That is not remotely the American way. The "young country" of Tony Blair's longings is Japanese in its veneration of elderly pols. The key to success isn't a little Leo in every cot, but bushels of grandchildren. Al Gore wheels his in a stroller along the beach of photo-opportunity. Family, family.

A George Junior home advantage? I'm not sure about his blonde twins as they fidget and yawn in the celebrity box. They look kind of restless in pre-wild-oats mode. But W has strength in depth. There's nephew George P doing his podium bit already, and nephew Pierce, a 14-year-old Mekon of political jargon to shame the juvenile Hague.

No, the trouble is all behind him. Proud dad George Senior can't stop taking bows and - worse - responding on camera to Clinton when the wondrously shrewd Bill portrays W as a cossetted rich kid. Proud mum Barbara is playing the Queen Mother for all she's worth. There are so many Bushes hogging attention that you don't need to see the shoulder pads to think of Dynasty.

The effect is curiously choking, an everlasting Bush family Christmas of the airwaves.

Back, back to the future. The gerontocracy rules curiously OK. Second world war vets, Korean vets, Vietnam vets. It may play well, but is this the real America? Maybe Prezza Hezza should up sticks and head west - this country needs him.

webTitle: Cop and robber write crime novel together

fields.headline: You couldn't make it up
fields.standfirst: Bob and John were friends at school. Bob joined the police, John became a robber, and Bob ended up arresting John. When John got out of jail he met his old mate Bob again... Sounds like a novel? It soon will be - they're writing it together. Emma Brockes met them
fields.trailText: Bob and John were friends at school. Bob joined the police, John became a robber, and Bob ended up arresting John. When John got out of jail he met his old mate Bob again... Sounds like a novel? It soon will be - they're writing it together. Emma Brockes met them
fields.body:
Bob Long and John Plimmer, childhood friends, hadn't met for 13 years the day they bumped into each other in a street in Coventry. Long had just carried out an armed robbery of a security van delivering cash to a supermarket. Plimmer had just arrested him after a tip-off. They faced each other across the interview table of the West Midlands serious crime squad. "Bob?" said Plimmer. "John?" said Long. "Yes," Plimmer concedes, looking back, "I think I was surprised that Bob turned out to be an armed robber. But I had a job to do, he had a job to do. There were no hard feelings."

"It was nothing personal," concurs Long. "We were both professionals."

The two men, 53 and from Birmingham, have collaborated on a slightly fictionalised account of the way their lives were interwoven for the greater part of the 60s and 70s, Long as a high-profile "target criminal", Plimmer as a detective superintendent with the West Midlands police force. The Inside Track, published this month, portrays them as Steve Blade and Detective Chief Inspector Jack Priestley, a man who reads like a cliché ("where did that sawn-off come from? Somebody's Christmas cracker?" and various permutations of "all right, sunshine, you're nicked").

Plimmer and Long rub along like relics from the good old days when villains had values, coppers spoke their minds and neither held a grudge over the odd knee in the groin between friends. "It's difficult to go by the book when a bloke's pointing a sawn-off shotgun at you," says Plimmer, cheerfully, in a broad Birmingham accent. "You tend to kick him and cuff him, and then read him his rights."

Sitting in Plimmer's front room in Meriden, a genteel village on the outskirts of the city, the pair appear to have struck up a workable but mutually suspicious relationship. Plimmer, who actually wrote the book, is the more talkative and assured. Long, who is short and stocky, provided all the details of how it feels to ambush a postal van and do time with the Kray gang, and is the more reticent, deferring to his writing partner while getting in the occasional well- placed dig. Producing the book required them to make certain psychological adjustments, given the divergent nature of their loyalties.

"Initially, I was going to write it and front it and Bob was either going to be a sleeping researcher or be open about his involvement," says Plimmer. "That was your dilemma, wasn't it?"

"Yeah," says Long. "After 30 years on the . . . other side . . . as it were, it was a difficult line for me to cross. I did have one or two people, old-style villains, taking the attitude that all coppers are bastards, that never the two shall meet, which I respect. Some of my former associates are respectable people now and they got a bit frightened."

"But you told them it was fiction, didn't you," says Plimmer.

"Based on our lives," says Long.

The two grew up in a working-class area of Birmingham, hanging out at the same dance halls and youth clubs. They weren't best friends, but were aware of each other as members of the same social circle, and had ambitions in common. Both thrived on discipline and hard, physical work. "I can remember Bob talking about wanting to be a boy soldier," says Plimmer, "and I had always wanted to join the police force. I think it's because there was a copper who lived by us and I used to knock on his door and run away - he used to catch me most of the time, but he never gave me a smack in the head. That might have persuaded me."

"I was coming up for 16 and about five of us walked past a recruiting office for the Coldstream Guards in Birmingham city centre," says Long. "We had a little chat and all signed up, there and then, not really knowing what we were doing. Then, two weeks, later I had the letter to report to Purbright in Surrey. After the initial shock, it was a wonderful life."

He was a good soldier and became the pride of his regiment when, after taking up boxing, he won the Imperial Services Boxing Championship by flattening the top fighters from the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy. He moved to Chelsea barracks, was put on ceremonial duty outside the Tower of London and fell in love with a girl from home. He was then posted to Germany, but didn't want to leave her. He went AWOL from the army and couldn't get a job or sign on without being busted, so he took up armed robbery.

Four years and two children later, the army caught up with him. After a court martial, he spent nine months in Colchester military prison. Such was his record that, when he came out, they offered to take him back. He refused.

While Long is telling his story, Plimmer is sitting waiting his turn with apparent patience, although when he comes to speak he rushes at it as if he has been holding his breath. "I was what they call a career detective," he says. "I did 18 months in uniform and the rest was 30 years in CID. I was a branch commander on the regional crime squad. I worked for the security forces for a short time. Then I was in the drug squad in Morocco, and ended up getting deported for finding out more than they wanted me to.

"Can't go back there, unfortunately. I miss that place like a bullet in the head - pits of the earth. Anyone who goes on their holidays to bloody Tangiers wants looking at. It's just sand and bloody beggars. The king of Morocco didn't like me very much."

The 70s brought what Long and Plimmer refer to, nostalgically, as the boom in armed robbery. It was a magic decade for Plimmer - 30 murders to investigate in five years, every one resulting in a conviction, interspersed with dramatic heists and rough ambushes. It was a good decade for Long too, who was robbing so frequently that he managed to develop a trademark - taking the pellets out of his shotgun cartridges and replacing them with rice. It was enough to stop a have-a-go hero but not to kill.

"It was a time when money was being carried about in Transits," he says, dreamily. "Her Majesty's Royal Mail was ridiculous. You had a postman given an extra tenner a week to drive a post office van with no security whatsoever, with anything between £30,000 and half a million in the back."

"Sixty-year-old postmen as well," chips in Plimmer.

"Yeah," says Long. "So instead of taking them out when they were walking between the van and the post office, people started to say, well, why not have the lot? Why not open the back of the van and have the lot."

"They were queueing up," says Plimmer.

"This ended with me in 1971, doing an armed robbery in Coventry that went drastically wrong," says Long. "In the middle of the rush hour the getaway car was rammed by a lorry. You can imagine the mayhem. I was eventually convicted and got 10 years in Gartree prison." When he and Plimmer met up again, it was 1977. Long had just been released and managed to lead a semi-straight life until one of his old associates rang up asking him to be a last- minute replacement on the supermarket robbery.

"Yeah, that was a tip-off we had. We just took them out," says Plimmer, with relish. "We didn't recognise each other when we had our battle on the streets. I never looked at him until we got back to the nick. I knew of Bob Long the armed robber - he was a well-known professional - but I didn't associate Bob Long the robber with Bob Long the school lad. But I recognised him in the interview room because he looked a bit younger then than he does now."

Long flinches, as Plimmer continues: "We had a rabbit about school days, but he wouldn't talk about the crime, which in fairness I wasn't bothered about because he got caught with a gun in his hand anyway."

Long was sent down for six years. In spite of this, when the two men bumped into each other in the Carpenters Arms in Birmingham in the mid-90s there was little animosity. Long had been straight for 10 years after landing a good job in the construction business. Plimmer had retired from the police force to become a writer. Long suggested that they do a book about their lives. They got £30,000 for it and are now working on the sequel.

There are unavoidable tensions. Long insists that the practice of "bagging", the brutal method of wrapping a plastic bag around a suspect's head to suffocate information out of him, was widespread in West Midlands CID in the 70s. Plimmer thinks he has "got his wires crossed". Long won't go on the Big Breakfast because he thinks that the television show's producer will make him run around waving a rubber truncheon. Plimmer takes a more relaxed view.

What unites them, however, is not only a sense of shared history, but a subtler sense of pride that they participated in some kind of golden age. "Being a professional criminal meant being in and out in 10 seconds," says Long. "If you had to use violence it meant something had gone wrong. It was professional pride to be in and out and leave them scratching their heads." And he shoots a little look of triumph at Plimmer.

The Inside Track is published by the House of Stratus on August 29.

webTitle: Enjoy the pound's strength while it continues

fields.headline: Enjoy the pound's strength while it continues
fields.standfirst:
Investors need to keep a close eye on exchange rates and currency movements in today's climate, says Robin Stoddart
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Investors need to keep a close eye on exchange rates and currency movements in today's climate, says Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Exchange rates are becoming a vital ingredient in investment decision-making. After the burst of strength in the dollar, which is unlikely to be reversed while further hefty increases in the official interest rate are expected, the trend of sterling, the euro and lesser currencies needs watching.

Holiday travel to the continent should be more pleasurable than for many a year and currency funds run offshore by leading banks and fund managers may be back in vogue.

Individual governments are powerless to rectify exchange rates, though chancellor Gordon Brown now recognises that the present pound-euro exchange rate is unstable. Strong economies and good government command a firm exchange rate. Market forces provide the support. Flights from a currency are the penalty of corruption and incompetence.

In recent frantic weeks, the ebb and flow in and out of high technology issues has been the worldwide feature of share markets. But the avoidance of less developed countries with serious political problems, overpopulation and natural or man-made disasters is the key to investment success.

The only really strong share market just lately has been China. It combines size and potential with the wheeler-dealing free-market philosophy of highly developed Hong Kong, itself now on the rack of a strong dollar and rising borrowing costs. Government stocks and bonds have been hit this week, so only safe and older economy shares in the right countries show resistance.

The long depression in consumer and engineering issues in the UK has brought a surge of takeovers and management buy-outs, involving sharp rises in share prices. Restructuring, including subsidiary flotations, amalgamations and some drastic cutbacks feature the continental and Japanese scene. Such moves are also extending to inflation-prone Latin America, partly under the influence of Spanish intervention. But fuel costs are a drag on many countries now that the oil price has sprung back close to its highest level since the 80s.

Inflation has become a factor to be allowed for in several countries and stock markets apart from the US. Ireland suffers from the effect of low euro interest rates on an economy that has been the fastest-growing in the west for many years, and some southern and eastern European countries are threatened. Productivity increases associated with the new technology help, but pre-emptive rises in interest rates are now the rule.

Falling unemployment still ensures rising consumer spending in most western countries. Germany has some way to go in this respect. The low euro enables high profits to be made on exports to the dollar area and UK. Returns on greatly increased overseas investment, particularly by France, Holland and, outside the eurozone, Switzerland, are also climbing. The euro is a good currency to borrow in order to exchange for one with a better interest rate. Its weakness arises because it is not yet the medium of exchange within any sovereign state, only the European Cen tral Bank having any responsibility.

Nevertheless, the combination of trade surpluses and sharply rising corporate profitability makes investment in successful continental companies one of the more attractive options at present. Whether the UK, can, uniquely, allow its manufacturing potential to fall in the hope that services, many of which are not internationally tradeable, will make up the deficit, must be highly improbable. If the new and often highly promising software and biotechnology firms that have offset the billions struck off the values of older manufacturing issues fail to make the grade it is difficult to see how the present belief in British success and stability can persist.

European funds are among the better performers as the modest recovery in the euro offsets falls in share prices from the recent peaks struck by some continental and Scandinavian markets. In the six months to March, growth of a third or more was common among funds with large French stakes. Some, like TR European Growth did better still through concentration on medium-sized but fast-growing companies, geared up by high borrowings. Specialists in small companies, notably Fleming European Fledgling and Invesco Continental almost tripled.

Meanwhile, a few emerging market funds achieved appreciation of around two-thirds, with Edinburgh Inca and F&C Latin America benefiting from the revival in Brazil, now in reverse. There was also a reduction in the high discounts on their shares. But risks are high as dollar interest rates rise.

The government's willingness to show its support for the e-economy was further in evidence yesterday with a series of measures to help small businesses go online and encourage the growth of web-based companies. But while the measures were welcomed by the dot.com industry the feeling was the chancellor hadn't gone far enough.

Among the announcements was the introduction for small firms of 100% tax relief on new technology including computers, software and internet-enabled mobile phones in their first year of purchase. That means the entire cost of the equipment will be included in a company's tax allowance in year one, reducing its taxable profits immediately and freeing capital to invest elsewhere. Costs are normally written off against tax over a number of years.

The 150,000-strong Federation of Small Businesses forecast that one million small firms would be looking at e-commerce and information technology this year, "and this boost announced today will accelerate that move. It will make the vast majority of them take the plunge."

There were also changes to make the Enterprise Investment Scheme and Venture Capital Trust initiative - which allow individual investors to target hi-tech businesses - more attractive.

A package of cuts to the capital gains tax taper rules was also announced to reflect the shorter investments common in the new economy and encourage so called serial entrepreneurs.

A maximum CGT rate of 10% will apply for business assets after just four years instead of ten. All employee holdings, of whatever size, will benefit from the tapered relief, stripping away the previous 5% threshold.

The Enterprise Management Scheme which governs option awards for small firms increased the number of people that can receive rewards of up to £100,000 from 10 to 15 people employees.

The key change which the dot.com community had been looking for did not appear. Industry watchers were hoping for the removal of national insurance contributions on exercised share options outside the existing approved schemes but the issue was only put out for consultation.

Most schemes in dot.com companies are unapproved because those given the Inland Revenue's blessing either need to be offered to all staff or have a ceiling of £30,000. Approved schemes also need to be held for three years.

John Browning, a co-founder of the First Tuesday networking group for the internet community, described the Budget measures as "small steps." He had been hoping for changes to the NI rules on share option schemes.

"Potentially this is a very big cashflow item that a company has no control over. The Inland Revenue will put a company out of business one of these days. What they've done is a fudge, which is a shame."

Mark Bernstein, co-founder and chief executive of Gameplay.com agreed. "We've just had to put a provision in our accounts for £2.5m to cover the liability and that's a lot of money."

There was also anger over the chancellor's decision to press ahead with the clampdown on IR35, a loophole which allows companies to hire individual contractors without paying national insurance - a broad practice in the IT industry.

The Federation of Small Businesses said: "We are dismayed that the chancellor did not take the opportunity to climbdown on IR35 - the attack on flexible personal service companies."

Conservative technology spokesman Alan Duncan said: "The chancellor's policy is absurd. On the one hand he has introduced the dreaded IR35 e-tax which is already provoking a massive brain drain of IT specialists who are leaving the UK, and then the chancellor has to make good his own folly by introducing incentives to attract new people to fill the skills gap. This is a ridiculous, self-defeating brake on e-commerce in Britain."
